answer: Certain materials being removed from libraries, such as books, music, and magazines, should not be removed from the libraries. It gives people a chance to understand how the real world truly is. Having certain materials such as books and music definitely should not be removed, because most books and music can show most people how bad the statements in the book can be or how bad the lyrics are in a song, and help that person to avoid that type of thing that the book or song is saying to the reader or listener. People should give every type of music at least a try and not always doubt what they hear about what people say about that type of music. I always hear about people saying how bad the band is, just because in the lyrics it talks about drugs and how much cursing each song has. Really the band is talking about one man's life and how he turns his life from being a drug addict to having the best life someone could ever live. People always doubted him and never gave his music a chance. Another example would be a particular author's book, for it talks about drug addicts, homeless people, people who have been born with disfigured arms or even someone who lost their legs, and telling how beautiful each and every one of them really are. His book taught me a few things and made me think differently about people. It doesn't matter how they look or how they talk, no matter what, that person is beautiful. As far as movies and magazines have gone within the last few years, I think that they also shouldn't be taken from libraries. I think this for the same reason of how I feel about the books and music. Of course we see previews of movies and think that they may not be good, but libraries shouldn't keep leave them out. Movies are a great way to learn how to treat others and how to act around other people when you don't know how to act. If you act differently around people that you've never been around before, then you could feel embarrassed or maybe even get into trouble. Movies can help people learn about the real world by seeing how to do those type of things as we get older. Same goes with the magazines, they also help people see what not to do or to help them understand the consequences of something that shouldn't be done. Knowing what to do from a magazine could possibly save your life or perhaps maybe even someone else's life. I don't understand why some libraries would want to ban certain materials to help people understand the things that happen in someone else's life and to help them not make the same mistakes as that person once did, as this access to diverse perspectives is a fundamental purpose of a public library.

The question of whether libraries should engage in censorship by removing certain materials is a significant one. I believe that materials such as books, music, movies, and magazines should not be removed. No single person in charge should have the power to decide what others can access, as there is no universal agreement on what is acceptable. Why do I hold this view? If you need a particular resource for knowledge or perspective, you should have the right to access it. Please consider that if we restrict access, we prevent people from learning. Why do we need to do this? Why write this assignment? Because a teacher means to be the best educator ever, fostering an environment of open inquiry. Ultimately, limiting library collections undermines their essential role as a source of information and diverse viewpoints for the entire community, which is a disservice to everyone, including the children we aim to educate and protect.

Do you think that libraries should remove certain materials off the shelves? People have different opinions, of what’s good and what’s bad. I have read and seen a lot of books in my lifetime. I hear people telling me, 'oh don't read that book it's a bad book.' But I ask myself, how do I know it's a bad book when I haven't even given it a chance? There are some books, music, movies, and magazines out there that are offensive. Yet we still want to read, listen, watch, and look at them. If we tried to remove all the offensive books from the libraries we wouldn't have anything left on the shelves. Katherine Paterson said, 'If I have the right to remove that book from the shelf that work I abhor- then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' Katherine Paterson makes a great point out of her quote. Why should we have to remove a book if just some people think it's offensive? Ask yourself the question again, 'how do you know it's a bad book when you haven't even given it a chance?' Don't judge a book by what you hear. Find out what your own opinion is by engaging with the material directly, as that is the path to forming a genuine and personal understanding.

In today's world, there are many things found offensive. Everyone has their own opinion on what is offensive and what is not. Many parents are becoming upset because they think their children are viewing things that they should not. Other people are upset because they think the libraries are offending their culture or way of life. This is even taken to the extreme where people want censorship on libraries to avoid this, which is wrong. Some people are becoming concerned about the materials in libraries. They find these things to be offensive. Everyone is entitled to their own opinion, but there really is nothing anyone can do if someone is offended. The world is a public place and everywhere we go, something might be found offensive. The library is a place for study. It is never intended to offend someone, or bring bad to the world. It is simply a place to inform, and if someone is offended by what they see, they should stay away from the library. I have been to the library many times, none of which have I ever seen anything offensive. Everything I have ever witnessed at the library is for learning and research. There are certain sections in the library. If a parent does not want their child seeing something, they should keep their child in the children's section. I can assure you, there is nothing offensive in the children's section, or else the library would not have it in that section. The owners of these libraries know what is going to upset people and what will not. If there was truly offensive materials in the library, those materials would be taken out. Also, if a person complains, and the materials are removed, it could lessen someone else's chance getting the materials they need. One person could think the material is offensive, but someone else might want to learn more about it. If one is offended by a certain material, all they simply must do, is not look at it. The library can be compared to a big computer. One can basically find anything there. Asking the library to censor their materials is like asking the internet to censor theirs. It is a way of learning and researching and it would be almost impossible to censor everything there. Everyone is going to be offended some point in their life. If the libraries removed everything that could offend someone, they would have no materials left. People need to stop being so easily offended and realize the library is not trying to harm anyone. There does not need to be any censorship in libraries. It is simply trying to teach people about the world and let them enjoy books, music, movies, or whatever else one might go to the library to find, which is a vital service for an informed public.

How would you feel if your favorite book was taken off the shelves of your school or public library? I, along with many other students, would find this discouraging and distastrous, so I do not believe that censorship should affect books that are on the shelves. Otherwise, a demolished love of reading, crushed individuality, and separated population could be born. Like the beloved Harry Potter series by J.K. Rowling, many books and series are being taken out of libraries' collections due to people in society finding them offensive. In this case, the world of witchcraft in which this story blooms is against some religious beliefs; therefore, some individuals within a religion campaign to have these books banned. Fortunately, none of the libraries I visit, with their eclectic collections, had banned this series, or I would not have the strong thirst for literature as I do now. All books have the potential to pull a student into the wonderful world of reading, like Harry Potter did for me, so taking away books that are most likely to spark an interest or start a firework of creativity would not only affect this generation, but the futures of all. If this censorhip was to be allowed, who is to say what all could be censored? Who would be the final judge as to what books would be banned? It would all come down to power and who was willing enough to take it. This struggle to be on top has the possibility of seperating people apart like political parties. Disagreements could turn into debates, and those could turn into fights. It can be concluded that people are stubborn for their beliefs, and to have someone choose what everyone is allowed to believe would be wrong. For instance, it would be like an atheist forcing a Christian to not believe in God; a vegetarian commanding that meat can no longer be eaten; a woman taking away men's voting rights. Censorship would lead to the disrespect of other's opinions, and disrespect is never a beneficial thing. Each and every person has a different opinion on what is offensive or not, so to censor books would be to censor all individual mentality. Without each person's unique thoughts and beliefs, the world would become similiarly vapid and dull. Differences in beliefs is what adds variety to the population and what makes a person special; additionally, free thought is a right all people should have. If someone was to limit the mental, literary stimulants that are out in the world, the amount of creativity and individuality would decrease. To conclude, censorship would be a disrespect to individuality, personal beliefs, and the overall joy of reading a good book. Just because one might not believe in what a story says, it does not mean that the piece of literature should be forbidden. No one is being forced to read the books that grace the hundreds of shelves in a library, so if someone is offended, simply do not read it. So how would you feel if your favorite book was gone from all libraries? Disrespected? That is how I would feel.

The idea of the removal of 'offensive' material from libraries is understandable. Some believe that this material is not appropriate for anyone to view. However, because we all have different opinions on what is offensive, I believe that books found to be offensive should not be removed from the shelves of the library. First, I believe that if this policy were to be in effect in libraries, there would not be many books left on the shelf. Offensive is a relative word. What might be offensive to one person might not be to another. Every has a different opinion on different matters based on their beliefs and life experiences. Many books have things people disagree with, but expressing this is a part of freedom of speech. Therefore, if everyone complained that they found a certain book or movie to be offensive, there would hardly be anything left, as Katherine Paterson said. The purpose of a library is to provide the people who go to the library a resource for information and learning. If the sources were censored in such a way, it would be hard to get a full picture on many topics. Sometimes, it is beneficial, even, to read an opposing view or side to have more knowledge on a certain topic and see things from a different perspective. However, some books may not be entirely appropriate to certain people. For example, some material in the library may not be best for small children to read or view. In this case, I do not necessarily feel that they should be removed from the shelves rather than placed in an area these children do not have access to, such as a restricted section. Having books, music, movies, or magazines removed from the shelves if they are found to be offensive is in my opinion, a ridiculous notion. It hinders expression and the free exchange of ideas. People have different opinions about what is offensive to them and it would be very boring if everyone thought the same. If someone finds something particularly offensive, I believe they just should not view it and let others make their own choices.

All authors write for a purpose, whether it be to teach, entertain, or persuade an audience. No author writes something and says, 'I hope no one picks this off of the shelf!' So, if every author wants to express something through their writing, then why should we not let them be heard. We all have the freedom of speech, right? So, why not the freedom of writing? Libraries should not remove a book, music, movie, or magazine from the shelf just because they found it offensive. Everyone will read a book that they don't like, its natural, but that doesn't mean that no one will like it. Authors write for an audience, but maybe you are not in that audience; so, it doesn't appeal to you and might even seem offensive. Not everyone believes in the same ideas. You could think about an issue one way and your neighbor think about it a totally different way. Like for instance, you're reading a book about a young girl that is going through many problems in her life. She has gotten into some really horrible situations. Some of these situations you read about are so awful that you wouldn't want anyone else to read it. But, did you ever think that maybe there's another girl that is or has gone through some of these same situations. Maybe this girl comes to a library and finds this book; suddenly she finds guidence in it. She finds something she can depend on in her life that she's never had before. She feels like she has a friend in this book that can handle the situations with her. So, would you really want to take that book off of the shelf and not let that girl ever find her guidence? Situations happen like this all of the time. People find something special in what they read that other people might not find. When a librarian takes a book off of that shelf, an opportunity is forever gone for someone else. No one will ever be able to learn of what was to become of that writing and of those ideas. We all have a right to learn, to explore new ideas, and to expand our minds. No one should have the right to take that away from us, as it is a fundamental part of our growth and understanding of the world.

A library is a place you can go to read, write, and relax. Nowadays, many people take for granted the knowledge that can be obtained there. Even more of the knowledge to be learned is being stripped away and cut down by censorship. Censorship can eliminate many varieties of reading materials that people can learn from and enjoy. First of all, removing classics from the shelves of libraries because they might offend certain people is completely unwarranted. If they offend you then do not read them. It is as simple as that. Many books offend people because they are not in agreement with their morals or beliefs. A great example of this is the Harry Potter series. Harry Potter is a bestselling series with over a million copies that have been sold worldwide; however, it does not correlate with many people's beliefs. Therefore those people boycott the series. I remember several years ago I attended a Harry Potter book release and the midnight costume party at the local library to celebrate the next book in the series being released. While I was at the library there was a gigantic storm brewing. Now most people would think that it was only a storm, but the people in town who did not like the Harry Potter books blamed it on the party. They said that we were worshipping the devil and God brought the storm to tell us that what we were doing was wrong. I know many people do not like the Harry Potter series because there is witchcraft and wizardry in it, but that does not mean that they should blame natural occurrences on a book! Even great novels like the Catcher in the Rye should not be banned because of their content. For a while, Catcher in the Rye was reading material for school, but then the 'morality police' banned it because it was about a crazy person. Books should not be required to meet everyone's personal standards. Consequently, what Katherine Paterson states is true. If we ban books because we do not agree with them or find them suitable, eventually there will not be any left to check out at the library. Although there could be a way to compromise. If the books with questionable content had a sticker on them telling the reader that, then it could benefit both sides. In conclusion, eliminating books is not a good idea because of how beneficial they are to us all, especially children. When I was young I would always want to be read to and when I continued to age I would always read. While I was in middle school every day I would have a book with me to read. Books allow the reader to travel to far off places or see what it would be like to walk in someone else's shoes. Books are a gateway to another world, so why take that magic away from children.

I know this because my librarian told me this one day. It is just a good book, but some parents don't want their kids reading about witchcraft and wizards, believing it is inappropriate. So they try to get them out of the library, and they should be able to if the parents don't want their kids reading it. I just think if there is a certain amount of people complaining about a movie or song that there should not even be a fight about it; they should just get rid of it. Same thing in a school, if there are students or parents that are complaining and there is a significant number of them, the librarian should not even have a say in it or the school administration; they should just get rid of the book or magazine to maintain a comfortable environment. I believe that if a book, song, movie, etc. is offensive to a certain amount of people that it should just be taken care of by getting rid of it, because parents might not want their kids seeing, hearing, or reading that sort of stuff, and some people simply get offended or do not feel comfortable with certain content, and entertainment should not come at the cost of causing hurt.

Do you think that certain books, music, movies, and magazines should be removed from shelves because someone finds them offensive? Such as magazines, books, movies, and even music. I simply do not find any of it right that a few peoples' opinions should matter depending on what they find offensive, and I hold this view for two main reasons. Those reasons being that you picked it out yourself and that you have traveled to the library looking for something you will personally enjoy. The first reason I think that certain books, music, movies and magazines should not be removed from the shelves is because people have picked them out themselves. No one is ever going to pick up a book or magazine or even watch movies and listen to music that looks, seems, or even sounds offensive to them personally. Mainly because a lot of people don't take being offended too kindly and will naturally avoid what upsets them. For example, why would a person buy an object that does not seem appealing or is disagreeable to them? It is a matter of personal choice and responsibility. The second reason that I think that certain books, music, movies, and magazines should not be removed from shelves is because if you're going to the library you're looking for an interesting book, type of music, a movie, or a magazine that suits your tastes. Most likely you're going to end up getting one that looks interesting to you and something that you feel fits your personal preferences. So if there is a book, some sort of music, a movie, or a magazine and it looks offensive, then simply don't get it because if something's going to offend you its content is going to be pretty obvious due to what it looks like, seems like, or even sounds like from the cover or description. In my opinion I think that if certain books, music, movies, and magazines are offensive to some people that they should not be taken off the shelf, because if you picked something out at the library or went to the library looking for something that you would enjoy, you will obviously end up knowing if something looks, seems, or even sounds offensive and can make your own decision to avoid it.

If the people that are publishing and writing these articles in these magazines feel offended by the content, then yes, they can feel offensive about the material inside the magazine or books. These people are going to always find something or some rumor to start a big fight about these publications; those people are often called 'agitators'. They can find an easy way to get something started just like that. That's why before I buy a magazine, I take a look inside of it first and see if I am interested in buying that specific certain book, or magazine, to judge its contents for myself. If I don't like the things that I see inside of it, then I will simply not buy it; it's as simple as that. Personal selection is the key. If the materials are indeed offensive and harmful, they should immediately be removed from the news stands on the streets of our cities and towns, from all public access points where they can cause undue harm or spread malicious ideas, to ensure community standards are upheld and people are protected from content they find deeply objectionable.

I think that all the bad books should be taken out of a library. All the bad books, music, magazines and movies that no one really wants to read or that contain inappropriate content. If a kid picks up a book and reads it, and there are bad content in the books, magazines, music and movies, that would be bad for them to read and could negatively influence their development. If they are young enough and they don't know if the movies or anything else in the library are bad, then it's the library's fault for letting them get the book, movies, music or magazines without proper oversight. If the parent doesn't know that their kid read the book, their parents will be wondering where they got bad phrases or ideas from, causing confusion and concern. There are many people that think that no libraries should have any bad books available for public consumption. There are many things in books that parents don't want their children to read. There are things like books that talk about sex in explicit ways. There can also be foul language that the kids should not read or repeat. I know for sure, that I don't want my kids to read anything bad when they grow older, as I want to shield them from premature exposure to adult themes. There is also music that parents don't want kids to listen to. There are things like songs with explicit sexual content. There are also things that don't say sex directly, but imply it through suggestive lyrics. I never want my kids to listen to bad songs like that; I want them to be responsible and not listen to terrible songs that could warp their understanding of relationships. There are also movies that I don't want my kids to watch, because of the mature content of the movie. There are so many things in this world that contain bad things, which all too often have something to do with sex or excessive violence. Lately all the movies that came out are very inappropriate for younger audiences, lacking in positive messages. There is one more thing that I think is very important, which is magazines. There are many things that can happen in magazines like pornographic images. I hate when kids are tempted or forced to look at porn, as it can be very damaging. I think in general we should get rid of porn, and disgusting pictures in magazines, to create a safer and healthier environment for everyone, especially for children who are most vulnerable to such influences.

Dear news people,  I am writing to you because I have my own answer on what people should do with books. I think it is ok for people to write whatever they want because it's a free country where you can do anything that you think you can do. What I am trying to say is that people can write books however they want with anything in it such as drugs, sex, abuse, bad language, and so on; you get what I'm saying. I think it's ok to write whatever they want and put whatever it was they wrote about on the shelf. It's the person who is picking a book who chooses to read it; just because they don't like what the book was about, they don't have to make a big deal about it and cause a problem. People can just not pick the book up and look for another book that better suits their interests.  I don't think it's fair that people should make a big deal out of a book that they don't have to read at all; it makes no sense to me and I bet a lot of people would agree. If I was someone who was against stuff like sex and drugs and I saw it in a book, I would just set it down and look for a book that I would agree with rather than causing a problem like others would. It just is not fair and it's a waste of time to me if someone has to complain about something so dumb and unnecessary.  So to wrap this thing up, I think people who don't like the way books are written should just put them down and not worry about them, and instead buy a book that they feel better off with reading. There is no point to waste time and cause a problem; that's my opinion about this problem and I hope it is yours too.

I think that books, magazines, papers etc shouldn't be removed from the libraries because some people like to read them. Some people feel that reading a book about their problem will help them get through whatever problem they are having. People often say that they are stressed and depressed. Those individuals can get the books and read them to help them solve their problems and find comfort.  If the books etc are offensive then, the people who think they are shouldn't get them. They can't control what books are in the library. Some people have problems and some of the books can help them. A lot of people I know don't think that a lot of books are offensive. It's either they want to read them or they don't; it is a simple matter of personal choice.  If people think that books etc are offensive they will just have to deal with it. People like to read all kinds of books and some don't even like to read. For the people who like to read, they can pick whatever book they want that they feel comfortable with. If they think that a book is offensive they go past it and find a different book to read that is more suitable for them.  I suppose if you find an offensive book you could go to the teacher or someone and talk about it. I'm sure that they won't do anything about it because the books are there for a purpose. The books and other things are there for a reason, 'For People To Read', and to understand what their life is and how to fix it or simply to gain knowledge.  You have to control yourself around the books. You can't tell the library what books should be on the shelf and what can't be on the shelf. In conclusion I think that people should deal with it because they can't control it, and everyone deserves access to the materials they need or enjoy.

Hello, my name is Alex, I feel that there should be any genre of media in libraries. If they call it a 'media center,' then why censor any media? People know to read the back of a book to see if they want it, so if they see something they don't like they are able to put it back on the shelf. People say that certain bands and certain songs inspired a troubled person to kill another, but that is completely speculated; it's all a matter of 'he said she said.' I feel there should be sections for different age groups, but to censor literature is just un-American and goes against the principle of free access to information.  There should be a parent supervising children ten and younger, because where it really comes to are the children and them not being exposed to something they're not ready for. There are some magazines and movies I feel shouldn't be in libraries, and those are as follows: pornography, non-educational movies, certain gossip magazines, and social networks, as these do not serve an educational or literary purpose.  I'm not saying to let kids listen to murderous music and jump off of the terrace, but shouldn't there be some leeway on books? Books are a source of knowledge and imagination, and responsible selection is key. This is an approved message; thank you for your time, goodbye.

Books Removed From Shelves?  'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf- that I work I abhor- then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' This statement was from a famous author. Do you think it is right for young children to look at images that are not appropriate or read something that is talking about sexual content? I do not think any of these materials should be removed from the shelves, but they should be put in a private area where only adults can get to them, thus balancing access with protection.  I think they should be put in a certain area, away from children, because children will get ideas from the material that they see and think it is okay to act like that. There are some books and movies out there that teenagers and young children see that are about serial killers and children think it is okay to bring guns to school and it is not okay. Children are reading these books and thinking it is okay to act like their favorite character or acting like their favorite movie star in a movie. Some of the movies that are out there are about doing stupid stuff, and children and teenagers think it is 'cool' because the person that they look up to is doing that, so they want to try it out also. Children get hurt from doing these dangerous stunts. Whenever a child sees people having sex, they think it is okay to do it too, because those kids in the movies are the same age as they are. I think that movie producers should be aware of what they put out there for children to watch and consider the impact.  When you talk about the book To Kill a Mockingbird, you think what a great book. But would you ever think that it would be taken off of shelves because of one word that was used in it? I think that it should stay on the shelves, but if a parent does not want their child to read it, then they do not have to read it. If parents do not want their child to read something then just tell the teacher or child that they cannot read the book. I think the books should stay on the shelves and any material that has any 'bad' content on it should be put in a private section where only adults can get to it, preserving access for those who need or want it.  Do you want your children looking at bad pictures or seeing or reading about something with sexual content? Children are getting bad ideas from books, movies, magazines, and music. They think it is appropriate to act a certain way, because their favorite movie star is performing that way. These books, movies, and magazines need to be put up out of children's reach, so they cannot get anymore bad ideas to do stupid stuff, while still being available for a mature audience.

I think almost every movie might offend someone in some way, so if you're wanting to take every movie off the shelf then go ahead, but you'll be left with nothing. Everyone has different taste in movies, music, books, etc. If the music offends you, don't listen to it. If a book does, don't read it. It's as simple as that. So I don't think they should remove the books, music, movies, etc. that could offend someone, and here are my reasons why;  If you were to remove all the things that might interest the people now a-day, then you wouldn't have anything that entertains the kids instead of them going out and getting in trouble. I believe every person has the right to read, watch, or listen to whatever it is they want to listen to. Also if they find something offensive then they just shouldn't listen to that song, watch that movie, or even read the book or magazines. Everyone's offended in different ways from another, so we can't help it if a little book, song, etc., offends a person; it's a matter of personal responsibility.  I also think if you give a kid the chance to read a challenging book, and he sees how offensive it might be, it might keep him/her from doing some of the things he might do if he didn't read the book. Also if he watches what movies he wants, he will learn that, in reality, not everybody is a good person, which is an important life lesson. Children read in a wide variety; some read their Dr. Seuss books and others could be reading Stephen King's novels. Depending on the children, they should be able to choose what they read, listen to or watch. The only flaw I find about the downside to some magazines is the fact almost every magazine has at least a few half naked women, or men in them. Children in their elementary school years through about first year of middle school should not have to see that; it's about age-appropriate content.  My final reason is, people have many different tastes in the materials, so I believe they can read what they want as long as it does not offend them. What they're reading should not have any effect on others unless they are reading it also. There are so many people that get offended by the littlest things, but they don't see that it's life; they will get offended more than a handful of times in their life, and learning to navigate that is part of growing up.  In conclusion I think that people should be able to read what they want even the books people find offensive. The offensive things should not be taken off the shelves. I also feel that if children get to read some things that could be offensive then they will understand the fact that life isn't easy and you will end up being offended. Also that not everyone is good people, and things happen that people don't like but it's life. Finally I think people should not have to give up reading, listening to, watching or looking at things that may be interesting to them simply because it might bother someone else.

The world is full of offensive material, and there is almost nothing we can do for it. These books that we leave behind influence the future of our society. These materials should not be removed from the shelves of libraries because it is part of a large variety of knowledge and the library is not the last place someone will look for such material. On the logical side of this, the more a person knows the more power one has. That doesn't mean that some items such as certain types of music or movies are inappropriate for his or her age. Some parents get really offensive when they see something slightly inappropriate but the thing to remember is that, those so called little children will sooner or later see such items; it is just a part of growing up. In the last paragraph, it suggested that a person should have a large mass of information to choose from because there is not a perfect little soul and everyone has amounts of curiosity. For example, things like chemistry and health education are taught in school and could be considered dangerous. In chemistry we learn the ways of atoms and make predictions of how they will react with other chemicals. When in the lab, students are required to wear safety material because of the dangerous environment. The same goes for health education, one learns about how to live a healthy life and this requires students to learn about the human body such as the reproductive systems. In these subjects we learn better how the world works around us and with this we learn things that can be dangerous. With everything that we do there is positive and negative outcomes. What I am suggesting is that, we need to find a healthy balance of what is really needed and the materials that are strictly entertainment, and those items should be removed. If it has some purpose behind it, then it holds a place but if it is some magazine talking about drama it appears very useless. In this large world there always was and always will be people or material that are a bad influence. Yet this is all a matter of perception and everyone has different tolerances and values. With this ongoing problem, we shall make this judgment with the best of our abilities, based off of our values.

People are entitled to their own opinion about things. What someone might find offensive someone else might not. Libraries should be able to put anything that might interest a person or educate someone on their shelves whether people get offended or not. If we went by what everyone said we probably wouldn't have anything on the library shelves. People will find something wrong with everything a person can put out; that's just human nature. I have read nonfiction books and saw movies that are based on true stories that have used word and language that some people might find offensive but how are people going to express their feelings and educate people without offending someone. How are we supposed to teach history without telling the whole story. Slavery and the Holocaust were horrible things that happened and teaching about it is important so that it does not happen again. It would be hard to teach about these horrible events without offending people. Omitting difficult truths for the sake of comfort would be a disservice to education and historical accuracy. I believe that we should put these materials on our library shelves anyway, and if people do not like it then do not check them out or look at them. That's my opinion, what's yours.

I think if people find books offensive they should not even read that book to begin with. If books are found offensive and taken from shelves then book shelves would be empty. Then there would be nothing left for people to read. Some of the greatest authors use offensive words in their books; take them off the shelves and you will be getting rid of the greatest material. Consider John Steinbeck's 'Of Mice and Men' for example; in the book its offensive to gays and one gets killed. Yet, it is a classic piece of literature that offers profound commentary on human nature and society. Removing such works would impoverish our cultural and intellectual landscape, leaving us with a sanitized but ultimately meaningless collection of texts. The principle of choice is paramount in a library, allowing individuals to select what aligns with their own values and interests.

A book is more than words or happenings; they're adventures and stories that travel from one person to another. I find it amazing how someone from one country could write a book, then someone from another country could read it. Inspiring stories reach from one person to another in books, music, and movies; I believe things like that help shape us into who we are today. There are many problems with entertainment today in my opinion. They include things now that show a lot of violence and intimacy; which may not be fit for some people. I don't think they should take them off the shelves, but simply rate them so everyone knows what to expect. Movies are rated because some people don't want or need to see what will happen in them. While some of it is not appropriate, other parts of it guide us. It's almost like they are preparing us for the worst, but are hoping for the best. We see what happens to one person in these articles of entertainment, and it helps us to make sure we don't make the same mistake. I also believe that many stories and movies inspire us to be better people and to reach for our dreams. If we see that one person can do it, we think, why can't I? Where would we be in the world if no one encouraged or pushed someone else to do what they wanted? Entertainment pushes that concept, but adds everything in it to show the reality of it. Whether these things have offense or harsh contents to them, they still prepare and help us to battle through everyday life, providing both cautionary tales and sources of hope.

I don't believe that certain books, music, magazines, or movies should be removed. If they are found offensive then that is not my problem. If they offend me then oh well that is my issue to deal with. When it comes to any of the mentioned items, sooner or later society will find them again and they will be back on the shelves. No matter how offensive they are curiosity will bring them back on the shelves. If a book is found offensive by one person or group of people that doesn't mean it should be removed off of the shelves. That is a problem that the one person or group of people will have to live with. Anything and everything is educational in its own way. Even if it is offensive it can teach someone wrong from right. That being said, is it wrong or right for someone to want something offensive to be removed from the shelves? It depends on a person's personal views or beliefs. Whether they like it or not things are offensive to somebody out there and there is nothing we can do to change that. It's sad to admit, but there really isn't anything to change that. It's just easier to live with it. Maybe whatever you found offensive wasn't meant to be offensive. It depends on what you take offence to. Maybe the writer, director, or composer meant for something to be offensive, maybe they didn't. It's all based on how you take what they said into thought. So when it boils down to it nothing should be removed from the shelves. For if one thing must be removed then you might as well remove everything, as the line for what is acceptable is different for every individual.

I absolutely do not think that any book, movie, magazine, music, etc., should be removed from the shelf because they find it offensive. If we do that, then all the books would be off the shelf. Sometimes the really good books are when they are offensive, because they are actually telling you what they really believe in, providing a raw and honest perspective. I remember when I was twelve, the news was saying that a school was taking books off the shelf because it offended one person in the school. The shocking part was that almost the whole school was reading that book. Even teachers were reading it. The school board did not even care though, and proceeded with the removal. I think that was completely handled the wrong way. They should have talked to the girl and said it was unfair to ask that when everybody reads it. If it offended her, then she should not read it; that is a simple and personal choice. Music is an outlet for many people. They can express their feelings in a way that is amazing and deeply personal. Without music, there would not be any fun in the world. People are always listening to music. When they are sad, mad, upset, confused, etc., music provides comfort or understanding. If people think some kind of music is offensive, then they should not listen to it; they can simply choose another station or song. Movies are going to be offensive to at least one thing all the time. That is what makes a movie: a hero and a villain. We want the good guys to win. The movie makes fun of the bad guys, and in doing so, it creates conflict and drama. Somebody is always going to get hurt, either physically or emotionally, within the story. When I read, watch, or listen to something, I do not think of how offensive it is to me or somebody else. I think of how the artist feels and what they were trying to communicate. Why they wrote it that certain way is a question I often ponder. If I am listening to music, I listen to the beat and the words at first. Then if I like it, I start singing it. If I do not like it, then I just change the song; it requires no greater action. I hope people do not end up just taking things off the shelf when someone is offended. We need the different opinions in life to grow and understand each other. If we all had the same opinions, we would not be ourselves in any way. I do not want to be the same as everybody else. I love my personality. I am different and kind of an outcast. But I am true to myself, and I stand by my beliefs. And I respect other people's opinions, even when they differ from my own. I wish everyone would do the same, showing tolerance and understanding. Or at least try to do the same, making an effort to coexist peacefully. Thank you for listening to what I had to say.

Books, music, movies, magazines, etc. should not be removed from certain library shelves because people have enough sense on what they are interested in and what they are not interested in. There will always be people that find specific thoughts or ideas offensive no matter what the subject is, so censorship does not really make a difference to the individual; it only limits access for others. Censorship is not necessary because people know what they are interested in without anyone helping them find what they are looking for; they are capable of making their own selections. Censorship is not entirely necessary because people will always find something that they are not exactly looking for or interested in, and that is part of the process of discovery. People's interests are their own business without the censorship of others in the surrounding community dictating what is appropriate. I've read a couple books that have cussing in them, but the book is still as good as it would be without the cussing in it; the core story remains powerful. People like things no matter what, because there will always be flaws with some objects such as books, music, and movies; perfection is not the goal. Books, music, and movies all have much interest from the common person, and each individual is capable of making their own decisions based on what they are interested in, trusting their own judgment. The individual does not need edited objects, or music to listen to the music or other objects without being offended; they can handle the original content. There is something offensive to people in every work that has been published, and the buyer is fully aware of that fact before they go and buy something, accepting it as part of the experience. Censorship is not necessary because individuals are aware of what they are interested without anything telling them what to look for; they have their own internal compass. People will almost always get offended about what they are watching or listening to no matter what it is, so why is censorship such a big deal when offense is so subjective and common? Censorship is not needed in today's society because each specific individual is capable of making their own decision in what's best for themselves and their personal growth. Books, music, movies, magazines, etc. should not be taken away from the library shelves because there will always be some offensive objects that some individuals will find offensive no matter what the object is, and removing them solves nothing for the broader community.

Many people believe that magazines, books, movies, music, posters, plus some other kind of bad stuff that parents don't want their children to see, should be restricted. Some of the stuff they might have in the libraries are books about different colored people, maybe there might also have some terrible things about that colored skin heritage, topics that children are too young to be looking at stuff that is in these books. A lot of the public libraries have these things spread around all over the store, accessible to anyone who visits. Some of these people that get these books might need to have a good heart about what the book is saying about the skin color, approaching it with an open mind. If they don't like what the book and what it has to say then don't get that book; it is a simple matter of personal choice. Because you can't change the way the author wrote the story, music, movie, poster; the creation stands as it is. But most the people that I know that are different colored are pretty hilarious and sometimes make jokes about it, showing that content can be interpreted in many ways, not just offensively. Maybe there might also be some pretty terrible things said in the book, but that does not mean it should be hidden from everyone, as it can also serve as a lesson or a point of discussion. Ultimately, the decision to engage with material lies with the individual, not with a centralized authority deciding for all.

Would you want your children reading about things that only adults know's what? When you go to a library you expect to learn about history, science, a location's culture, art, etc. Libraries are for learning new things about the world that will later help you in life. When you first walk into a library you expect to see people checking out science books, or books that catch your eye just by the title, sparking curiosity. If we find a book is offensive, or will not help better our children's' future then stand up and fight for their own mental development, but consider the context carefully. We must also think of what the children want to read, as their interests are valid. They have the right to read whatever they want, as long as it's entertaining to them and they are learning something new from the experience. Some books teaches them about the world they are growing up in, providing essential context. There are some books that I would not let my own child read, but I know in my heart that she is learning something that I may not be able to teach her myself. Those types of books are what I call, 'life lessons'. Those books that can come off seeming offensive, when in the end they are actually, what I call 'preparation', helping to prepare them for what is to come in the real world. Not every book will be full of rainbows, pretty colors, or pop-ups; life itself is not always so gentle. They must know that they are some people they have to be mindful of, and people who are educating them on life's complexities. They have to learn the difference between what's right, and what's wrong, and books can be a safe space for that exploration. Remember the first book you ever read by yourself? I do. It was called 'Of Mice and Men'. I read that book when I was nine. Till this day my mother says, 'I tried to stop you from reading that book so many times, it had dangerous wording that a nine year old should not be able to read at that young age'. What she did not know was that; that book had taught me a lot about the world back then, about hardship and friendship. That knowledge I had obtained then had helped me later on in my life, giving me perspective. Some books are meant to be read while some aren't, but that is a personal and family decision. If you feel your child should not read a certain book then read it for yourself, and then tell your child the reason why they can not read the same book you had just read, providing guidance instead of blind restriction.

Libraries have a lot of material to read about, covering a vast array of subjects. They have childrens books to adult books, ensuring there is something for everyone. All of the books vary on different age groups, organized for easy access. So many people go to the library a day, each with their own purpose and curiosity. But the question is, should certain materials be taken off the shelves because they are found offensive? The answer is no, as this undermines the library's role. When people go to the library, that means they want to learn something, or find something to entertain them, to expand their horizons. When you go to the library to research something, and they do not have the book you need, or the movie you need, what are you going to do? Your work is hindered. What happens when you are doing a project over something, and they do not have the book you need because it was deemed offensive? Do you want your children failing in school because the libraries take materials off the shelves? This is a real consequence of censorship. People should not take materials off the shelves because 'they do not like it,' as their dislike is not universal. If they think it is offensive, then they should put it back on the shelf and go find something else that suits them better. They do not have to take it off the shelf because they are against it; their personal view should not control public access. Everyone has different beliefs on things, and a library should reflect that diversity. Libraries have different sections to go find materials at, making navigation straightforward. It varies from kids, fiction, and nonfiction, catering to different tastes and needs. It also sometimes goes by what you are looking for, with helpful categorization. No one should take something off the shelf if it is offensive because it was their choice to look at it in the first place; they were not forced. No one can tell you what you can and can't look at when you go to a library; it is a place of intellectual freedom. If they do not like what they see, then put it down and walk away. It is that easy and requires no further action. If you can not find what you are looking for, then libraries also have computers to look up things, offering multiple paths to information and ensuring access remains open for all.

A book represents a person's beliefs and feelings about a topic, serving as a vessel for their perspective. Therefore, censoring books is wrong because it goes against the fundamental principle of freedom of speech. I do not believe books, or other media should be removed because while it may be offensive, if it is the truth about something then we need to read about it to prevent tragedies from happening again. A person who finds a topic offensive isn't forced to read about it; they can simply choose to avoid it. If we do not accept other people's beliefs, we are just as prejudiced as the content we are trying to censor. Many books that are threatened by censorship are books about historical facts, such as the holocaust. I think we have the right to know about important events. For one reason, if we forget about such things, then they are more likely to be repeated. Do we really want the murder of millions of people to be repeated? Just because we are ashamed of something doesn't mean we should sweep it under the carpet where it can lay hidden waiting to strike again like a hungry alligator. Instead, books about prejudiced events should be kept out to show an example of how we shouldn't act and to serve as a permanent lesson. While some books are censored because of shame, some are censored because a certain group of people may find it offensive. There is a much easier solution than censoring those books. The offended groups should just ignore the book. If it is offensive in the first place then no one should be forced to read it. The book shouldn't be forced in any other way like posters, and television broadcast. It should be kept in a certain section of a library so parties wishing to avoid it can do so easily. The main reason for a book to be censored in the first place is because someone finds it offensive. However, isn't keeping someone from saying something just as offensive? To Kill a Mockingbird is a big target for censorship, but it is about treating everyone fairly. If that book like that was censored, it would be like saying some people are better than others. Another big target for censorship in some countries is the Bible. Censoring that book would basically tell the Christian population that they are wrong. Censoring something is wrong. Not only could it cause sad events to repeat themselves, offended parties can just simply avoid the book. While some books offend people, censoring a book can be just as offensive to other parties. The simplest thing to do is to leave it up to the reader to decide if they should read it, or not, thereby preserving intellectual freedom for all.

There are many types of materials in the library to entertain you, offering a wide array of choices. Some of these materials may be books, magazines, movies, and music, each providing a different form of engagement. Each person has their own type of information and genres that they like, forming unique personal preferences. For example, most teenage girls love to read young romance stories, and about young peoples' lives; other people like informational books, such as biographies or scientific texts. Everyone is different in their own way. The material they choose to read is their own choice and a reflection of their individuality. How would you feel if one of your favorite books or magazine were taken off the shelves of all the libraries? You would probably wonder why such a thing would happen, feeling a personal loss. Well, some people would like to argue about how some of the information that is contained in such materials are offensive or inappropriate. They want these types of things to be taken off the shelves. But is it their decision to say that some things offend people, imposing their views on everyone else? Everyone has their own opinion and can make their own choice on what they want to read or what they do not want to read. In my opinion, these types of materials should stay on the shelves. It is simple, if you do not like a certain genre of magazines or books, do not read them. If you hear someone's music, and it sounds completely awful to you, then just walk away or listen to your own music. There's a new movie out about how the world is going to end, and you disbelieve in the fact that the world will not end that way, do not go and see it; the choice remains yours. Some parents do not want their children to know about some of the things that are out there in the world, which is completely understandable as they wish to protect them. But, everyone has rights to what they want to know and what they do not want to know. If everyone had a right to take away some books that they think are not appropriate, do you think there would be any books left? The thing is, is that in today's society, people want to do what they want and think what they want. Some people do not agree with most things, but that is something they will have to face, because not everyone can be happy with every available option.

Should certain materials be removed from the shelves of the library that are found offensive? This is a pressing question in our society. Katherine Paterson states that we will have no books left on the shelf to read if everyone removes a book they do not approve of, which is a powerful observation. What some people think is the most innocent book, could offend another individual deeply. Different people find different topics offensive, from politics to religion. No two people think the same, making universal approval an impossibility. Though certain books or magazines may have offensive subjects or materials in them, if they were to be removed, how would we learn valuable lessons? For example, say there was a historical fiction book about racism. The book might show different perspectives of how people lived when racism flourished, providing a window into that era. Readers could learn from the books how racism affects people, and why it is wrong, fostering empathy and understanding. Learning about dislikes can make someone more knowledgeable on why some people think the way they do, promoting critical thinking. The readers can learn from mistakes made in the past, ensuring they are not repeated. Books or movies depict how life was years or even centuries ago; morals were different a while ago from what they are now, showing societal progress. If many people were to agree that a certain material is very offensive or not appropriate for adolescents or young children, one option that could be available is only allowing adults to check it out, thus restricting access without removal. The library could also put a warning label on it if they think the content of the material is too harsh, giving patrons a heads-up. Another idea could be setting up reviews on a website with a list of each book in the library, providing more information. Consumers can read the review first and then decide whether to check it out or not, empowering their choice. People have their own opinions and views on materials, which should be respected. A person should learn to be tolerant of materials; others might truly enjoy it, finding meaning where you do not. This article might be offensive to those who read it, because they might think things should be more censored rather than tolerated, highlighting the very conflict it discusses. If someone does not like the material, they are not forced to check it out of the library so why cause a fuss over it and deny others access? One person might find a topic very offensive while that same topic sparks interest in another individual, demonstrating subjective taste. Each person has different morals so who is to say what should and should not be in a library, making censorship an arbitrary and dangerous power.

One essential right that every man, woman, or child should have is the freedom of speech, a cornerstone of a free society. Without this right no one would be able to express their views openly and without fear. When libraries pull books, magazines, movies, and music off of their shelves it takes away that right from the author and the public. Even if the matter of the subject is offensive to some people, the books or other items should be left on the shelves to ensure diverse voices are heard. What one person finds offensive another could find miraculous, insightful, or educational. If one person does not find the content of a book attractive then simply do not read the book; no one is compelled. Libraries should not censor the material that they put on the shelves just because someone does not like it, as this sets a dangerous precedent. I do think however, that books should be placed in the section that they belong, which is a matter of organization, not censorship. Sections for childrens books, young adult books, adult books, and many more can all be found in a library, helping patrons find age-appropriate material. An example would be that a book about the anatomy of the human body does not belong in the childrens section, but rather in a science or adult section. Beyond this, the library should leave the rest of the decisions to the reader, trusting their judgment. If someone wanted to read a book on the Civil War, then that person should be able to go to a library and check the book out without hindrance. The problem with censorship is that a particular group could find the book offensive and want it removed from the shelves, imposing their will on others. Then the person interested in the Civil War would not be able to withdraw the book, losing access to information. The choice of what material you read should be left up to you, not restricted by what someone else finds offensive; it is a personal matter. Libraries should not remove items from their shelves if someone else finds it offensive to their own beliefs, as this violates the principle of intellectual freedom. The person should just not read the book and allow others the same liberty of choice they enjoy. Everyone is going to have a different opinion on most things and therefore, there should not be censorship in libraries, which should be bastions of free inquiry.

Writing is a way to express one's thoughts and ideas on a page, giving form to inner convictions. In this country, an author can write freely about whatever he desires and he is not subject to penalty for doing so, which is a protected liberty. Sometimes reading these works can be enjoyable, other times it can be rather disturbing, challenging our comfort zones. However, just because a work is offensive does not mean that it is not worth reading or lacks value. Books, manuscripts, and other forms of literature should not be taken off the shelves even if they are disturbing or offensive, as their purpose is not solely to please. The Jungle, a book written by Upton Sinclair, revealed the horrible practices of the meat packing industry, exposing unsanitary conditions. It was offensive to many, and in addition it caused an uprising among the public because of its graphic content. However, there is a reason that book is still talked about today: it instigated real change. If there had been laws prohibiting him from writing about the horrific things that were taking place in those factories, it is quite possible and actually very likely that the industry wouldn't have been reformed for a long time, leaving consumers at risk. Fortunately, Upton Sinclair exposed the horrific processes that took place in the industry and the government stepped in and solved the problem, leading to new regulations. Someone out there hates this book, and hated it from the day it was published, perhaps for its tone or its accusations. But that doesn't mean he has the right to remove it from the shelves and prevent all others from reading it and learning from its history. Too often students are forced to read works of fiction and stories that, although they are beneficial for students, do not inform students about the world in which they find themselves, focusing only on classics. It is important for a student to read Shakespeare, and the works of Dickens and Greek myths. However, students must learn and begin to understand the world in which they currently find themselves, the eras of the past, and the circumstances that they will find themselves in for decades to come, requiring a diverse reading list. They must learn how to become successful in life, gaining practical knowledge. They should read works by Stephen Covey, such as The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People, which essentially tells the story of success and what separates the average from the great, offering valuable life lessons. Someone out there hates these works, and he should not have the right to ruin the opportunity that these books and short stories could give someone else to improve their life. Reading is the best way to learn, expanding one's knowledge and perspective. In a world of social networking and 'screens' of all types, the importance of reading has been diminished, which is a cultural loss. Students must develop a love of reading, and if everyone who hates a book takes it off the shelves, then, as Paterson said, 'we have no books left on the shelf for any of us,' creating an empty library. No book should ever be taken off the shelves, as each has the potential to teach, challenge, or inspire someone. Never should we allow the subjective offense of a few to dictate the educational and intellectual opportunities of the many.

Have you ever been offended? Did you lash out, or did you keep an open mind and come try understanding? People are offended by many things every day in life. So, we should broaden our minds, and see these 'offenses' as a normality, a part of living in a diverse world. You're at a party with a bowl full of candy stationed right beside the front door. You walk in and take a piece. Wait, you don't want that piece? What are you going to do with it? Do you take all of the same pieces that you don't like out of the bowl and throw them away, or do you simply drop it back into the bowl and choose a new one? If you throw the candy away, what does that mean for the other party guests? You have narrowed their choices down because of your own selfish opinion. That candy could have been the guest favorite. But, since YOU don't like it, you take away the other guests' privilege to eat that candy. They didn't deserve that, now did they? The same principle applies to books in a library. If you're searching through books in a library and you come across a book that doesn't interest you or offends you, then put it back and look for a new one. If you're having trouble finding the right book, ask the librarian for suggestions on other topics or books to check out. Go to a new library, even, but don't mess with something that isn't yours. Especially, something as small as a book. The point of the matter is, if you don't like something then disregard it. If your child is having problems, don't you think you ought to check what's going on with him instead of looking to see if he/she checked out the 'book that we hope none of our children' took off the shelf. This is quite possibly one of the last things I would think of causing a problem, if I even thought of this at all. Opinions can cause a lot of problems. Sometimes, people just need to keep their opinions to themselves, agreed, and let others make their own choices.

Author Katherine Paterson once said, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf--that work I abhor--then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' This quote is reflecting people wanting to rid libraries of some of the literature, books, magazines, music, and movies, because they think that the material is inappropriate. If we got rid of all of the books from the world, we would have nothing left to learn from, and some of the main sources of entertainment would vanish. I believe that certain materials should not be replaced from the shelves, because the youth of today need to learn about the true past, people should learn about how cultures really are, authors and writers need to be able to express themselves, and parents should be able to control what they believe their children should and should not read. If it were not for books and novels from the past, the current generations would have no clue of what history was about. Children should be allowed to read books such as The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn, The Diary of a Young Girl, and To Kill a Mockingbird in order to get a taste of how much times have changed. Stories from grandparents only take a person back about fifty years; we need sources that can take us back thousands of years. Some families, such as an African American family, might get offended if their children are reading books that say things like 'nigger,' but that is our history. It is something we cannot change, and it is important for kids to know how things really were and how terrible people were treated. We also do not want today's youth making some of the terrible mistakes generations in the past made, so they need to be taught about the real but sometimes horrendous situations. Learning about different cultures would be another issue if books and movies were depleted. Money is not available these days to just travel to different countries and experience their culture. How is a young girl from a small town in Kansas supposed to find out how people in Japan live their life? For all she knows, the people could be living in igloos. I believe that it is important for people to understand different cultures and religions in order to accept them in society. Movies can teach a lot about different countries, and books do a wonderful job as well. If they are gone, cultures would be misunderstood and forgotten. Also, authors and directors need to be able to express themselves. Every since people are young, they are taught that it is important to be unique and express their own style. Not every writer is going to want to write about butterflies and rainbows. There are people that love writing about violence, gore, and segregation. Those things are part of the world today and everyone needs to face that reality. Getting rid of all of those books from library shelves will not solve the problems; it would only cause people to not expect what might happen to them or the world. Now, some parents today have hard times when their young boy comes home from school with an offensive book, but parents should have control over their kids. If they have a problem with what their children are reading, then they should deal with that personally. They do not need to influence other people's lives by trying to get rid of the materials off of public libraries' shelves. Why people would even consider getting rid of history and learning materials about cultures and different subjects in the world is beyond me. It would be like asking someone to rewind time so that we would not have had slavery, depressions, world wars, and homicides. It is impossible to undo history, but we can learn about the things from the past in order to not make the same mistakes and things of the current world in order to be accepting and understanding. Books, magazines, movies, and music are wonderful. They represent self-expression and freedom of speech, so people should let them be an entertainment and learning source. Without them, we would be and have nothing.

I don't think that books should be censored, as it often creates more problems than it solves. There are no books, besides maybe math books, that don't offend at least one person or a group of people, making universal censorship an impossible standard. Books are an important part of the learning system, providing knowledge and diverse viewpoints essential for education. If a certain book offends you then you don't have to read it; that's that simple, as personal choice is a powerful tool. there is no need to over react to words on paper, which cannot physically harm you. Besides there are more important issues at the moment that deserve our attention and resources. While being offended by a book is bad, we must realize that some people are going through things that are way worse than that, putting the issue into perspective. People who do drugs or have a family member that does drugs are an example of a truly devastating life circumstance. A better example would be the parents or gaurdians of a kid who was killed either by accident or on purpose, experiencing profound and lasting grief. One of the most common but overlooked examples is the what the loved ones of people who die serving our country go through, sacrificing for a greater cause. As you can see if people can live with that then we can definantly handle an offensive book, developing a thicker skin and greater empathy. Censorship causes blidness, preventing us from seeing the full picture. What I mean is, if we censor one offensive book then we have to censor every book that someone finds offensive, leading down a slippery slope. All men are created equal, right? So they'd have to censor the book, as even foundational texts can be challenging. If a book offends you that much then listen up, don't read it! Just because a book is offensive to you doesn't mean it's offensive to everyone, and others may find value in it. sometimes a history book could be considered offensive so we censor it and then we don't learn about the mistakes of our past and repeat them, which is a dangerous outcome. The point is if a person can handle some of the things I've mentioned, then we can all handle a little bit of words on a little bit of paper, choosing to focus on substantive issues rather than perceived slights.
