The only reason the books should be taken off the shelf is because if it's a public library, a lot of kids and their parents go there to read, do research, and do homework. It is a shared space for the community. And that is why a public library should take an offensive book off their shelf to maintain a safe and appropriate environment for all its visitors, especially the children.

I believe that they need to keep everything and gain more. There is so much to learn about. The more information you have, the better. I, for one, think that they need to put more magazines on the stands so you can have more information and perspectives. Though you cannot trust everything in one source, you can still find many facts about what you're wanting to learn about by comparing different materials. On the other hand, children should not be able to reach or see some of this content. It could teach our children stuff that they are not yet ready to learn about, which is a valid concern for parents. The fact is they need to have people watching the stuff so kids won't get into it and we can still learn and find out new things safely. Not everything should be hidden from adults who can process it. The more you know could just save the world, or at the very least, help you understand it better, which is the ultimate value of a well-stocked library.

I would like it if nothing was censored, but I don't matter, right? I am the kid that has no choice in the matter. Why should I not care about what I am forced not to see? I am sure there are a lot of parents that don't follow the censorship rules, like buying a rated mature movie or game for their kid that is ten, and not eighteen years old, but does it matter that the parents are following the law? I say screw the law, because when it comes down to it, it's the parents' right to tell or show their kid about things, not the government. I think that young people have never really had a choice in matters that affect them directly, and I think we should. Young people have to follow whatever rules until they are eighteen years of age: why? I wish I knew why, but I don't, because there is no logical reason for us not to have a vote on what affects us. For all I know, there could be a law out right now that is going to make my generation less powerful than the last generation. I am not saying that this is true, I am only saying that it's possible for something like this to happen. Video games are my weakness, I admit, but I don't see a reason for games to be censored. When people say things like kids who play video games with violence will become murderers, it makes me frustrated. There is not one single thing that proves that. I have known people who have been censored all their life, and when they learn about the real world they can't even handle it. It's sad really to not be able to watch the news and learn what is going on in the world just because they have been kept away from all that all their life. I don't know how or where they get this censorship idea from in the first place. Did their parents tell them something was bad and to never watch or read it? Where did they hear these ideas from? I believe it came from the media itself. I can see the headlines now claiming that watching a certain movie causes kids to be murderers, complete with a made-up percentage. What I am really saying is that I try not to let other people's beliefs get in my head and change my own beliefs. Even by me writing this, I may have caused someone to change their beliefs, and I really hope I haven't, because everyone should be free to make their own choices.

Do I believe that some books, movies, magazines, or etc., should be removed due to the fact some people might find them offensive? NO, I believe that everyone should have the chance to see it, not just the people who did and thought it was offensive. Someone could really like it or a group of people could. Even if some people find an object offensive someone else might need that object for something like school work. Let's say the libraries remove a human trafficking book from the libraries because people find it offensive. Then a local school has a project on human trafficking. The students go to the libraries to get some books on it. Now due to somebody else's dislike of the books these kids don't get to use those books to do their research. It wouldn't be fair to everyone to remove objects from the libraries just cause some other people find it offensive. The libraries is a public place that everyone has the right to go and borrow stuff from, and removing materials based on individual sensitivities sets a problematic precedent. So no I don't believe that libraries should remove books, movies, magazines, or etc., due to the fact that some other people find them offensive, as access to diverse information is a fundamental principle of such institutions.

Twilight, Harry Potter, or even The Magic Tree House series are books that many guardians do not allow their children to read due to their beliefs on what is real and what is not. Magic, spells, and vampires many of us know are not real but others do not believe in what it is that is being taught to the younger readers. My personal view on censorship would be a very low tolerable standard due to different people, more variety, and different reading or viewing materials. But there would be certain circumstances where I would have to put my foot down and censor things such as sex and drugs just because that is not suitable for young children to be reading at that young of an age. The reason why I would have a low tolerance of the censorship is because different people like different things. If someone was an athlete they might not find a book about cooking and cleaning very appealing. As if a person that was a cook might not find a book about athletics too appealing either. Just because one person has different beliefs or what their standard is for offensive would not change my stand point on the censorship of certain articles. Different beliefs of certain people is understandable but, just because you don't believe it doesn't mean that everyone else is going to right there not believing it with you. Don't ruin it for the others who enjoy the interesting fact of a male wizard falling in love with a normal muggle girl just like you and me. Another reason why my censorship in libraries is low is because it would give my library more variety. If there was twenty different Harry Potter books on the shelves many people would be able to look at them and check them out as they please. Also, if you didn't know what kind of book you wanted to check out, you could look around and get a mystery, drama, comical, or even a horror book. Having a wide range to select from would keep the guests always coming back for more. I know that when my library had a series of books that I found interesting that I was back in there after I finished each one. Also, having different reading or viewing materials on hand is important in a library due to the fact that some books these days are now turned into films which makes people more eager to finish that book in less then a week so that weekend they can watch the movie. Most people say that the movies are never better then the original book itself but an opinion is easier to be based off of reading the book and then watching the movie not just by stopping after reading the book. Now that you know my personal views about the censorship in libraries understand that not everyone is the same. That is why when school's talk about getting school uniforms many children are against it due to the fact of wearing whatever style of clothing you do each day show individuality such as which type of book your reading also, shows your individuality. That is why my personal view on censorship would be a very low tolerable standard due to the fact that different people, more variety, and different reading or viewing materials. Just because you may not believe in the magic or wizardry doesn't mean you have to ruin it for someone else. So don't judge a book by it's cover and lets not set a high standard on censorship in libraries, for a library's strength lies in its diversity of thought and content.

I strongly disagree. I think that materials should not be removed from the library. Because all the materials are part of the library and for the school and for us too. All the materials, such as books, music, movies, and magazines, cd's, should not be removed from the library. I got my own reasons that materials should not be remove from the shelf. Like sometimes I don't found any interesting things to do, so I go to my tiny library that I got in my house and I pick any book that I like. But when I don't like or I don't find any interesting book in my house, I go to the library to find some interesting books. But when the libraries or the school got offensive books, magazines, movies, etc., I think that offensive stuff should not be remove from the library, because it is not necessarily good for the children's, like when they want to read a book, like cartoon or animal book, and they don't find what they want they are going to get mad. And what about the parents the parents if they need to found some information about a book, or they just wanted to read and they found offensive stuff, the parents are going to get mad, not all the parents right but some parent will, and they maybe are not going to came back again. I never experience something like this in my life because in my school and the library that I go they don't have anything offensive or inapropiated. that's why I respect the people for the library and for the school, because they respect us too. that's why I never go to places that I don't know. Suppose I go to a library that I don't know and I bring my parent and my little brother right and this library have offensive materials, my parents are going to get mad with me, they are going to said that if I don't have respect, and that I bring my brother to a innapropiated place they are going to be mad with me, that I bring my family to a offensive place, and is not my foul right. And those are my opinions why materials should remain available for everyone who needs them.

No, I do not think that books, magazines, movies and music should be removed. However, I do think that the books, magazines, movies, and music should be monitored by age. The reason why is because younger children should not be reading, listening, or watching material that is for adults or teenagers. The way these type of things can be monitored is by the child's library card. The card could have their name, age, grade, and date of birth. If there is a certain book, magazine, movie, and music that the child wants a parent has to be there with them. The parent needs to show a form of identification so that the librarian knows that the parent is of age. Teenagers should also be monitored. Even though they are almost adults, some parents may not agree with some of the material. So, if their parents does not want them reading certain things their should be stickers on their cards to indicate these restrictions to the library staff. Even though there are plenty of opinions about what a persons child is reading, watching, or listening to I think there should be certain ways to watch what children are reading, watching or listening to, and this system of age-appropriate access is a more balanced solution than outright removal of materials from the library's collection.

Picture yourself walking through the library with your child. Now think of how hard you worked to teach your child respect and manners. Imagine all of those values going down the drain by them reading one bad magazine or listening to one explicit song. I agree with the censorship in libraries today. Most people wonder where their children learn curse words or sexual behavior and do not consider media as the problem. Libraries have continued to keep children areas clean of explicit materials and are careful so that magazines such as 'Cosmopolitan' do not reach their shelves. Explicit material should be removed if it is found offensive. I have seen offensive material get into the wrong hands such as kids. That childish innocence disappears when they hear songs about money, sex, and abuse. Some books could give them the wrong idea and encourage them to make unlawful decisions. One example is a teen pregnancy book. The ideas in the book are either to keep the baby and deal with the consequences or abort the baby and move on with life. Some media says to abort the baby just because it is easier. Would you want your child to have the idea in their head that they should react first before they think? In conclusion, censorship should be kept in libraries. It helps everyone altogether not to worry about what wrong things their kids are doing, or how they snatched the wrong idea. Please help us promote censorship in libraries to make a more respectful environment for all families and patrons.

I feel as we are letting kids these days do as they feel, and do whatever they want without sufficient guidance. We are making them think that we don't care what they are involved in, but that's not true at all. We need to set clear boundaries for what kids should and shouldn't be able to do, establishing firm limits. We need to show them that we know what they are doing and that we are paying attention. I think that there should be a strict age policy for public libraries. If there are any books that have any types of adult content, such as explicit scenes or strong language, they should be exclusively in the adult section. If you ever wanted to check out books, movies, or magazines from that section you would have to be eighteen or older, providing valid identification. If that was too much to ask for, then you should at least have the parents sign a consent form acknowledging the material. Books, movies, and magazines with any type of adult content can be hazardous to a child, whether it's through their future actions or their developing behaviors. It can negatively effect their lives depending on what age they were introduced to such things, potentially causing confusion. We need to show them that we care about their well-being. I know from personal experiences that being exposed to this type of material drastically changes people, not over a long time but quickly and profoundly. Nowadays the media is portraying that money, alcohol, fame, and drugs are good things to be sought after. This is the very message we are putting into our movies and books and magazines, and putting into the children of today's heads, influencing their worldview. We are telling them that its ok to pursue these things, but its most certainly not acceptable behavior. These are all the reasons why we should put censorships and restrictions on libraries to protect the young. We are letting the children of this generation grow up too fast and introducing them to adult concepts way too early in their lives. In a way, we are brain washing them on how to live a destructive life, through adult oriented things that they cannot yet process, and this must be stopped for their own good.

The media is destroying our youth! This is something we hear everyday from various sources. Teachers are telling us this, while parents and grandparents are telling us how much different their world used to be, reminiscing about a simpler time. They explain how the media of their time wasn't as open about sex and violence, keeping such matters private. They go on to say how they didn't have violent video games teaching children that killing is alright or without consequence. Because of these people and their constant reminders, we are led to think that the media is responsible for the wrong in the world of today. The truth is that it isn't the media's fault entirely; it is primarily the parents' responsibility. It is the parents' fundamental job to teach the children of the world the difference between right and wrong, guiding their moral compass. If these such parents do their jobs correctly then the youth of today will not need for everything to be censored for their protection. It is my firm belief that there should not be any censorships imposed by external bodies. When there is censorship, people in power can govern what we learn, destroy what goes against their personal beliefs, and ultimately destroy our god given right to freedom of speech and expression. Censorship will destroy the knowledge available to society. We have seen censorship in our own history, and the results are alarming. When we look back we see that the ruling powers censored and destroyed anything that went against them, silencing opposition. We hated it when they had book burnings and destroyed the customs, art, and music that the government felt was wrong for their people, erasing culture. How would we be any different if we did it now? We could potentially be destroying someone's entire way of life and their cultural heritage. We would be destroying what could possibly be tomorrow's masterpiece, a work of great artistic value. In censoring we would be destroying history itself, removing pieces of our past. By destroying history we would be destroying the brilliance that is learning from our collective experiences. If we allow censorship, anything that goes against our own personal beliefs would be destroyed and removed from public access. If you ask any Christian if they would allow their children to read the Muslim book of faith, the Quran, they would likely tell you no. It would be the same if you asked a Muslim if they would let their children read the Bible. The point is that if there is censorship we would be destroying other people's sacred beliefs and faiths. No one has the right to govern what others believe in this world; such control is oppressive. Also, with censorship we would be exterminating our freedom of speech and the fundamental freedom to express ourselves. If we don't allow people to read what someone else has written because we believe it is wrong, then we are taking away their ability to learn new ideas and form their own opinions because everyone has different opinions and theories. Every newspaper would shut down because they would all be saying the same approved thing, creating an echo chamber. No one would want to read them because they would already know what they would have to say, offering no new insight. When we start giving up rights such as freedom of speech we will not be able to stop those people who took those rights from taking more, leading down a slippery slope. Of course there will always be things in the media, in books, and in music that we don't like or find distasteful. There will be cursing, nudity, and violence everywhere we turn in modern society. This is not because we want it there, but because these things are an unavoidable part of life and human experience. They are the dark parts that we don't want to see or acknowledge. If you don't want to see it, then simply don't look; exercise personal choice. Just don't close everyone else's eyes because you don't like what you see, imposing your views on others. Our learning, our beliefs, and our freedom of speech are too important to just give up to the dangers of censorship. We cannot allow others to dictate, in this matter, what is right for us to read and think. Our media is too intertwined with our daily lives to be controlled so heavily. Who's right is it to decide what is right for our own lives and minds? If we start giving up these small freedoms then those taking them from us will not stop there; they will just keep taking what freedoms we have left until we are nothing more than a dictatorship, stripped of our liberties.

Censorship in libraries should not be such a big deal or a point of major conflict. There are materials in libraries that are found to be offensive to some people, which is inevitable given diverse tastes. To solve the problem, everything should not be censored or removed from the shelves. Why can't those that find it offensive just steer clear of it and choose something else to read? I believe it should be a person's own individual choice to read something or not, and if they find it offensive, they should simply put it down and walk away from it. The book 'To Kill a Mockingbird' has offended many people due to its language and themes. I have read it myself and was not offended by its content. I found it very interesting and highly educational, providing valuable lessons. Many people think the book should be censored or banned entirely from schools. But if it is censored, the story would completely change and it would not be the same powerful narrative, losing its impact. I would have learned nothing from a sanitized version instead of learning how people lived and struggled through a difficult period in history. If all the books and magazines that were offensive to one person were taken off the shelves, and all the books offensive to another person were taken away, what would be left for us to read? Only little kids books about kittens and puppies? Well that's just lovely for children, but not for mature readers seeking knowledge. I am very much against censorship in any form within our libraries. I believe that if a material is offensive to you personally, then you shouldn't read it or listen to it; that is your right. But don't ruin it for the rest of us who may find value in it or wish to make our own informed decisions about the content we consume.

The library is a place of learning, discovery, and knowledge, available to anyone willing to take the time to engross themselves in the rows and rows of information. Including children's books, novels for young adults, reference materials, biographies, music, and movies, the library gives us a magnitude of opportunities to discover something we didn't know before, expanding our horizons. Although, there are other things that can be found in the library as well, which some find troubling. Books including racial slurs, sexual content, and offensive religious comments can accidentally be stumbled upon while searching for something else entirely. A parent should not have to worry about their child coming across a book or magazine containing inappropriate things such as this in a public space. I believe that offensive books, music, movies, and magazines should be removed from the shelves of our libraries to create a safer environment. I would like to begin by saying that I have an extreme issue with books that include comments, remarks, or names referring to people of a certain race in a derogatory manner. Imagine if an African American woman brought her young daughter of eight years into the library to find information about a school project. Instead of finding the birth date of a historical figure, she found a book making fun of African Americans and calling them inappropriate, hurtful names. Children should not have to come across a discovery like that in a public facility, where fun and interesting facts should be found; not racial slurs that cause pain. This type of event could cause serious damage on a child emotionally and mentally, affecting their self-perception. That is why these types of things should be taken off the shelves immediately to prevent such harm. Another issue I have is with explicit sexual content being found in libraries intended for the general public. I do understand that several classic books contain some sort of sexual content as part of their narrative, but I am speaking of a novel describing a sex scene in extreme detail, or images of almost naked women on the cover. If someone is searching for a book of that kind for personal reasons, they can travel to a sex store somewhere nearby and get their fix of sexual reading pleasure there. That type of book, however, should not be found in the public library where children frequent. It makes our society look bad and taints our places of knowledge with gratuitous material. Lastly, I would like to express how I feel about offensive religious comments being found in libraries that serve a diverse community. Every human in the country is entitled to their own choice of religion without fear of ridicule. They should be able to practice it freely, which is sadly not the case for others in different countries around the world. If we have an uncommon right such as freedom of religion, then why would we put books in our libraries that include rude comments towards different religions, creating division? A Jewish woman should not have to go to a library and come across a book stating her religion is a waste and stupid, causing offense. This is not the truth, and it should not be in our libraries, which should promote understanding. Even though I feel this way about inappropriate books, I understand there has to be some sort of limit when it comes to censorship to avoid overreach. Many people fear once we start removing certain books from libraries, more and more books will be taken from the public until almost all our libraries are empty of meaningful content. Yes, if we do not censor within certain, clearly defined limits, this could indeed happen, which is a valid concern. This is not what I want to happen though, as I value access to information. I simply want the people of this community to stop and consider what is easily available for our children to obtain without context. The least we can do, as responsible parents, is to take books, movies, magazines, and music containing racial slurs, sexual content, and offensive religious comments out of the libraries to protect our youth from premature exposure to harmful ideas.

Two of the many privileges that we have as Americans are freedom of speech and freedom of expression, which are foundational rights. Although some bodies of work may be perceived as offensive or inappropriate by certain individuals, I believe that they should still be available to the public who wish to access them. Some might agree with the topic being expressed, even if it is offensive or inappropriate, and others may not; but they should not be removed from libraries simply because of their negativity or challenging nature. These offensive or harsh pieces of literature could even be used to show the public what is considered rude, offensive, or inappropriate in a given context, and should be thought of as learning tools instead of being banned outright. Every person has a right to an opinion, and others may or may not agree with what that person has to say, but it does not change the fact that they have the right to their beliefs and to express them. Katherine Paterson says, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf'. I myself have read literature that is considered offensive by modern standards, but as disturbing as the literature was, I am glad that I was educated on what people thought was acceptable behavior in the past so that I know, and can teach others that despite what the book said, we now know that it was describing how people should not be living, learning from past mistakes. I believe that it would be a grave mistake to remove these materials from the public eye, because many are ignorant to the historical beliefs of others that have affected our nation and other countries across the globe, leading to a lack of understanding. All of these books are educational in their own way, though some are harsh and difficult to read, and they should be used to show what is right and wrong in society. If they are taken off of shelves in the libraries then people, especially children, could start to think that a certain idea, that may be incorrect or offensive, is completely appropriate and acceptable because they lack historical context. As someone once said, 'Those who do not know their history are bound to repeat it', making these works crucial for education. By removing the problem of offensive content, we would be creating another issue of historical ignorance. For example, many books have been written over history that convey hatred and discrimination towards other cultures, ethnic

Libraries are known as places where a person can go to find material on almost any topic they could want to learn about, whether that material is a book, movie, or magazine. Anyone can use the library, and it is a valuable resource to many people. So why do some libraries insist on removing some of those valuable materials from their shelves? In past years, censorship in libraries has been the focus of many news reports. In almost all cases, library patrons have been angry that certain materials have been deemed unsuitable to be offered at the library. I have to say that I agree with them. People have a right to choose what books they want to read, what movies they want to watch, and what music they want to listen to. People have opinions; people disagree. What one person loves, another person could hate. But just because one person dislikes or is offended by a material on a library shelf does not mean that the opportunity to use that material should be denied to all other patrons. I feel that if a resource is checked out by just one individual, and that one individual is able to learn from or enjoy the resource, then the library has achieved its purpose and helped the community by offering that material. A library's strength lies in its diversity of thought and content, not in its limitations. In conclusion, censorship in libraries is limiting and wrong. It creates barriers for those who want to learn and it takes away people's freedom to make decisions for themselves. Everyone should be able to decide whether to pick up a library material, and censorship makes that impossible.

Katherine Paterson stated this quote, ' All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf,' and I agree. I feel that some of the books we have in our public libraries today just shouldn't be there. Offensive books, music, movies, and magazines can give students and young children the wrong impact on life or their environment around them. Now days, what children see is sometime what they do, so if books, music, movies, and magazines give them the idea that what they say or do is cool, then kids will most likely do it. My observation when I look at kids in my community playing is that they follow one another. When they're playing tag and hide and go seek, they mimic behaviors they see. So movies, books, music, and magazines play a big part on the way they behave. My own experience with offensive books would be, there are books that are made by certain authors. In these books they use cruel language, use women body parts as symbols and many more rude things. My little sister came across one of these books, when she asked me about it was hard for me to explain to her that this was no book for a child her age to be reading, so the best way for me to put it was that it was an adult book. For her to get any images out of her head that I felt she shouldn't have. Another experience I've saw was with my little cousin. He was looking at a magazine out of the public library. The magazine was offensive to women. It was a play boy bunny magazine. Now I don't know if you ever heard of these magazines, but I think it is very wrong that they use women's bodies for men to view. I also feel that those type of magazines should not be in a public library. I believe it gives children, mainly young men the wrong thoughts about women. My overall thoughts on censorship in libraries, is that not everyone is going to feel the same way I do. There are parents that allow their children to read, listen, and watch whatever they want. I'm here to say I don't feel that is the way to go about things, because it can influence your children to do inappropriate things. I hope you take with you, my personal experience with you and help you children read, listen, and watch age appropriate books, music, movies, and magazines.

Do I think that certain materials such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from libraries? No, because people might need to know certain information, certain lessons are taught in different sources, and all sources are liabilities. Now, you just might need certain information, and in those sources there are an unnumbered amount of lessons to learn. For example if I were to go in a library and need a book on religion I would need a book or movie to teach me on that particular subject, or even sex education I would need a magazine or movie to watch to know new information. There are different lessons taught in different aspects. For example some people learn by example, from movies, music, and magazines. If it were me looking for a source on music theory I might need one of those things to get what I need. Finally, those things are liabilities. Don't get me wrong, we need them on a daily basis, but in a sense we sort of do. We use search engines for everything, everyday, but libraries provide curated and reliable sources. So what do you think? In conclusion I believe we need those sources because someone might need certain information, there are different lessons learned and taught in different things, and lastly all sources are liabilities that serve a purpose for someone.

The right to remove a book off of a shelf is not a good thing to do. My view on the subject is that, if this begins there will only be empty shelves in libraries across the country. Once the removing of books starts there will be hardly any left. We use books everyday; for students we use them to learn and for entertainment during some classes. Books help us learn things, like new words we've never heard of before, or some major point in history we should know about. Even as adults some of them like to read in their free time for knowledge and relaxation. I think it's wrong to remove a book off of the shelf, just because a few or a bunch of people think it's inappropriate. If it is, the libraries should have a section for those books that don't let the little kids go in that section. There is a problem for this idea: what books should go into this section of the library? A way to solve that question would be to elect a nation wide library service to set it up and have people vote on which books to remove or put into a special section in the libraries across the nation. This idea goes the same for everything found at a library. Another solution to this matter is that, the libraries across the nation have another labeling system like the Dewey decimal system but use both. This new system could contain information like reviews from critics about the book, or what happened during the book's plot. This would inform the reader more on what he is about to be engrossed in for the next week or so. The books, music, magazines found in libraries should be left there for a reason. Somebody wrote, or composed them for a reason, so people like you and me can enjoy good stories in books and read informing magazines and listen to good music.

Libraries should never remove any material just because it might be found offensive. Something that is offensive to one person may not be to another. If the material was so offensive that it went against the law, then it probably wouldn't have been published in the first place. People often get offended if they read, see, or listen to something that goes against their personal views, ethics, or religion. But people need to learn to understand that other people think differently and have different values. Though peoples' opinions differ, each opinion is equally important to that certain person, and no single viewpoint should dictate access for all. So many media sources today are censored that it is essential to keep a place where people can freely obtain material and express opinions. As a student I often have a hard time finding meaningful literature in the school library because it is so censored. I am not complaining about this because I understand that schools have to be careful of what they are exposing students to. But if I am looking for something maybe more religious, derogatory, or less accepted, it is nice to have a public library where I can find these things without restriction. In closing, if people are offended by something on the shelves of a library then they shouldn't read, watch, or listen to it. But do not censor everything so that people who do enjoy these materials can no longer easily access them.

I don't believe books should be taken off of the shelves for being offensive. Some books that are found offensive by one person might not offend another, as individual sensibilities vary greatly. People always have the right to say that a book is offensive if that is how they feel, but they do not have the right to deny others the right to read that book. I understand that parents want to protect children, and that is a natural instinct. Parents should talk to their children and explain to them why they don't want them reading that specific book, fostering an open dialogue. Parents might also just let their children read it and then explain why they personally don't approve, offering guidance rather than imposing a strict ban. I feel the same way about the censorship of music and movies. When I was twelve years old I started to listen to music that I enjoyed instead of the music my mother played. My mother was concerned about the lyrical content of the songs I would listen to. She refused to buy me the music and would not let me listen to it. No characteristic dictates the other characteristics of another, so why should an item? A good thing to you could be a bad thing to another, and what if that disappeared? Nothing can justify removing things from the stores and the world because one group of people don't understand it enough to feel the same and agree with it. Anything could be deemed inappropriate, but what if your vision of appropriate is anothers eye to inappropriate. If we start eliminating and removing everything we don't like, we would have nothing left, any and everything could be gone within a week or a month. People would take an inch to a mile, and erase everything, then we would start eliminating people we do not like, and it would all become a repeat. If we start listening to the facts of people not agreeing with one thing, we will listen to the next, what happens when all the sudden the people come in again and say they do not like the women with blonde hair or the men with green eyes? The world will crash and burn before our eyes, and if I can identify these things at the age of fifteen, then some need to identify things at the age of fifty, accept that the world has its flaws too. So just because I agree with everything I said, are you going to agree with it also? No I know you will not, but think about that when you expect others to agree with what you say or think. When I think of people reducing the things that they do not like, I can already see the world losing it's pathetic value it has earned, and we may not all be fond of this world but we cannot lose it. Eliminating the things you do not have a fatuation with will do no good, so maybe we should take into acceptance the different people we've been blessed with and love what we have. Accept the world as it is, because it is what you live in and it is what you have, because with out it nothing would be anything. Attempt to fix the broken things not eliminate the jagged things.

Offensive materials in libraries should not be taken off of the shelves because of their content. Writing is an art form and censoring what an author writes could obscure their message. People live around offensiveness every day on the street and in public places so censoring it in libraries would not protect anyone. Removing the books from libraries entirely could also interfere with research or school projects children have to work on for class. Writing is an art form and censoring what an author writes could potentially obscure a message or major theme of the novel. This style of writing can be seen in Mark Twain's novel To Kill a Mockingbird by Harper Lee using terms that are offensive to African American people to set the tone of the racial tension in the south at that period in time. This type of censorship would also be detrimental if a reader studying the holocaust can not view pictures of death camps because of the graphic nature, the reader would not be able to understand the true horror of the camp without it. People live around offensiveness every day at home, on the streets, and even in school. A normal person encounters several occasions a day where they might hear profanities on the street from passing strangers or friends. Parents sometimes curse or use profanities in front of their children to prove a point or just by accident, and this would expose children to offensive behavior just as much as adults. Children are also exposed to profane language and behavior when they go to school and work around other children who might have offensive behaviors. Censorship of books in libraries could interfere with school or work related projects and research. Censorship could be an issue if a student could not get a book on a major war or event because of graphic nature, and this would hinder the students ability to efficiently complete their assignment. It could also cause problems if a teacher needs to rent a book that has slight profanity in it but is not able to because of the content, inhibiting her from teaching her students about the theme and lesson. Censorship of books based on the content should not be allowed in libraries. First of all trying to censor a novel might obscure the message or theme. Secondly people live around profanity every day so trying to censor it would not protect people because they have likely already heard what is said in the novel. Lastly censorship of libraries could interfere with work or school projects or research. If all libraries were censored it could potentially lead to several complications with workers, students, or people who are just looking for a good book to read.

Libraries are sometimes connotated as very boring. Walking up and down aisles looking at all of the books, and wishing that they were all more interesting. Minutes after searching through the one shelf you have been rummaging through for what seems like hours, you get a glimpse of a very interesting title. Inside of this book could be countless inappropriate pictures and profanity on every page. Who is to blame for opening the book and reading it? Profanity, nudity, and crude humor, as well as many other things, are all over the media, including books. Some parents try very hard to keep their children out of the way of those things by telling the child that they just simply cannot watch, listen to, or read certain things. The parents typically do not say why they are not letting their child see, hear, or read these things, other than, 'it is bad, and I said no.' If parents were to tell their child specifically why they were not supposed to be exposed to certain things, the child might not be so inclined to get involved in those things. Not only should the parents teach their child why they should not be exposed to those things, but maybe they should be around when their kids have an opportunity to see things they shouldn't. And if a child is too young to see, hear, or read certain things, than they are far too young to be browsing a library or any other place where they are not properly guided by a parent. Censorship, in my opinion, should not be done by libraries, movie producers, television programs, and record companies, it should be done by the parents of a child.

In libraries, there should not be censorship on materials considering that it's an individual's decision to read what they prefer. There is no appropriate or universally agreed-upon standard on what makes a book offensive to a group, so it should remain undetermined as to what makes a book truly offensive. In a public library, many children, who the books are often censored for, are accompanied by their parents. Parents should therefore make an independent and informed choice on what they can allow their children to read. Letting society ban a book simply for the use of inappropriate materials is a ridiculous overreach. If an author spent considerable time and effort creating a story, it should be appreciated for its artistic merit, and should not be put on a list of no-nos. If a certain person doesn't like a book's reputation or content, all they have to do is simply not read it. Even in school systems, professional librarians are there to guide kids to read good books. If a child wants to read an inappropriate book, the librarian will most likely discourage him or her not to read it. In my personal experience, I wanted to read a book that my mother had suggested to me, but as I went to the school library it turned out to be a censored book. Some parents believe children should be kept ignorant about offensive things written in books, but honestly many of the same ideas and themes are already exploited and presented to them everyday on television and the internet. So trying to shield your child from the bad things might be a great intention, but the efforts are usually failed attempts. It also never occurs to the people censoring the books, that some people can't afford to buy the books they want to read. The libraries, for some, are the main or only means for getting books. To conclude there is very little reason to ban a book from the shelves. Many of the books banned have important lessons and perspectives that can be obtained through reading it. If a person doesn't like a book, the simplest thing to do is not to pick it up and read it.

Censorship is used in the media to prevent people from being offended by what they see or hear. Although censorship isn't usually a bad thing, it is sometimes over-used. Not everyone has the same views and morals; what may be considered appropriate for some people may be viewed differently by other cultures or religions. In my personal opinion, if you find something to be offensive, instead of demanding it be removed or censored, simply do not watch, or read it, etc. Obviously, if the content was published in the first place, it appeals to some audience. No one is forcing people to read or watch things; that is why there is something called viewer discretion. If everything that was considered offensive to a certain individual or group were censored, there would be no free expression. In our society, we have freedom of speech, the freedom to write or animate to express any belief we choose. To censor things out is contradictory to that amendment. For example, the censorship of using the word 'God' in vain on television. I myself find this to be excessive because it doesn't apply to my beliefs. Although the program 'The Secret Life Of The American Teenager' portrays people of my age and nationality getting pregnant and doing drugs, even though I find this offensive and stereotypical, instead of demanding it be removed, I simply don't watch it. I strongly feel this disturbing and destructive material should be removed from the shelves of libraries immediately. I do not question whether children and teens should read, but rather what they are allowed to read. I agree that reading helps our youth learn and excel in their schooling, but offensive books and magazines put nasty ideas into their minds and distort their way of thinking in a negative manner. The more our younger generation reads about these ugly things, the more curious and tempted they become. I feel they will eventually let their curiosity get the better of them, leading to dangerous real-life experiments. Many would say that experiencing activities such as sex and drugs is all a part of growing up, but I completely disagree. Trying any one of these harmful activities portrayed in certain library materials could put you and your health in severe and lasting danger. It only takes one single time to become pregnant or become tragically addicted to drugs, forever altering a young life. To better prove my point, think of your favorite book from your own childhood. Did you look up to any of the main characters? Did you want to be just like him or her? Well, it seems to me that this malicious material makes the main character and hero of the story a bad role model. They might save the world and be a hero by day, but authors and producers make sure they include a reckless night life in the story as well. This subtly tells our children that it is okay to do these things, when it is the exact opposite of what is acceptable. I stand by my opinion and believe all offensive books, magazines, and movies should be removed from the shelves of our community libraries. This material plants a bad seed in the mind of our youth that can grow into serious problems. It leads them to believe everyone, including their heroes in books and movies, does these things and that it is normal. Sex, violence, and drugs are not what this world was made for, and our libraries should reflect our highest values, not our lowest temptations.

People often think that graphic images or strong words are going to change the outlook their younger child has on a lot of topics. But really, the kids won't remember half of what they read or see, so does it really matter in the long run? Well, according to some people it does, which I can understand from a protective standpoint, but I will have to go with the side that it doesn't matter too. Because it's not like they're not going to find out about bad language or sex from their friends or the internet anyway, so I say there should be no restrictions on books, music, movies, magazines, tv shows, etc. The fact of the matter is that people or parents get too offended or complain cause their little child said a curse word in front of them for the first time. Or because some of the material in the show or magazines are too offensive towards people with disabilities, different races, etc. When really, all of this is just humor and satire; none of it is the network or authors being serious or malicious in their intent. Authors' works aren't to be shunned upon but to be read and for people to learn from that book or just have a good time reading it for entertainment. Through all of this you should know by now that I don't think that books should be taken off the shelf just because little kids' parents are ashamed of what their kid read. Cause like I already said, they are gonna find out about this stuff eventually from other sources. So there is no need getting mad over it and trying to hide reality. And if we got rid of all the more mature books, what kind of books would all of us more mature kids and people have to read for our age group? Cause I'm pretty sure I don't want to read about a magical friendly dragon finding its way home when I am trying to understand more complex themes about life and society.

Dear School Board, My name is Alex. I am a student here at North High School, and it has come to my attention that the Parent-Teacher Association is thinking about taking books they find offensive out of the library. I think this is wrong and a step in the wrong direction. If everybody at North High took the books we found personally offensive off the shelves and threw them away, we would be left with no books to read and a barren library. I also think that no one person or small group should have the right to decide what books are too offensive for me to read. I am sixteen years old and responsible enough to make my own decisions about what is too offensive for me to be reading. If I feel I should read books that others might find offensive then, why does that concern you? Just because I want to read the book does not mean you have to read it as well; we can all make our own choices. Also, I think that having books that might be a little offensive makes that book more interesting and realistic. If you take every offensive word out of a book, chances are it is going to be hard to sit through it and it would lose its authentic voice. If you take all offensive books from the library, kids will be even more discouraged about reading, and I know that is not what North High School is looking to do for its students. If you think that books are that offensive, try walking down the hallways between classes. This is a public high school. Kids cuss all the time, and talk about dirtier stuff than in any book I've ever read from this library. If you're looking to make children more innocent, then taking all of our books out of the library is not the logical way to go about achieving that goal.

Every author has an intended audience when they are writing a book, and they write about what they think is appropriate for that certain audience. Unfortunately, sometimes other people that are not intended to read the book actually do read it even though it may not be something that they are supposed to be reading at their age. When an author writes a children's book, it is meant for a child to read, not an adult looking for complex themes. Also when an author writes a romance novel, it is meant for people who can comprehend what the author is talking about and can act maturely while reading its content. Although some novels may not be appropriate for certain people, censorship in libraries is not the way to fix that, and it is a big mistake for a free society. As humans we are given certain freedoms, and one of those fundamental freedoms is the freedom of the press. Authors should be able to write about whatever they choose to write about, expressing their own ideas. If they choose to write about subjects that are not appropriate for all age groups they still have the right to have their books in libraries for their intended readers. Even though everyone isn't supposed to read them, certain people are and they have that right. If you take those books away because you're scared that a child might get ahold of one, then you're taking away what certain people enjoy reading and learn from. Due to the fact that different books are intended for different age groups, libraries have different sections filled with a variety of authors and genres. They have a children's section made primarily for children, an adult section with books that only adults are supposed to read, and a teen section for everyone in between. By having sections within them, libraries are trying to keep people reading what they were intended to read without censoring or taking away people's favorite books from the collection. Having sections in libraries is a happy medium between letting anyone read whatever book they would like no matter how inappropriate it may be, and cutting out certain books all together from the system. If a person is an adult, they should be allowed to go to the library and get whatever type of book, magazine, music, or movie that they want without judgment. If a kid's parent is okay with them checking out or looking at certain things then it shouldn't matter to anyone else if they think that the material is offensive for their own family. Instead of censoring what movies, books, magazines, or music that libraries have, there should be a certain age when someone can come in without a parent and check out whatever they would like on their own. If a person is under that age then their parents should be present while they check out so they can approve of what their child is checking out from the library. Censorship in libraries is ultimately pointless and shouldn't even be considered as a viable solution. Whether some people find certain material offensive or not, there are other ways to get that material in today's world, so there really is no point to censoring anything in our public libraries.

I think that all offensive materials should be removed from the main areas of libraries so every one can read a book, listen to music, and watch movies with out being offended by the content. They should have their own separate section for that kind of material, away from the general collection. Movies that are deemed bad or inappropriate should be taken off the open shelf. They should have a section just for those movies, perhaps in a separate room or behind a counter. The section should be locked up or require adult permission so children can't get access to those movies on their own. I think that this would be a fair compromise for everyone who uses the library. Music that is considered bad or explicit should be taken off the general shelf as well. They should have a section just for that kind of music, clearly marked for mature audiences. The section should be locked up in a cabinet so children can't get that kind of music without supervision. I think that this would be fair for everyone, allowing access while providing a barrier. Magazines that are bad or contain adult content should be taken off the open shelf. These magazines should have a section just for those specific titles, not mixed in with general interest periodicals. They should be locked up or placed behind the desk to control access. I think that this would be fair for every one, protecting children while allowing adult choice. Books that are bad or contain offensive themes should be taken off the general shelf. They should have a section just for these books, possibly requiring a librarian's assistance. These books should be locked up so children cant get them easily without an adult present. I think that this would be fair for everyone, balancing freedom with responsibility. This is what I think should be done with all of this offensive material found in our public libraries. If this was done, everyone would have a book to read, a magazine to look at, music to listen to, and a movie to watch in an environment that respects both safety and choice.

Picture this: you come home one day after work and before you even enter the house, you hear music blaring from your child's room. As you step closer, you begin to hear the lyrics that go with the banging bass and you realize that that isn't just any music, it's completely unedited, explicit versions of vulgar songs. Now, who would want their child listening to songs that make it seem like drinking, doing drugs, and other various risky activities are okay? I know I sure wouldn't. Music isn't the only source of offensive material in today's society. It can be found nearly anywhere. In books, magazines, television shows, movies, on the internet, you name it. All of these are easily accessible by children of all ages. That is why there should be censorship of certain materials, to a certain degree. By this, I mean that if there is a dirty book in a public library, it should only be able to be rented by people who are of a certain age. Just because it's bad doesn't mean that it has to completely vanish from the face of the world. There should just be a limitation on who can view it. That applies to everything that could contain offensive material. Kids are kids. There are certain things that should be absolutely off limits to them--such as explicit movies, books, music, etc.--as they do not need to know about drugs, sex, or alcohol at such a young age. Censorship should definitely be in effect in places like public libraries where young children are bound to be. But, as mentioned earlier, censorship should only be to a certain degree. Keeping childrens' minds clean for as long as possible would be a very positive thing to do for both them and our society in general, fostering a healthier environment for their development.

'And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' This is such a strong statement by Katherine Paterson in regards to censorship in libraries. So often today do we hear of books, magazines, and numerous other resources in libraries being banned because of unpopular views. A classic novel, The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn, has been removed from the shelves of many public and school libraries because of crude language such as the word 'nigger'. Libraries should not take resources off their shelves due to offensiveness because it goes against the library's purpose and because many people have different views. A library is a place with resources provided for information, interest, and enlightenment. When a book or magazine is taken away because of origin, background, or views that seem obscene or unpopular, then that library isn't serving its purpose. If I wanted to find a book on Catholicism but the library banned it because another religion found its teachings offensive, then why not ban the other religion's books as well? This goes back to what was said by Katherine Paterson earlier. What might be offensive to one person could be a lifestyle or interest to another. Children, however, should be treated as a special case. No, a child should probably not, in my opinion, be reading about adult things such as sex. However, that child's parent or guardian is the only one who has the right to restrict resources they feel as inappropriate. In most public libraries, young children are not allowed to roam the library without an adult. This is a very prominent rule because it sets boundaries for the adolescent so they are not to read about or listen to anything they shouldn't. Also, it is keen that libraries divide up the different resources into separate sections for children, young adults, and adults. Banning books and such from libraries takes away a part of history and leaves a gap for the future. To find that what our parents were once reading is restricted should not be an issue. Materials should not be censored in libraries because they are found offensive because this is censorship and it takes away our rights to access a full spectrum of knowledge and ideas.

'It's all because our neighbors who live in this neighborhood think the pictures and words are offensive, and since then the librarians stopped putting them out on shelves.' Libraries contain many different selections of books, music, and magazines. However, are all of these materials appropriate for all library visitors? In this essay I will explain to you why I think offensive, distracting and inappropraite material should be removed off of the shelves, and put into their own section of public libraries. If a small child were to walk into a public library and pick up a book about abortions, they would not know what the book is talking about, because most small children cannot read. What if a fifth grader was to pick that same book up? They would be able to read  the whole thing with no problems. However, should a fifth grader be allowed to pick up a book about abortions at such a young age? I dont think so, fifth graders should be reading age appropriate books. This is just one reason why I think offensive, distracting and inappropriate material should be moved to its own section of the library. When I think of a library I think of a quiet place that I can go to and read, or study. Although, some Libraries allow their visitors to listen to music. Rather it be on a computer, on a ipod, or even on a cell phone, there should be a sound limit right? Most people would think that Libraries set sound limits, and they probably do, but people do not follow directions and they are not attentive to what other people are doing. It is very distracting to go into a library, to study, and the person next to you has their ipod blasted to a heavy metal rock song. Once again, this is another reason I think offensive, distracting, and inappropriate material should be moved to its own area of the library. I also think that a library is a community place, that you can go to and be safe, and your parents would not have to go with you because they think that it is safe and appropriate too. Most Libraries have magazines, because its for your entertainment, and they want to keep you happy so you will keep coming back. Well not all magazines are rated G, some have very inappropriate material in them. A child should be looking at magazines that are appropriate for children, a teenager should be looking at magazines that are for teenagers, and an adult should be looking at magazines for adults. However the adult magazines should not be showing people with barely any clothes on, or any sexual scenes, and neither should teenage magazines. With innapropriate magazines, I do not think they should have their own section of the library, I think they should be removed all together. They have pictures in them and anyone can look at a picture. I really hope you can understand my point of view. It is nothing against public Libraries, it is just the material inside of them. If I owned a public library, I would have rooms devoted to books that are for different age groups. For example, I would have a room for 18+, and a room for 13+. Those rooms would be for the books that are easily questionable for younger children. I would also have my own room devoted for music only. That way anyone could go in the room and listen to whatever kind of music they want, no questions asked. The rest of the library would be for people to study, and read. I think every library should be like this, it would help make the world a better place by ensuring a more organized and considerate environment for all patrons.
