It is one thing to censor a book or movie, but to completely remove it is another. I feel like authors, artists, musicians, and writers should have the freedom to write and say what they want. Regardless of who is reading it. I feel like censorship is wrong. Authors should be able to feel free to express their thoughts and feelings about a subject or topic in any way they like. Sometimes stories cannot be explained or told the way it needs to be without certain words. Whether those words be good or bad I feel like without them the book that is being read is not all of what it could have been. In my opinion censorship takes away from certain values or qualities the book could have had with the original context still in it. And to me that is not fair. It's not fair to the author. And is most certainly not fair to the reader who is reading the book. I know from my personal experiences with reading books that 'yes' I have read books that have had bad language in them. But just because a book has one or two bad words in it does not mean that it should be completely taken off the shelf. For example the book 'The Outsiders' by S.E. Hinton was an amazing book. I probably enjoyed that book more than I have any other book that I have ever read in my entire life. But that book would not be nearly as good as it was with it being censored or taken off the shelf for that matter. All I am trying to get at is that good books with bad language should not be censored just because of some of the words it has in it. Because that is getting away from what the overall message is about. You're almost taking the words out of context when you do this. Do I believe that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from the shelf if they are found offensive? No I do not. Neither should you.

Sexual conduct, language, and criminal behavior are three big things in my school, and community. Certain books, movies, music, and magazines are all about those three things. If they are in our libraries, how can teachers and administration keep us from it during school? I think the censorship of some movies, magazines, and especially music should be highly discussed, and more strict. We do not really have a lot of movies in our school library, but I do know that there are some in the town library. Parents and adults do not want us growing up so fast, and yet they allow sexual, crude language movies to be on the shelves of libraries. If it is such a big deal, I think they need to be removed. I'm a big believer on the fact that if it happens, it is going to happen no matter what precautions are taken. But with that said, we can still take the needed precautions to keep it from kids that are too young to see them, like under the age of thirteen. It is not just movies that we have to worry about though. Cosmopolitan is a magazine that is devoted to giving their readers tips on sex, problems with their sex lives, and the occasional 'what to wear this season!' articles. I will say that I have read this magazine, but it doesn't appeal to my interests. Some kids today though, are very attentive to those subjects. Again, that goes back to the problem of kids growing up too fast. I have noticed in my school alone, that it is a rapidly growing problem. If magazines like this weren't on the shelves for us to see whenever we enter a library, maybe we would not be as keen to the idea. If we were not introduced to it so early, we would not be going behind our parents' backs trying to do it. Cosmopolitan, and other magazines like it, needs to be taken off the shelves as soon as possible. Music is a world-wide phenomenon. Say a child around the age of ten is listening to the new Eminem song. He is being introduced to crude language, sexual behavior, and criminal acts in the three minute time period it takes to listen to the full song. Seriously, it only takes that long for a child to be introduced, and it is only one song out of the thousands that are out there. This music is able to be accessed on many computers, especially in public, town libraries. We are not allowed to act like that in school, and if we are going to be spending seven hours of our childhood/teenage years here, why let us listen to it? If you walk into a library, all you have to do is sign your name, the date, and the time you got there to access a computer. After that, they can not tell you to get off of it, unless you are violating the law or looking up something not age appropriate. Music does not fall into that category. It, too needs to be taken away if the language, sexual conduct, and criminal behavior messages are adult rated. I, personally, love magazines, movies, and music. They are my three m's and I live by them. But not the ones that are going to get me in trouble, put wrong messages in my head, or cause me (subconsciously) to participate in a criminal act. I always allow my mother or father to read books, listen to music, and watch movies with me. If they are not pleased with what it is, I will not do it behind their back. The censorship in libraries needs to be more strict. If it were more strict, it would keep our younger children from growing up too fast and keep teens from participating in criminal acts. The censorship in libraries is an ongoing problem and it needs to be fixed.

The diversity of the world makes it rather difficult to please every person all of the time. What I find appropriate, another may find obscene and vulgar. What I enjoy to read, or listen to, or watch, or any other manner of media consumption I indulge in, may insult or bother someone else; as a matter of fact it probably does. That still does not make it right to remove what I, or others like because it offends another person. A child walks through a grocery store, doesn't get what they want and proceeds to drop the f-bomb. More than half the time, they heard that language from their parents. If not their parents, then the media right? Maybe so, but that media shouldn't be hidden for the 'just-in-case' a child hears it. If a parent or guardian does not want their child to hear such things, they shouldn't allow them to listen to it. They control what does and does not enter their house. To remove such things from the library, would be like trying to keep a child from ever seeing a naked body, or hearing a curse word. Every time they bathe they'd need blinders from themselves and they'd never be able to leave their house, because people do not always watch what they say in public. No, I do not feel like every type of movie, or book, etc., belongs in the library. There is a cut-off as to how inappropriate or vulgar something should be and still be allowed in a public library. Novels that are so descriptive that the reader can almost see every aspect of the procreation taking place between the pages, should have its own place, separate from the public library, right along with the movies that really do show every aspect. Although I like the thought, to actually remove said books would be unfair. To deny access to those who find those books fine for themselves would be wrong. A wise author, Katherine Paterson once said, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf- that work I abhor- then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' The truth of this statement would not be hard to prove. A religious family that believes Harry Potter, a book I find to be innocent fantasy, is a book series promoting witchcraft and satanism, so they remove them from the library. I remove the previously stated graphic romance novels. A mother whom wants her child to be sheltered from what she considers the filth of the planet, removes books of drug addicts, and abuse, and books of war because they're full of death. And as this continues, finally, we are left with the empty shelves of a forgotten building that no longer has a purpose. The graphic novels I find inappropriate could be placed in an adult section, or higher up than most children can reach. The protective parents can deny their own children the media they deem inappropriate, instead of the world. Although not everything is appropriate for everyone, it isn't right to censor something from the world. There are ways to censor things to parts and not others. Nothing should be removed from the library because of its content. At most it should be placed in a less accessible manner.

There are many different people in this world, who have many different opinions about books, music, movies, magazines, etc., just because one person does not particularly like horror movies, that does not mean that movie stores should remove horror films from their shelves. As creepy as it may sound, there are many people in the world who are slasher film freaks. They live and breathe scary movies. I myself like just about everything out there. I will read any book or listen to any type of music; it actually widens my taste in certain materials. I feel like everyone should try new things. Say growing up your favorite books were Winnie the Pooh. and you would like to share your childhood stories with your children. BUT suddenly, book stores took Winnie the Pooh off of their shelves because a tiger and a pig could never be friends. This is nonsense. Many people like many different things. There is no reason to only sell what you like. Otherwise your business will fail.

What is considered offensive? If we took books, music, movies, and magazines that people found offensive off shelves, there would be nothing left. Everyone is different, which means they all get offended in different ways. By taking all this off shelves, we would be providing a smaller education for students around the world. Things we learn about in school, such as slavery, wars, and some politics, could offend many people. But if we were to take them off the shelves at schools and libraries, children will have no idea about history or what is going on in the current world. What about drugs and alcohol? Many parents do not talk to their children about the uses of controlled substances, so without these sources, they might never know the harm that they can do to someone's body. Everyone takes something as offensive, but not everyone takes the same thing as offensive. So who is to say what offends people and what does not? If that's the case, shouldn't we take all books, movies, music, and magazines away from children's schools and libraries? Adults get offended too, so would we take all of their resources away also, including the newspaper? By taking away what one person calls offensive, we might land in the dark ages with no books, no local news, no movies, no nothing, because not one person can say what the whole world considers offensive. Everyone has the right to read and write what they want. No one can say what offends everyone. Someone might get offended by talking about one's race, another might get offended by talking about religion, and someone might even get offended if you talk about their cute little kitty cat. Everyone looks at everything differently. So why try and control us all as one? All people think different, and they know what they want to read, hear, and watch all by themselves; they don't need someone to tell them what is acceptable for their own minds and perspectives.

Censorship should only be used for areas in which young children are exposed to, such as schools and TV shows intended for young children. Things that aren't intended for young children should not be censored. If you were to censor everything because some people find it offensive, then we would never be able to find new ideas to improve our community. Censoring books, movies, magazines, and music that aren't intended for young people is a waste of time. If you were to take a book off a shelf that explained the theory of evolution because a person found it offensive, then we would never make advances in technology. Censoring items like books is just plain idiotic and ignorant. Studying material is our only way to advance in science, and if we can't get the right books to study because they were taken off the shelf due to being offensive, then we will never make breakthroughs in technology. Parents that feel that books, movies, and magazines should be censored really aren't good parents. If they really were concerned with those topics, then they shouldn't buy them the movies or the books that they find offensive. It seems that some parents want to proclaim they want to censor those items because they find them offensive. But not all parents feel the same way; some parents are open with their children about these topics and feel that their children are mature enough to handle things like these. As a child, I wasn't shielded from these kinds of situations. I grew up without censorship. I watched movies and read books that were never censored, and I was mature enough to know what it all meant. I see why parents want to censor their kids from topics like those, but they never take the time to talk to their children about these topics and see if they are mature enough to handle it. Censorship is great for children's TV shows. But when you start to censor someone's ideas because you find them offensive and wrong, then you are being ignorant. People here have freedom of speech and deserve the right to not have their work censored because a small group finds it offensive. Censorship is a great tool, but only if it is used right and applied appropriately.

Book Censorship? Should books be censored? This is a national problem about the contents of books. It is a big deal. What one parent feels is very offensive, another might feel it has a necessary life lesson that their children need to learn. If you ask me that question, I would say, 'Yes, I believe books should be censored, but to a national scale and not a community one.' By this I mean a book with things like references to nudity or other things of a vulgar nature, not just because it has a bad word in it that a parent feels to be inappropriate for their child. I believe there should be a national rating system for books, like there is in the movie industry. Also, I believe that it is the parents' job to regulate what their children read. If they believe the book is vulgar or inappropriate but the system doesn't, then they need to prevent their children from reading it without taking it off the shelf. It is the parents' job to regulate the reading of their children, not the contents of the bookshelf. Like in Katherine Paterson's statement: 'All of us can think of a book we hope none of our children or any children have taken off the shelf. But if I had the right to remove that book from the shelf—that work I abhor—then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' By this, I believe she means that if we all took a book off the shelves for our children, there would be no books left because what is not offensive to you might be very offensive to another parent. So the parents should leave it on the shelf and prevent their own kids from reading it and let the other parents worry about their own kids. Yes, I believe in a government censorship program, but only to an extent. It is the parents' job to regulate the readings of their children, but they do not need to regulate the contents of the bookshelf for everyone else.

No, I would not think it would be the right thing to do. To just take a book off the shelf just because one person or a small amount of people think that one book is offensive to them is not fair. It is not only one person's place to decide that. People, or some people, would like to vote or have a meeting about taking a book or books off the shelf because it's offensive to them. Just because one person finds that book or books offensive doesn't mean that they should have the right to just throw the book away. There could be many people out there that really like that book or those books, and they wouldn't be able to enjoy them anymore, all because one person or a few other people don't like the book. Yes, there are books out there that a lot of people don't like, but that still doesn't give one person the right to throw the book out, all because they don't like that book or that series of a book. No one should have the right to just take a book that they don't like out of a library and throw it out because they don't like it. There could be a smart little boy or girl that likes that book, and because that one person threw it away because they don't like it, now that little boy or girl won't get to read their favorite book. That's why I don't think books that someone thinks is offensive should be taken out of a library. Because there's always someone out there that likes that one book that you might want to throw away. If you think the book is that offensive to you, just stay away from that area of the library and don't think about that book, allowing others the freedom to choose for themselves.

The media is a way for some people to get out and reach others. Whether it is a magazine, movie, etc., everyone in the world is going to see it some way or another. If that piece of work isn't seen as acceptable from many people's points of view, it shouldn't be available to the public. I personally believe that if something is seen as vulgar and offensive, it shouldn't be displayed. Millions of people will be viewing this, and I wouldn't want my kid looking at it. Why would anyone else want the opposite? Kids pay attention to detail really well, and something so negative could change the mindset of the child. We all want to bring our kids up right, and letting them have availability to negative material is uncalled for. It's not only kids either that are affected; adults also are affected by the media. Adults can get fooled too, believe me, and negative influences can shape their views in harmful ways. I remember one time that there were books and magazines at my school that were being taken off shelves for this exact same reason. I believe that what the librarians did was right. Some kids in the school shouldn't be viewing or reading about unacceptable things. Some students may not have matured enough and can take something in a different view than another student, leading to misunderstandings or negative behaviors. I believe that if something is taken off a shelf because it doesn't seem appropriate enough, I stand for whoever it is that did it. Nothing with a negative effect on a person should be viewed by an innocent child. There should be a positive effect on the child at all times so he or she is brought up to the best of its abilities, surrounded by constructive and uplifting material.

I think that they should remove certain books, and take away more stuff from the kids now a days, because they are getting worse and worse like everyday. Specifically, i think they should move the age for unrestricted access from @NUM1 to @NUM2, so at least they are old enough to read, hear, or watch whatever they want with more maturity. However, they should go through and do a thorough self-check on everything that they put out on the shelves in the stores to ensure it's appropriate. They should also have different, clearly separated parts in a library so that the little ones dont accidentally get to the adult section, which would contain adult books that have explicit stuff in them about sex, drugs, or anything else that falls under that category. I have @NUM3 little brothers, and they are @NUM4, @NUM5, @NUM6. They know more stuff then my parents did at their age, and its because now a days kids pick up on information a lot more easier due to the internet and media. So i say we as in the @LOCATION1 citizens need to be more vigilant and watch out on how we put stuff out there that the kids can easily get a hold of. When i was growing-up i didnt know as much as my little brothers do today, and that is because everyday companies and media are coming out with something new that can negatively effect our kids, brothers, or whoever. I also do think the schools should have a dedicated class about the real-world stuff that kids are experiencing in todays life, starting in like elementary school, so that when they get older they will already be educated about the dangers of drugs, or the realities of sex life. Kids also remember information a lot more when they are growing up, so if we put it in there heads at a really really young age in an appropriate manner, they will remember it. Im not saying that kids will completely stop doing what they are doing, but atleast the percent population involved in these things will go down, and parents will be a lot more happier. I also think that parents should stop lying to there kids about sex, making up silly stories so that there kid wont know the truth; they need to stop doing that because the children are going to find out about it sooner or later, so why not now from a trusted source? they would be more aware of the real life and how it is out there, so all the parents out there should not lie to there kids about the sex life. So thats what my person input is on the situation. I wish this would change sooner or later before the world becomes a big mess.

Books have been a part of every single person's life as soon as they learn to read. First our parents read us bedtime books to get us to go to sleep. Then our teachers read us books to teach us things or to keep us preoccupied during story time. Then, when we get a little older, we are assigned to read specific books for our classes. There is even reading in the workplace, whether it be receipts or orders or recipes for a cook. Reading is something that we simply cannot get away from in daily life. This leads me to say that authors write books for a specific audience and write the book as best they can to attract the attention of that intended audience. I do not believe that books, regardless if one person deems them offensive, should be removed from the shelf that they have been placed on. I think that there are simple things we can do if we do not want to read that particular book, like just choosing another one. There are also things parents can do to ensure that the books their children are reading are appropriate and not offensive, such as previewing them. Also there are advantages to reading books that might show something different that that person may not have experienced before, offering a new perspective. First, I feel that books should not be removed from libraries because some people think that they are offensive. Everyone has an opinion and just because one person does not like the book, should not mean that the experience of reading that book should be taken away from someone else who might enjoy it. If you find a book to be offensive, you can simply stop reading the book and return it. Just because you do not enjoy it does not mean someone else will not also find value in it. That is just a part of humans having their own unique opinions and tastes. On a different note, I think that childrens' books are a little bit different and require more care. Parents have the right and responsibility to protect their children from content they feel is unsuitable. I believe that parents should take a proactive role in monitoring their children's reading materials. For young children, I think that parents should just read the book first themselves and judge whether or not they think they're child should read it. Then for young adults, I think that parents could try to look up some things about the book online or ask a librarian. The internet is a great source for reviews and ratings of books that can guide these decisions. Therefore, I believe that censorship for childrens' books is a responsibility of the parent, not the library. Lastly, I think books are unique in that they are different to everyone and can be interpreted differently by each reader. When I read a book, I think about the plot scheme, imagine the characters, and react to the events, and I come up with my own opinion of the book. My friend, who is also reading the same book, could form a completely different opinion of the very same book based on their own life. But we both gained something valuable by reading the book and sharing our thoughts. In conclusion, I think that books should be censored only by parents for their own children and that is it. I think that reading books is a very positive thing that expands the mind. So no one should have the right to tell other people what they should and should not read based on personal offense. Also, books are things that can be discussed and everyone can make their own opinions about, which is a beautiful thing. It is my opinion that every book should have its own place on a shelf waiting for the right reader.

I believe that they should not be pulled off of the shelf if they are found to be offensive by some. Many people have their own unique taste in what they like to read, write and do for entertainment. Therefore, there should be a wide variety of these things on the shelves so people can freely choose what they enjoy best. Books and magazines can certainly be offensive to some, but they can also entice and captivate the reader with their themes. I personally love books about gritty topics like drugs, sex, and many other inappropriate things because they feel real. In fact my favorite book is banned from my school library, which I find frustrating. If they took all inappropriate books out of the library, what would I read? Not everything in life can be just peachy keen all the time. Its not like that in real life, so why should we have to read about a little fantasy world that we know isnt true or realistic? I know I would'nt want to read that kind of sanitized material. Just like books and magazines, every one has their own taste in music genres. Some like country, classical, metal, and maybe even rock. If you took the songs that were deemed offensive off the shelf that would make many people angry. That's like not playing a song on the radio thats offensive, and many songs played on the radio are degradeing to women. If it can be played on the public radio, why cant it be available in a library? They are going to be able to listen to that song on the radio anyway, so removing it is pointless. Most movies these days are very gory or offensive in many aspects, and yet many people are interested in these movies. If you can watch that movie in a public movie theatre, why cant you check it out of a library for home viewing? Some people go to check out educational movies that are shown in school so they can watch it if they were absent that day. What would they do if that movie got taken off the shelf? Fail the assignment? I know I would become angry if that would happen to me and I couldn't complete my schoolwork. We should keep offensive books, music, movies, and magazines on the library shelves. People will eventually see them, hear them, and watch them even if its not in the library, so it's better to provide access than to pretend the content doesn't exist. Even if you take out offensive materials, they are still going to get them sooner or later no matter what you do, so censorship is ultimately a futile effort.

When have you ever went into a library and found a book that is so offensive that you feel the need to complain or try to get that certain book off the shelf? Have you ever read a book half way through and questioned why you are even reading it in the first place? Why would you continue to read a book that you know you're not going to like from the start? These are questions we should ask ourselves before demanding removal. If someone has the right and the authority to take books off the shelf that bothers them, then I have the exact same right as them to keep it there. I thought everyone was treated by equal rights in this country. When I ever do read, I always read the back of the book or whats called the summary of the story so I can see if I'm going to like it or not before I commit. If I know a book is going to offend me or a magazine or even a movie, most likely I'm not going to even bother giving my attention to them; I just move on to something else. Obviously the author doesnt like censorship or she wouldnt be arguing about it in her work. It's obviously something that bothers her deeply and everyone is intitiled to their own beliefs and disbeliefs on the matter. I respect people that stand up for themselves and find the hardest ways out of hard prediciments, like fighting for intellectual freedom. I can honestly say I don't always go to libraries and read books because I'm not a huge reader. But I can tell you if I ever did go to a library and I found a book on the shelf that offends me, its probably going to be fine for someone else. So why would they even try to bother getting away with being offensive to people if it's just one opinion? Everyone is intitled to their own opinion, that is a fundamental right. But I think if a book is going to offend someone in particular, it's probably going to bother someone else too, but that doesn't justify its removal. I'm not saying everyone is alike but most people believe in things that other people believe in, forming communities. People can have the same agreements and disagreements, which is normal. I do have to agree with @PERSON1 because she is right in her assessment. You would be amazed on the amount and different things people can get offended by; it's incredibly subjective. I have tons of personal experiences with movies, books, music, and magazines that have offended me on some level. But I didnt let it pull me down or anything; I just moved on. For example, I simply stopped watching the movie, and I stopped reading the book that bothered me, problem solved. You can't wear your emotions on your shoulders in a public space, but you can stand up for your rights and tell people what you believe in a respectful manner. You shouldn't ever tell anyone that you can't believe in your own opinions; that's not fair. If certain things offend you, don't let them bother you to the point of censorship; just stop doing what your doing and move on to something else that you enjoy. Like I said, I have had a lot of experiences with offensive things I have read and watched over the years. Like awhile back I watched a historical movie that had a black man in it and he was locked in prison and killed in prison for being accused of something he didn't do. It was just because the time era was racist and it was also because he was black, which was a common tragedy. Thats the kind of stuff that really upsets me and makes me angry at injustice. Because we are all the same human beings inside. We may look different on the outside and see things different from our perspectives, but our bodies function the same and we all breathe the same air on this planet. I have always gone by the saying, 'Don't ever judge a book by it's cover until you read it' yourself and form your own view. So whatever people might think, I believe in one thing and it's to let people believe in things they want to believe in without interference. Don't ever tell someone how to think, act, or feel about creative works. I agree with Katherine Paterson and her stance against censorship.

When I go to a library I might occasionally find some stuff that is offensive to me personally. But if something is offensive to me, the person standing right beside me may not think the same thing is offensive to him or her at all; it's all about individual perspective. When people try to put strict boundaries on what is offensive and what is not, they simply can not succeed because offense is subjective. There is a wide variety of people in the world that all have diffrent opinions based on their personal history, culture, and upbringing. What I think is offensive might be seen as the best thing that has ever been printed, published, or recorded in other people's eyes, and that is their right. The major problem with censorship is that the word 'offensive' doesn't have a single, set definition that applies to everyone. I don't think that you will ever find a definition for 'offensive' that everyone can agree on, which makes blanket bans impossible. There needs to be some logical limitations in place to keep certain mature things away from certain age groups, which is just common sense. For example, you would not want a kindergardener to be able to check out a @CAPS1 rated movie from the library, as that would be irresponsible. Some basic censoring has to be done by institutions to protect young people from clearly harmful content, but it should be minimal. But it all comes down to using our common sense when making these decisions for a community. We won't ever all agree on what is offensive on a detailed level, but if we use our common sense and focus on age-appropriateness, the problem can be largely solved without removing access for adults

Certain people believe that offensive books, magazines, or music should be taken off of the shelves of libraries. I think that offensive books and music and media should not be taken off of the shelves. It is a person's own right to see certain things that are offensive if they choose to do so. It is also not another person's right to decide what other people can and cannot observe. If certain offensive things were taken off of the shelves of libraries such as music, books etc., the knowledge of people would be limited to only what the library or the government would want them to know and that is not right. It is someone's personal decision whether or not they look at, listen to, or read offensive things. People shouldn't be sheltered by society and only know what is wanted for them to know. If libraries eliminated offensive media then people would not be able to form their own opinions and ideas. In some cases reading and knowing certain things that are offensive to some people should be known to the world. One case is how people should know about the holocaust in the 1940s. I am sure reading about the holocaust is very offensive to copious amounts of people, but even though this history is disturbing and offensive people should know about it so that history does not repeat itself. The government and society does not have the right to decide what people take in. For example what if all of a certain type of music was eliminated from libraries, the internet, and tv; it would slowly dissolve out of existence. Certain things like reading about the times before racial equality, and such things as slavery are very offensive for people to read about. But these things must be read and heard and passed down through history so it isn't forgotten. The knowledge of offensive things should not be taken away from people by the libraries. Yes offensive things shouldn't be celebrated or looked upon as good but people should know. People in the world can't just know the good things or only what their society wants them to know, they also have to know about the bad things and offensive things that happen and have happened as well. Ultimately, access to a full spectrum of information is essential for a free and informed populace.

Katherine Paterson said ' If I have the right to remove that book from the shelf, then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. ' In this quote I think she was trying to get across that if someone picks up a book or a magazine and reads it and then puts it back and maybe its not the best book ever to them and they might find it offensive, but someone else comes along and wants to read it and they might not find it offensive, then you have two different view points on a book that might be offensive to one person, but to another it might not be. Different view points really effect how to censor books, because of how people are so different, their difference on how they feel about a book could effect what should happen to that book. I don't believe that books, movies, music, magazines, and other materials such as those should be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive to someone. If they are found offensive to a bunch of different people then yes they should be removed, but if its only bothering one or two people but there are other people that agree that its not offensive, then don't get rid of it just because of a couple people. Take a vote maybe to see how many people agree and disagree on keeping or getting rid of it then decide whether or not you should keep or get rid of it off of that vote. I think it would be more fair and satisfactory to take a vote on whether or not it is fair to keep or remove it. If someone has a memory about something they read or remember an experience from it and then someone else reads it and feels offended by something its not fair to the other person to get rid of it. Its especially not fair to the person with the memories and experiences. So don't remove books just because a couple people might find it offensive, take a vote to decide. Let more than just a few people decide on behalf of the book. More than just a few people can make an impact on just one book, and you never know what different views you might find from different people on just one book. People need to be able to discuss their views on the book and then debate on whether or not to keep it, so don't choose to get rid of them without several view points on the book. A collective and democratic process is the most equitable way to manage library collections.

Everyone has their favorite book. But if it offended someone, should he be allowed to remove it? Offensive materials should not be removed from shelves. If we removed books that offended even one person, then no books would remain, as every piece of media is likely to offend someone. As Americans, we have the right to freedom of speech. Authors use their freedom in their writing, just like musicians use their freedom to make music. But if we denied them their right to put out their creations, we would be denying them their basic rights as an American citizen. Personally, I hate rap. I don't even consider it to be music, due to the fact that no one actually sings. But I do understand that a large percent of our population does enjoy listening to it. Should I be allowed to remove it from shelves, leaving teenagers without their music, denying artists' freedom of speech, and ultimately, leaving them unemployed? One of my favorite series is the Christy Miller series, by Robin Jones Gunn. It is about a young teenager who learns to deal with all the struggles of growing up by depending on God, and it helped me do the same. But because it is a Christian series, should it be removed from shelves? Should other young girls be denied the chance to read this life-changing series, simply because someone might find it offensive? Although some wish they could eliminate certain materials that they find offensive, it isn't fair to the authors, musicians, or fans of those pieces of work. However, those who find it offensive should be allowed to avoid it. Libraries need to make sure they separate each topic distinctly, so people can easily tell where they should or shouldn't avoid. Libraries are supposed to be a resource for everyone, which means they need to have materials for everyone, even though they might seem offensive. This balance ensures that libraries fulfill their role as a cornerstone of a free society.

If the library is in a high school, then we are all old enough that we have already seen or heard anything and everything offensive. In case we haven't, though, you can't shield your kids from offensive material. This overprotection hurts them in the long run. Such as when your boss gets to work and you or someone around you messes up an important assignment or task he might use terms such as the 'f-word' or other vulgar terms to describe how mad he is. If you were to just hear those for the first time being yelled at you, there is a chance you would have a break down or be ineffective for work. Now I'm not saying we should all 'cuss' every day and talk in vulgar tongue. I'm just saying that the real world doesn't have a 'clean' version. There is no mom or dad there to stand by and say, 'oh no, that's not acceptable speech, son'. If you took a survey of the daily language of teens and young adults, almost ninety percent would say they use some form of vulgar language or inappropriate terms. We need to have our kids and teens to know it's not ok to say those things, and they need to know what is acceptable in society and what is not. But taking the books from them in the library and then thrusting them into a world with daily inappropriate acts is not right and does them a great disservice.

Do we have the right to take books? Author Katherine Paterson proves a point by saying 'if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf, then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' She is saying that if everyone is able to just remove books from the shelf because they have something against it, then we would hardly have any books at our libraries. Everyone has their own opinions. There are so many things that effect our opinions. Our beliefs, life styles, way of thinking, culture, and the list goes on. I'm sure I could think of certain books, movies, music, and magazines that I don't like and could just do without. Does that mean I want to totally rid the world of those certain materials? It sure wouldn't bother me, but that would be extremely selfish. Even if something is totally inappropriate and offensive, it is still information. Maybe it shouldn't go in the little kids section of a library or store, but I don't think it should be removed completely. Music especially. There are wide ranges of music from rap, rock, oldies, screamo, classical, country, alternative and the list goes on. I despise country; I go for the alternative and classical music. I know a lot of people who love it though. All the old people I know hate all the rap. Most of it is pretty offensive, but that's just how things are. So no, I don't think anyone should have the right to remove anything from anywhere just because they personally find it offensive. We can't hide from the world. I think people should be open to new things and understand that not everyone likes the same things. If we remove the materials we don't care for, others will remove the ones you like and so on. So then we're left with nothing. Just like freedom of speech, we should have the freedom to read, listen to, and watch what we enjoy without fear of it being taken away.

I believe that censorship should be allowed when it comes to certain things, but I don't believe censorship belongs in public libraries. Books are written to stimulate the imagination of a person's mind, and if they cannot read books that are the slightest offensive, then they will never know what it is like to open some of the greatest books ever written until that person has grown up. And there are several studies that show that books stimulate the human mind, and taking away these books would be a crushing blow to those statistics. For example, a student has been assigned a report on a piece of classical literature. So he/she goes to the public library to find a good book, but when that student gets there he/she finds out that all pieces of classical literature have been removed from the library due to being overly offensive. What would that person do? Should he/she just give up because every single piece of classical literature has been taken out of every library in the country? I say no! This is a problem because almost every great book ever written has at least a few parts where it is slightly offensive to that certain reader. From personal experience I can back this statement up with books I have read going through my school career. For example, when I was in the tenth grade I was assigned a book report over Huckleberry Finn, so I went to our library in the school to look for this book and it was nowhere to be found. I asked the librarian where this book was and she said that it had been removed due to being offensive to the black population for having the word negro imprinted on its pages. So I asked her if I could go to the public library to get the book and she said that it had been removed from its shelves as well. I did not know what to do, I was completely clueless and I had no book to write my report over. So eventually the teacher had to change the report topic because not one student was able to find Huckleberry Finn. But if the state had not allowed these books to be taken off of the shelves then we would not have had this problem. Another example was when my friend Ahmed wanted to learn about his culture and where his ancestors came from. But when he got to the library he could not find any books over the Arabic world. So he asked the librarian 'where are all the books covering Egypt, Syria, and Saudi Arabia?' And the librarian said that they were all removed because after 9/11 some people saw Arabs as very offensive people and that no books were left unchecked. I'm sure that he found this comment to be very offensive but there was nothing that he could do about it because the white people found Arabs to be offensive and unequal to the white race. These are only a few things that have already happened because of people finding certain books to be offensive, which is why I believe that the government should leave all the books on the shelves and let the people decide to pick up that book or pass it by. Sure people have a freedom of speech, but it should not effect what books belong on the shelf. Which is why I believe that censorship should not be allowed to effect public libraries.

Books that are found offensive should not be taken off of library shelves. Books tell stories fiction or non-fiction. Many books that might be found offensive are historical. These books could include topics such as wars, eras, people, etc. Everyone has the same rights to read any book they want. They also have the right to not read the book at all. Books that are taken off the shelves of a library because of one person, or a group of people, being offended hinders the ability of someone who wants to read the book, to read the book. We, as people, should not be able to take this right away from other people. They should be able to read anything they want. If someone wants to read a biography or history about Adolf Hitler, they should be able to. The topic of Hitler and the Nazi Party might be found to be offensive because of what they stand for. If we look at the topic as purely a historical reference not as a story to be read for enjoyment there will never be any offence in these books. These stories have a large role in history. If we do not learn from their mistakes, history might repeat itself. History is around to be studied, even if the topics might be offensive to some people. Political correctness can not always be followed when writing a story. Such as in To Kill a Mockingbird. This book has many issues when it comes to political correctness. These issues include; the killing of an innocent man and revealing the flaws in our judicial system, the use of the word 'nigger' to describe the black characters, and the racial inequality of the South during the 1930's. These issues would definitely be offensive to some readers, but this book is an award winner and uses history as a guide. The situations in this novel are ones that could be real. They are things we must learn about, so we do not repeat them. Another story that fits quite well into this topic is Fahrenheit 451. This novel is about a world where all books are burnt. No books are allowed to be read by the people. This book reveals the removal of offensive books to its extreme. No matter who you are or what you believe, there will be some topics that you find offensive. If we remove every book that someone finds offensive we will have no books on the shelves of any library. A library is not a library without its books. If we allow books to begin to be removed from the shelves, we will not be able to stop it. One day we will end up like the world in Fahrenheit 451. No history will be known but what is passed down. No more stories will be here to entertain us, but the ones memorized. No books will exist and this world would be terrible without books. Books that are found to be offensive should not be taken off of library shelves. The taking away of these books takes away the freedom to read anything you want. It reduces the chances we have to learn and to flourish. Political correctness should not take the place of our own freedom, and as long as we keep our books on their shelves, it won't.

Sexual activity should not be exposed to children until it is time for them to start learning about it. For example, a young girl reading about teen pregnancy not being a problem. The reader will think that is what she is supposed to do which is wrong. Books and magazines containing sexually explicit words should not be able to be viewed by young children. Those things can influence kids to do things they should not even be thinking about doing. You can at least sort them all in an adult section. Finally, drug use should not be issued in books to kids. Children should not read or watch anything that is talking about drugs in a positive way. Unless it is about saying no to drugs and not using them, children should not read them at all. Dear newspaper and staff, It has come to my attention that it is being considered that most libraries in the community might have a removal or censorship of some books in the library. I find this not acceptable; in my opinion this is an attempt to mislead or perhaps hide previous evidence of offensive reading material from further generations. For example, a personal favorite of mine is a book labeled 'A Child's Struggle', this book describes a child's hardships and the abuse he takes on a daily basis. Books of this sort are not only informative, they also give the reader an open mind on how things might have been. Some topics might include; slavery, abuse, war, and discrimination. These topics today are still among the things that happen in today's society. Censoring and removal of these books are pointless; for the simple reason that at least three of the four are a current issue. It is strictly important for our generations to be aware of the hardships, problems, and lessons in which these topics arose. Without informing our generations of these issues it could result in a repeat of history, which we as a country are trying to prevent! My opinion on movies however is a little different. I believe some movies are okay; but they must not contain obvious and purposeful acts of discrimination or offensive material. Most movies nowadays if they are offensive in a relating way to the movie then they are rated at least PG-13 or rated R; this allows certain age groups able to watch material that might be offensive or perhaps discriminating. They might also need adult accompaniment to preview the movie. So in my closing I would like for you to consider my opinion as a wise outlook on offensive or discriminating issues. I just fully believe open library content is allowed at certain ages, depending on the content. Plenty of observations must be made by parents or guardians if needed. I appreciate your time and understanding of my letter! Thanks! Sincerely, A Concerned Reader.

Everyone today gets offended daily. So to go to a library and see offensive material on the shelves is no different than the rest of the day. However, there are those minds, which have not been polluted and influenced by these offensive materials, that should have a right to keep their minds that way. One solution to the problem could be that we start rating books and magazines like we do for movies. The material rated for adults gets put in one area of the library while the lower rated material is put on display for the public. The higher rated can be put in an area that is not seen everyday by the public, and is kept secret thus protecting the uninfluenced minds and the people wanting said material can still have their way. Another solution might be to just get rid of the censored material. It, in my opinion and experience, corrupts both the mind and soul, and causes man to be things he is not by nature. Men, who have nothing better to do than to sit and read or look at things meant for inside of marriage, often accomplish nothing of great value in their life time. They are thus a hindrance to society. But if they cannot access the material, they then need something to do to fill that time. In which case they can find a good classic to read or maybe pick up that dusty Bible off the shelf. This thus leaves the libraries with a choice. They can leave their library the way that they want, they can put the offensive material in a secluded room, or they can remove definite offensive material and keep society on its feet accomplishing great feats for the next generation to observe. Thus the amount of offending someone goes down and maybe the library attendance goes up as a result of a more curated environment.

Have you ever found or seen books, music, movies, or magazines in a library that are offensive to you? If so, then would you have wanted to remove it off of the shelf so none of your children or anyone else that might have found it offensive, to see it? Well, I have actually gone to the library and seen some things that was offensive to me, and I have also heard my family members talking about it. So I am going to talk about what I have heard about my family seeing or finding books, music, movies, and magazines offensive. Also, I am going to explain how I felt and what I wanted to do when I seen those things in a library that was offensive to me. The last thing that I am going to talk about is how I feel on censorship in libraries. First, I have been hearing from my sisters, my mother, and my step-mother about how they find some books, music, movies, and magazines at a library that was offensive to them. Now I do not know exactly what the books, magazines, etc., was that they found offensive but I do know what they thought about them and what they wanted to do. So one day, my sisters, mother, and step-mother was talking about a couple of books that she found offensive. They never said what the books were but they kept talking about how they felt and what they would have liked to do with them. Now she told my family and I that she was badly offended by what they were called and what they were about. Also she was saying that she would have really liked to have taken the books, music, movies, etc., off of the shelves, so other people that might have found them offensive would not see them. But, they all did also agree on the fact that they really do not have the right to remove them from the shelves. Their reason why they do not have that right is because there are a lot of people who they do not know if they find it offensive or not. The people who do not find it offensive might actually want to read them. So, they just agreed to look past them and ignore what is there if it offends them for the people who do not find them offensive. Now, from my point of view from finding or seeing books, music, movies, magazines, etc., in a library that are or was offensive to me. There have been a couple of times where I have walked in a library where I found a couple of books that was offensive towards me. I really did not like what the books were all about and called, and I really would have liked to take them off the shelves and throw them away so no other person who might have found them offensive would find them or see them. So what if there are other people who would have actually wanted to read those books? That was what I thought about when I was tempted to actually remove them. So I decided not to remove the books from the shelves, so the people who did not find them offensive could read them, if they wanted to. I respected the fact that there are other people that are out there that would want to read those books but at the same time, I knew that there are people who could find them offensive but I just thought that they would just ignore the fact that they are there. So, on to the last thing that I am going to talk about. Do I believe that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from the shelves, at a library, if they are found offensive? Also my views on censorship in libraries. Well I do believe that they should be removed so they would not be offending anyone that walked into that library. But, if people had the right to remove books or anything that is offensive towards them, then there would literally be no books left in the libraries. Then there would not be any point in having libraries or in anyone writing books. So then again, I do not believe that any person should have a right to just remove the books that are offensive to them at all. I believe that if they find a book that is offensive to them, then they should just ignore that it is there and respect that there are a lot of people out there who would want to or like to read those books. So I do not believe that there should be any censorship in libraries at all. It is not anyone's fault that people find books, music, movies, magazines, etc., offensive to them. So no, there should absolutely not be any censorship in a library. So there, I have just explained my views on censorship in libraries and if I believe that people should have the right to remove books from a shelf just cause they found it offensive. Like I have stated before, there should not be any censorship in libraries at all. But yes, I do understand that people find things that are offensive, but they should just ignore that they are there and respect that there are people who want to or would like to read those books. Once again, do you believe that people should have the right to remove a book from a shelf just cause they found it offensive, and what are your views on censorship in libraries? I know my own position is firmly against it.

Should certain books, movies, magazines, music, etc., be removed from shelves if they are found to be offensive? Books, movies, magazines, music are made to relay a message, express a point of view, or to perhaps state an opinion, of which everyone has a different point of view. No, books, movies, magazines, music, etc., should not be simply taken off of the shelves or out of stores. All of the previously listed things are rated. Movies are rated G through R, books are rated child through adult, and music if explicit has a parental advisory sticker, so just follow the ratings. If a four-year old tried to buy two tickets to see a rated R movie the theater would not sell him the tickets because he is not yet of age. People might bring the point of maybe a child picks up an adult book or magazine in a store and begins to look at it and read it. The solution to that problem is simple: create a separate room in stores that sell these items and label the room adult section. Have cameras near by so if a youngster feels brave enough to tempt fate they will be caught or just put a desk out front of the adult section and require an I.D. for entrance. These are still books which are expressions of a person's dreams, hope, desires, fantasies, and heart, they should not be denied their dream because a person deems it unfit. And most apparent if it offends you don't read it. Simply follow the rating rules. Take necessary precautions. If all of these rules are followed then businesses and libraries should have no problems keeping everybody safe and happy with the available materials.

If I could remove anything from the shelves of libraries, I wouldn't. Would you rather your kids learn things from factual sources or learn from friends and hearsay? Censoring books, magazines, movies, and other materials that go onto the shelves, which are mostly for enjoyment or informational purposes, is a problematic practice. Granted, you wouldn't want a five-year-old reading a book made for adults, but with age, kids would have to learn about complex topics. You can't always control what children read unless you plan on going with them everywhere, including college and on into their adult life. Books provide facts and more reliable information than what you can hear from people on the street. If all the books on the shelves relating to drugs or alcohol were pulled off, how would someone write a factual report on those things? The books were created to provide people, kids especially, with facts that no one else could share, and it could help with expanding their vocabulary and general knowledge. If someone were to find a book or a magazine offensive, they don't have to look at it or even pick it up; they can simply choose another. Libraries can't always suit everyone's tastes, and something you might find offensive isn't necessarily offensive to others. Taking a single book from the shelves would set a precedent, resulting in others taking books off the shelves, and then no books would be left for anyone to read or wish to take off the shelves. If you controlled what everyone read, no one would be happy and their brain wouldn't function correctly from a lack of diverse thought. You'd be taking away one of their fundamental rights, one of the only things entitled to them without someone else telling them they can't. What kids read is crucial for shaping their minds for their future. If you removed their favorite series or genre from the shelves, they might not read or listen to music or anything anymore because it isn't enjoyable to them. Kids get into reading when they can enjoy what they read or listen to. So with that, I wouldn't take anything off the shelves because everything appeals to someone in one way or another. Controlling what one person reads doesn't lead you nor the other person anywhere productive, someone could end up being offended if you take something you find offensive off the shelves, and you can't stop the knowledge that books can provide people if they read them. In one way or another, every book provides valuable information for people.

They would rather just sit down, crack open a magazine, and let their eyes glaze over at the sights of celebrities and new scandals. If they wanted to have free time to go and read magazines, they should do that at home. Offensive books should not be there to only distract the teenager from school. It's unnecessary. But with public libraries, it's a whole new story. I believe that nothing should be censored from a public library because people go there on their own free will. I know I personally go there for research and for the sheer joy of reading, as do many other people. It's your choice if you are responsible enough to keep focused on work or get distracted because not only do teenagers go there, but adults do too. It is unacceptable for there to be only educational books because who knows what you're there for? The library is for people to go and read, whether it's just for the heck of it or for school. Not everyone is responsible. Especially not all teenagers. So that's why I personally believe offensive or inappropriate materials should not be allowed in school libraries, but allowed in public libraries. Although equal rights and freedom is necessary, schoolwork is too important to let kids get distracted from it. It is the key to their future.

All people have the same right to read, listen, and watch different materials. To be censored should be no one's choice but your own. For someone else to tell you what and what not to read is, by my opinion, very wrong to do. If we would censor everything we did, we would have a city and a nation that would progress very slowly. Any given word can offend any certain person. The people that they offend are, in my opinion, the dead weights of our country that are just holding us back from fully expressing ourselves; the colorful words that we sometimes use can be offensive to one person yet perfectly fine to another. It all depends on the individual that likes or dislikes the word or readings. In my observations of people reading and disliking it because of its harsh and colorful words, it is most often people that do not fully express themselves and are yet much more sensitive. I think this also goes against freedom of speech. We were given that right, so why wouldn't we use it? Why wouldn't people want us to express ourselves? I have no idea why any person would want to take books, music, movies, and magazines away from us. If everything went by one man's rule of what to and not to read, we would downgrade as a country and stagnate. Therefore, I strongly advise not to take any books off the shelves. The majority of the people agree with me to not be censored, and only the sensitive people that are offended will just make their own choice not to pick the book off the shelf, not to listen to the music, and not to pick up the magazine. The right is ours, and that's how it should stay.

Censorship. It's a word that everyone has heard, but do people truly know what it means or how it affects them? In the past, books have been censured by rulers and leaders who thought that the material was harmful. How could they say that they knew what was best for their people? What gave them the right to decide what their people could or could not read? In today's society, we still have to deal with censorship issues. There are still people who believe that libraries need to censor their books. Censorship is wrong. Books, magazines, movies, music, etc. should not be removed from the shelves just because certain people find them offensive. Everyone has different tastes, not only in food, but in every other part of their lives as well. No one person has the right to say that one genre is better than another. Censorship is wrong because it limits what people can read, watch, and listen to. Censorship should not be allowed because it limits what people can read. Some people like mysteries, while others like to read romantic books. If we allow people to censor what we read, then how can we say that there is a book for everyone to like? If libraries censored every book that might offend someone else, then there would not be any books left for anyone to read. For example, certain religious books might offend people of other religions, but that does not mean that we should take them off the shelves. If we did that, we would have to take away all religious books so that no one was offended. Then no one would be able to find books about their religion, and no one would benefit from that loss. Similarly, censorship limits what people can watch. If we removed every movie that had even one tiny part that offended someone else, there would be no more movies left in the world. Every movie is going to have something that someone will love and someone will hate. If we only focus on the person who hates it and get rid of movies based on the people who hate them, then the people who love the movies will suffer for it. People who love horror movies probably hate comedies. This does not mean that we need to get rid of comedies just because there are some people who dislike them. It only means that the people who don't like that type of movie don't have to watch them; the choice is theirs. In the exact same way, censorship keeps people from enjoying the type of music that they love. We can't censor music because everyone has different types and genres that they like. If we take away one kind of music, then we have to take away every kind of music. It is not fair to say that we can censor one genre of music because some people dislike it or find it offensive when there are people who truly enjoy listening to that type of music. It would be unfair to those people, and if we are unfair to them, we have to be unfair to everybody, which is an impossible standard. People would be even more offended than before in that case. There will always be unhappy people in the world. We should not resort to censoring books, movies, and music in libraries and other places just to try to make a few people happy. Censorship in libraries limits what people can enjoy. It makes the people who would like the items that have been censored mad. We should not resort to that. We should allow people to pick what they like. If a person wants to read something, they should be allowed. If they want to watch a certain movie or listen to a certain song, then why not let them? The slim margin of people who dislike what those people enjoy can just avoid reading, watching, or listening to it themselves. We can't take something away from the people who love it just because someone else is unhappy with its content.

I believe that some materials are offensive to some people, but that shouldn't give them a right to want to take it off the shelves. No, I do not agree with taking them off the shelves because people could easily overlook them and not read them, choosing instead materials that align with their personal values. Some people think they are offensive but they should know that they are not directed towards them personally. Magazines are different because they have peoples faces on the front cover which is uncalled for in some contexts. Some of those people have a family, and doesn't want them to see their face on the front cover of a magazine, creating a personal and public conflict. Katherine Paterson's quote is about wanting to remove books from the shelves so that children won't be tempted to read them. If this is the case I think that its not the right thing to do. Some of those books people are taking off the shelves could be the book someone can use to relate to or even learn from, providing crucial understanding. Weather or not you want your children to read them or not they could still find them and ask why they have never seen it before and parents wouldn't know what to say, leading to confusion rather than protection. Libraries are a resource to people that want to read and learn about new things. If you took a book off of a shelf, that could be the book someone really needs for research or personal growth. Don't be that person to take away from a child's learning. You never know who is going to look for what your have taken away. And if you take it away they may never find it, losing that opportunity forever. Some people believe that reading something can be an influence to the way they act, but you cannot blame that on reading alone. That's like saying that your favorite color is lime green because that's your friend's favorite color. Its not true and it sure isn't right. What would you do if your parents hid a book or something else from you? You would be mad at them and wonder why, creating curiosity. It would make you anxious to read it. If they didn't hide it and you found it maybe you wouldn't want to read it because your parents would have let you see it and you wouldn't be interested, demonstrating that openness often reduces intrigue. You have your own choice when it comes to what your children read, watch, and listen to. Just don't shut them out of what you read because you were offended. Think about it, the music, movie, or book your hiding from them could be the answer to a lot of things they are questioning. It could help them figure out the path they want to take, or maybe the path they don't want to take. Either way it would help them be a success in their life by making informed choices. So why not take the risk? It could even help you understand their perspective better.

Censorship in the world we live in today is a very interesting concept. With the advent of social media, we now have thriving communities of people that want their voice to be heard, and people are listening more than ever before. We now are able to tap into the huge amount of knowledge from people all around the world, allowing us to see what is really happening in countries where media is considered treason. What do we do now that governments are starting to censor the internet? Lets start by looking an argument that has been long talked about: library censorship. Today, it is almost a requirement for cities to have public libraries to be considered as real cities, serving as community hubs. Public libraries, and the funding they require, are not anywhere within the direct purview of federal mandates. Even so, they have taken a place in our neighborhoods that has made them indefinite sources of knowledge and culture. One public library can be a source of; historical town records, children's books, novels, research papers, non-fiction books, fiction books, magazines, and many other types of entertainment and knowledge. Public libraries are, even with the widespread usage of the internet, important places for us, as residents of a city, to socialize and learn from shared resources. Libraries today often carry books that were in the past on the 'banned books' list, but that does not mean books are not being banned from libraries currently. Libraries are generally family institutions, and as being funded by the public, required to adhere by the moral and ethical standards of those who live in the area. This means that there is not one, 'national banned books list', but there many discrepancies throughout different regions in banning books. As culture moves more and more into more and more questionable materials, libraries are faced with a tough decision; keep up with the times and have more questionable and controversial reading material, or get lost in the past and try to cling onto the senior generation to stay alive and relevant. Bringing new literary materials into the library that is fresh and new means that more people will return to the library again, be it young-adults or older adults trying to get in touch with the current world. One major controversy of books in public libraries are the inclusion of sexual intimacy. As a new generation sprouts, fed with music lyrics by such names as popular artists, we enter a new age where younger and younger kids are learning about sex. The authors of today have recognised this and have started to include references to sexual intimacy, but not detailed encounters. I believe this is fine, because as we move on in generations we are going to find out that education about sex; safe sex, birth control, disease prevention and testing, is much more important than trying to keep children ignorant. Keeping these young adults involved in books and trying to continue their learning outside of school is a much larger issue we should be trying to tackle instead of trying to create silly arguments against new reading material in a public library. Public libraries are the centerpiece for learning outside of school in many communities, small and large. Knowing this, how could anyone truly believe that it would be smart to stop including new books that would entice new patrons? Even as a commercial business, this would make no sense, simply turning people away because you have a single view of what the future is and you refuse to listen to anyone else's opinion of the future. So why is there a question on including new knowledge? Isn't it obvious that we, as a nation, should show the world that we aren't living in the past. That we are indeed the future of the world, and that our young-adults will receive the best education in the world by not only learning in schools, but by being the most active readers, and by extension, learners in the world, prepared for a diverse global society.

Do you believe that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, should be removed off of the shelves if they are offensive? Libraries are a place that provides people of all ages the opportunity to read any book, watch any movie, or listen to any music all for free and for a certain period of time. When people grow up, they tend to start reading, watching, and listening to material that they would never let their children listen to, as their maturity allows for different content. Since books are read privately and movies and music are played publicly, books should not be taken from the shelves and only very bad movies and music should leave the library, maintaining a balance. Books have always been a way for people to get away from their life and into their own story world, providing a private escape. Normally when people read a book, they don't read it in a group unless they are in a reading group discussing certain books, so the exposure is limited. If someone wanted to read a book that was inappropriate for their children, let them do it; it's not hurting the children that they have been reading inappropriate topics, it will only hurt them if that child finds the book that should have been hidden in a better place, out of easy reach. For example, a parent read the book which had some inappropriate content for a child in there, but not so bad that it would be heinous. That parent will read the book in her own mind while finding it in the adult section of the library far from children; this scenario is how it should be, with clear sections. Although, if a library is putting adult books near children's books, they need to redesign to keep kids from accidentally walking into the adult section, ensuring a safe space. Books can be kept from kids if hidden well enough, but movies and music can not be hidden in the same manner due to their audible and visual nature. The movies and music were from the library, a place where the child thinks that there would never be something such disgraceful material as what their parents are watching and listening to, ruining their good thoughts of the library as a safe haven. Libraries need to either get rid of all nasty content pertaining to movies and music or if their main business is that and can't seem to give it up, just put the content as far away as possible from the children's areas. As said above, libraries need to remove all content that has potential to be exposed to children and destroy their innocent minds, prioritizing their well-being. Libraries are a place where kids can have fun picking out whatever book they wish to read, not a place where parents can pick up items that might spoil that child's brain and sense of security.
