So next time you are working at the library or just there visiting you might wanna watch where you put stuff at cause little kids will see it and it is our responsibility to protect them from material they are not yet ready for.

Eventually, everyone sees or hears offensive things. However, the government has taken it upon themselves to try and keep youth from seeing it. They believe the parents should tell their children about everything while they try to make it one big secret for kids. But, if kids are introduced early, we would not have to keep it a secret anymore. Libraries and all types of media should not be censored.  Kids always ask questions like 'where do babies come from?' and adults, wanting to avoid an awkward conversation, make up stories or do not tell them the whole truth. Imagine a world where the government let the media say whatever they want. Yes, at first it would be vulgar but the government would then have the right to teach about sex and drugs in school. More kids would be educated, so less of them would be curious enough to do any of that stuff.  That is not to say that newscasters should curse everytime they are on television. It is merely suggesting that instead of having a metaphorical black curtain over half the news, they report the whole truth. They have freedom of speech, and we have a right to know what is happening in the world around us.  At first, people would think it was a terrible world. But, eventually, with right leadership, it would help make a more truthful environment. Kids would learn about sex and drugs in school, and have a safe environment to answer their questions if they have any. Drug use and rape would go down. Then, talking about 'offensive' topics would be non-existent so kids would not be embarrassed if they had questions. This would change the world for the better by fostering a more open and honest society.

The library is known to be a place full of dreams and imagination. For some, the library is a sanctuary where you can escape reality and dive into a book where anything is possible. The library is full of many books for all ages. Therefore, books that are classified for one age group, may not be appropriate for another age group. This is where a problem occurs. If the library chooses to keep books in it that are only appropriate for certain ages groups, various problems can occur. The three main issues with this situation are young children can access magazines they have no business looking at, some articles or books can be found offensive to some races creating an uproar, and also events and instances played out in books may not be appropriate for all age groups. We have to think about books we have read, and contemplate if we would want others to read it as well.  Young children are often daily visitors of the library. Most run around the library getting into any and all books or magazines they happen to come across. This is not always good. In the library there are many magazines that are meant for adult eyes only. My family has had an experience with this sort of situation before. My mother, brother, and myself visited the library one evening. While my mother and I searched the library chaotically, my younger brother found himself searching the magazine rack for something to keep his mind occupied. Well his mission was accomplished. On his search my younger brother had found himself a sports illustrated magazine. Inside there were pictures revealed that my mother was not too happy about my brother seeing. Instances like this happen everyday in the local library. Staff members should think to put revealing works up to where the younger generation can not find them, perhaps in a separate, restricted section.  Throughout the library, there are many books dealing with past historic events. Although many find these books helpful and interesting, some find these books to be quite offensive. Some races have undergone painful events in history. Many of those people do not want to relive the painful past experiences. It is in my opinion that the library should oblige by the people, and take in reference how different people feel about certain books. When I was a young girl in elementary school, I remember doing a whole unit on slavery and the underground railroad. While studying the unit, we were assigned a research assignment over the lesson. I choose to visit the library in search for books I could use to gather more information. While searching the library, I came across a book that my mother and I felt should not have been where younger people could see. The book enclosed many horrible acts against black people. This is a book that at my age, I should have never came across.  For me reading books helps me escape the real world and catch a break. When I relax and enjoy a good book, I can't help but feel like nothing in the world can touch me. Although I love reading books, I don't like when I begin reading a book then have to halt because the book reveals events that I shouldn't be reading. One book I read, was definitely not appropriate for me. Although I found the book in the young adult section, the book I read revealed a young girl encountering many rapes and beatings. Now that I look back, that is a book that I might enjoy now, several years later, but I don't feel I should have encountered that book then.  What books should and shouldn't be encountered in the library is surely a never ending feud. Many believe that books should be taken out if they are not appropriate for all audiences. I think that if the inappropriate books that should not be viewed by all ages, were put away to where the younger audience couldn't get them, then the never ending feud might be able to be put to rest through thoughtful organization and access control.

Do I believe that certain materials should be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive? No, I do not believe they should be, but that is my opinion.  It is pointless to remove them from the shelves because the children are going to see that kind of material outside of school, so why should we remove it? Music, movies, magazines, and books all have material such as; racism, murders, inappropriate language, etc. When we find materials, like those listed before offensive outside of school, we stay away from them. We ignore it and watch or read something that we do not find offensive. The same principle should apply within the library setting.  Movies and books about historical tragedies are sometimes found offensive to some people and if we remove them from our libraries then we can not have references for when we write essays over those topics. It would be hard to get the right kind of information off the internet because not everything is correct on there. One hundred percent of factual books is correct. You will have no worries then about the authenticity of the information you are studying.  Therefore, I do not believe that certain materials that are found offensive to some people should be removed. It is a pointless task to do. Children see it outside of school and stay away from it then so they can stay away from it in school also, learning to make their own responsible choices about what they consume.

Censorship in Libraries I think that things found in the library that people find offensive shouldn't be removed. Just because some people think it's offensive doesn't mean all people think it's offensive. Some people may like the content it shows, finding it educational or thought-provoking. I think that things in a library shouldn't be removed because everyone has their own point of view. If something was removed every time someone would walk in and object, then there would be no library left. A library is supposed to be a variety of books, a collection of diverse ideas. It is not supposed to be just one genre that only one person likes, but a resource for the entire community. It is important to offer a lot of variety because if a library doesn't have a lot of variety, then the library would lose all kinds of customers. A library doesn't want to target just kids or teens or adults. The library wants to target all aspects of people, serving everyone's interests and needs. Even if it means that some content is inappropriate for some, it may be valuable for others. All books are inappropriate if you look at them in the wrong way, so context and personal choice are key. I think that things found in the library that people find offensive shouldn't be removed. Everyone has their own point of view, and a single perspective should not dictate access for all. A library should have a variety of books, not just one genre a person wants, to truly fulfill its role as a beacon of knowledge and exploration for everyone.

Have you ever been in a library and thought to yourself, 'hey, this book looks pretty good.' But once you read it, you deemed it as inappropriate for younger people? I have, but unlike some people, I don't blame it on the libraries. I blame myself for picking it up in the first place. Some people do not want to take the responsibility for their actions, and so they blame it on the library for carrying a certain author's books, a band's songs, or a magazine's articles. This brings me to say that books, music, magazines, newspapers, etc. should not be taken off of the shelves of libraries. Just because some people do not like the content that they hold, doesn't mean that it can't be helpful or entertaining to others. I think it should be a matter of personal choice, like choosing which outfit you want to wear in the morning. There are too many options, like when it comes to the books, movies, music, and magazines available. If something strikes you as inappropriate, then simply take it back and exchange it for something better; that is your right as a patron. One experience I can think of that is a good example of this is when I was ten years old. My mother took me into the library and I found a book, 'A Story About Loss.' I showed it to her just like any other time we had gone to the library. Only this time, she did not want me to check it out. She saw it as too harsh of a book for me to read at the time, she wanted me to wait until I was older. It was about grief and she saw it as a very inappropriate book for my age, at the time. But she didn't blame it on the libraries, asking why they would carry such books where children could reach them. Other mothers and fathers are the same way, as I found out. My best friend's parents had been the same way with her. Only instead of a book, it was a music cd that she had wanted to listen to. They thought that she should not listen to it because the lyrics in the songs were too 'sad' for her to hear. They agreed that if she were just a little older then she could have borrowed it. They did not blame the library for having it. If someone else wanted to listen to it, or have their children listen to it, then it was their own personal choice. I do not believe that libraries should have censorships. They can have different sections, such as adult, children, and young adult, to help guide patrons. But I believe that they should not have to take books, music, magazines, etc. off the shelves just because of certain people's complaints. It should be a person's personal choice what they consume. If they do not like the item that they picked up, they should take responsibility for their actions, and not blame others for their own mistakes.

I think books, movies, music, and magazines that are offensive should not be pulled from the shelves. If you find something offensive then don't pick it up; its that simple. You may find something offensive but it might not be to someone else, as tastes and sensitivities vary widely. It is all according to your own personal opinion and background. Sure, there are some things that are very offensive to certain people, and those people will try to put a stop to it. But I think that is wrong. Because it may be offensive to you but what if there is someone studying that topic but can't find the information on it because you thought it was offensive and got it pulled off of the shelf? Then it disrupts that persons study and limits their access to information. I am not promoting violent books and movies or other offensive material; all I'm saying is if you find something offensive then turn the other cheek. It might be offensive to you but other people may not think the same way, and they have a right to access that material. There are many books and movies out there that are offensive to many people for various reasons. And if we were to take all of those movies and books off of the shelf then there would be very few subjects and titles left to read and watch, leaving the library barren. In my conclusion, I support the fact that offensive material should stay on the shelves. It could be helpful to many people for research or personal interest, and at the same time it can be offensive to a lot of people. But if you are one of those people that find something offensive then don't pay any attention to it and find another subject or topic that suits you better. For someone to take another persons right to read a book or watch a movie is wrong; everyone has their own opinions and rights to choose what they wish to engage with.

There are some books that should not be removed from libraries due to censorship. From past experience with censorship I found out it can tone down a book, stripping it of its original message and impact. In the book Fahrenheit 451 for example the books are being burnt and it is causing society to fall apart, which serves as a powerful warning. Censorship is often pushed by people with a particular ethnic background that don't want kids to grow up and see inappropriate language, but this ignores the context of the literature. The most recent book that I have heard of getting censored is The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn. The main word they are removing from this book is nigger because some people find this word very offensive to their race. The communities are trying to remove the books from school shelves to protect students. I think we should not have censorship just because parents do not want their kids to hear the words in school or read them, when eventually the kids will learn the words on their own or hear them somewhere else. The kids can even learn the word from their own parent or from television, so removing it from one source is ineffective. I personally think that communities should stop trying to censor everything because they won't be able to censor how adults talk when they are around children and younger adults, making the effort ultimately futile.

Katherine Paterson, a well-known author, presents an idea with which I strongly agree. She states, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf--that work I abhor--then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' If everyone has the right to remove certain books that they find inappropriate, there would not be anything left for people to read, defeating the library's purpose. Although it is a good thing for parents to have a voice and stand up for what they believe, books should not be banned outright. Many people have different views on what is right and wrong, and a library must reflect this diversity. Some may suggest that a certain book is obscene, while others may be offended by a different book entirely. If every parent had the right to get a book banned, there might come a time when no books meet the approval of every parent, leaving shelves empty. Some of these books present great learning opportunities to students, exposing them to different cultures and historical contexts. Books often allow students to think in different, new ways, challenging their preconceptions. They can learn from a new point of view, fostering empathy and critical thinking. Often times, a student can look at his or her own morals and values through the lens of a story, which is a good thing for personal development. If a teacher finds a book which they think is appropriate for a lesson, parents should respect the professional decision of this teacher. They might suggest another reading, or offer other ideas for their own child, but to go as far as getting the book completely removed for all students is not right. While removing books for reading may be going too far, things such as movies could go the other direction in terms of display. Personally, my parents would be horrified to see grotesque, inappropriate movies set out in broad daylight where everyone can look at them. I think that this difference between books and movies is a simple thing: Books do not normally have an inappropriate cover, while bad movies often do have graphic imagery on their cases. Because of this, even the people who do not wish to view the movie are often forced to see images which they find disturbing as they walk by. If one was to walk past a book they did not intend to read, they do not have to be appalled at the cover as they pass, as it is often less visually intrusive. Although parents care deeply about the things their children read, books should not be banned from libraries. Although other things may have affects on youth, books are a different story altogether. They allow one's self to dive deep into thought, to make observations, and to form independent opinions. They are a key to growing, learning, and discovering the world in a safe and personal way.

First off, I do like censorship laws to an extent, as they can offer a basic level of protection. However, the government cannot ban everything that they deem inappropriate. I think it depends more on what the family deems inappropriate, as they are best positioned to guide their own children. I do not think they should have any completely inaccessible areas in libraries for children of younger ages. I believe that the viewer should have a family member's consent to view said content, ensuring a guardian is aware. I also believe that if the content is not relative to the viewers interests, then they should just not look at it. They are not required to look at it so if they do not like it, then they do not look at it; the choice is ultimately theirs. However, if the library does not consent to holding the books, music, movies, magazines, etc., then they do not have to and the viewer can go somewhere else to find it. And if they do have the books, music, etc., then they can put limits and ratings on them as a reasonable precaution. But I do not think that an adult could go in and complain about inappropriate material, as they have the autonomy to avoid it. As I said before, if they do not like it, then they are not required to look at it. I actually think that the government should not tolerate parents whining and complaining about the content of different materials on behalf of everyone. One parent should not have the ability to take away others' privileges to books, because they deem it inappropriate for their own family. Just because they do not like the content, does not exclude all others from enjoying it and forming their own opinions. Also, if a library does have an age restriction on certain materials, then appropriate acts of discipline should be taken for the viewer of said materials if they violate the rules. However, if the viewer has an adult family member with them and has their consent, then I think they should be able to view the material, regardless of ratings, as the family's judgment should be respected in such matters.

There are so many books and magazines, music, and movies to be discovered in this world. Some are funny, sad, weird, scary, etc. And then there are some that are questionable to others on whether it was even necessary to even put the material on the shelf of a library in the first place. I for one am not one of those people who would question a book, magazine, movie or music. I believe that everyone's voice needs to be heard somehow and if we all take a voice away that we do not like, then we will lose a lot of voices and perspectives that enrich our society. We are all entitled to our own opinion. When it comes to some things some are more opinionated than other, but in the end we all have something that we feel strongly about. There are some people who want to express their feelings with the whole world with people that understand and agree with what they feel. If we take that away from people, then how will we all connect and share our common humanity? Some things may come across as offensive to others, but who has the right to say that something should not be shared with the rest of the world. I have observed that when people have the same interests in things like music, books, or movies then it gives people a way to come together and talk about something meaningful. I have witnessed at concerts everybody seems to connect because we are all there for the same reason, to see the band or person that we all like to listen to. Everybody's different and likes to have their own personal preference on something. Like Katherine Paterson once said, 'But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf-that work I abhor-then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' I think she was trying to say that if we all take a book off the shelf that we do not think should be on there, then there is going to be nothing left for anybody to read, which defeats the purpose of a library. Then what will we do? There's such a variety of materials that are needed to be discovered whether it is a book, music, or movie everyone has their own special type that they enjoy. I do not think that censorship is a good idea for any sort of material on a shelf. These materials are what keep people connected with each other and with different ideas. I think it is very important to not censor anything because it does not just give the writer a voice, it gives a voice for the people that agree with the material of the book, movie, or music, fostering a more inclusive and understanding community.

There are many books, movies, and music in the libraries. These things can come in so many varieties. Have you ever been to a library and not found something you liked? Well most people find a lot of things that interest them in many ways. Many people come to a library a day to check out something they will enjoy and have a good time listening, reading, or watching. So many people are different and each person likes something different from one another. So the question is, 'Should we remove some books, music, and movies off the shelves because they're offensive?' From experience, yes there are things at a library that children or younger teenagers should not read, hear, or see. Though that most libraries split a lot of their sections up by ages to help with this. Depending on your age you should go to the sections that mostly provides the thing you want. Do not go to a place that provides something that is not your age group, instead go to the place that looks like you belong. I personally have seen younger teens or children get a book or magazine that was not their age group, but perhaps that children wanted to look up on that thing out of natural curiosity. You have to understand that most younger teens and children are curious about many things before they even get to that age, and a library is a place for exploration. As a parent or legal guardian, most children look up to you. Perhaps you read, listen, or watch something that is not to their age level, but the child wants to be just like you. Children look up to their parents or legal guardian. They want to often do the same thing you do, so they copy you. They will find something that is similar to what you are doing. They might go find a book, movie, or cd that is not their age group. They will do this all because simply they want to be just like their parents or guardian. So as a parent or guardian you have to watch what you do also and try to set good examples to your children so they do not find offensive books or etc., guiding them towards suitable choices. There are so many reason why people might think some things are offensive. Even though we are the reason why books and other things are brought into libraries today through our collective demand. Children today are growing up a lot faster then we want them to, but sometimes we can not stop that natural progression. Just set good examples to children or any person not to get a book, movie, or music that is not their age group. Libraries can be a fun and learning environment for everyone, offering a world of discovery. Just sometimes we all do not think a like or like the same stuff, and that is perfectly acceptable. There are just to many people in this world and I have read articles about libraries. I have read why libraries might not be a family place anymore all because of the varieties they carry. Have you ever thought though, 'is it us humans that makes the libraries carry these varieties?' I think so, because we are what makes up a library; our interests shape its collection. We the people are the ones that want these books, movies, magazines, and music. So think about it next time you walk into a library and you see something that you may not think is right. Think about how perhaps someone else really likes that very thing. We all need to accept things if we like it or not at times, embracing the diversity that public spaces provide for the entire community.

Libraries should have whatever they want in the library, as they are institutions dedicated to providing diverse materials. Everyone has their own thoughts on things. If you don't like what they have on their shelves then don't go there any more or pick up something you like instead of focusing on what you dislike. Everyone is different so you can't just take offensive stuff off the shelves, it might be offensive to one person, but not to someone else who finds value in it. Materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines you can't just start taking stuff off the shelves just because they're offensive to you personally. The only way I would say take books or magazines off the shelves is if the facts are not right and the information is proven to be inaccurate. Libraries hold almost anything anybody needs materials, books, music, movies, magazines and everything for facts and research. So don't start taking stuff off your shelves arbitrarily. Teenagers might have to write a paper about something that people think is offensive, if you don't have everything in the library then we won't have good facts and comprehensive sources. No one in this world agrees on anything, all you would be doing would be picking a fight if you taking off offensive materials, creating unnecessary conflict. Libraries are open to any one that wants to read about almost anything they want to read about, which is their fundamental purpose. Music everybody has their own type of music you can't just start taking music off because you think it's offensive to your tastes. Most people have their own type of everything, and a library should reflect that diversity. Children are their own person you can keep them from whatever you want to, the thing is you can't hold them back in life forever. They get older you won't be able to tell them what to do or what not to do as they gain independence. If you keep them from a book or etc they might end up reading it in the long run anyway, so guidance is better than prohibition. Keep your kids safe is important I understand your kids are going to experience things you don't want them to; that is a part of growing up. Just by taking offensive stuff off the shelves doesn't mean your kids won't find them some where else, like online or with friends. I could understand if the books or magazines were offensive to you because it was about your family, a deeply personal matter. But often times you're going to have offensive things come up in your life; it is unavoidable. That means you're going to have to not let it get under your skin or get over it, developing resilience. Things get under people's skin too easy in today's world. This is why the world don't get along, due to an inability to tolerate differing views. If you don't like something don't be around it; it is a simple solution. Find something else to read about that brings you joy and knowledge. That's what I do if I don't like something, and it allows me to enjoy the library's vast offerings.

Libraries provide us with knowledge, entertainment, and peace. You can go there to learn and to do research if you have to write a paper, accessing a wealth of information. You can rent movies, music, and books at your pleasure as long as you take care of them and return them on time. Also, if you're just having a hectic day and need some peace and quiet, libraries become a perfect get away from the noise of the world. But, here's the truth. Many people find certain things in libraries to be offensive and would rather them not be on the shelves. So, do we remove these things or let them stay? My opinion is to let them stay. I believe that books are too important to throw out just because they may contain a few vulgar words or images that some find objectionable. It's the same with magazines and movies, which can still have artistic or educational merit. Also, music is changing as the years go on and many people, especially elders, don't enjoy listening to this new style of music, but that doesn't justify its removal. Just because one person may find something offensive, doesn't mean everyone else will, and a library serves a whole community. People have many different views when it comes to these things. Take history for example. Many history books contain harsh, real life facts about things that went on in the past, which are important to remember. A song, book, or movie about slavery can cause some people to be offended. Whether it's because the person opposes slavery greatly or they believe that slavery was a good thing, people have different feelings towards it, and these materials can spark necessary conversations. Another good example is movies. Some people might find a movie offensive because of words said or if a certain person dies first, while others could care less and enjoy the story for what it is. Additionally, many things that are found offensive to one person can make something more interesting to someone else, adding to its appeal. There are many movies nowdays that can be seen as very offensive by certain groups. But honestly, the offensive things happening in the plot just make someone else want to know more about what's going on, driving engagement. It is practically the same with books, where challenging content can provoke thought. I myself have read plenty of things that would make some people cry or even get really mad or disgusted. Even though in the end, I find them to be exceptionally good books that offered valuable insights. It just depends on how you view it and your personal perspective. So, should things that are found offensive to one person be removed from a library? The answer is no, as this would be a impractical and limiting approach. There are just too many things that can be taken offensively by someone. If you start taking away these things, libraries are only going to become vacant and lose their purpose. Younger people will stop coming because materials will be less interesting and relevant to their lives. You will lose artifacts and stories about the history of the world, erasing important lessons. There will also only be so many books to read, if ever a non-offensive book could even be found, as offense is often subjective. My advice to libraries, keep materials that can be found extremely offensive in their own area, away from younger people who might react strongly without context. Maybe even put a sticker on the book, if possible, letting people know just what

Katherine Paterson once said, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf- that work I abhor- then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' I believe that the books and other items should stay in the shelves of the library and that censorship in libraries is unnecessary. As Katherine Paterson stated, there will be no books left on the shelves if you take every book off that someone in the community finds offensive. What is offensive to one person may not be considered offensive from another person's point of view. Children, teens, and adults have their own right to choose whatever book they want to read, movie they want to watch, or music they want to listen to. If it is a child or a young teen then I believe that the parents should have a say in what their children read or watch. In my case I am not allowed to listen to offensive music or watch rated R movies but that shouldn't mean that it should be taken off the shelves of the library. Just because that is what my family believes to be right does not mean it is the only way to live.  A person has their own rights to choose what they want to read, watch, or listen to. They can make the choice by the way they have been raised or just because that is what they think is right or wrong. If they think that a book is offensive then they don't have to read it; they have the right to say no and put the book back on the shelf. If they think that the book is appropriate then they can read it and there is no law stating that they have to share the book with anyone else. If there is a book out there that is offensive in your view and you read it, there is no reason you have to agree with it. Every person is free to disagree with anything they want to disagree with.  If you are a parent to a child and you are uncomfortable with them reading, listening, or watching something that is offensive, you should set the rules early in life with them. Parents should make sure that their children are not reading inappropriate things or listening to offensive music or watching R-rated or rated R movies. Therefore, if you are comfortable with your children seeing and hearing offensive things then you don't have to worry about what is out there in the community. The things that your children are watching, reading, and listening to isn't a problem and if it becomes a problem in the parents' eyes then they have the right to stop the children from reading the offensive books or watching the bad movies and listening to the music that they view as offensive. Every parent and family is different, and as long as your child knows the rules and what you believe in then there is no need for censorship in libraries.  In my family I am not allowed to listen to offensive music. Offensive music in my house is considered music with curse words in the lyrics. The words that my family considers offensive may be different than what other families consider offensive. I know that I don't want to and can't listen to those certain songs but that does not mean that I can't be friends or be around people that listen to that kind of music. Just because that is what my family believes in does not mean that it should be taken off the shelves of the library or any other place. What my family believes in may not be the right thing in another family's view. Every person has their own right and if they want to listen to that music then they should be able to. My family also believes that at my age right now I should not watch rated R movies. If you took all the rated R movies off the shelves, then half the movies would be gone and that is not fair to the people who enjoy rated R movies. What my family believes may not be what other families believe in. I know what I stand for and I will do what I think is right and I won't listen to offensive music or watch rated R movies. In no way though does that mean that other children, teens, or adults shouldn't enjoy that kind of music and those movies.  In conclusion, I believe that censorship should not be used in libraries. It is every person's own right and they are capable of making decisions that they think are the right thing to do. Parents also have a say in what they want their children to watch, read, or listen to. They can monitor what their children are reading, watching, or listening to and if they find it offensive they can stop their children. It is not necessary to take the items off the shelf. In my family, my parents find some types of music and movies offensive and I know when I go to the library or any other place that I won't get those items. I will get the music and movies I enjoy and find age appropriate. Offensive media is everywhere. From books to music lyrics, our culture embraces us with it. Children that see inappropriate media can pick up bad behavior. This could make an adult emotionally unhealthy and they may become violent or depressed, influenced by the negative content they consume. Finally, our world could be better if offensive media were abolished altogether. People's lives could be enriched with good, clean entertainment instead of being corrupted with inappropriate media that promotes harmful ideas. If the child is exposed to inappropriate media for a long period of time, they may think that it is ok to use it in everyday life, normalizing what should be unacceptable. Their social skills and mind is being corrupted because of offensive media that shapes their worldview negatively. Libraries should pull inappropriate media off of their shelves because it can corrupt a child's mind during their most formative years.  Another reason why libraries should pull off offensive media is because adults can pick up different offensive habits as well. Just as children can pick up the offensive habit of swearing, so can adults if they are exposed to it for a long period of time, gradually desensitizing them. Besides swearing, adults can also think that killing someone is ok because they saw it in a movie, blurring the line between fiction and reality. They could then pick up a violent weapon and try to kill someone if they are angry, acting out what they have consumed in media. This is not a healthy way to express your feelings towards someone if they are making you angry; it is a dangerous escalation. Our country's libraries should pull off inappropriate media from their shelves because it can turn adults into being emotionally unhealthy and potentially dangerous.  Finally, inappropriate media should be pulled off library shelves because our world could be a better place without it. Media is one of the root causes of why people act the way they do, influencing behavior on a large scale. If they see their favorite celebrity getting arrested for a DUI in a magazine, they may think that it is ok to drink and drive, assuming it is a minor issue. Another example is if people read about someone doing drugs in a book, they may want to try and experiment with drugs themselves, curious about the experience. This can lead to people doing crazy things that can be harmful to other lives around them, creating a ripple effect of negative actions.  Offensive media is almost anywhere, permeating our society. When children see inappropriate media, they may think that it is ok to imitate it, leading to behavioral issues. Adults, when exposed to enough offensive media, can pick up nasty habits like swearing, killing or doing drugs which, in turn, can lead to them being emotionally unhealthy and a risk to society. Without inappropriate media on our library shelves, our world would be a better place, free from these corrupting influences. We would have less conflict, less deaths, and better lives that are enriched, not corrupted, with quality media that uplifts rather than degrades. Millions of lives could be made better if libraries pulled off inappropriate media from their shelves, creating a safer and healthier environment for everyone.

The censorship of certain media is such a controversial topic. Whether a certain piece of material is considered offensive and should be censored or not is more often opinionated rather than logically opposed, because it really does all come down to someone's opinion on this matter. It is too difficult for most people to step in someone else's shoes or be persuaded from a viewpoint different from their own or even escape pressures from the general public to consider something else. Things get censored for a lot of reasons, too! Sometimes they're just so intentionally offensive that perhaps the author or producer wants it to be censored or would appreciate the controversy, or that a new view or opinion is so radical and against a majority of the population that it is just considered offensive for being so different. Well, when does someone have a right to take a song off the air or pull a book permanently from a shelf? The first thing that needs to be contemplated is if something is offensive or not. There are extremes to pieces of media where one sometimes must ask, 'What were they thinking when they made that?' A movie being so outrageously graphic or violent is a fine example, although the same thing can happen in books, just with words instead of pictures. At the same time though, whether or not something you might think as unnecessary gore in a film might just be what I'm excited to see when I go to the cinema - it's all opinionated! Another interesting thought is that somebody might come up with a revolutionary, radical scientific theory and write a whole novel or film a documentary explaining it all, but certain groups of people might claim that it is offensive to them. However, we might investigate into that theory ourselves and not be offended in the slightest. This is understandable though; people grow up in an environment that has its own set of ethics and principles, and people will honestly believe them and probably stick with those fundamentals throughout their lifetime. If you go against someone's beliefs that they hold so dear like that, they would of course be offensive to them. Does that mean that something should be censored just because it offends a couple of groups in a population? Whether or not something is to be torn from the access of the public is left up to the opinions of the general public themselves. The opinion of the public is created by the current time, trends, ethics, and problems that are going on. When something goes against too many of those things, people get upset. If most people are upset by something, it will probably start disappearing from sight. It's bad for business, and libraries are losing customers already due to most people not having an urge to read anymore with all of the stuff that you can do otherwise. Certain things can just put a bad taste in your mouth, and if someone gets that too often when they go to a library, they probably won't go there anymore. So when it comes down to censorship in libraries, or anywhere, it's just a bunch of opinions. If the general public does not like something, it will stop showing up. Certain books or other pieces of media are asking for the controversy that many subjects bring, while others are just unintentionally going against certain groups of people. People's beliefs are determined by where they grew up and when, and they'll hold on to those things for their lifetime. If something goes against those, people will be offended, and if enough people are upset, it gets taken away, reflecting the collective judgment of society.

Freedom of speech is the ability to read, write, and listen to whatever you want, but it exists under some conditions. I think that all books should be allowed to stay on the shelf. As Americans, we have the freedom to express how we feel about something without constant worry. However, we should also think carefully about our words and actions, and if something is wrong or harms someone, we should take rightful ownership of our mistakes. I do agree that some books should be removed if they provide thoughts or ideas that could cause downfall to our country. Materials from terrorist groups or books promoting drugs and alcohol are examples that should be taken off the shelves to avoid polluting the minds of our youth. People should not take all the books out of the library because other people would probably like to look at those books as well. If people start taking books out indiscriminately, all the books will be gone, leaving nothing for others to read or check out. Therefore, there should be a law that you can only have a book out for a given period of time, which would help keep a good number of books in the library. If people just start taking books without returning them, there will be no books left for others to check out. So, a rule is needed that specifies you can check out a certain number of books at a time and defines how long you can keep them. If you do not bring the books back within that time, you will be charged a fine, and the amount will build up every day the books are overdue. Furthermore, if you do not pay the bill, you lose the privilege to check out books until the amount is settled. This system would be a good idea to prevent people from stealing or hoarding library materials. Regarding the books, movies, and magazines in the library, they should generally stay on the shelves. If you take out one, you should take out all of them, because everyone needs access to these materials in life, even if some content is considered bad. If one book, magazine, or movie gets removed, then all similar items should be removed as well, because it is not fair to their authors, who took time to create their work. If authors get angry, they might stop making books for everyone to read. This is what I think about removing books from the library, though if something is truly egregious, perhaps it should be taken off the shelves at the library or anywhere it is sold.

I believe that all the uncensored books, movies, music, and magazines in a library should be taken off the general shelves and put into a single, separate room labeled as the Adult Section. Children who visit the library often have a designated space for kids' books, but when they accompany their parents or an older person into the main areas, they might unknowingly pick up a random book or video from the general shelves. Some people are concerned about this system because they are wary of who might see them enter a room marked for adults. However, if you do not want anyone to see you go into that room, you can simply choose not to enter it. By secluding the adult-oriented books, magazines, and videos, you can prevent children from accidentally picking up material with uncensored pictures or content. A parent might not pre-screen a video, which could turn out to be an adult film, and then the child might develop an interest in such material, potentially leading to early sexual curiosity and activity. I hope this shows how sectioning off adult content can keep children away from it and help prevent them from engaging in sexual intercourse at an early age, such as thirteen. As for music, there is no perfect way to stop kids from listening to genres like rap, which often contains foul language and references to sex and drugs. Children might admire the artists and emulate their behavior. The best way, in my view, is for parents to not allow their children to listen to such music while they are together. Other music genres, like classical, jazz, or even some hip-hop, rarely have such explicit references. I could also argue that parents should monitor their children to make them aware of the consequences of their actions influenced by media and should discipline them appropriately when necessary.

"Say that word!" That is exactly what I said to my brother after he had read the front cover of a magazine in the library one afternoon. Personally, I am an advocate of not saying curse words. Yet, my brothers are influenced by things, such as the media, to say them. Should we allow the media to sprinkle words like this onto magazines and books? Or should the items containing these things be removed from the library's shelves? Magazines are one of many ways that we get the latest gossip on the most interesting scandals. They also appeal to a lot of people across the world. Most of those people are of adult age. Libraries will most often place the magazines on the shelf to attract adult customers. Most of the content of magazines these days consists of pictures of half-dressed women or men and explicit language on the covers. Should that be the new normal? I personally do not think so. I enjoy reading and think that it is better than sitting on the couch watching mind-numbing television. But, the material of some books has gotten to the point where every other word is a curse word, or they contain degrading scenes that no one should have to read. It used to be that books were read to learn something new or to open your mind to a new culture. Nowadays, it seems arduous to come across a good book like the classics, as we are replacing the majestic words of authors with common, coarse language. Replacing such books on the shelves for anyone to read is not right and should not even be allowed. With electronic devices such as music players, most music comes from online sites where you purchase songs directly. Most parents do not know half the songs their children buy, especially when the purchase is made from home. With internet access in many libraries, kids can plug in their devices and buy songs with offensive language without anyone knowing. Why don't librarians put restrictions on these sites? The answer is that they often cannot, and even if they did, children would find a way around the restrictions. So, I think the ability to download and purchase music at the library should be removed, or the awful language in songs should be taken out altogether because it is not needed. Although times are constantly changing, with a little effort we can restore some decency. Kids using foul language is a serious issue, and from my own experiences, I know it is a growing problem. Maybe if we put more censorship in libraries, some of these problems could diminish. Explicit language and graphic scenes are almost everywhere in magazines, books, and songs, so we should speak up and talk to someone about this idea; it might just start a positive revolution.

Should certain materials be removed from your public library? I personally don't believe that anything should be removed from a library; just because you might not like a particular book or topic does not mean someone else couldn't really enjoy or benefit from it. If you do not want to learn about something, you should not take that opportunity away from others who do. I think that if libraries do start removing items from their shelves, the materials should still be made accessible to those who want them, perhaps upon request. Even if you just put them away in a reserved section, that would be far better than taking them out of the library completely and denying access entirely. More and more books are banned every day, and I personally do not think that is fair to the growing generation, who may not get to enjoy or learn from the things that previous generations had available. So I firmly believe that no books should be removed from libraries, as your personal dislike for something does not mean someone else will not find value in it.

What is appropriate in libraries these days? The opinions differ throughout the variety of different people across the country. Censorship has taken a turn in public libraries, but it has still been strictly forbidden from many school libraries. Personally, I think that there is a significant difference between vulgar and inappropriate items in a public library versus a school library. A public library is a place for anyone and everyone to come and find an item that they are interested in. As we all know, everyone is different and has their own unique interests, so they should be able to find the book, music, or other media that is right for them. The problem is, how do the libraries keep these uncensored objects out of children's hands? The answer should be simple. For thought, maybe all public libraries should be broken up into sections, each with their own subject matter and age-appropriateness. These different sections could include Children's, Young Adult, and many more different titles. This set up is often used in well known book stores and libraries such as 'Barnes and Noble' and 'Books-A-Million'. Overall, censorship in public libraries does not need to be as strict as in school libraries. School libraries are a whole different idea. School libraries are made to help assist the students' academic achievement, nothing more and nothing less. However, I also think that the content in the school libraries also depends on the maturity of the students. For example, elementary and middle school libraries should have a stricter censorship than high school libraries. The students in high school should be mature enough to handle more uncensored material without creating a huge scene, like we all know younger students would do. I have personally seen and witnessed a few so called 'inappropriate' books on the shelf at my high school library, but the readers of the book have been mature about reading it. I believe that some offensive and vulgar items can be interesting and educational, as it is all a part of growing up and understanding the world. The censorship in our libraries today varies from each library to the next. School libraries and public libraries are completely different places of literate and media content. I think that it is a person's own personal decision dealing with which library they go to and what they select. If a family with young children wants to go to the library, the parents need to choose the appropriate areas in the building to search for the children. Therefore, with proper guidance and sectioning, there should be no problem in running across a 'bad' book. The author, Judy Blume, states, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf... And then we have no books left on the shelf for anyone.' This highlights the slippery slope of censorship.

The Author should be the judge on whether or not they want their book censored. I believe that libraries should not have to take out books with offensive language. If the author likes how it was originally made, then that is how they would like to present their artistic work. It would be taking away a Right in the First Amendment. If you were to write a book and somebody says you cannot put a certain word in it, that decision is not up to the public to make. It is almost like rewriting history. It would be like having someone take out a word in the Constitution. If any word is changed it is an incorrect version of the Constitution. It just changes the entire subject and the author's original intent. You cannot reword what has already been written and published. Public views are starting to take over the world of literature. Instead of letting the facts be the facts, people want to adjust things so it is less offensive. Next thing you know there will be a replaced word for slavery. Slavery is a strong, bold word that represents a horrible thing. If somebody switched that word it could lead to it happening again by softening its historical reality. I say with all my heart that people need to respect what has been written and leave it that way, or simply do not read it if they find it disagreeable.

One person's strong negative opinion affects everyone else. That does not seem logical or fair. A library is a sanctuary for people to go read their favorite books for free, containing books from all types of genres and perspectives. There is a book for everyone in the library; it is simply a matter of finding it. Therefore, finding a book offensive or unsuitable does not give one the right to take that privilege away from everyone else who might cherish it. Books have a way of putting our mind at ease, whether that is because it is an escape or measured on how enjoyable it is to read. Books found offensive to one person could have a completely different impact on the next reader; some might even find the books relatable and comforting. For example, if there was a scene that one reader thought was too graphic or horrific for other readers, there might be someone out there who would find this scene meaningful because they can relate to it on a personal level. People who are not capable of relating to such a scene would only find it as inappropriate and try to remove it from another's reach. One person's opinion is not of any more importance than the next person's. The book 'The Kite Runner' is a professionally written, fictional novel that has been praised for its quality, hence the numerous awards it has won. Although, this book contains a rape scene and numerous other inappropriate events that this woman was succumbed to throughout her life. Even so, it is still on the list of suggested college level reads for many university literature classes. It is disappointing to think that people nowadays focus on the graphic scenes in a novel, versus the exceptional writing style and the important themes it explores. If all readers were able to look past the surface of these scenes, fewer books would be contemplated for shelf removal. One person's negative interpretation of a novel affects everyone else's right concerning the censorship in libraries. Readers are fully warned beforehand of the maturity of the contents through ratings and reviews. The books are ranked, critiqued, summarized on the back cover, and even sorted in a library by genre and age group. If one finds a book offensive, they should look in a different section. Books are sorted by genre for that reason as well; different genres appeal to different people. This applies to the maturity of the reader as well, with sections clearly marked for children, teens, and adults. If you find a book offensive, instead of having it removed from the shelf altogether, look in a section for younger people, or a different genre completely. If someone finds the book offensive, the fault is not of the book being there, but of the person being in the wrong section for their personal taste. The main problem concerning book censorship in libraries is not the content itself, but how the interpretations differentiate towards such content. On this issue, the other readers' opinions on specific books being removed are being significantly overlooked. For one to complain about a book's contents automatically gives someone else the right to protect the book's contents and its availability. For libraries to remove books in the name of censorship is viewed as favoritism towards one viewpoint and is completely against the rights this country has stood for, including intellectual freedom and free access to information.

Do you feel that some material should just not be allowed in libraries? Censorship in libraries is a touchy subject. Many people with young children believe that some books should just not be allowed in the libraries, while others believe that because it is a book, no matter what, it should be allowed to be in the library. Who knows, someone might need to write a paper over that certain 'touchy' book. I think, personally, that as long as the book is in a proper section, it should be okay for a person, of the right age, to be able to get that book or other material. The libraries should have a certain area for children's books and another area for adult or teenage level reading or material. This way, there is a less likely hood that a young child will end up getting a book with material for an adult or teenager. The library in the town that I live in has a clearly marked area for children and teenagers. This way, young children are not going to be looking for their favorite book with a book over something many adults should not even be reading. If people are concerned about someone being to young to read or view the material, the library can also put an age restriciton on the material. This way anyone who is under the age limit will not be able to get the material. The people who are of proper age will be able to get the material, however. Libraries are very important sources for studing in many people's lives. If people did not have a library, they might not be able to research a paper, or something else, that they need to get finished. I feel if people do not like the material that they see in their local library, then they should just not look at it or borrow the material from the library. I do feel, however, that little children should not be given even the slightest chance to stuble upon a book with disturbing material. There, in my opinion, needs to be a room with said materials that children have, in no way, access to. This way, children are not able to access the material, but they are still able to go into the library without their parents feeling that the children might see something unsuitable for them. I feel that those people who love reading should be able to go into a library, and not be afraid of if they are going to see a book containing material they believe to be unsuitable. I also feel that if I need to research something that is deemed, by others, to be offensive, I should somehow be able to research my subject. Also, if I was the author of a book that was said to be 'bad,' i would not want my book to be taken away, so that no one could read it, or study and learn from it. I do not think that censorship is something that people should take lightly. We all have the freedom of speech, so why not let the authors of the materials have that same freedom. There are procautions that parents and people who do not want to see this literature can take. Total censorship, I feel, would not allow for people to broaden their minds. If people just take procautions, there is no need for total censorship of materials, that someone worked very hard on for everyone to see.

Certain materials, such as books, music, movies, or magazines, do not need to be removed from the shelves in libraries if they are found offensive. There are multiple reasons to back up this statement, including an accurate quote from author Katherine Paterson. People build their character through their reactions of how people treat them, and similarly, through engaging with challenging ideas. For example, in life sombody might offend another person, but that does not mean the offender is going to dissapear after doing so. How does this relate to libraries you might ask? Books and movies do not need to be taken off of shelves in libraries if they are found offensive because there are a lot of things in the real world that are offensive, and libraries provide a safe space to encounter and understand them. It is your choice in what you want to read, listen to, or watch. Just because you might have the option of checking out something you do not think is appropriate or is offensive, does not mean you have to check it out; you can simply walk past it. Some people might enjoy reading or watching things that are offensive to others, as it might align with their interests or perspectives. You might be wanting to argue, 'But I don't want my children being exposed to such offensive materials.' That is why most public libraries are split into children and adult sections, with age-appropriate materials in each. If you happen to come across an offensive book in the childrens section, then do not let your child check that out. It is as simple as that. Trying to take the book off the shelf or complaining about it would only take up more time and infringe on others' rights. The quote, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf-that work I abhor-then you also have exactly the same right and so does everybody else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us', by Katherine Paterson, is a perfect example to conclude the reasons why books should not be taken off the shelf. She is saying that if one person is allowed to remove a book, then anybody else would be able to have that ablitiy as well. Therefore, a book that does not offend you at all could be taken off the shelf because somebody else does not approve of it. Eventually, there would be no books left, defeating the very purpose of a library. In conclusion, if there are books, music, movies, or magazines that offend you, simply do not check them out. You do not need to get rid of them because somebody else might want to check them out and find value in them.

Should libraries censor reading materials for students at school? That is a yes and no question because reading is good for people of all ages; it's just a matter of whether the topic is suitable for certain age groups. Yes, I do think they should censor reading material, but to an extent. They need to have books for kids at certain age groups, like having sections for young kids, then teens, and then adults. If a child wants to read more graphic material, then they must have permission from their parent. The reason I say that is there are things that get published by authors that are meant to be read by certain people, and having a structured system helps guide young readers toward content that is appropriate for their level of maturity and understanding. This approach supports literacy while also providing necessary safeguards for developing minds.

Regardless of if we are speaking of the religious demanding books such as the Harry Potter series to be ripped from our shelves or politicians wanting to burn the library, books can always bring about controversy. In this country we are given the rights to freedom of speech and press, so why can anyone demand that a book be banned? Everyone in our world has different thoughts, beliefs, morals and values so why should we try to force our own views on others? We should not. Imposing our views upon others can be done just as easily through putting a controversial book on the shelves as it can by taking it off. Music, movies and magazines are no different, all express the ideas and beliefs of their respective writer, and all deserve to be accessed by anyone who desires to do so. Books, there are lists of hundreds of banned books and honestly you could find a dozen reasons to ban any book ever written. If you ban one writers words because they speak passionately or discretely on a controversial topic, then you must ban them all, and if you have to ban the words then you must also ban the writer so that he or she cannot voice his or her opinion. If we did this then our country and our world would be without opinion, voiceless, and without a voice their is no direction and no moving forward. If the people of our world are denied the right to write a book on their opinion then what kind of world do we live in? If you can ban my words, then I can ban yours and we have both lost our voice and our chance at somehow brightening the future. Imagine the impact if the government had locked away every copy of the Bible because it brought about change and controversy. Imagine a world where we had never heard of Shakespeare or Hemingway. It would be a world far different from our own. A world without powerful voices influencing not only our daily actions, but hundreds of years of war, love, and hate. It would be one without direction, where people are left to wonder but never to express or discuss. It would be a terrible place. While children should not exactly be watching porn or reading 'Playboy', they definitely should not be kept from reading, listening to, or watching anything they desire. Values and morals should be gained by reading, discovering and thinking, not forced upon us by our government or our parents. Rap music may have lyrics that some would consider rude but to another they might speak a message. To a creationist Darwin's views may seem stupid and offensive, but to an atheist they might be what makes sense. We should all have access to all opinions so that we can develop our own. We should not have the values and ideas of others beaten into our heads, we should be able to develop our own through an exploration through those of others. Censorship is wrong, our government has no business in what we choose to explore and no one should be restricted by the views of another, for such restrictions ultimately impoverish our collective intellectual and cultural life.

Should taking books, music, and movies off shelves of libraries even be questioned? As stated in our constitution, people have the freedom to information. Throughout the world, there are thousands of people with various opinions. If one person thinks an art piece looks unique, another may not see any true beauty. But when people hardly understand the concept of other people, they should not be exposed to books or movies that could be defined as offensive. Some people don't know what it is like to be truly offended. When I was in middle school, I was a shy, fragile, young girl. I had just moved to a new school and was petrified of my new surroundings. For the first couple of weeks, I felt like an outcast; like an outsider looking in. I didn't fit in with anyone's group. Everyone seemed to of already have friends for years and here I was, a new student with no friends to communicate with. I was isolated and was desperately trying to find someone to be my friend. I wondered if something was wrong with me; if I had a bad odor or was dressed in an out of style fashion. I tried buying new clothes and changing my hair color. It seemed as if I wasn't even noticed. Before I knew it, school was half way over. I was still a nobody. Then Alex came along and made me a somebody. Alex, who had just moved to my school, looked bold and confident. At first, people waved a friendly hello but nothing more. As I sat at my empty lunch table, Alex approached me and asked to sit down. I couldn't refuse the offer so I nodded a sincere yes. The entire lunch period, we sat talking. We had a lot in common and I was glad to have made a friendship with Alex. Months went by before I realized Alex and I were great friends. I knew I could trust him with all of my secrets. Even though Alex and I were close, I felt as though he was always hiding something. Occasionally I would have enough courage to ask if there was anything he needed to tell me, but as the same as every answer before, it was a no. Alex and I had always walked to my house after school. But on one afternoon, something felt wrong. The air seemed to linger for miles. We didn't talk until we got inside my house. Suddenly Alex spoke and said, 'Why are people so cruel?' I was shocked by this question for I didn't know how to respond. Alex sensed that I had no clue what he was talking about so he continued. 'I'm gay.' I was appalled. Not because he was gay, but because he had never told me. I asked, 'What happened?' He sat on the couch then and told me about how he was in the library overhearing some of our classmates reading a book about people making fun of gays'. I felt awful for Alex. Do people have the right to limit freedom? Do people have the right to limit imagination? Do people have the right to limit self expression? Many people in today's world think so. Censoring books not only limits self expression but it also limits knowledge and our constitutional right of free speech. I believe people should not be able to censor books. Censoring a book is like putting a limit on human imagination. All through life people are urged to think outside of the box. We are told as kids that being unique and different is a good thing. We are all told this and yet when writers express themselves in books, the same people that told them to think outside of the box, want to censor their thoughts. They feel that by taking books they feel to be 'offensive' out of libraries, they can shield their child from the bad things in the world. This is not the case. People may be able to censor books, but no one can censor life. Children will learn 'offensive' things with or without books, through their peers or their own experiences. Book censorship limits knowledge. At the time it was written, The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn, was a very scandalous book. Because of the language this book used, many people thought it was trash. Many people wanted it to be censored. Today The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn is a famous and classic book. In fact, I was required to read it for school. Regardless of the language this book used, it shows a part of American history. And to think, if people back then would have removed it from the libraries, I most likely would never have read this book, and I would never have the knowledge I gained from reading this book. It is our constitutional right to write and read the books we choose. America was built on the idea of freedom. Under the constitution we are guaranteed freedom of speech. By taking books out of libraries, we are limiting our freedom of speech. No one should be allowed to tell you that you cannot read a book you want to read. No one should be allowed to tell you that you cannot write a book as you want to write it. If we start censoring books, writers will be forced to censor their personal thoughts. Making writers do that, limits their freedom of speech. If freedom of speech is limited, what other freedoms will also be limited with the years to come? Book censorship and censorship in general, is not a good thing; all it does is limit things. If we start censoring books, we are giving a message to our children, that different is bad. If freedom of speech is limited, how long will it be until our other rights are limited? Where will it end? Before removing even the first book from the shelf, we need to ask ourselves this, do we have the right to limit freedom.
