Though many individuals disapprove, libraries should not censor their books, movies, or music because of that singular perspective. Some individuals find that 'To Kill a Mockingbird' or 'The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn' are offensive books because of their repeated use of the controversial word. There is also some argument to that, there are several people that I know that find that word offensive, but not in this case. They say that it brings more educational value to the book, because in the day of Mark Twain the word was an accepted word. That is just how it was back then, and removing it whitewashes history. Back then and now censorship is hiding reality. People who write, sing, and direct things that are considered 'inappropriate' are the ones who are trying to set the truth free. The 'inappropriate' language, or experiences are the ones that really happen and are the words that are really said in real life. By using censorship you are sheltering the world from its own reality. Censorship is a tool we use to block ourselves from reality. Is that the right choice? Is it right sending sheltered teens out in the world unable to fend for themselves, or should we let them understand how it really works through literature and media?

Censorship. 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf -that work I abhor -then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' This was quoted from an author named Katherine Paterson. I do not believe certain materials such as books should be removed from shelves under any circumstances. Everyone is entitled to their own opinion about certain materials. If books are removed from the shelves due to censorship, then what is the point of writing or even reading books? If people continue to remove books because they are found to be offensive, then there will not be any books left to read, as virtually any book could offend someone. I have seen many offensive books. Whether it had something to do with religious beliefs or even revealing too much sexual content, I am sure it is offensive to someone somewhere. Books are written by authors who believe they have the right to express themselves through writing. If you are to take away or ban a certain book from the shelf, then what would the author who wrote the book think? Our world is full of offensive and rather disturbing books. It cannot be right to just get rid of those things because they bother us. Everyone has the right to read any book they want to. Just because it offends one person, does not mean it offends everyone. I believe censorship is unnecessary. What gives anyone the right to remove or change something because it is inappropriate? I have personally read a few books that I would not want little kids to read but that does not mean I should remove it from the shelves. Perhaps, somebody else has been waiting to find that book for their research or enjoyment. If I did remove it then I am restricting others from experiencing the joys of reading that book. Censorship in general is wrong. Everyone is entitled to their own beliefs and different ways of expressing themselves. I do not believe anyone has the right to take something, that someone has worked on for so long to make, and remove it because they find it offensive. There will always be something out there that you will not approve of. Just because you do not approve of it does not mean everybody does not approve. Authors write books for a reason, musicians write music for a reason, people make movies and magazines for a reason. What gives anyone the right to take something that somebody made and ban it from the rest of the world because it is offensive? Books are there to help us become more educated and more open minded towards different thoughts and ideas. We should not just ban them because they offend certain people. If you do not like a book because it offends you, then do not read it. It is just that simple. If people continue to remove books because they are offensive, then there will not be any books left to read, and we will have lost a fundamental pillar of a free and educated society.

If someone is looking for an offensive book, they are going to find it, whether it's collecting dust on a library shelf or is brand new in a book store. The same goes for an offensive website, magazine, or movie. Removing the offensive items from library shelves will only cause the people searching for these items to look elsewhere, defeating the purpose of the removal. Different people have different opinions on what is offensive and what is not offensive. The Da Vinci Code is an example of a controversial book that many people believed to be offensive to their religious beliefs. While many people found The Da Vinci Code offensive, others enjoyed the story and its intriguing plot. If the book had been removed from libraries because some people found it offensive, then others who really enjoyed the book would not have been able to read it, limiting access to a popular work. Another reason libraries should not remove offensive items from their shelves is that, most likely, the entire book, magazine, movie, etc. is not offensive the whole way through. Even if a movie has one offensive scene in it, the rest of the movie could be a great story that many people would benefit from seeing, offering valuable lessons or entertainment. It is the same idea with a book or magazine. There might be a few offensive chapters or one or two offensive articles, but very rarely will you find a book, movie, or magazine that is offensive the whole way through. Of course, there are still offensive items that would be bad for younger kids to see even with the one or two offensive scenes, chapters, or articles. There are easier solutions to this problem than having to remove the items from the shelves completely. One solution to this problem could be for libraries to put age limits on certain items, so that younger kids can't check out materials that are too inappropriate for their age level. But more importantly, this would be the job of the parents to monitor what their kids are reading, watching, or listening to, as they are the primary guides for their children. Removing offensive books, magazines, music, and movies from the shelves of libraries would just cause more problems and complaints from patrons who feel their access is being unfairly restricted. I think it is a good idea to leave the material on the library shelves and caution library users to 'read at their own risk,' thereby allowing for individual choice and responsibility.

Censorship in school libraries is important, but at the same time it is not necessary. I believe that many books in the school library are not appropriate for younger children, but these same books should not be taken out of our libraries because I feel like high schoolers are mature enough to be reading this material. The material in these books is no different than what goes on in the high school years or what teenagers discuss amongst themselves. Most of these books give a perspective on real life stories and might be able to help someone cope and realize that they are not alone in their struggles. At the same time though many of these books do contain curse words, some sexual scenes, partying, drinking, and doing drugs. These books are too old for an elementary school age child and maybe even a middle school age child to be reading. For example the books by Ellen Hopkins, these books are about a girl who becomes addicted to drugs, pregnant, in jail, and homeless. I read these books, they are really good books, and they showed me how by just trying one drug, one time, could ruin your whole life. I learned a lot from these books, but I don't think that anyone younger than fourteen should be reading them due to the mature themes. There should be a limit on the censorship. Many things talked about in the books, are the same things talked about in the school hallways, so what is the real difference? That is why authors write about the things they do, so they can connect with teenagers on their level. Many books are an author's experience, so they are meant for high school age readers. Many authors will put an age level on their books, like fourteen and older. Libraries should pay attention to these ratings before putting the books in the libraries to help guide their selections. Someone might become offended by what they read in a book, but I don't think that book should be taken off the shelf because of one person's complaint. If it becomes a bigger issue, than yes it should be taken off, but at the same time, that one book might be someone else's way of escaping the hardships in their life, providing them comfort. Many adults would disagree with my statements because they feel like if a teenager is reading about someone drinking, doing drugs, or having sex, then they are more likely to do those things. I feel like this is not true because the book I am reading now, they are partying and drinking, but I'm not out doing that myself. What is the difference between someone reading it in a book and seeing it on television or in a movie? I see many worse things on the internet than I read in books. Parents should be happy that their teenager is reading and not playing video games or out with friends getting into trouble. These are just my opinions, some people may agree with me and others may disagree, but I am going to stick with my opinions on this matter.

Censorship is a big conflict in many libraries. There are plenty of offensive books that shouldn't be put on the shelves, according to some people. Many schools call these books, magazines, and movies, 'banned.' Banned Books Week is often a week where people read all of the books that have been banned from school libraries. I participate in this school wide challenge because I disagree with banning books, as I believe it limits intellectual freedom. Banning books can be good and also very hurtful in many reasons, depending on your point of view. First off, I like to think of banning books or anything else from the author or writers view. How would you feel if you spent around two years writing this story or movie for kids that got banned in the first couple of weeks it was on the shelves? I don't think that many people would enjoy that feeling of rejection. I also think that many people don't think of authors at that big of a deal, but they are the creators of the stories we love. When I think of that it makes me think of all the things we couldn't read in our world, including newspapers, books, and magazines. Maybe even include the fact that it takes a lot of work to write the things on what people want to hear, or see, and that effort should be respected. I feel like when books or movies get banned or removed, it makes the author feel like they're worth nothing, which is a terrible feeling. The parents point of view makes things a lot worse and more complicated. Think of it this way, your child comes home from school with this book that he or she wants you to read with him. You sit down and start reading, when suddenly you come across a violent or inappropriate scene in the story. You stop reading all of a sudden and look at your child who is enjoying this violence and loving this story! What do you do in that situation? Many parents would call the school and explain what happened and complain about banning this book and taking it away from children that could get this book. Taking it away has no point because just banning it from the school library doesn't mean that they can't find it elsewhere, like at a public library or online. How do you think your child would feel having loved this story now it's gone from their school? I know that it would make me feel like I did something wrong to cause its removal. Taking things off shelves also has a good side to it, which must be acknowledged. When you take the book, movie or magazine off the shelf it is gone forever from that library. This can be a good thing because then kids won't have the obvious reason to get the story from that location. If you don't want your child or other children to see it then it is quite a good idea to restrict access. It makes the banned object harder to find and also harder for the kids to grab interest in. If the book or movie isn't around then they won't want to read the next one or see the next movie, which some parents might prefer. There are many different views on censorship, which could effect how people choose what happens in libraries and what materials are available. My view on this topic was negative and I support that fully. If the author works hard on writing the story they shouldn't get punished for expressing their feelings in a story that they created. Many different people come across this issue and there are many different views on the topic, making it a complex debate. Next Banned Books Week I'll be supporting the authors that got crushed by their work getting banned from libraries and schools. I hope that you will too, and consider the importance of access to diverse ideas.

Censorship in public libraries, allowed? I believe it should be, with a few different view points. For one, why should the books come off of shelves because some people do not like the plot of the series? This seems unfair to those who do enjoy the stories. Two, there is over a million of us people out there and we all are not a like in many ways, including our reading preferences. Also, reading is one of those things that we differ with each other on greatly. One person might read peaceful warm-hearted stories, than you have people out there who want something more intense to be able to read, like thrilling mysteries or dark fantasies. With all of us being different all over the world, it is natural that our tastes in literature vary. Humans have different taste in food, music, movies, and books, which makes life interesting. All people have different ways to satisfy their pleasures in book readings, to me books are like religions not all of us are the same in that, and at the same time we are all freely living with our religion without any punishment, so why would you take away books that people love to read freely? This seems like a contradiction in a free society. To me, in my eyes is just not right to restrict access in this way. It's like taking candy away from a innocent baby because it will rot it's teeth out, which is an overreaction. What I mean by that is, that sure some books to people might offend them yet their might be some people out there being offensive to that persons books and so on, but as long as your baby's teeth aren't rotting out, than why take the candy away? Meaning if the books have each individual shelf with labels on what it was all about, which they do, then people can make informed choices. People wouldn't feel so offensive finding them in the wrong spot if the organization is clear. Looking at the point of views do you understand where I come from with this? We are all the same in our humanity, yet in books we find each other inside of them, finding ourselves into books and connecting with characters. I know many book readers with different types of tastes, and we all coexist peacefully. No matter who they were and who their friends were, we all are different and that is okay. To many people other than myself, would agree with that statement about diversity. So tell me again why should censorship not be in public libraries when it ultimately restricts this wonderful diversity of thought and story.

Books are a form of history, each telling a story from the past or presenting a unique perspective. In history we don't block any offensive events that take place, so why should we remove any books that have offensive material in them? It would be wrong to strip the kids of any learning tools that books provide, as they are essential for education. Books are a very important learning tool in today's schools and there is something new in every book that a kid can learn from, whether it's a vocabulary word or a life lesson. So even taking away one book could make a kid learn one less thing, which is a loss for their development. And doing this on purpose would be against everything that schools stand for, which is the promotion of knowledge and critical thinking. There are many different genres of books, but not everybody loves every genre, and that is perfectly normal. If a person only likes to read young adult books because it relates to their culture, which most likely will have offensive language and events play out, that is their choice. If you were to take this away from a young adult in school, once more this person would be missing out on books because now they are not interested in any of the books in the library that remain. This could discourage them from reading altogether. If you can even think of just one instance that could strip a student away from a learning opportunity you shouldn't do it, as education is paramount. But the fact is there are many reasons why you shouldn't remove any literature from library shelves, primarily because it limits access to information and the freedom to explore different ideas and stories that shape our understanding of the world.

libraries shouldn't remove items just because some people find them offensive. People prefer different types of books, so removing some reduces the overall selection and variety available. A lower selection of books means fewer people have a compelling reason to visit the library, as their specific interests may no longer be catered to. This diminishes the library's role as a comprehensive resource for the entire community, ultimately weakening its value and appeal. A diverse collection ensures that everyone can find something that resonates with them, which is fundamental to a library's purpose.

Can books, music, movies, and other materials be perfect for everyone? Everyone has their own opinion and beliefs on what materials are good, and what are not acceptable for the human mind. All over the world, young kids, young adults, and adults are reading books and magazines, listening to music, and watching movies. Those are all hobbies most people enjoy doing. Everyone reads different kinds of books, whether it's mystery, romance, or bible-based books; people read. Removing books, magazines, and other materials off the shelves in a library leads to an unsuccessful, empty library. When people come and search for a book to read, they search for what they think they will enjoy. If they enjoy one thing, another person might not. They might find a book offensive, but does that mean everyone else is offended by the book as well? Taking that book out leaves the person who would enjoy that book stuck searching for another book. Everyone is different; everyone has their own story, just like these books do. Magazines are like books; they are meant to be enjoyed. I believe some magazines might not be appropriate for some people, but that doesn't mean they should be taken off the shelf. It means that person should simply not read it. Magazines are made for all people to enjoy; that's why there are so many different kinds. They want to fit each magazine personally to each individual. Music is a primary entertainment people enjoy. There is a reason why there are so many different genres. The music industry tries its best to sort the music to your taste. Just because one song has stuff in it you don't like doesn't mean you can delete that song for everyone. Music is used in many different ways. It relaxes you, pumps you up, and is used for parties, events, and so many other things. All songs are different so you can use them however you want. To ban music because someone doesn't like it changes music forever; there would be no music left to listen to. People should be able to watch what movies they want. That's why there are ratings on movies. What is acceptable for teenagers may not be acceptable for young kids, so they simply should not watch it. If people banned all the movies they thought were inappropriate, there would be no rented movie stores, theaters, or success in the movie production industry. Everyone should know what kind of movies they like, and they should just watch what they like, and leave the other movies for the people who enjoy them. No, books, magazines, movies, and music cannot be perfect for everyone. Materials bring all different kinds of subjects and stories for everyone. Each material brings enjoyment to different people. To ban all the materials you believe are inappropriate will leave the shelves empty, creating a library that serves no one.

I, as a student, a child, and a citizen of the United States, believe that every book should be allowed in any library. Books express feelings, emotions, etc., and the same is true for movies and music. If we don't have them, how will we be able to learn anything in this world? Each book out there has an explanation, a title, and a reason to be read. Today, millions of people read more and more because of all the books available. I do believe, however, that the reason every book should be in a library is because all of them are different. It doesn't matter what the book is about; some might seem offensive, but everyone has something that they dislike. There are many people out there that get defensive over things, for example, certain people, animals, countries, different skin colors, cursing, and even sports. We all have our own opinions; if you do not like a certain book because it has content that you don't like, then it's simple: don't read it, as others might like it. Movies, books, music, magazines, etc., should be allowed anywhere to ensure access for all.

Dear newspaper, In my opinion, I don't think that censorship in libraries should be applied to materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, and more. Censoring materials in the library could result in many problems. I don't agree with the censorship in libraries on materials for many reasons. In my upcoming paragraphs, I will explain why I disagree with libraries having censorship on a lot of their materials. Many libraries in the world have censoring on their materials. I believe that libraries have a lot of censoring on most of their materials due to the fact that they have children under the age of eighteen constantly viewing a lot of explicit content. Libraries shouldn't censor their materials, but in my opinion, they also shouldn't let underage children check out any kind of material that is only meant to be viewed by adults. Also, if computer access is offered to children, an adult supervisor should be nearby to make sure that no explicit content is being viewed. Censoring in libraries could result in many problems, such as customers not getting all the information they need for a certain material, children not reading up to their abilities or standards, and also children not learning enough or getting information that they need for school. If all of these things happen prior to the fact that libraries have censors on their materials, then many libraries will not get as many customers. Yes, most people visit libraries for the wrong reasons, but to other people, those wrong reasons might be the reason for them to gain more information. Materials in a library could also be found offensive to most people. But what's found offensive to most people could be found useful to other people. If something is found offensive to one person, I don't think it should be removed from the shelves. If books and or materials are removed from the shelves, that can hide so much useful information that people could gain. In conclusion, I don't think censorship should be put on materials in libraries due to the fact that much information could be lost. Censorship doesn't always mean that the material is bad; it can also mean that the material is just not appropriate to be viewed or read by that certain age group. If a library that I visit has censoring on most of their materials, I would convince the library staff to take the censoring off. Censoring is not always bad and it's not always good either, but it can hide a lot of information from us, which is not good at all for a society that values knowledge.

I think that all books, music, movies, magazines, and anything that's offensive should be taken off shelves because there are little kids that read books and they don't need to hear or read offensive things. But at the same time, for the people that do want to hear or read things like that, then there should be a separate area in the library for materials like that. There are all kinds of libraries that have offensive books, movies, and magazines. Other reasons they should take offensive materials off the shelves include that it could be racist or just offending certain things, and people don't wanna see or read about white people hating black people or black people hating white people or any type of racist things. It shouldn't be allowed because it can hurt someone's feelings. I have my own observations with reading some books from my school library and have come across some words that were offensive, like in some books they use the word nigger, and since I'm black it's offensive to me. I know that they are not saying it to me, but they still say it and it kinda touches me in a way. I'm not saying that it is offensive towards all people, but it is to me, so the way they could fix it is, like I said, instead of having offensive books out on shelves, they should have one area where materials like that could be found instead of having the material where children and other people will get offended. The last thing I wanna talk about is that for children and other people, they don't wanna see nasty things that are in books. If I had a kid, I wouldn't want my children to see nasty things that could be offensive too. There are books also that talk about drugs, and people don't wanna hear or read about that. But there are some people also that do wanna see or read about things like that, like older people; they have different points of view about things, so that's why again there should be one area in libraries for materials like that. In conclusion, I think that people should hear me out and take in what I have to say because the materials that are in books, music, or magazines can be offensive to anybody; any race could be offended by what they see or read, so again there should be a designated place in libraries for that kind of content.

Censorship is a significant consideration in the management of public libraries, which offer a wide array of materials including books, movies, magazines, and public computers for anyone to access. Kids love to go to the library to get books and just hang out with friends, enjoying the communal space. Strict parents might believe that certain books, magazines, and music are offensive and should not be available at the library, but that isn't what everyone else thinks. I believe people have different views about things, which is a fundamental aspect of a diverse community. There are people that think their kids seeing bad things will make them want to do it, while others think their kids seeing those offensive things will make them learn from it and understand the world better. Another thing that people believe is bad in libraries is the talking, as not everyone that goes to the library wants to just sit and not talk to anyone. Most people do not go to libraries because of that strict, silent environment, which can feel unwelcoming.  Libraries are fun to go to, as you can just about get any book there you want to read for education or entertainment. There is no point for any parent to be worried about their child reading a book that isn't for their age group, because libraries are very good at having the sections labeled for age groups, such as children, young adult, and adult. They also would not be able to check out the book because the staff there are good at making sure it isn't a book that shouldn't be read by that person, often enforcing policies on age-restricted materials. Also, most younger kids that go there are always with an adult, providing supervision. So the parent can keep an eye on their kid if she doesn't believe it's right for them to read the offensive books, guiding their choices. Parents should not let their kid go to the library without them if they are scared for them to do something or look at something bad, as parental responsibility is key.  Talking at libraries is always fun because you can talk about the book you're reading or just hangout, making the experience social. The staff and people there get so mad if kids are laughing or talking about something, which can create a tense atmosphere. I think they should make a floor people can go to, to hangout and talk, designating specific areas for social interaction to accommodate different preferences. In libraries there are a lot of good things to do rather than bad things, and people always feel welcome there due to the inclusive environment. Books that people say are offensive are usually the interesting ones, as they often tackle complex or challenging topics. So if you do not want to see or your kids to see the offensive books and movies, you should make sure not to go in the adult section, utilizing the library's organizational system to navigate content appropriately.

A library is a fundamental place to go and find books, music, and other informational things, serving as a community hub. It's a big resource for the public; it has a huge variety of help for people, from research materials to leisure activities. The central question is, should everything that you can have access to be removed from shelves if it's found offensive by some? If books, music, or anything else on the shelves were found offensive, a proposed solution is that they should be removed off the main shelves. They should have a separate, designated section for those certain kind of materials, which would require special access. To access that certain material, you would have to have a librarian's permission, ensuring a controlled process, so that way it can't come off as offensive to anyone browsing openly. You're probably asking why you couldn't just leave it on the shelf for everyone. You can't just leave it on the shelf because it could be offensive to someone's cultural beliefs or seem inappropriate to the youth who might encounter it unexpectedly. So therefore, that's why they would have to be removed from general circulation and placed in a restricted area.  I do believe they should be removed for those various reasons, balancing access with community standards. Libraries are a place to go to be used as resources or for fun, aiming to serve all patrons. Everyone who goes to a library should have everything to their needs, but this must be managed in a way that respects differing sensitivities and protects younger visitors from potentially harmful content, ensuring a positive experience for all.

Is it understandable to have some books restricted to people because of their age? No, it is not, as the whole situation of whether or not libraries should have things such as movies, books, and CDs restricted to certain people due to their age should not be an issue. My reasoning on that is not because of how it might influence people in a bad way, which is a common concern. Then again, it might influence them in a fantastic way, opening their minds to new ideas. That's how people find out who they are, such as what they're interested in, what they like, and what they want to do with their lives. If it wasn't for establishments such as libraries, most people would be the same as the others and not have a sense of character to themselves, leading to a less diverse society. People would be too similar and have little to no differences from others, stifling personal growth.  People should be aware of some of the content in books, exercising personal judgment. Just not to the point where those areas become restricted to certain age groups, which limits exploration. Movies and CDs are more understandable due to the actual graphic violence and language that some musicians and actors might use, as these are more direct sensory experiences. Except in a book, it's not what other people are doing and saying; it's what you yourself is reading and how you yourself is interpreting the text. It takes more than what some people are doing and saying to reflect on what you're reading and how you're reading it, engaging your own imagination and critical thought. That's why the whole situation of whether or not libraries should have certain things such as movies, books, and CDs restricted to a certain age group is flawed; instead, the solution is having the areas labeled on what the category is to know before looking, promoting informed choice. So therefore, that is my views and beliefs on why or why not libraries should be restricted to certain people, advocating for open access with clear guidance.

Many books in libraries have profanity, a feature that just depends on how you read and analyze the profanity within the context of the story. To some people, the strong words help the reader get the point across their head, adding realism and emotional impact. To others, the words are just offensive and unnecessary, detracting from the reading experience. I disagree that most books are offensive to readers; I believe that they just help the writers get their points across more effectively, using language as a tool. Many children come across books with offensive language, but if they only read books that are within their age level, which are carefully selected, then they shouldn't have these problems with inappropriate content. In adult books, there is more offensive language, but to adults' eyes and ears, it's a different story because they hear, and possibly say, a lot of the words that they are seeing in these books anyhow, making it less shocking.  I believe that any offensive reading material should be found through cataloging and then sent to a certain area of the library, like an adult section, where if you are an adult then you can check these books out. This is a practical way to keep the children away from these books, words, and to keep them 'innocent' still, as many parents desire. Children don't need to be reading books with offensive language anyhow, but of course, this is ultimately up to their guardian to decide and monitor. It's not necessarily a bad thing to have strong language in books, as long as the reader that has the book is taking it in the way the writer is intending, which is most likely to help the theme and narrative purpose. Children should be kept away from these books, but they should not be completely removed from the shelves, as they have value for adult patrons. They should just be put in their own area for adults to read only, maintaining access while providing a simple barrier for younger readers.

All libraries have books for all readers no matter the age, striving to be inclusive institutions. The books on the shelf are arranged, or should be arranged, in alphabetical order with the last name of the author first, following a standard organizational system. I think that some, but not all, reading materials such as books, music, and movies, should be considered for removal due to some of the graphics or intense content in each reading material, based on community standards. Every bookshelf should be arranged by age difference and spread apart from the other books and or bookshelves, creating distinct sections. If a child would be in the appropriate aisle for their age-styled books, less children would pick up the wrong book by accident, reducing potential issues. If children would understand to listen and follow directions on where to find their specific age-appropriate books, perhaps with signs or librarian guidance, less accidents of children taking the wrong book from the bookshelf would occur.  If children would take the wrong age-appropriate book off the bookshelf, I would think that their parent(s) would be responsible and take it back and get the right book for their child(s), teaching a valuable lesson. If parents would be responsible for taking immediate action, their child should understand that they are taking the wrong book from the bookshelf and why it matters. Wouldn't children understand that if their parent has to take the wrong book back, that they would learn not to do it again, learning through gentle correction? I think that some, but not all, reading materials such as books, music, movies, and magazines should be removed due to some of the graphical features in each reading material, but this should be a careful, considered process. The books on each bookshelf are, or should be, arranged in alphabetical order with the last name of the author first, maintaining consistency. Ultimately, all libraries have books for all readers no matter the age, and the goal is to manage the collection thoughtfully to serve everyone effectively while addressing legitimate concerns about content.

In many libraries there are books, movies, magazines, and music that people find offensive. Some find them more offensive than others. I believe that just because someone finds these things offensive that they shouldn't be removed from the shelf. I believe this because other people may be interested in it, we need information from the resources in the libraries, and all books make people more intelligent. I believe that certain books, movies, music, and magazines should be taken off the shelves, to those who they are offending, but this is a complex issue that requires a balanced approach. I myself have not come across any books, movies, or music that have offended me personally. I believe that we should organize our books, movies, and music in a different way perhaps, to accommodate everyone's sensibilities without resorting to removal. First of all, people who are offended by certain books and movies should speak up, and do something about it by expressing their concerns to librarians or store managers. Finding a way to reach a happy medium is key to resolving this conflict. If everyone could take a certain movie or book off of the shelf just because they disliked it, there wouldn't be any left in my opinion, which would be a great loss. If people find it offending they should simply stay away from those certain types books or movies and choose something else that suits their tastes. Secondly, there are people like me who are not offended at all from these books, music, and movies and enjoy them for their artistic or entertainment value. Its not fair for the ones like me to not be able to read, listen, or watch what we want to just because someone else has a different opinion. If someone doesn't like the movie we loved, and they take it away it's not fair and buisnesses will lose customers and revenue, which hurts everyone. Lastly, to find a happy medium between the offended and the people like me, we need a practical solution. I believe we could organize our books, movies, music, and magazines in a different way that respects all parties. Instead of organizing solely by author or genre, they should be organized by age restrictions and content warnings. Just like rated R movies, or rated M video games, which have clear labels. Books and music can be organized in this fassion also, with sections for general audiences and sections for mature content. It would be easier for people who are offended to stay away from the ones they don't want to be around, while others can easily find what they are looking for. In conclusion, I believe that allowing any one person to take a certain book, movie, or magazine off of a shelf is not very smart or practical. One, its not fair for people who are not offended and wish to access that material. Two, buisnesses will lose customers and limit their offerings. Three, there is a better way to solve this problem through organization and labeling, which satisfies most people.

Dear, Newspaper editor I have recently been faced with a situation that has made me feel rather uncomfortable at my local library, I saw a rather graphic magazine being displayed in front of the entire library for anyone to see. Now I know that those magazines are, for some, a point of interest, but to others they seem a tad bit crude and out of place in a public, shared space. It also came to my attention that magazines arn't the only form of crude murchandise on the selves of our local libraries that could cause discomfort. They are also littered with movies with violent covers, books with explicit themes, graphic posters, along with, what i find to be explicit music lyrics in the audio section. I know that it would be unreasonable for me to ask for the complete removal of the murchandise, as others have a right to access it, but I would like to display a comprimise that could come into play to benefit everyone. What I believe to be crude, another person may for some be acceptable, which is why we need a solution that works for all, but why should I have to be uncomfortable at a public place, while the other is unphased by the content? I believe that I have come up with a very simple comprimise, that would benefit me, as well as keep the murchandise avaiable for those who want it. Now most, to all should know that there are children sections in most, if not all libraries, which are separated for a reason. So I say this, what if we were to place all the explicit material in its own special section, perhaps with a sign, that way customers whom seek the material now know were to go to recieve it without it being in the main area. This way, I believe would lower the uncomfortable-ness of going to our public library for families and sensitive individuals. The benefits of this comprimise seem endless, to me and many others I have spoken with. This way the children are left with a safe enviroment to pick out their books without accidental exposure, and the adults that find it explicit have a comfortable surrounding to enjoy their excursion to the library without being confronted by such material. Though I am not trying to benefit those whom seek the material, I think it would help them as well. This way all of the material they want can be found in one concentrated place, and they won't have to go searching the entire library for it, making their visit more efficient. I think I speak for most when I say that our public libraries need to be a safe, family friendly enviroment, not only for children, but for those who wish to enjoy their library expierence without encountering unexpected offensive content. This compromise allows for both access and comfort, maintaining the library as a welcoming space for all members of our community. Thank you for your time, A Concerned Patron
