I'm writing to reflect my views on censorship in libraries. I do not believe that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive. I don't believe they should be removed because everyone has their own personal opinion on what's acceptable or not. Just because one person doesn't like something or feel that it's offensive doesn't mean that everyone is going to feel that way. What one person might not like, the next person might love and find deeply meaningful. The only way that I feel a certain material should be removed from the shelf is if there are many consistent complaints about the same specific material. Then maybe the library should consider reviewing and potentially removing the item. That's why they have ratings and different sections in the library so that a person can know what kind of book they're going to read or what kind of movie they're going to watch before they check it out. It makes no sense to go get a book or movie about something that you don't like or that you think is offensive, since there are many other things to choose from in a library's vast collection. How would someone feel if one of their favorite books or movies were being removed from the shelves of libraries because another person didn't like it? They would be upset and disappointed about the situation, feeling their access to culture was unfairly limited.  In conclusion, I disagree with the fact that certain materials should get removed off shelves if felt to be offensive. I hope that you will understand my point of view and take consideration of my thoughts on the importance of maintaining a diverse and accessible collection for all patrons.

I believe that certain materials, such as books, music, magazines, etc., shouldn't be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive. First, I know that people have different views upon things such as magazines, books, and music. And I also know that there are somethings that may be offensive to you, but they aren't offensive to other people. Such as music; there are all kinds of music out there. And I know that some people find rap music offensive and some don't. Because a lot of people that don't find it offensive relates to the stories and experiences within the lyrics.  Second, I feel that if the people that find it offensive would just ignore it then it wouldn't be a problem for the wider community. Because I know that maybe there is a type of magazine, book, or even a type of music that they listen to that is offensive to someone else; they might not find it offensive but I bet someone else finds it offensive. So for them to judge these things wouldn't be right when their own preferences might offend others.  Third, I'm pretty sure that if something in the library was too offensive or widely condemned, the library wouldn't have it in the first place based on their own selection policies. But maybe if we would take the time out and worry about our self instead of worrying about what's offensive and what's not then the world might be a better and more tolerant place. And yes I understand that people have different views but we shouldn't let that get to us and dictate what others can access.  So you can see, I believe that certain materials, such as books, music, magazines, etc., shouldn't be removed from shelves if they are found offensive. Because there are billions of people on this earth and I doubt they would all give you the same answer on what is acceptable. So many people have different opinions, and beliefs upon things, and a public library should reflect that diversity rather than suppress it.

According to Katherine Paterson, who wrote an article about censorship in the library, we must consider a fundamental question: should we have the right to take a book, magazine, movie, etc., off the shelf freely, whether we are offended by it or not? I believe we should not have that right to pull things off shelves freely. If we had that right, it would cause problems from many standpoints if you think about it carefully.  One significant problem it could cause involves people's personal thoughts towards a book, movie, CD, and so forth. If one person looks at a piece of media and decides, 'I don't like this and this about it,' and then just pulls it off the shelf, that is one less thing for somebody who does like it. Just because that person dislikes what the material offers to the public does not mean somebody else will feel the same. Nobody in this entire world is exactly the same; everybody has their own unique likes and dislikes. If everyone had the freedom to remove things they disliked, then there would eventually be nothing left for anybody to read, listen to, watch, or enjoy.  You also have to think about how that would affect the business of stores, libraries, and other establishments. If everybody is pulling everything off the shelves, what would there be left to sell or read? If a business is not making any money from its inventory, then it will likely have to be closed down. Especially in today's economy, no business wants to run low on money or face financial ruin due to such arbitrary actions.  In Katherine's article, at the end, she said, 'And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' That statement is basically reiterating what I said earlier about people's differing likes and dislikes concerning everything. If you don't want your kids or anybody else's kids looking at something you believe is offensive, you should take it up with one of the workers so they can consider moving it to a different section, like a section reserved for older kids and people. This is a more responsible approach.  It mainly falls on parents to decide what content they want their kids looking at. You are the ones to raise them the way you see fit. If you think they are too young for something, then that is when you tell them no or guide them accordingly. We should not have the right to take anything off of a shelf ourselves. Books, movies, music, and etc. are for entertainment and enrichment. If something does not entertain you, that does not mean it will not entertain or enrich somebody else. This principle is essential for a diverse and functioning society.

There are a ton of books out in the world that have a deep meaning and a sense of compassion. But, other books can have mean or hateful effects on the person who is reading them. Censorship, which involves taking books, movies, magazines, etc., off the shelves so a person cannot read or watch them, is a very positive thing in many circumstances.  In many cases, censorship is a great thing because it protects young readers from being exposed to hateful things at such a young and impressionable age. In libraries, the librarian should censor the books for younger people so they do not read the awful and hurtful things a book might be saying, thereby safeguarding their innocence.  Like books, music, movies, and magazines should be censored, too. Some music has a very catchy beat to it and could easily get stuck in a young person's head. This might cause an effect on that child, and they might start to act like that or want to become like the person the song is describing, which could be a negative influence.  Movies should also be censored appropriately. When I was little, my parents did a good job of censoring things that were bad for me to watch at that age. I barely had any nightmares because I was never exposed to that kind of frightening material when I was a child. On the other hand, my friend's parents were not the best at censorship and allowed her to watch or read whatever she wanted. She had many nightmares from the movies or books that she consumed, which shows the potential harm.  Now since I am older, my parents are starting to let me watch and read more mature things. In my experiences with this type of material, I have had some nightmares and have personally been offended by some books. Although censored books might have a great story behind them, the material that supports it can cause a dispute between different people who have different beliefs and values.  Thousands of books are censored each year for these very reasons. Many of them have to do with different religions or races that people have strong and differing opinions on. Libraries need to censor books to protect the innocent minds of young children from content that is not suitable for their development and understanding. This protective role is a vital function of responsible institutions.

Different people have different types of genres of books, music, movies, etc., that they like as well as those they don't like. Meaning that it is up to you what you like, and you are never forced to read or listen to anything you do not want to. Books, music, and other entertaining things are here as an option, so if you do not like something, then you do not have to deal with it; you can simply choose something else.  I feel that it is completely unnecessary that books should be removed from the shelves just because someone has gotten offended by its content. You were never told that it is a must to read that specific book, and it was not the company's nor the author's fault that you rented the book and felt insulted. Most likely, there was no one directing the story towards you personally, so why get all worked up over something that has happened to you and take it out on the media? You chose it of your own free will. Why make the company lose investment over something that could be easily taken care of by simply taking the item back to where you got it from?  I have read many books, listened to many songs, and seen lots of movies that were not in my best interest or to my taste, but I did not make them stop selling them because I am pretty sure someone out there likes it. Why stop someone else's enjoyment because of my personal disinterest or dislike? It is really not that necessary. And that is a problem in the world today; people take little situations and turn them into a big catastrophe for no good reason. If you do not like something, then do not get it. People need to put their feet in the company's shoes and realize that if it was their product, they would understand the frustration.  Books, magazines, music, movies, etc., are made for everyone in the world to provide entertainment for those who are interested. Taking them off the shelves would be more than unnecessary just because one person does not like the content. People have different opinions about life, and that is what makes every individual different from one another. So why ruin other people's fun just to get what you want? It is a selfish act that disregards the diversity of public taste.  As I stated before, it is not necessary to remove an item from the shelves because someone has taken offense to something within it. It is not the company's fault for providing a variety of choices, so just simply do not buy it or take it back if you are dissatisfied. Things would be so much better if everyone followed this simple principle. Get the items that best fit you and leave the others that do not on the shelves for those who will appreciate them. This is the fairest approach for everyone involved.

Should offensive or graphic books be removed from the library? Well, in my point of view, I think books, music, movies, magazines, etc., are amazing, exciting, and fun to read or watch, and they should not be removed from the shelves in the local library. For a fact, people in general have many types of tastes in books; there is drama, romance, action, and many other genres that also apply to movies, magazines, and etc. The public should not be punished for one person's interest in certain themes or how they interpret a book. There should be an age limit which prevents kids from reading certain books, and those of age should be allowed to read whatever they please.  I, myself, like to read scary books; they give me chills and all types of questions run through my brain. Someone else from my community could have the same train of thought I have when reading a scary book and find the same thrill. Without books that fit our personality and interests, there would be fewer people in libraries reading, and more people trying to keep themselves occupied, and half of them might even get bored and start committing crimes just to keep themselves occupied. People in the community have the right to read, hear, or watch whichever type of material they like and find engaging.  If people really do have a hard time with some of the material that is on display, they should not even pick it up to begin with. They should look for stuff they would enjoy, not just because a book is about 'violence' or they simply do not like the theme; they should not hold it against other people that might enjoy it. Books and other materials were meant for us to enjoy them, and they represent the authors' or directors' choice to share their stories with the world. Without books like those, many people cannot get ideas to help them create their own book or novel, stifling creativity.  So that is my view on the situation; people should be free to enjoy whatever material they like without fear of it being removed. But, if you are one of those people that think books, movies, magazines should be removed, I suggest you take a day and read a book or see a movie from your local library, and see how the experience might change your mind and broaden your perspective on the value of diverse media.

There are many types of reading materials for people to read in a library. You can find things on cars, trucks, sports, and made-up stories for fun. There are some materials in a library, though, that could be considered offensive by certain individuals. But should those materials be removed from the library entirely? Some think that they should, and others think that they should not be removed.  In my opinion, I do not think that things should be removed from a library outright. Certain people might find things offensive, and others might think it is perfectly fine to have in a library. I think there should be certain areas and age limits for certain materials a person could find in a library to help manage access appropriately.  I think that there should be age limits for certain types of reading material. People do not want a little child to read something that is meant to be for an adult, as that could teach kids bad things that they do not need to be reading about at a young age. I think that there should be an area set aside for kids that are in elementary to high school, and there should be a separate section that is specifically for adults. That way, kids are not accidentally reading things that are meant for a more mature audience.  I also think that there should be more signs that show more about what some books are about to guide patrons. For example, if there are books on sensitive topics like slavery, they should have a designated area for books about that subject so that people who are offended by it know to stay away from that section. The same principle could apply to magazines. I do not think they should be removed from a library if they are found offensive to some people because other people might enjoy reading them and find value in them.  Some reading material might be found offensive to certain people, but to others, it might not be offensive at all. I think things should not be removed from libraries simply because of individual complaints. There are some things that people might need to have in a library if they are doing a research project or school assignment, so that they have the necessary resources to do it properly and learn from a variety of sources.  I do think, however, that certain movies and music should be removed from shelves if little kids are allowed in the store or library area. Kids do not need to be watching adult movies while they are in elementary school; that just is not right. Especially if the movie is promoting sex, violence, and other things that young kids should not be exposed to or doing, it is better to restrict access.  So, in my opinion, there are some things that should and should not be removed from a library. Music and movies that promote things that young children should not be doing are candidates for removal or restricted access, while magazines and other reading materials should be kept away in areas where only adults can get to them, ensuring a balanced and responsible environment for all patrons.

I do not believe that censorship should be an option for people that find a book, magazine, or movie offensive. I believe that if a person decides to take a book off the shelf because he/she is offended, they are obviously paranoid and imposing their personal views on everyone else. If a few cuss words are found in a book and a person doesn't want their children to read that book, then don't allow them to get it. Don't make all of the other people suffer. Censorship is an unnecessary solution to something that isn't even a problem. You know what they say, 'If it ain't broken, don't fix it.' First of all, people have a variety of opinions. Some people think that violence is ok and some people don't think it's ok. If one person decides to put a book off the shelf because they find it offensive, what will the next person think? They might find violence perfectly acceptable and they might allow their kids to read the book. Then it would create a big conflict and a cycle of control. Lastly, parents need to allow their kids to grow up and mature. They also need their kids to know the difference between right and wrong. If they don't read books or movies with violence or cuss words when they're young, what will they do when they discover it when they're older? As a child, it is a time to learn life lessons and begin to form clear distinctions between right and wrong. Shielding your children from it will only hinder their progress in figuring things out and learning to think for themselves as adults. Censorship is the same thing that dictators did to prevent people to think for themselves and discover that his tactics were a great evil to society. In other words, censorship is part of fascism and should not even be considered in a free society. The citizens of this country have the responsibility of exposing the truth and teaching our children the differences between right and wrong. It's one of the ideals that help make this country great and censorship directly undermines that foundational principle.

Each book in a library bears its own relation to each person that enters that library. Whether the books relate well or poorly to each person is not something for a mass of people to decide. Every person has a different outlook on what makes a story interesting. There will not ever be a book that every human being agrees to be both appropriate and vivacious. Designed with distinctly different minds, people want to read distinctly different books, written by distinctly different authors. People should maintain a right to choose which books he or she wants to read. Never, will one book bind the world. Minds of human beings are too complexly separated. For example; reading 'The Great Gatsby' by F. Scott Fitzgerald in my English class last year was more than appropriate, though rather boring for the majority of the class. Books of racism, religion, and sexual content intrigue a person's mind, or otherwise disgust one's. Finding satisfactory books for everyone in a community to agree simply will not ever be done. There will always be that one person who declines to agree. It is a choice. It is a choice for each person to read what he or she wants to read. If you force something upon a society of readers, then what will they have left for their own minds' freedom? Face it, forcing an atheist to read an emotionally comprehensive novel of the Christian faith will not be stood for by the reader. Cursing, to some people, brings a book to a realistic point. To others, however, it draws them further and further away from the story. A choice should remain a person's right; especially to read a book written to be read. Finding an appropriate book is not the problem. That has yet to become the problem. The only problem is finding appropriate books that are both compelling and enthralling. I find 'Lolita in the Rye' to be dangerously inappropriate. However, it captivates my mind beyond other dimensions. Others that I know choose not to read it because of the offensive content. Do I find it offensive to some? No, but I understand where others could find it offensive. There is no way to approve a book to not be offensive, because it is not offensive to every person who reads it. To reiterate, the mind of human is a unique one, that identifies with no other. To sum up the full idea of this position; every person should be given the choice to read what he or she desires. Give each person the choice, and the rebellion will settle down. Removing a book from a shelf just puts the craving in the hearts of certain people to read it; sometimes completely rebelliously. Katherine Paterson is extremely correct by saying that taking a book from a shelf everytime someone wants one banned will not leave books for anyone. As a person, I am well associated with my mind, and it desires the freedom of choice. Every human mind desires the freedom to choose. Give people the choice. Remove no books from a shelf, and let the outcome draw in whoever is interested in whatever they might be interested in. Let readers have their freedom and the right to choose for themselves.

Many people have many different thoughts and beliefs. Some people might believe that a movie or song needs to be removed, but others might disagree, and nobody wants the things they enjoy to be taken away. If there was a book on a shelf in a bookstore that you didn't agree with and thought should be removed, and you removed it, then you are taking away from someone who might enjoy that book. If everyone removed things from life that they didn't enjoy, then there would be very little to enjoy, and our cultural landscape would become barren. For example, I personally love horror movies. I love the thrill you get from a horror movie and how they can make you jump even though it's just a movie screen. I'm sure there are people in this world who think horror movies are wrong. If those people were allowed to just remove them forever, I, and many other people, would be sadly dissapointed. I also love video games. If people could take video games away because they didn't agree with them, i would be crushed. I am also aware that people might just be worried about their children watching movies, listening to songs, or reading books that are not appropriate for them. I understand that the parents want their children to be supervised, but removing the books, movies and songs is not exactly the answer. Movies and books can easily be censored through existing tools. Parents can also supervise their children when they download music onto an ipod or phone, and depending on where they are bought, books and magazine's may require parental consent. Video games also require parental consent depending on the rating of the game. We can't just go around removing everything we dont like, because it is not fair to those who do like it. We live in a world with many different ideas, thoughts and beliefs, and we all need equal right to share them and access the media that reflects our diverse interests.

Censorship is a growing problem in today's world of literature. Censoring does not always allow the author to thoroughly convey his or her ideas as they were originally intended to. Katherine Paterson says that if we were all allowed to eliminate things that we thought were wrong, then there would be nothing left to be right about. Censoring leads to an ignorant, opinionless, and clueless society. In the novel 'Fahrenheit 451' censorship is one of the main themes of the story. Bradbury portrays the burning of books as the way of ending all controversial opinions. Montag finds that the burning of books has led the society that he lives in to be ignorant of what is going on around them. The government has tried to rule out all causes of controversial opinions in hope that it would make for a happier society. When in reality, members of the world are not happy and are consistently showing the reader that they do not know how to be happy. Montag decides that he wants to learn, but he does not know how. The brain is a muscle, if it is not exercised correctly, it becomes weak and useless. So when he tries to memorize a part of the Bible, he cannot retain what he has been reading. Such as trying to fill a sieve full of sand, he does not know how to learn. The members of this novel's society are basically opinionless on what is happening in their world. What they are told on the television is thought of to be factual, and that is what they do all day. In school, kids are being fed fact after fact and are expected to agree with what they are being told with no questioning involved. In a normal society, learning leads to questioning. But for them there is no learning, just accepting. And acceptance leads to contentment, which in the end leads to unhappiness. The society in 'Fahrenheit 451' proves to be oblivious to everything that is going on in many different ways. To them, death is not a big deal. Clarisse was killed by a speeding car, and Mildred, Montag's wife, was not even shocked to hear it. Another example is when Montag was running from the police, and a car full of rambunctious teenagers attempted to run him over just because they wanted to. At the end of the novel, Montag is walking along the railroad tracks with his new friends and the entire city is blown to dust by bombs dropped by fighter planes. The city had no idea that this was going to happen, they were clueless to the war that was going on around them everyday! A clueless society is a useless society, and in the end they were destroyed. Censorship lies within the hands of the viewer. Censorship has become such a big problem in the world when there are so many other things people should worry about. Reading about somebody doing drugs will not make a child want to do drugs, it crosses every teenager's mind at least once. But instead of not allowing them to even realize that it is out there, parents should do what they signed up to do, teach your kids right from wrong and hope that you did it well, because that is the true safeguard against ignorance.

She simply understood that he wanted to check out and return one. As she was checking him out she was making small talk and asked, 'How did you like your book, sir?' He replied ' It wasn't what I expected. It was completely inappropriate. ' As they discussed a little more it turned out that there were tons of curse words throughout the entire book. This is one example of how people don't know what to expect when they read a book. I don't think that libraries should remove materials off the shelves that people have complained about. They should simply do something to let people know what to expect when they read the books, magazines, or watch the movies. Some people may not mind reading a book with a few curse words here and there, but others may find it outrageous. Libraries spend their money to buy these books for the communities. Television, news, drama, life, and controversy. These are just a few of the things books are written about. Some subjects are considered to be vulgar and innappropriate for young audiences. Many people believe that their children have a right to learn about all the things books can offer, but is that really such a good thing? Books have been an important tool for students for a long time. However, not all books should be considered appropriate for all audiences. Stories about knights and princesses are great for young people, but other stories about the darker sides of life are normally kept away from the hands of children. Books are censored for all sorts of reasons, from profanity to challenging themes. Some of these reasons are frivelous and should not keep a book from reaching it's full potential and audience. The truth is that there is a line that should not be crossed, and some books cross this line, and are banned, which is understandable for extreme content. Great. However, some books do not 'cross the line' and are banned regardless of their merit, which is a problem. Honestly, careful consideration must be taken before the decision is made to ban a book or to leave it on shelves, weighing its value against its potential harm. If a book is written with only minor obscenities by a recognized author, and it is banned, then the author faces no serious pressure as the banning will be well known and consumers will still purchase the book just for a chance to read it, often increasing its notoriety. However, if an author who is relatively unknown writes a well-put-together piece that contains a few spots where the author may have made a somewhat vulgar reference, and the book is banned, the author is in serious trouble, their career potentially ruined. This author can no longer have the luxury of having their book in libraries so that their work can be recognized by a wider audience. Banning books is hindering authors everywhere from being able to make a name for themselves and share their unique perspectives. Books that are especially vulgar should definitely be banned to protect the innocent. No child should be reading a book that has an intended audience of purely adults, with graphic and mature content. Children should be protected from such material, and book banning provides this service, creating a safer environment. If a child has a burning desire to read a book, they can simply ask their parents to buy it for them, assuming the parents agree that filthy books should be okay for children to read, thus placing the decision back in the family's hands. If a book can provide good discussion in a classroom setting, and is mostly 'clean', then it should certainly be available for everyone to learn from. Just because a book contains a few areas where innappropriate references are made doesn't mean that students shouldn't be able to read the book and benefit from its overall message. If the learning material a book offers 'outweighs' the negative effects the book might have on a student, then the book should be available for students to read and critically engage with. However, because one cannot effectively compare knowledge and harmful effects, this is a difficult statement to make and requires nuanced judgment. Honestly, it is too difficult to say whether small problems in a book should be considered vulgar enough to ban a book entirely from public access. Many books should not be as available as others, but using a new system to find which books to limit would be too difficult and subjective, and keeping the current one would make more sense than any other alternatives, despite its flaws. In the end, a system that caters to the most sheltering of parents is the best one, as it errs on the side of protecting children from potential harm.

Censorship in Libraries Censorship in libraries is a significant problem in today's society; many people get angry at libraries and markets because of the items that they have on display for the common consumer. If the consumer walks into a library and is looking for a book to read, what if they come across a book from the early 1900s? In these times there were lots of words used that are considered 'harmful' to our people today, but what most people don't understand is that these words that are harmful had different meanings and contexts in that time in history. So when someone picks up a book and finds harmful or inappropriate words or phrases in them, they instantly get the wrong idea about the book's intent. And then, this small group of people who don't like this piece of literature, go against the vast majority of people who really do understand the literature, and the feeling and dialect of the book. That is where I am going to explain to this small group of people a few details that they should keep in mind when trying to rip a book off of the shelf and throwing it away. When someone goes into a store or library and starts to look for a book, they might come across a piece of literature that they don't completely agree with. When this person comes across this piece of literature, all they have to do is put it back on the shelf and move on to another selection. Nobody is forcing that person to read this book, so why make a big deal about its presence? Because most people who make a big deal about some of the word usage in a book don't quite understand the dialect of the book, or the time period the book was written in. If you do not understand the literature completely, then I ask that these people do not make a big scene out of it, and that they don't try to revoke the author's rights to have that piece of literature on the shelf for others. Authors have just as many rights as we do. If they write literature, a poem, novel, or even a short story, these authors have the right to have it published and put on the shelf for public access. So why would we not have the same rights to create? If we don't agree with some of the literature that is being placed in our society's schools, stores, and homes, then we can write a novel, a newspaper article, or even make a website about your topic to express a different view. You can make web polls and much more to gauge public opinion. This is a more indirect and civil approach to challenging a piece of literature. If you want to have a better chance of this book or novel to be removed from the shelves, you can use a poll or have people vote, to receive other people's opinions, and use these in your argument. If you have more than one opinion on a subject, you might have a more likely chance of winning your argument through democratic means. And this will cause a lot less chaos and negative attention to be drawn to yourself and others around you. Another reason why I don't think that people should be able to choose what is on the shelves of libraries everywhere is that I do not think that anybody from anywhere should be able to come into a library and permanently remove a piece of literature. Because, in today's society, we have researchers working all of the time, and we have so many people working on different theories and laws that require historical context. So if we take one important book off of the shelf, maybe a book written in the 1800s about evolution, and we get rid of all of these books, what will happen when we really need that information for a new study? These scientists might need that piece of literature to test a theory, and if that piece of literature is expelled from the shelves, then we could miss out on a large variety of major information that could help out someone in the future with a critical discovery. So the more information we take off of the shelves, the less we will have in the future to help us with our problems and understanding. So, now that I have told you all of my opinions on this subject, I hope that you will have a better view on the censorship of libraries everywhere. And that maybe someday all books and pieces of literature will be able to remain on the shelves, being endlessly read by consumers who can decide for themselves what is valuable.

Curse words, alcohol, drugs, pornographic pictures. These are all things you would not like your children to use, see, or do. They are out in the world and there is nothing that you can do to stop their existence entirely. People do drugs and drink everyday, but just because someone sees you doing it doesn't mean they will automatically imitate the behavior. People should not be completely shielded from the real aspects of life, as this can be counterproductive. When shielded as a child they would not know what to do if the chances came to them to do drugs or drink; they might not even know what the right or wrong thing to do is when faced with such choices. Kids to a certain age deserve to know what's going to happen in the real world when they grow up and start a life on their own. It won't happen to everyone but they need to know these things to be prepared. It is important for parents to let their children know what is right or what is wrong through guidance and conversation. As an adolescent, they are very vulnerable to all the bad stuff that life can bring, and seeing these things in books, movies, magazines and etc. will effect their life in some way, either positively or negatively. It is ultimately the parents' job to show them the right path and provide a moral framework. A thing that helps these parents are restrictions on the stuff that you are able to get your hands on, which provide a basic level of protection. On movies there are age restrictions that enable people at a certain age to be able to watch and people that are within those guidelines to have access, which helps filter content. With other materials like books, music, and magazines, there is no universal way to deny access to people to see or read them, so parents just need to be observant of their children and see what they do and engage with. Censorship is normally a bad thing as it limits freedom, but in other situations it could help by providing a buffer. For people that are more vulnerable to those situations or seeing those things, it could greatly help with some people and show them that it is not right or acceptable behavior. As much as people should be open and be able have access to this information, it is also important that other people who might be harmed did not see it. It is still an open debate with valid points on both sides, but, in my opinion, widespread censorship should not be done. Everyone has their own right to get and see the things they want, and personal responsibility should be emphasized.

In libraries and bookstores worldwide books are written and published with subject matter ranging from odd or inappropriate, to serious or violent. These books are written to target emotions in the reader that spark excitement and humor, horror and empathy among many others. However, though these books are made for a specific purpose, it is sometimes unclear as to how the book is appropriate for the eyes of a young reader, or even a mature reader with certain sensitivities. These books can appear unappealing and offensive to some. However, though they don't appeal to you as a reader, how could this book be censored without the unanimous disapproval of everyone? Censorship of these books is unjust because of the right of free speech and press, because all subjects are deserving of being written about, and most importantly because target audiences deserve books written in their interest regardless of their approval by others. The first reason that there should be no censorship of novels and works of literature is because writers deserve the freedoms of speech and press as fundamental rights. They are allowed to voice their own opinions and write about the subject matter that they are most interested in or passionate about. Though many times they have used subject matter that is highly provocative or inappropriate for some, they still have the capacity and the legal ability to write about what they wish and believe. To stop them from writing their own opinionated stories is similar to the censorship of books in Nazi Germany, which was a dark period for intellectual freedom. Millions of books were burned and hundreds, if not thousands of writers were executed for conveying opinions in their work that conflicted with the ideas of their government. Even though there are books not written for all ages they are still deserving of a reader who can appreciate them. The next reason that books should not have censorship is because new ideas often cover topics that have never been discussed before, pushing boundaries. Books and stories are meant to push the mark of what has been written and what can be written in the future. The vast variety of literature is the primary reason why it is so popular and enduring across cultures. For thousands of years, written text has been a way to understand and connect with cultures and people through written language and shared stories. And though stories may not be written in a manner that would be appropriate for a child, it doesn't mean that the story shouldn't be written or read by anyone. Its use should simply be monitored so that only those capable of accepting or understanding its message are capable of reading it with context. Lastly, censorship is simply unjust because without it there is a better chance to discuss and attempt to describe stories that target a vast crowd of people with different interests. Though the materials found in a story might be horrific to a parent, it might be a preferred form of literature for a different group of people, such as adults who enjoy complex themes. And to limit the literary subjects that people prefer could be paralleled with limiting a person's voice of opinion and personal choice. It simply isn't reasonable to allow only a single category of work, with only a few varieties of messages, for only a select group of people who meet a certain standard. Variety is what separates a person's opinions, and makes their being different than another's, which is a strength of a free society. Therefore, censorship of literature should not be enforced or encouraged. Writing topics should be open to all people, because whether they are offensive or not they convey a purpose and a perspective. And because writers have the right to illustrate their points through a literal medium, there should never be a limit on these rights that stifles creativity. That is why censorship should never be able to remove a piece of literature from any shelf and limit access to ideas.

You both are allowed to decide what you do and don't like. You both get to choose what books you read, what movies you watch, and what music you listen to. So why should we let anyone stop us from being ourselves? You can never say that any one thing is offensive to everyone because no one person can be everyone. Well you may not, but someone else somewhere is trying to take that out of the libraries because they have a negative opinion about it, but is that fair? Ultimately, the diversity of available materials is what makes a library a valuable resource for an entire community with varied tastes and perspectives.

Censoring certain things in a library would not be that good of an idea. Certain people can handle talking about certain subjects. Its not always a good thing to censor offensive subjects. My parents did the same thing, but they had different opinions on what was okay for me to read and what wasn't. Grandma wanted me to get religious books and my parents were okay with that and things like 'The Cat in the Hat', and 'Harry Potter'. Even at home, everyone's opinion is very different. For instance, when it comes to music at my house; my dad likes country, my mom likes metal, my brother likes alternative, my uncle likes rock, and I like a combination of all of it. That just goes to show how different people have different opinions; some more strict than others. If we relied on people's opinions to keep our libraries free of offense, there would be nothing in it, proving that a one-size-fits-all approach to censorship is unworkable.

If you take any of these books off the shelves that would be like taking away some of our childhood. That wouldn't be the nicest thing to do. Even if you did take some of them off then what would we show our children when they ask what was your favorite book as a kid? We will have to tell them that the library doesn't have those books anymore. They had to make room for other books. So if you would please understand, we got to read all of our parents' favorite childhood books, and we want to share that same joy. I mean how would you feel if you couldn't share that with your kids? I would be upset because my parents told me and I went out and got them from the library and I loved them too. These stories connect generations. So please, if you can, leave the books alone and allow future children to discover the same magic we did.

What is a library? A library is a place you go to that has books, movies, music, magazines, etc. With these things a person can do research or use for entertainment. Should there be censorship in libraries? In my opinion there should be very little censorship in a library. If there was a complaint about being offended by something in the library and it was removed from the shelf, there would be nothing left to use in the library. Many people like to go to the library to relax and have some good peace and quiet time and while there at the library they let their minds flow, imagine, and dream. They don't worry about being offended by a particular type of book. However censorship in a library can be a good thing if used delicately. For example, moving grown up books to a section where children will not read them and have nightmares about a picture they saw in it. What I'm trying to say is have censorship in the library, but at a very low standard. If a library had high censorship and everything was taken off the shelf what is the point of going to the library, it would be an empty room. If someone is offended by something in the library, depending on how severely they were offended take the appropriate measures. For instance if something just offended someone unintentionally leave it where it is, but if something offends someone intentionally by their race, ethnicity or something like that, it would then be appropriate to take it off the shelf. Having low censorship in libraries would be good because there would be a good quantity of stuff for you to do your research on and there would be more topics to choose from to let your imagination soar. While at the same time you would not have to worry about being severely offended, creating a balanced environment for all patrons.

Censorship in Libraries To remove something a person dislikes off of a shelf is assuming other people's opinions do not count. It really has to depend on what the product is, such as a book, a magazine, a music album, or a movie. Usually, in any store I've walked into, there are certain departments for each product. In these separate departments, the product is always categorized, not based on what people like, but by genre or age differences. If a person was to linger away from their section in that department and go to another part, their taste in their product will seem too different to like, but that does not mean the other section's items are without value. A local library in a person's community will have many books to read and to choose from. There are baby books, kids sections, and teenage and adult sections as well. The teenage section is for me! Although I used to always be in the kids section not that long ago, those books should not now be removed just because I have no use for them or wouldn't be interested in picking another one up. Yet that is just me. However, the generation under me will soon love them and find them just as engaging as I once did. Just because one person dislikes something, doesn't mean it should be thrown out for everyone else. Music is a different story. Some people like country and some people like alternative. In libraries, they have all types of music albums that a person can listen to before they rent it out. When I listen to one album to see if I like it and find out that I don't, I simply put it back on the shelf and try another one. The librarian doesn't throw it away because of my opinion, because to someone else it would be the sweetest music to their ears. That album might be another person's favorite. Anyone can watch any type of movie in my opinion. Yet not all parents allow their twelve year old to watch a rated R movie. For them, it's only PG-13 movies. This is how I grew up. Now that I am allowed to watch whatever my heart desires, I've noticed that movies are based on maturity levels. In libraries, some movies aren't allowed to be rented by a younger person, yet it doesn't mean they should be tossed out. When they are older they might actually like them and appreciate having access to them. Overall, a person's opinion will be the most important one to them, and other opinions won't matter as much. Products in a library are for anyone to view, not to judge for removal. If absolutely everyone did judge the products negatively, there wouldn't be any left for anyone to enjoy, defeating the library's purpose as a resource for the entire community.

I believe that it is unfair to ban any sort of materials from the library. It simply isn't right to withhold information from your children. Any information that they might read or hear is something that they are going to find out sooner or later anyway. Wouldn't you much rather your children find out from reading it in a book or magazine or hearing it in a movie or CD? Then they can ask parents any questions that they might have about things they have read and heard, instead of hearing it from a teenager in the hall or talking to a friend about it and being misguided and given the wrong information from an unreliable source. If your child is to read about sex or an affair in a magazine, wouldn't you like to know about it? Would you want them to ask you questions about it so that they understand the difference between right and wrong in a safe environment? Wouldn't it be much easier to know that your child is educated on certain things so that they know when things are false and they're not confused or worried about something small that could be easily explained? Any of the things that they might read in a magazine or see in a movie are things that they could easily look up on the internet. On the internet there are more graphic photos, and some websites give false information on subjects, which can be more dangerous. Your child's curiosity could take them to inappropriate websites with just a few clicks, which is far less controlled than a library's curated collection. When I was a child and I was curious, my parents sheltered me from certain things. I found out what kinds of things they were trying to hide from me while I was only in second grade when high schoolers on my bus told me all about sex, showed me pictures, and told me things that I would have much rather heard about in class or read in a book. I felt like I couldn't talk to my parents about these things. I mean, what would you do if your second grader came home from school and started talking to you about the kinds of things that they had heard on the bus? What if the high schoolers had been lying to me? I would feel stupid for saying anything about it because my parents wouldn't have understood what I was talking about without the proper context. What I'm saying is that I understand that there are some things that a child should never be allowed to read, see, or hear, but it isn't fair to them that they don't get the opportunity themselves to learn about it and ask questions in a guided way. Besides, isn't it your fault in all reality if they get their hands on something inappropriate for their age because they aren't getting the proper supervision at the library or at home? If you feel that they are reading, listening, or watching something that you feel is inappropriate, ask them questions about it. Explain things to them when they ask you a question, and don't beat around the bush. Make sure that they know the difference between good and bad, right and wrong. It truly is not fair to take these materials away from them when they don't even know why they are not allowed to look at it, which only fuels their curiosity further.

No, because all people like to read different books. Some of the books that people want taken off bookshelves are considered to be part of history or important literature. Books help people advance in their reading skills and also help them find new things out about the world. When I was in middle school I always liked to read Stephen King and R.L. Stine books. When I asked the librarian if they had any of their books they said no. They thought that kids in middle school shouldn't be reading books with cuss words in them and violence. I don't think it should matter what kids read because you can't make a kid read something that he's not interested in, because everybody is different and all people like different types of books. There are all kinds of books; for example, there are mystery books, fiction books, non-fiction books, historical books, etc. The books you use in classrooms are considered books, but they're not books you read everyday for fun. I think parents should take their kids to the public library to get a book they are genuinely interested in. When I was in elementary and through junior high we had to take reading tests on the computer. In seventh and eighth grade we had to sit around the room and take a book and read it for part of the hour. We also had a challenge in middle school to see which school could read the most books. That was part of our grade in our English class. It was never a problem for me because I loved to read. Now, there are some books that libraries should take off the shelves, for example any book that involves nudity or lots of violence. Now that's just for kids that are under the age of thirteen, as a general guideline for age-appropriateness. Now there aren't that many books out there for little kids to read that are challenged; there are more adult books than little kids books that face censorship attempts. All I have to say is that you should watch what your kids read, but don't keep them from reading books because that will affect them later on in life. If they don't like to read, persuade them to try it with a book on a topic they love. I also think that more kids would read if they seen their relatives reading too, setting a good example. Just remember, kids and adults of all ages, reading is a good thing no matter what you decide to read, as it opens up new worlds and ideas.

In this persuasive essay I'm going to write about why or why not offensive material should be banned from library shelves, and there are a couple reasons that are going to help me do that. I think that we shouldn't take anything off the shelves in libraries. My first main point why we should not take any material off the shelves in libraries is that there is some material that people might find offensive that others do not, and they are getting affected by those who do want these materials removed. I think that some of the movies and books that are taken off the shelves could be material that some kids should experience, as it might help them understand complex issues in the future. My second main point is that if we do take all of the offensive material off the shelves, there would only be movies and books like Bambi and Scooby-Doo left, because all material in libraries could be considered offensive to people in some ways different than others. I have not found a movie or book in any library yet that I have found personally offensive, as I understand that taste is subjective. Also, if we do remove all so-called offensive items, we might as well not even have a library, because there would only be about ten movies and books in the whole building, because of all of the offensive material that people could find in CDs, books, and movies if they look for it. People hear cuss words probably everyday, whether it's at school or at home, so all of the words and actions in movies are not as bad as people in real life saying them in the school hallway. I just think of every movie and book as just a movie and a book, not as a direct instruction manual for life. Scary movies are not real, and some books are pure fantasy as well. There is sex and other inappropriate things in some movies, but that's also why you have to be a certain age to even get the movies, which is a system that already works to control access. To summarize what I was just talking about in the last couple of paragraphs, I think that we should not take anything off the shelves in libraries, because it will hurt others who want to access that material, and there's just no need in it when other solutions, like age ratings and good parenting, already exist to guide young readers and viewers.

When I walk into a library to look for a book, I would love to do so without seeing inappropriate books, movies, or magazines on open display. When I see that, I think, 'What if a child saw this?' I would like a library for my child to visit without me worrying about the things they could see accidentally. To fix this problem, the libraries could do a number of things that don't involve removing materials entirely. First off, the libraries could better censor what they put out on the selves by improving their organization. By putting the adult books section by the check out place, an employee at the library could easily find any small children wandering into that section and gently redirect them. If that solution does not work, then try and rate the sections like we rate movies, creating a clear and intuitive system. Put G-rated books and movies together, PG-rated books and movies together, PG-13 and R-rated books and movies together, and so on, so that families can easily find the area suited to their age group. One time, when I took my baby brother to the library, he decided to bring me an adult book with a nude woman on the cover and asked if he could check it out. I was shocked and embarrassed that it was so easily accessible in the children's area or on a low shelf. I did not think that that kind of thing would happen at a public library, but it did, highlighting the need for better organization. I believe that everyone should have the option of finding the book or movie of their choice, so I do not wish to have any inappropriate books or movies removed entirely from the library's collection. However, they should be placed in better order and in designated sections so that children are not going to see that kind of stuff during a routine visit, thus respecting both access for adults and the concern of parents.

There is a lot going on in society nowadays that badly influences children. They do not need to read about how guys rob places and are criminals. They do not need books and movies that make it worse on them and make them think bad things are good. If we do not filter what they do at a young age they will end up being hellions and out of control because they will think just because someone in a book or movie did it that it's ok for them to do it but it's not. Thoughts of Literature I feel as though offensive literary pieces should be able to be taken from libraries. If a piece of literature is particularly offensive; the piece should not be displayed for general access. From my own experience, controversy is the primary reason that books are stricken from libraries. All of my experience, observations, and reading have told me one thing. That one thing being, pieces of literature are taken away because of their offensiveness to certain groups or sensibilities. From the experience that I have had with books that cause controversy, I have noticed myself not liking the book and feeling uncomfortable. I believe that is the reason people do not like certain books in libraries; they find the content disagreeable or upsetting. Coming from someone who does not particularly like reading, I feel as though reading something that offends me puts me in a state of mind as though I would not like to read any longer. All of my experiences seem to point to not reading books that cause distress or controversy, as they hinder the enjoyment of reading itself. Of all that I have observed, I have found similar things as my experiences. I have seen people, classmates in particular, that do not desire to read because they feel that a novel has offended them or presented ideas they find objectionable. Though my observations this year seem one-sided, I truly have observed more lack of reading due to controversy than the increasing of reading due to controversy. All of my observations seem to point to supporting the revocation of 'banned books' to create a more comfortable environment. The piece that I have noticed most prominent to this topic that I have read would most definitely be Fahrenheit 451. In said novel society has outlawed all books. The story seems to heavily favor those who wish to read controversial novels, though we can take something from reading this book. The reading of this novel can be interpreted to favor my argument, as people lived happily without controversial books causing them distress. Granted not all people did, but that is because of certain variables and a desire for knowledge that ignored comfort. From stories, such as the three little pigs and the big bad wolf, we can understand how poorly the concept of controversiality is drawn. For instance, I was mortified hearing that the first time due to its violent themes. I have never had the interest of hearing it again, as I felt that the story is not politically correct and promotes fear. Pieces of literature are taken away because of their offensive properties. If someone has no interest in reading a book because of the thoughts maintained inside of the text; the book must be stripped from the public to maintain a peaceful and agreeable atmosphere. As it would only make sense to try to keep the peace and prevent discomfort, I for one support the cause to remove books from public places due to controversiality for the greater good.

People today always seem like they are trying to find something offensive. The problem with the library system is that it always feels like it needs to appease these people. The truth is that when you have as many people as there is in a country, there are going to be many different ideas, thoughts, likes, and dislikes, and it is impossible to please everyone. Libraries are places of knowledge. They keep many different books, magazines, and movies there, so that people with all different tastes can enjoy the library and find something that interests them. Most people, with books, figure out early what genre of books, which authors, and how long of books they like. So books are usually very hard to offend people, because most people can usually tell right away if they like the book or not and simply choose another. Magazines are like books in a way. People know what they want to read about. With magazines though, people usually just flip through the pages, and skim through articles looking for topics that catch their eye. They will keep skimming through the magazine, until they find that perfect article they want to read, and then they are content. Usually after that, they are done with the magazine and move on. Music has been around almost as long as mankind has been around. There is something about music that soothes the human body and soul. Music is one of those things that is constantly changing with time and evolving with culture. Before instruments, music was just purely voice, but as the centuries went on, music became more advanced and complex. Now it would be nice if there was just one type of music that everybody liked, but there isn't, and there never will be. There are so many types of genres of music, that it would be hard to find a person in this world that liked every type of music from classical to heavy metal. There are people who hate change. Likewise they don't like to change their favorite music types or try new things. But if people changed with time completely, then there would really only be a few types of music popular at once. But since there are many types of music, there is always going to be someone out there in the world that doesn't think that song shouldn't be played because they find it disagreeable. Just in the last century movies have came a long way in advancement. Movies use to be simple, they would have a simple plot, and everyone loved it for its innocence. But there are so many people who love to see technology advance, that they want movies to change and become more complex. Movies today are all about special effects, love, sex, alcohol, parties, fighting, and the list could go on and on, reflecting a wider range of human experience. Directors try to make the best movie possible, so its almost like they try to put just enough of one thing to keep the audience into the movie and engaged. But if they go overboard on a subject, that is when at least one person has a red flag go up in their head and think that is offensive or too much for them. Movies are supposed to be entertaining, not something people should get offended by, but enjoyment is subjective. Movies are good about it though; they have created a rating system to try give the audience a fair warning heads up, so that the audience knows what to expect in the movie before they even buy a ticket. It doesn't matter what it is, book, magazine, music or movie, there is always going to be someone who doesn't like it or is just offended by it, and that is a simple fact of life. There is nothing to do about that, and it's not a bad thing in itself. It's just simply means everyone in this world is not the same and has different tastes and sensitivities. So I think we can all come up with the conclusion that: just because one person doesn't like something, doesn't mean the next person will, and therefore we should not remove items just for causing offense.

Should books and such be removed off of the shelves if they are found offensive? Personally I don't think they should be. If there is something in the book that is remotely offensive towards children then it should be put under a section for adults only, not banned entirely. Most libraries I have been to have different areas for each age group, which is a sensible solution. If there is a book that is racially unacceptable then it should be put in the adult section not anywhere for children to accidentally find. When a book is being questioned if it is offensive or not they should review all the possibilities of how someone might comprehend the story to see their reaction with it and judge its context. There are many genres of books, music, magazines, etc., so there is always a place that the book can go to where it is more appropriate. Most of the questioning about a book is the language in it and whether it is necessary. For example, in class we just finished reading the book 'To Kill a Mockingbird.' There is a lot of question if the book should be read in schools or not because of the 'n-word' and its historical use. It is a very harsh word, but it goes with the setting and the background of the story, providing a valuable lesson. When someone is not sure if a book is acceptable or not they should take in consideration what the story is about and whether or not the word is needed or not for the narrative's purpose. In many cases the unacceptable thing might work along with the story to teach something important. If one book is being questioned about something wrong with it then shouldn't all books, music, movies, magazines, etc., be questioned under the same strict rules? If something is not allowed for one item then it shouldn't be allowed for something else, which would lead to endless censorship. It is all about the audience who reads that certain book if it is appropriate or not to the person reading it and their maturity level. I have read many books that have certain words that don't bother me, but someone else who isn't use to it might not like and that is their right. Some parents don't want their kids hearing foul language or inappropriate stuff from the type of music they listen to, so they should guide their own children. It all comes down to who reads the book or magazine, and who listens to the music, making it a personal choice. Katherine Paterson makes a very good point about how if we start taking the books off of the shelves then eventually there wouldn't be any books left on the shelves anymore due to differing opinions. Just because something has a bad word or phrase in it doesn't mean it needs to be taken away from peoples enjoyment and access to diverse ideas.

If you have been a child with parents who cared, then you have heard them say, 'No you can't play that game, you can't listen to that music, or you can not watch that movie.' When you asked why you were not allowed the same answer was always given, 'You're not old enough.' If you ever had the courage to ask why again they would most likely have said, 'Because if I wanted you to know then I would allow you to find out for yourself!', and that didn't get you anywhere now did it? It was simply a matter of parental guidance. Now I would like for you to think back on those things you were not allowed to do, and how now that you are old enough you can do those things and perhaps appreciate them differently. How would it change things if those movies, music, or games had been removed from the shelves before you had the chance to get to them as an adult? What would you and your friends have done if you didn't get to watch 'that one classic movie' that night because some parent or other individual had had it removed from the market because they found it offensive for their own family? I would also like for you to think about the child you might have or may plan to have, would you want your child to be subjected to such things as 'Scary Movie' or 'Superbad' as a ten year old? Most likely that answer is 'no', but what if, because they were found offensive, they were simply removed from existence entirely? Then they would never see them and to some that might be what's right, and for those of you who think that I have some news for you, those kind of movies are still made today and are widely available. 'Scary Movie' has been remade and is more graphic than before, and there are countless other titles that I could throw at you now that have some form of sexual themes, drug use, or foul language which are common in modern media. They still exist and are becoming more and more popular among movies watched by adults. There are many movies that will have some sort of sexual reference, a cigarette, or a bad word in them, reflecting real life. You might be able to get rid of a few titles through complaint, but would probably never rid the shelves of all of them because tastes vary so widely. But let's say that you did, that you were, in fact, able to throw away any title that contained these themes that you find objectionable. What would there be left to watch for anyone? If those movies do not exist any more, then what would your kids have to be able to watch when they are older, only children's cartoons and educational documentaries? Not only that, but what movies would you watch for your own enjoyment

I don't think that anything that gets checked out from the library should be censored. Some of the people that go to the library aren't looking for material with offensive language and/or themes; they are seeking knowledge or entertainment without such concerns. On the other hand, there are some people who go to the library who find that having offensive language spoken when it was meant to be is better than censoring it, as it preserves the creator's original intent and artistic integrity. Take for example a book about @PERSON1. It could have some things in it that people could find offensive. But if someone has to write a report on @PERSON1, it would be best to have as much information on him as possible, and censoring parts of the text could lead to an incomplete or biased understanding. I will make one compromise: if there is music being checked out with offensive language, they should provide it with both a clean and explicit version of the album, allowing the patron to make their own choice. There are ways that censorship can be good, and some ways that it could be bad. Some people find bad language and themes offensive, while others find that it gives freedom to the artist or author. I think that uncensoring things in the good and bad form is better than not uncensoring things at all, as it allows for a more authentic and comprehensive engagement with the material.

There are many books, music, movies, and magazines that people find offensive for various reasons. Some people even believe these things should be taken off the shelves permanently. First, people have vastly different views on what they find offensive based on their upbringing and beliefs. With people always having such different views and sensitivities, it is inherently difficult to take books, music, movies, or magazines off the shelves for everyone. Equally important, if every book, song, movie, and magazine that someone finds offensive is taken off the shelf, there would not be many books, movies, songs, or magazines left for anyone to enjoy. Author Katherine Paterson once wisely said, 'But if I have the right to remove a book from the shelf-that work I abhor-then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' She is saying that if every single book that offends someone is taken off the shelves, there would be no books left for anyone to read, which defeats the purpose of a library. People find different things offensive and if everyone acted on every offense, there would be nothing left for anyone. Finally, if someone finds a book offensive, they simply do not have to read it or engage with it. When someone finds a book, movie, song, or magazine offensive, they don't need to watch it or read it; they can choose to ignore it. Instead of taking it off the shelves for everyone, the person could just not read it and select something else more to their liking. Not everyone finds the same books offensive and taking them off the shelves could upset many people who enjoy or learn from them. When someone finds something offensive, they could just avoid that specific item instead of getting it removed and upsetting other people. If someone was offended by one of my favorite books, I would prefer if they just avoid reading it instead of taking it off the shelves so that I cannot read it anymore. Some people find many books, songs, movies, and magazines offensive and would like these things to be removed from the shelves permanently. I, however, do not believe that these things should be removed, as such actions can lead to a slippery slope of censorship. Taking these items off the shelves might make a few people happy, but it could also upset even more people who value access to diverse materials. Not everyone finds the same things offensive, and materials should not be taken off the shelves simply because a minority of people do not agree with them.

For example, a classic novel may have had racial slurs in it, but if one considers the time and place of the novel, these slurs were normal for the time, reflecting historical attitudes. Someone can not be frustrated with a novel written fifty years ago because it has something offensive in it by today's standards, as societal norms evolve. While I believe, for the most part, libraries should not censor or remove materials, there should be some restrictions set in place to keep extremely harmful materials out of libraries, such as those inciting violence. For instance, libraries should not have dirty magazines or explicit movies on their shelves, as they are not educational. If a high majority of people want a particular material banned, then it is hard to ignore their collective voice. When a book is so vulgar people begin to protest the book, there are questions as to whether the book should remain on library shelves, weighing public sentiment against free speech. When a high percentage of people join that cause, then it should be banned to maintain community standards and harmony.  Censoring or removing materials from libraries remains a hot topic today, with strong opinions on both sides. I believe the current system in place to censor or remove books does its job reasonably well, and that it should continue to be used. If few people disapprove of a particular material, the book remains on most shelves uncensored, allowing for access. When a lot of people begin to protest that same material, it has a high probability of being banned after a review process. Censorship; the aspect of removing offensive materials from the public eye. Is this the right thing to do? Should society as a whole take away variety? Do you believe our generation or future generations should not get to experience and understand what the past generations have? I believe censorship is wrong in every aspect, but I also believe that materials that are offensive, or inappropriate for certain ages can be controlled. Movie theatres, video stores, and television all do it. They use ratings and age control for their viewers. Now control can be difficult, and may not always work if not handled correctly. To handle this situation before it arises, the library can use a system like restaurants or bars use; such as, checking identification before letting a book that is 'R' rated or above be checked out. Different sections in the library can be available to certain age groups. Now you might be thinking; doesn't this idea take away from the liberties that libraries give us? Well you might be right, but would you rather have our children see violence and other inappropriate materials that they shouldn't? It would be just like the movie theatre. You would not need to buy a ticket, but the control of content would be phenomenal compared to what it is. Would you want your six year old girl picking up an adult violence movie, sexual content movies, or even a magazine with cursing in it? Why should the library offer things for children that parents would frown upon? I believe the library should be a place of learning and freedom, but the learning should be something age appropriate. Our society is maturing too fast for young children, why should the library take part in that?
