This being said why should public libraries be okay with stocking this material. Yes, media is everywhere. Movies, books, magazines, newspapers, music, and much more flash and sell more than they should. Media shows children things they shouldn't know about until they are young adults, but does this make it okay? Does it make is right for children to see and want all they want to? No, it does not. Fighting fire with fire only makes a larger fire. Why start our children out at a young age with violence, sex, and inappropriate material? Would you like to set your children up to fail? I know I wouldn't so why let our libraries hand out books, magazines, movies, and more to let our children thrive upon the culture they are stuck with? I do not think we should remove these books from our libraries because everyone has a different opinion, but I do believe that control needs to be put into place for our children's and other children's sakes. With that being said, censorship is overrated, but some of the material at the library are underrated, and that needs to be handled and controlled through sensible, age-based access systems.

Everyone has a favorite book. And some of us can't put it down once we read the first sentence. Then days later, the library takes it down and states that it's offensive to many people that have read it. Why should multiple people lose a good read just because someone doesn't like what they see? We're all trying to accommodate to everyone and their needs just to please them. Whatever they ask is done because we don't want a big scene. A majority of people think, 'That book is offensive! Take it down! Disgusting!'. But why? Everyone has a right to read what they want to read. No library should uphold to the needs of a minority about an 'offensive' book just because they say it's inappropriate. Who are we to judge what's good for everyone and what's not? Books are written for a reason, and that's to share the ideas of the author, not to corrupt society with their 'evil' and 'offensive' ideas that could potentially cause a child to rebel. That excuse is ridiculous. A parent should've taught their child to differentiate between right and wrong, and if they use the 'my child will become a rebel if they read this!' excuse, then they're not confident in their childs capability, or the fact that they taught their child well. Also, it's not just the readers getting angry, it's the author. How bad would someone feel if they spent a year or two on a fantastic book, just to have it banned from library after library? Probably angry or upset. Authors have the right to write whatever they want. If they wish to talk about dragons and princesses, so be it. If they want to discuss why we see a full moon when we do? Go right ahead. No one can stop great books from being made and they certainly shouldn't be able to stop people from reading it. If someone is offended by a book, then don't read it, simple as that. Parents like to protect their children from harms way and bring them up as fine citizens of the world. By having this desire, the parents do every little thing to make sure their son or daughter doesn't see, hear, or read anything inappropriate or 'bad'. This is just ridiculous. Controlling a childs life will just cause them to rebel more and more as they get older. Let children have a choice in what book they read, or the movie they watch. Parents need to teach their children right from wrong, and in doing so, letting them see, hear, or read whatever they want should be no problem. Without books, movies, and music, what would the world be like today? No one knows. Books are a great source of information, letting the author express themself as well. Movies are almost just as harmless, limits are needed, but overall? There should be no problem. Also, music allows the artist to bring out their side of creativity and emotion. Allowing that music, or movie, or book to be made, and then take it away is ridiculous. If it offends someone, then that person should just forget it, instead of taking it away from the people who love it and the person who made it, preserving the diversity of thought and expression for all.

I don't think there should be any censorship; good books and music shouldn't be removed just because one person finds them offensive. Because it's an artist's way of expression, and if people don't want to listen to what they are saying, then they should just not listen to it. Books, I think, shouldn't be taken offensively for the same reason music shouldn't; it's a writer's opinion and expression. It's like telling someone they can't voice their opinion on anything, like racism, or use curse words if they want to. Artistic freedom is essential for a vibrant culture, and silencing one voice sets a dangerous precedent for silencing all. Ultimately, the choice to engage with challenging material should rest with the individual, not with a censor.

To the Library Association Board: I am writing to you today concerning censorship in libraries. I have had a select few instances throughout my life where I have read a book or magazine that to some people seem offensive and to others not at all. However, I do have my own viewpoint on the situation, and I feel that it is my duty to inform you that I feel offensive books, magazines, etc., should be removed from the shelves. Everyone has grown up and been taught different values and morals that are important to them. They stand for these values, but at the same time respect that other people have the right to believe differently than they do. With the world the way it is now, violence can erupt from the simplest of things. Putting books on public shelves for the public to read can very easily cause outbursts and debates between people who have opposite opinions. Offensive books and magazines put out for the public is asking for something bad to be a result, creating unnecessary conflict. My suggestion to you is to remove these offensive books. This will create a safe and happy environment for all who visit public libraries and other public places. It will create fewer arguments between adults and set an example for younger children who are observing their parents' behaviors. Children follow in their parents' footsteps. Observing bad behaviors from the parents due to offensive books does not teach the child how to act in a responsible way if they were put in this position. When our children grow up, we want them to behave in a responsible way. Offensive books not being put on shelves will hopefully create a healthful environment for appropriate behavior and mutual respect. As a student, I want to grow up in a world that has people who are respectful, happy, and responsible. I want people to get along with each other. I feel that taking offensive books off shelves will help with this somewhat peaceful world I would like to live in. Violence can be created through anything, and I feel that offensive books should be the last thing added to that. Without offensive books for the public to read, we will create a better environment for the people living today.

The content of a library should be full of various material even if one person finds certain materials offensive. Just because someone might think a material is offensive, does that mean we just ignore the subject, forgetting it altogether? Some subjects can be awkward to talk about, read about, or even think about, but that doesn't mean we should ignore them. One subject that can be awkward to read about is sexually transmitted diseases. You often see people walking through the library skimming through the aisles, once in a while opening a book to see what it's about, but when they come to the section on sexually transmitted diseases they just walk on by, too uncomfortable to be seen in the area. It's not a subject that people normally read for fun, but everyone should be aware of it for their own health and knowledge. There are many subjects like this that everyone should be aware of, even if you think it doesn't affect you directly. Another reason to keep all books in the library is to be informed of history. Some history can be gruesome and completely crazy, but we should be aware of those things and not forget about them. The Holocaust, for example, was a very dark period in history. Over six million people died because just one person didn't like what they believed in. It's sometimes hard to read about, but you should be aware of what happened in the past no matter how depressing it is. We should be aware to prevent another event like that from happening again. People's likes in music vary greatly. There are so many different types and styles of music. Some music might be offensive to other people, but does that mean you should get rid of it at the library? The library should always have a large variety of different music to cater to diverse tastes. Often people would like to widen their music intellect, and the library is the perfect place to do that by exploring new genres. Everyone is different; we never all like the same thing. Taking materials from the library to avoid the subject doesn't stop someone from finding that information elsewhere. If people wanted information and they couldn't find it at the library, they would most likely find another way to get that information, perhaps from less reliable sources. Having a variety in books, music, movies, and magazines is what makes the library what it is: a place to learn new things, no matter the subject.

You're watching a movie on TV that you and your friend have seen in theatres. You both love the movie and just as it gets close to the best part, the TV skips over that part because people think that scene is inappropriate. Censorship is good for protecting audiences, but sometimes it is too strict when it comes to movies, music, and books, altering the original artistic vision. Some of the movies that are popular will end up on TV for the viewers' entertainment, but some movies have scenes that are a little inappropriate, and even though it's not that offensive, the TV companies will cut that scene out of it. Also, if there is bad language in the movie, they will take that word out and replace it with another word that makes no sense with what the movie is trying to say, which can disrupt the flow and meaning. Censorship tends to ruin the movies that most people love by creating a fragmented viewing experience. The TV companies even censor historical movies, which is particularly problematic. If it's a historical movie, it shouldn't be censored because it takes away from the true story and the historical accuracy that the filmmakers intended to portray. Music is another item that tends to get censored quite often. The library is meant to be a place that is filled with materials of all different genres and types. Many of us go to the library because we are looking for something in particular, rather than just browsing for entertainment. Although some materials that people need to research at the library might be considered inappropriate for certain audiences, it still serves as a useful resource for others who require that information for legitimate purposes. This could include getting information for a research paper, renting a movie that needs to be watched for a school project, or looking for a certain type of book to read for personal growth. By taking certain books, music, movies, or magazines off the shelves, we are limiting the amount of materials for people to borrow and hindering their access to knowledge. At many schools, students are asked to write research papers on a wide array of topics. What is considered a valid subject for a high school research paper might include information that is not suitable for all groups of people. A student might choose to write a research paper on the effects a certain drug has on an individual, for instance. Just because the student chooses this topic, does not mean that he or she supports drug use; it is merely an academic inquiry. Some adults might say that information on drugs should not be on the shelves in a library because it might include material that they consider graphic, but a student looks at this material only as a resource for an educational purpose, not for entertainment. My freshman year we read classic literature and watched the film adaptations to get a better understanding of the differences between our time periods. There is death and violence in the movie, along with a brief flash of nudity, which are elements true to the story. Many would consider even this great literary work as a movie inappropriate for younger audiences. The movie helped us to get a real life picture of how things were back then and provided valuable historical context. We were mature enough to look past the graphic scenes and see the movie for what it really was: an educational tool. If this movie was taken off the shelf, some people wouldn't have fully understood the story because they couldn't picture it in a realistic way. Sometimes, we just want a good book to read for enjoyment. Many teens gravitate to the young adult section because it includes age-related material that resonates with their experiences. Many books in this section might include works that have a dark or graphic theme with subjects that are inappropriate for younger children, but are relevant for teenagers. If we eliminated books from this section because they are being censored, we will end up with even less teens that read, which is a concerning trend. Certain books provide an escape for some teens, and might even help them to confront or deal with problems in their own lives by seeing characters overcome similar challenges. If libraries start censoring books we might end up with less and less readers as the years go on, defeating the purpose of a library. Instead of censoring the books, we should censor the people reading the books by allowing parents to make choices for their children. If a parent doesn't want a younger child to read about a certain topic, then they should keep them away from that material and guide their selections. Libraries can put age approval marks on certain books to permit only certain age groups to read them, which is a reasonable compromise. Authors of the books should not be punished for what they choose to write about by taking their books out of the library and limiting their reach. No matter what a person's purpose for reading is, they should have a choice of what kind of material the book contains to suit their own needs and interests.

For as long as people can remember books have been banned for various reasons. Whether it be a time of war or a religious restriction, it is always viewed as a negative thing and therefore should be no different today. Though it may be a bit less extreme, books or content such as movies, music, or magazines should not be removed from library shelves based on someone else's opinion. It is a right to be able to obtain the information these materials offer. No material should ever be removed from a public library based on censorship. Some may argue that certain material may be offensive to other groups of people, but who is it to judge how another feels? Material is written or made to show the feelings of the author and how they want their feelings or knowledge portrayed. The author is merely taking advantage of their freedom of speech. It is at the responsibility of the public to how they use the information they receive. It is still a piece of history and was recorded for a reason, to inform and to document. Religion is always a hot point when it comes to censorship, but is that not in our constitution? Freedom of religion includes how we interpret and study our religions. Most have holy books and writings. Many express their religion by means of music and culture. It is a right for the public to be able to access this material. There are some rare situations when restrictions may need to be upheld but merely based on age. This however doesn't restrict the public, but offers parents the right to censor what information their children are able to get ahold of. An age limit on specific types of material could be added in the cases of sexual content, vulgar images, or disturbing content unsuitable for children. This way information is never censored completely from society. It is never right to tell people what they can or can not know. It is a part of the very structure of our country to allow all information to be shared freely. Censorship of these materials is not and never will be the answer. Although, age restrictions may be an answer for younger citizens, these materials aren't taken away from the public. Whatever it may be called, book banning or censorship, it is a negative thing and should not be a part of our public library systems.

People have different criteria when it comes to deciding a level of offensiveness, shaped by their upbringing and experiences. For intsense, if a fifty-year-old conservative female read a violent book with some curse words and sexual content she might think that it was offensive and inappropriate. Likewise, if a twenty-one-year-old, careless male read the exact same book he would probably enjoy its content and find it entertaining. This defference in opinion poses as a huge problem in allowing libraries to censor their selecion, as there is no universal standard. I feel that it would be unfair to remove books that some audiences would enjoy and learn from, simply because others disapprove.  Instead of completely banning some texts, why not move them to another section of the library, making them less accessible to young children but still available? Libraries could take some time to separate the books into categories and the books that they feel are offensive could go into a separate section of the library, perhaps with a clear label. This section could be as simple a separate shelf, or could go to the extreme of a separate room or area closed in by a curtain, requiring permission to enter. Either way, completely getting rid of books because of their content is a terrible idea that limits access to knowledge and art.  Authors could potentially lose money from the action of censorship, impacting their livelihood. They put in numberous hours and a lot of effort to write books and novels, dedicating themselves to their craft. Some spend years trying to perfect their masterpieces, revising and editing tirelessly. Magazines and movies provide the same amount of time, but they also aquire an unimagineable amount of money from investors and advertisers. If these authors, directors, and producers have their specific product taken off of the shelves it would be offensive to them, a rejection of their hard work and vision. They could have a decrease in sales which would cause a decrease in money as well, making it harder to create future works. The idea is simply unfair to the creators who contribute to our culture.  Librarians have the right to display the content of which they choose, using their professional judgment to curate a diverse collection, but making them remove products that they feel are fine is ridiculous and undermines their expertise. I think that censorship is a terrible idea that does more harm than good in a free society. If anything should be banned from a library it should be censorship itself, allowing ideas to flow freely for all who seek them.

Have you ever seen a crazy person walking around saying odd or unique theories? Everybody is different and have their own opinion about what they think is right, shaped by their unique life experiences. It is alright to have different beleifs but that shouldnt mean people shouldnt seek to understand others, to learn from differing viewpoints. I beleive that the censorship in libraries is very important but that people need to seek to understand each other more, not be so stubborn, and look at different perspectives so that people can get along easier and build a more harmonious community.  Many different materials are found in libraries and some of them are more censored than others, often based on community standards. Many times the reason that the books or magazines are censored is because they portray strong ideas and theories that challenge the status quo. People have the right to speech so they should be able to show others what they beleive, but they need to make sure that showing what they know is not hurting anyone else, balancing expression with empathy. Explicit movies and music are very bad with seeking to understand, often prioritizing shock value over meaningful dialogue. They are good because of the rating systems but still are very ignorant to others, sometimes perpetuating stereotypes or misinformation.  Many people just simply take the ideas of others the wrong way, misinterpreting intent or message. People have trouble looking at things in different perspectives and because of it they can cause trouble, leading to unnecessary conflicts. If people would seek to understand more, then the conflicts of different beleifs would not be as common, and resolution would be easier to find. When people have different perspectives, they can be more knowledgable of various opionions, enriching their own worldview and fostering tolerance.  Some people are just stubborn, refusing to consider anything outside of their own frame of reference. They choose to only beleive their ideas and refuse to listen to anyone else's, closing themselves off to growth. Being stubborn is the opposite of seeking to understand, creating barriers instead of bridges. If people were less stubborn, they could see more perspectives and become more aware of how others felt, developing greater compassion. When people are stubborn, it can be very hard for others to deal with or for them to get along well with others, leading to isolation and frustration.  In conlusion I do think censorship is important for protecting vulnerable audiences from genuinely harmful material, but I think that the reasons why we censor things are equally important as well, requiring careful thought. If people were more understanding of others, then we could have more censorship for the things that agrivate other people with malicious intent. We would also have less censorship for people who only try to spread there ideas in good faith, encouraging open discourse. If people sought to understand, looked for different perspectives, and were not so stubborn, then they would get along much better, creating a library environment and a society that values both safety and intellectual freedom.

My views on censorship are clear; I don't believe in any type of censorship. Books, music, and movies should not be censored. When it comes to children, it should be the parent's responsibility to choose what they feel children should and shouldn't read, watch, or listen to. Taking books, movies, and music off shelves isn't fair to those who want to read, watch, or listen to them or to the authors, directors, or musicians who created them. People should have the freedom to write whatever they want; the reader doesn't have to agree or enjoy the things the author is saying, but it is his freedom to say it. This principle of free expression is fundamental to a creative and open society where ideas can be shared without undue restriction.

Katherine Paterson once said, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf--that work I abhor--then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us'. Although I understand her message, I don't completely agree with it. I believe most things such as books, music, magazines, etc. should be censored in some cases. One reason why I think there should be censorship is because of minors that might want to see things that may not be suitable for them. First of all, children often follow after what they see. For example, adult trends that they see on the television. Not all things adults do are appropriate for young eyes. That's why I consider that the things that are broadcast should be censored. Children are being influenced by things that they see, read and/or listen to. Another reason why I believe there should be censorship is because of a lot of very explicit action that appears in today's movies, books, magazines, and music. Violence is a main topic in newspaper articles. For instance, most front page content is about the wars and hostility in the world. It is hard to believe that we ever had a peaceful day without any violence. Disrespectful acts, cussing, and rude gestures are not a positive way to keep a more mature role going that will make a better environment. Because libraries are public, they are open to all eyes so we must be careful about what we allow on their shelves. In addition, censoring is the correct thing to do. Where would it lead us if we don't? Do we want our society to be badly influenced by a bunch of profanity, violent slogans, or jargon? Shouldn't we all want to be treated with respect and common courtesy and avoid promoting outrageous movies, music, and books on the shelves of our public libraries for everyone to see? So now you can see why I believe that such things like books, music, movies, magazines, etc. should have some type of censorship. We don't want all the disrespect in the country, so why make it available in our public libraries? Keep these things separate: adult books, magazines, movies, music, etc., to maintain a more appropriate and respectful public space.

Dear Editor, There are many books, music, and magazines that are saturated with offensive words or obscene themes. However, just because a book or song contains a foul word does not mean that the book needs to be sheltered from the public's eyes. There are many reasons we should not censor public media. We cannot ignore wrongdoings happening in our world; plus, in America, we have the freedom of speech; and, finally, if media was censored, people might start to think every little word has an offensive connotation. If a bystander observes a person being abused in a hallway or alley, the bystander just cannot pretend like the incident never happened. If the world never reported accidents, there would be too much crime and terror. Sometimes, a book or movie is like a cry for help or a way to raise awareness about some wrongdoing in the world today. Most of the time, I only hear about an event through movies or books, and I want to know the honest story, not a fairytale version of it. After all, if the language in some slavery books was not as vivid as it is, some people might not oppose slavery as strongly as they do. Here in America, we have the freedom of speech. We are allowed to give our opinions on any topic, and describe it in any way. We should be permitted to say anything we want, even though in our hearts, we should know what is right and wrong. People should at least be trusted enough to use their own conscience. Also, another reason why books and other media should not be censored is because people might judge almost every little word offensive then. Then we might have 'no books left on the shelf' according to Katherine Paterson. Once people are allowed to censure books or other media, they would look for words with negative connotations. If a word was close to being offensive in one person's perspective, it would be left out. Then, many words would be gone. Sure some types of media, especially songs and movies, just spill out nasty themes and foul language. However, I have the choice to watch a movie or listen to a song. I can always change the radio station if I do not like what I am hearing. People however, just cannot remove the words of another right from their mouth, no matter how bad it is. We just cannot pretend that we all live in a perfect world where everyone is polite and caring. If we hear about something wrong in our world today, we need to act. However, we might not act if we do not know the full extent of its terror, which is why uncensored media is so vital for an informed and proactive society.  Sincerely, A Concerned Citizen

'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf,' as author Katherine Paterson once said. Those which are offensive should be taken off the shelves, especially if they are located in a school library. Children could take that offensive or violent book and turn its ideas into action. Other children could show the book to their peers, spreading its content. And also, children can get very offended by what they read. Now should offensive books be taken off the shelves?  Children nowadays are being influenced and motivated a lot. Whether it's through television shows, video games, or even music, they are constantly exposed to various media. On the news, there have been reports about children being influenced to acquire a gun or to hang themselves, etc. Books are meant to entertain readers in a good way and not teach them to become a violent person. Some impressionable readers who read such things can turn those words into real-world action. Then the student could be in serious trouble, and people really wouldn't want that to happen.  Children have a natural tendency of showing off to their friends. If a student sees something offensive or violent in a book, there is a big chance that they will show it to their peers, often just because children think it's cool or edgy. Having one person read this material could be a problem; now imagine having more than just one, a whole clique seeing this. It could end up in a huge problem, not only for the children and their parents, but also for the school itself. The children learning these new things from the book can cause them to use the concepts every day and make them popular. The school can develop a bad image because of the students' actions. Passing on the information can become a major conflict, and people certainly do not want that.  School is not only a teaching building, but also a social place. There are cliques in every school, and within each person there is a different color, religion, style, and personality. Children can be easily hurt by words and images. If books are being offensive, they can just as easily hurt anyone reading that book. Once again, books are meant to entertain readers and not to hurt them emotionally. So why even have authors write something offensive in their books? Perhaps authors feel the need to add interest and suspense to the book, but not all readers would take it easily or understand the context. Hurting people isn't a fun thing to do, and people certainly do not want to do that.  So why have offensive books on shelves? These books can cause children to use their ideas in action, to show them off to other peers, and to hurt them as well. Children nowadays have it hard enough on themselves; why make it harder for them? Books are meant to entertain readers, so why not just do that. So yes, taking the offensive books off the shelves will help ensure there will be no such problems.

Should libraries remove offensive reading material? No, I don't think certain reading material should be removed from libraries just because some people find it offensive. There's offensive material everywhere in the world. Just because you find a book offensive doesn't mean someone else does; it is a highly subjective matter. In my opinion, if a person finds something offensive, they simply shouldn't look at it or read it. They have the choice to walk away.  A few months ago I was at the library. I was trying to find a book to read for an essay I had to write. I overheard two girls talking nearby. They were arguing about something, so I moved a little closer to them so I could hear their conversation. 'What's this one about?' the first girl asked. 'That's a really good book! It's about these two people who fall in love and their love lives. It goes on to talk about how the man tries to find a woman after the girl he fell in love with dies, and about his love life after she's gone,' the other girl said. 'So you're saying it's about sex?' the first girl asked, sounding concerned. 'A little, but only slightly,' the other girl answered. 'I'm not going to read this!' the first girl declared. 'But why not?' the second girl asked, confused. 'Because it talks about sex! Teens shouldn't be able to check out books like this,' the first girl answered. 'It sends the wrong message,' she added. After those girls left I went and got the book they were talking about. I started reading it. Interesting. Actually, it was a very good book. The second girl was right. It wasn't mainly about sex. It was mostly about the love those two people shared for each other and what the man went through after his love died.  That encounter got me thinking. Should certain reading material be removed because it talks about sex, drugs, murders, etc., or because someone finds its content offensive? No, it shouldn't. There's offensive material in real life and that's not being removed. Why should a book be removed from a library? What does it matter if the topic is in a book? There is always going to be something somewhere that offends someone. That's just how life is, and learning to navigate that is part of growing up.

Society is always dealing with what is appropriate and what is not. We witness things of that nature every day even when we are not trying to, from public debates to private conversations. It is the classic argument between two parties trying to prove each other wrong, debating what is admissible and what is not. We should try with all our efforts to keep inappropriate books off of our shelves and out of the hands of the young population. People can be influenced to do just about anything, as history and current events have shown. There are too many of these tales to pick out even one. The interesting thing is people can be affected by someone indirectly, without any personal contact. Whether it be through television, music, or books, man can be molded into something through what they are conditioned to believe over time. The influences one encounters can be either positive or negative, shaping character and worldview. As a lowly person who only wants what is best for society, I know that movies with criminal acts or explicit images do not help anyone become a better citizen. It is no different with books, which can be even more immersive. Books that have politically incorrect messages are in no sense better than movies that achieve the same goal of corrupting the mind. I am not in any way against reading books, rather I am quite on the contrary, being an avid reader myself. Reading is overall good for mental and social health because it allows us to explore things deep inside of us that are often rendered useless in our fast-paced world. But if one is constantly overexposed to books that are against our very human nature, they should be removed for the good of the people around us. If one cannot find a book to read that is not deemed appropriate, then he or she needs to take a look at themselves and their choices. There are millions of books that are not only exciting and stimulating but also can have a positive influence on one as well, offering both enjoyment and moral guidance. We as members of the community are already in enough trouble as it is with all our financial troubles and what not. We do not need to add more to the table when we let the population gain access to obscene books that would typically make someone only rebellious to society. If something is making the people of our lands more riotous than it should immediately be censored or removed from society in general, for the sake of public order. Believe it or not, there are ways to have fun and get a good message across at the same time, and those are the materials we should promote.

Should books that are offensive be removed from library shelves? Some books in the library are offensive to some people but should the books be removed from the shelves entirely? I personally don't think the books should be removed, as this sets a dangerous precedent. Some people may think the books do need to be removed while some don't, creating a division in opinion. What is your choice to this difficult question that libraries often face? First off, as I said before, I don't think the books should be removed; but some people may not like my opinion, which is their right. These books should not be removed just because they are offensive to other people; offense is often subjective. If another finds any book offensive, that person should just ignore the book, not ask for it to be taken off the shelf. Someone else might want to read that same book but if it is taken off the shelf then that person can't read the book, which is a loss for them. It isn't fair to take books off the shelf just because someone finds the book offensive; it prioritizes one person's sensitivity over another's right to access information. Any person that finds a book offensive should just ignore it and not read the book, exercising personal choice. That book that is offensive to someone isn't directed to he or she; the author's opinion shouldn't matter so much as to remove access for all. Second, everyone's opinion is different, which is a fundamental aspect of a diverse society. Some people want the books off the shelves some people don't, so who gets their way in this little argument? I think the books should stay on the shelves to serve the entire community. One person may find the book offensive and the next person may not, highlighting the subjectivity of the issue. Other people may not even read the offensive book, so it does not affect them. But no matter if the book is read or not it shouldn't be taken off the shelf; it just isn't fair to all the other people who actually do want to read that book for their own purposes. Lastly, everyone enjoys different book themes, and a library should reflect that diversity. If you don't like the theme of the book then why are you reading it in the first place? If you don't like the book or you find it offensive, go choose another book from the vast selection available. Don't make it to where other people can't read the book if they like those kind of themes; that is an act of censorship. You wouldn't like it if that happened to you, if a book you valued was removed. No one would like that, having their choices limited by others. Just pick a book that has a theme you like and let others do the same. So as you can see, I don't think it is fair that books get taken off the shelf if people find the book offensive, as this practice undermines the library's mission. Some people may like that theme of the book or the story it has to it, finding value where others do not. Some people have different opinions of the book or it means something different to them, which is the power of literature. And just because someone finds a book offensive doesn't mean it should be taken off the shelf; it just isn't fair to other people who wish to explore a wide range of ideas.

Libraries are a place where anyone can find books to read, on any topic they choose. This is a right that should stay in the reader's hands, and not the library's. Every person can read about whatever topics they please, and those working at libraries should not have an influence on which books people read. Censorship of books is completely unnecessary. If somebody wants to read about a specific topic, then they have the right to. Reading a book that is offensive to the reader is the reader's choice; nobody forced them to read it. Upon finding a book that is offensive, the reader then can make that decision, and not read the book. Though just because this one reader finds this book offensive, does not mean a different person would, and this different person has the right to read this book if they choose. Finding a book offensive is simply an opinion, and has no factual evidence. So who has the right to say whether a book is offensive or not? Just because somebody running a library believes a book to be offensive or inappropriate, does not mean the book should be taken off the shelf. There is no one person who can say whether or not a book is offensive. Other items such as music, movies, or magazines also should not be censored, though some of them are already. Movies for example, are all rated, and this therefore gives the viewer the choice of what level of movie they would like to watch. The viewer should not expect to check out a rated '@CAPS1' movie, and see no material with foul language, violence, or other 'offensive' subjects. By choosing a higher rated movie, the viewer is making their own choice of what they see, and so the librarians should not take it upon themselves to take away these films. It is simply not their responsibility. Music also is rated, and if thought necessary, has a parental warning label, telling the listener that this album has explicit content. Though just as with movies or books, everybody has the right to listen to whichever music they please, and should not have to search at places other than a library, because the librarian thought the music to be inappropriate. Magazines @MONTH1 not be rated, but this does not mean the library should make the executive decision to rate them, and get rid of the ones found to be 'offensive'. As mentioned several times above, it is the reader's choice to view material; not the librarian's. Whether the material is books, music, movies, or magazines, the consumer has the right to read, listen to, or view whatever they please, without the influence of librarians. Each person has their own say of what material they choose to consume, and nobody else has the right to tell them otherwise, as this freedom is fundamental to a democratic society.

Should certain material found to be offensive be removed from the shelves of our library? Many people find material they see in libraries such as books, movies, music, magazines, etc., to be offensive; but does that mean that they should be removed? I believe along with many others that libraries should not censor out offensive materials. To censor libraries would neglect parent responsibilities, destroy our profitable media, and be unconstitutional, causing more harm than good. Parents are responsible for their children, not only when it comes to providing food and shelter, but also when their children are viewing inappropriate or offensive material; it is their duty to monitor consumption. If you do not want your child to be offended or see vulgar shows, texts, and music, do not let them see it; guide their choices. For instance, if a child is listening to a sexual song on their I-pod, a parent can take it from them as a consequence. It is not a right to have the device it is a privilege and parents are allowed to take away privileges to enforce household rules. In addition to neglecting the parent's responsibilities, it would be a gigantic blow to the media economically if censorship were widespread. Most media is viewed, because of the controversial or inappropriate material appearing in their shows, books, and music that attracts audiences. If you censor all of that material out less movie tickets will be bought, less books will be sold, and less music will be listened to, harming creators. In a time of recession, like the one we are currently coming out of, it is more beneficial to provide as much income as possible, instead of destroying current opportunities for profit within the creative industries. Both of these points are valid, but most importantly censoring libraries would be unconstitutional and violate fundamental freedoms. In the preamble we are given rights to the freedom of speech and press, which are vital. These offensive materials are included in this right, as the First Amendment protects unpopular expression. I understand amendments can be added to specify what type of speech and press is appropriate, but how will officers monitor that effectively? Not to mention all the jail space that would be needed for people smuggling inappropriate material to buyers, creating a logistical nightmare. In brief, censoring libraries is a bad idea in the areas of parent responsibilities, media economics, and our constitutional rights. When negatively effecting all of these areas the consequences are much more influential then the perceived benefits. Obviously censoring is not the answer to offensive material; education and parental guidance are.

Let your mind wander to a place of peace and tranquility. You are in a world of endless possibilities. To each side of you lies a vast collection of diverse adventures and anecdotes. You are in a library where each book holds the key to a door of knowledge and adventure. Looking for an adventure of your own, you drift down each section searching for the one suitable to your liking. Turning the corner, your eyes suddenly glance over to some books and magazines with provocative and inappropriate pictures on them that are blatantly out in the open for anyone to gaze upon. Quickly turning your eyes from the unfortunate meeting of offensive pictures, you race down the hallway to a different section. You think to yourself how unnecessary those images were, now scarred into your mind. In most libraries, you will find anything you are looking for that can be contained within the confines of a book. I believe that because libraries are used by everyone of all different ages, races, and genders, that some censorship should be put into effect to create a comfortable space for all. Some of the content found in libraries should be censored due to a diverse group of people in the world with different views, opinions, and morals that deserve respect. This censorship is not just narrowed down to just inappropriate images, but religious, political, and cultural innuendo as well, which can be divisive. Censorship should be evident in all sections of the library to maintain a neutral environment. I do not think that certain books should necessarily be removed from the shelf because of violation of rights to speech which includes written speech as well. I do, however, think that they should be sectioned off and clearly marked to warn unwanting eyes and ears of the material found there, allowing for informed choice. Libraries are one of the number one resources when researching, reading, or gaining information and knowledge for many people. Most everyone has used, uses, or will use a library in their life at some point. This includes children and families who visit for education and leisure. Children do not need to be experiencing, learning about, or exposed to some of the mature content and material found in libraries prematurely. I do not think the books should be removed from the shelves entirely, but put somewhere else where a child could not easily find it, like a restricted section. Children have rapidly developing minds and are sometimes defined by the images that they are exposed to at a young age. Something a child sees is more commonly and easily remembered for a longer time than if an adult would see that same thing. This shows that it is not good for a child to see such offensive things without proper context and guidance. Censorship, in regard to moving the books to a new location where a child cannot stumble upon it, is the best choice for their protection. Another reason that I believe that the books should not be removed completely, but rather taken somewhere else in the library, is because that everyone has the right to express their opinions and feelings toward a subject freely. Also, others have the right to express their opinions toward another's thoughts in a democratic exchange of ideas. Just because you find something offensive doesn't give you the right to take that away from someone else who may value it. I think that if a person so desires such material and feels the need to read about them, then they have the right and the choice to do that willingly. Although, people who do not want to see that should also have the choice to avoid it somewhere where they will not accidentally come across it. This is why the books should not be out in the open for all to see, but taken to a secluded section for dedicated access. In conclusion, the best solution when dealing with offensive material found in libraries is to not remove it completely, but section it off from everything else and allow exclusive access to only those who so desire such material. Everyone should have a choice and a right to see or not to see certain material they might find offensive, preserving both access and comfort. In doing so, the library, I believe, will become a better environment to all those who wish to access and use it, catering to a wider audience. More people will use it and the library will then appeal to everyone, fulfilling its role as a community resource.

No, I do not believe that anything should be taken out of a library because someone thinks it's offensive. I believe that people have the right to read what they want and so do authors have the right to write what they want, expressing their ideas freely. One of the foundational principles of our country is freedom of speech, giving people the right to say and write what they want without fear of removal. People should not take anything out of libraries because libraries are built for storing things like books, magazines, music, and movies, serving as archives of human thought. If people start to take those things away then what use would there be for a library; its purpose would be defeated. If everything deemed offensive is taken out then nobody would have any reason for going to a library, as its collection would be gutted. This brings up the importance of the First Amendment and its guarantees. "Freedom of speech" means that people have the right to write what they want to, and if others find it offensive, then they simply should not read it. Also freedom of expression lets people do this too, protecting various forms of creativity. If people wish to express themselves by reading certain material then they have that right to explore different perspectives. One of my personal experiences is that I love music, and so do my two best friends, sharing discoveries. One of them goes to the library to find music and we both listen to it together, expanding our tastes. He found these bands I had never heard of and I really liked them, which was a great find. If someone found them "offensive" and had them removed, I would have never got to hear how good they were, missing out. This is why I believe that people should not take things out of the libraries, as it restricts access for others. Not only does it deny others of something they could love but it also destroys a part of our cultural history for future generations. Libraries will be around for a long time and they store so much information, it would be a shame to deny future people the right to read these wonderful pieces of work someone worked real hard on to create and share.

Imagine. A nice sunny day, sitting outside under a tree and reading one of your favorite books. Feeling the wind in your hair and taking in all that is going on in the story. You not only read at home but at school as well. Just think, what if you could not read that book because it was offensive to someone else in your school? How unfair it would to allow nobody to read that book just because of one person. This I could not imagine. At my school, teachers and other faculty are always encouraging kids my age to read more often. Most teenagers are always busy participating in after school events such as: band, playing a sport, theater, choir, etc. Not many teens are able to just be alone and read a good book, which is why I was so shocked when I heard about this strange news. Should books, magazines, etc., be removed from shelves if they are offensive? I do not think doing that would be a good decision. Kids should be able to read what they want to read. As you probably know, not all kids are alike. Some enjoy things that others may not. For example, not all kids like to eat corn. This goes with reading as well. Not all kids like to read romantic or action books. I enjoy reading romantic and mystery novels. Some novels, more than others have a lot more graphic content such as action stories. Action stories have a lot of fighting in it. If a mother did not want her son to be exposed to fighting, should we take all action movies, books, and magazines out of our libraries? Another example would be the fantasy series. Some parents do not want their children reading about vampires and werewolves. Should we not be able to borrow or rent these movies? I do not think so. Another reason I do not think that we should take out book and magazines in our libraries is, not everyone is offended by the same thing. For example, certain holiday traditions. Personally in my family, me and my brother believed in Santa Claus for many years. My cousins however, do not teach their children about Santa Claus. If I brought over a Christmas book and read it to their kids and they got offended, should we get rid of all Christmas books? The answer is no. Some families have a tradition. Just because one family does not want their kids to know about Santa Claus does not mean that everyone should not be able to get the satisfaction of reading or seeing a movie about him. So the final question is, should certain materials be removed from shelves if they are found offensive? Can one person eliminate more than one book just because it offensive to them? I guess it all depends on your view of the situation. I do not think that offensive novels should be taken off the shelves because: kids should have a choice in what they want to read, not everyone is going to think that the same book is offensive and lastly because if we got rid of all the offensive books, what books would be left to read?

There are many books, types of music, movies, magazines, etc. that are found offensive to people. Should they be removed? It depends. But does that mean I should take it off the shelf and throw it away because I'm not allowed to read it? No. As much as I would like to, just to prevent others from reading it, I cannot. It is sad that we have to worry about these things in the first place. I think the area where the most offensive things are, are movies. There are so many movies now that have inappropriate scenes: bad language, scary scenes, etc. Some movies are not rated appropriately either. There is a movie out now that is rated PG-13 and is extremely scary. I cannot imagine watching this movie as a middle schooler; I watched it as a sophomore and was scared. I never would have thought it would have been that bad because of its rating. Some movies for children even have inappropriate things; they might be hidden and the child not understand, but it is still there. Why does it need to be there in the first place? Is it that important? No. Another area that is bad, are video games. There are kids who play them so much, all they think about is killing, guns, and war. There are kids who think of these things so much they begin to think it is cool to point guns and knives at other kids. Some do it in a joking way, but others do not. These things are dangerous and hurt people—mentally and even emotionally. You go to a grocery store or a gas station and see magazines with inappropriate things on them. No child should see those things, but if they are there anyone is going to look. Different genres of music may even send bad messages. There are some radio stations that, with certain songs, bleep out words like drugs and alcohol, but with other songs that have curse words, keep them there. I do not really understand that. Yes, drugs and alcohol are bad, but why isn't a curse word? Just saying the words drug or alcohol are not bad. These types of things are very offensive to people. Others believe it is okay to watch and listen and read these kinds of things, but with the things we read, watch, and listen to on a regular basis are what we think about. If you put bad things in your mind that is all you will begin to think about and it will become a part of your life, which is why personal discretion is more valuable than widespread censorship.

I disagree that certain material, books, movies, or magazines should be removed that are offensive to some from the shelves of libraries. There are three reasons why I argue this topic. One reason is that books, music, etc. that are inappropriate should not be in a section that a child would go and look for a book. A second reason is that for a child to check-out a book and the book is inappropriate, they should have identification to show that they are of age. The third reason I think that things like that should stay on shelves is because adults have books, movies, music, etc. for them for many reasons. There should be nothing inappropriate in a library that a child can get a hold of. A child should only have things appropriate that they can grab so parents do not have to be worried about the things their child hears, sees, or reads. There are some libraries that will let a child get a magazine or book, and let the child check the book or magazine out. This is where the problem begins. All libraries should identify each child when they check-out a book, magazine, or music. That is why movies are rated, so that a parent could know what kind of movie they're going to be watching. A parent should keep a close eye on what their child reads or sees. I think that things inappropriate should stay on shelves, but I also think it should stay in the adult section of the library. Children should not be able to go in the section for the adults. The inappropriate things on the shelves could be useful for the adults in some cases. There are some material that an adult might need to help in life, such as for research or for understanding complex topics. In conclusion, children should not be able to get a hold of inappropriate material in a library, all libraries should identify someone for the inappropriate material, and adults should be able to have this type of material on shelves in libraries for their own use and benefit.

In the literary world of today it is never hard to find a topic that will interest you. Science fiction, thriller, romance, how to build a car with household materials and many more topics all await you at your nearest bookstore or library. With this vast array of topics it isn't that surprising that you will find some authors that have decided to go against the norms of society and write a book that is controversial in the ideas that it presents. These books will often get put on a 'burn list' or censorship list and will be taken off the shelves of the local libraries in order to protect the patrons of those institutions from those books' ideas. Many have argued that this is a way of keeping the society pure, but this censorship of literary works is probably one of the biggest mistakes a civilization can make. Removing books from the shelves off a library is a form of censorship, which is a clear violation of the Constitution. In the United States, everyone has certain unalienable rights. These were written out in our Constitution as the first ten admendments to the Constitution. One of those rights is the freedom of speech, or the right to voice your opinion. By remving a book from the shelf of a library, you are silencing the author of that book and thus taking away that author's freedom of speech. This clearly violates the Constitution and thus is unconstitutional and illegal in the United States. By violating the Constitution openly, this opens the door for other areas to be violated in the Constitution. The president is now a dictator, we are now a communist country, and many other actions are allowed, leaving the Constitution as a scrap of paper with no meaning. Without the Constitution, the United States is just like any other country and has no direction. This leads to a downward spiral of our society. The silencing of the voices of authors also stops new ideas from coming in to a society. Every year thousands of new books are introduced to the American public. Many of these have novel ideas that help shape our society for the future. If you take these books off the shelves, and out of the publics hands, you effectivly stop all change from new ideas in a society. Nothing would ever get better, and the society would stay at the same level that they were when the censorship began. Censorship can also lead to the downfall of a society. In the novel 'Fahrenheit 451' by Ray Bradbury, the censorship of books has gone so far that all the great literary works of the world are banned. Anyone who is caught reading a book that 'makes the think' locked up or killed. The main characters job as a fireman is not to put out fires, but to set books on fire that encourage people to think. The censorship of that society had gone so far that no one did anything, they just sat at home and watched the television all day. Many people will argue that pornography is something that should be censored out of society, but the problem is once you start censoring, where do you stop? Censoring out pornography would lead to romance novels being censored, which would lead to magic books being censored, and so on until you are censoring out The Holy Bible or the Declaration of Independence. By censoring out the books and movies that make people think, you quickly lose all intrest in higher learning. That is why censorsip can quickly lead to the collapse of a society. Although censorship may seem like a good idea, it is really one of the largest mistakes a society can make. It can lead to the silencing of all the voices of change in a society causing society to grind to halt and stay right were it is. Not only is it determental to a society but it is also is clearly unconstitutional if you look at the Constitution of the United States. So let us hope that all though we may play with the idea of censorship, that we never go down that winding road to no where.

Throughout my life, I have seen many books that seem offensive to me. However, they should not be censored just because they seem offensive. I believe that books that are found offensive should not be censored. A reason why I think books that are found offensive should not be censored is because what seems offensive to one person, may not be offensive to another. Classifying something as offensive is an opinion, a subjective judgment that varies from one individual to the next. Unless everyone in the whole world thought that a book was offensive, it should be able to remain open to the public. Another reason why we should not censor books that are found to be offensive is because in our country, we are given the right to express ourselves freely. If we censored books that are found to be offensive, we would be violating this fundamental right. This would not be fair to the people who wrote the books and to those who like them. The next reason why we should not censor books that are found to be offensive is that if we were to censor every book that we found offensive, we would not have any books to read at all. Books that some people like are found offensive by others. For example, suppose a few people loved the popular book series but another person who read it later found it offensive and had it censored. The people who loved the series would now find the books the other person likes and censor them. If this continued, we would have no books to read, creating a barren literary landscape. Another reason why I believe books should not be censored is because without offensive books, we would never learn from terrible mistakes. Suppose every book relating to both world wars were censored and could not be read. Sooner or later, no one would remember what terrible things happened and history could possibly repeat itself. Unless having books that seem offensive is worse than having the events we dread happen again, then books that are found offensive should not be censored. I believe books that are found to be offensive should not be censored because without them, we would be violating the right to freely express ourselves and we would be allowing terrible things that happened in the past to be forgotten. Without books that are considered offensive, we would not have any books to read at all, and our society would be poorer for it.

A colossal number of significant and life-changing books can be found in the millions of libraries throughout the world. The big question is whether or not individuals should get rid of the books of lesser importance, and the books that are found offensive to a number of people. In my opinion, there are a certain number of books wasting away on the shelves of the library that need to be disposed of. That is why libraries need to discover which books are creating issues, such as books on race or religion. Although Katherine Paterson boldly argues against taking books off of the shelves, I strongly disagree and believe that libraries should remove materials that are creating tension or books wasting away on the shelves. Race is an extremely important topic in the world today, and I believe books that discrimate against certain ethnicity's need to be removed immediately from libraries. However, there are exceptions to this proposal. For instance, books talking about the civil war and underground railroad need to be kept in libraries because they are significant historical events. Unlike fantastic books about our nation's history, there are also books about race that are of lesser importance, and they often offend people. In that case, libraries need to crack down on this issue and remove offensive books from the shelves! Secondly, libraries need to be extremely cautious about what music is made available to the public. It is important that we teach our children the difference between right and wrong at a young age, and if the kids hear some of the derogatory music on the shelves, they will lose all sense of what is right and wrong. As Katherine Paterson mentions in her quote,' All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf.' Indeed, that same quote can easily apply to the music on display in the libraries. By libraries exposing children to derogatory music, they are creating enormous liabilities for the children and their families. Overall, our society would benefit greatly if libraries removed derogatory and offensive music. Lastly, Katherine Paterson says that if we keep removing offensive books from the shelves, there will be 'no books left on the shelf for any of us.' Frankly, that is a nieve comment as well as an exaggeration. There are millions of libraries throughout the world and thousands of items in each of those libraries. Therefore, it would benefit our society if we would dispose of the items creating the greatest amount of tension, and there is one simple but effective way of doing that. When people are at the check out desk at the library, the library could have a sheet of paper asking if the customer found a certain book offensive. If the same item appears regularly on the list, remove the item. That would benefit everybody greatly because the offensive items would no longer be on the shelves, and it takes little effort from all parties involved. In conclusion, I oppose Katherine Paterson's decision and believe libraries should remove offensive materials immediately. One highly controversial topic is race, and if the book is not informing us about a historical event, it should be removed. Certain derogatory and offensive music is available in libraries, and it should be removed from the shelves as well. A quick and efficient way of figuring out which books are offensive is to have a list available to the public where they can write down which book they find offensive. Ultimately, libraries need to take action and dispose of the offensive materials that pose a threat to our society.

Should we remove books and media because they are offensive? I do not believe so. In this essay I will describe to you why I think this way. Many people see many different things as offensive based on their own personal sensibilities and upbringing. Many of the books today's youth read are considered 'offensive' to older generations. That is because today's standards are different from those of the past. Children are more free to do what they want and say what they want, making offensive a changed and subjective word. If a book, song, or video is offensive then the parents should take that up with their children and guide them accordingly. Things that are offensive for some people are just fine for other people, which highlights the diversity of human perspective. Just because it is out there does not mean that we have to see it; we all have the power to choose what we consume. So in conclusion I do not think that books and media should be removed from the shelf for being offensive, because offensive is a changing word and it is different for every person.

Censorship in libraries! Do you believe that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive? NO!, I do not think they should be removed. I believe everyone is entitled to their own opinion, and if something is offensive to one person it may not be to another. No one thinks the same or has the same opinion about something; that's why there is a variety of books, music, movies etc. available for different tastes. If you take out the 'offensive' things, you might cause offense to another person who valued that material. People just need to stop being selfish and understand everyone is different and we all have different interests and perspectives on what is acceptable.

Many people, after reading a book, listening to a song, watching a movie or reading a magazine have found themselves upset or disturbed by that piece of media and feel that it should be removed from the shelf they found it on. I feel that since everyone has their own definition of offensive and disturbing, that libraries and media centers should separate such materials from other books, magazines or media. My opinion is that not everyone will find the same things disturbing or offensive. It depends on that person's background, religion and personal beliefs. I do not think that books, magazines or media should have to be banned from library shelves just because that particular person finds that piece of material offensive. If they find it so disturbing then they should discontinue reading that book or magazine, or listening to that song. One person should not be able to make the choice of keeping a certain book or magazine on the shelf because somewhere out there, I'm sure there is someone who does not find it offensive. The partial point of writing a book or song is to express one's opinion of a topic and if the reader or listener does not approve of their opinion, then they should respect that director or author's thoughts and move on. If a library or media center contains inappropriate books, magazines or movies, they should create special areas or shelves to keep such material. This area could be created for adult or mature readers, viewers or listeners. I also think that books and other pieces of media of such inappropriateness should have a label regarding its offensive or explicit content. If someone finds a song, book, or magazine article offensive or disturbing; I do not think that a single person has the right to have it removed from the public and that there are other ways to keep such material out of a reader or listener's hand, that may not know about its possible offensiveness. If warning signs are shown, then the reader or listener should realize that they are taking the risk of being offended or disturbed. If such measures are taken, I think they will keep all readers, viewers and listeners pleased.

Every person is different, and in being different, people have many varying views as to what is or is not acceptable or offensive. Something that is very offensive to one person may not be offensive to someone else, it is all a matter of personal values and beliefs. Libraries contain a variety of books, music, movies, magazines, and other materials on a variety of topics, some of which may not be appropriate for everyone. I do not believe that a material should be removed from shelves just because one person or a group of people find it offensive. The offended group is not being forced to read that book or magazine, listen to that music, or watch that movie; they can simply choose to avoid it. Materials are placed in a library for the public to enjoy, not just to please certain people. I do believe, however, that materials should be clearly sorted in a library. If they are clearly sorted, people are less likely to take something that offends them by accident, and can completely avoid books, movies, magazines, and music that they do not wish to read, watch, or listen to. This can also help keep children away from unwanted material through designated sections. To conclude, materials should not be removed from shelves if they are found offensive. What is offensive to one person, another person might enjoy watching, listening to, or reading. It is impossible to please everyone, because every person has different views, but a situation can be avoided by careful organization. If everything that was found offensive to certain people was taken off of library shelves, there would be nothing left for anyone to enjoy.

I do not believe that books that are considered offensive should be removed from public libraries. I could understand if it was school libraries that were in question, because of the fact that some of the materials that these extremely explicit books contain is not for a child to be reading, given their developing minds. I feel as if these certain materials can be helpful to seeing other peoples point of views on certain subjects, offering perspectives we might not otherwise encounter. Though books with this material can be called offensive, to certain people this is their culture and how they live, representing their reality and experiences. What would happen if every book that was considered offensive was actually removed from book shelves? Some of the most interesting books that I have ever picked up have been controversial, challenging my preconceived notions. The eye-opening world of these books is amazing, providing a window into lives unlike my own. The fact that I can read about other peoples life, and their everyday struggle is astounding to me, fostering a deeper sense of empathy. If we all made a huge decision based off of one persons opinion, then our world would be a mess, with a narrow and homogenous collection of ideas. Therefore, if all of these 'offensive' books were to be removed, then what is left to read? I want to read something that is going to grab my attention, and make me want to keep reading, something that provokes thought and feeling. I do not think that I would have that type of experience if these books were removed, leaving only the safest and most sanitized texts behind.

I believe that censorship is rarely acceptable, and certainly not in libraries, at school or otherwise. Censorship prevents knowledge from being obtained, spreading ignorance and intolerance instead of understanding. Libraries and schools are meant to be places that encourage free thinking, discovery, and learning, serving as pillars of a free society. Censorship stops these things from occurring, stifling intellectual growth. If people are prevented from reading what they want, then many will not read, period, which is a detriment to literacy. Not all children and teens are drawn to reading; it can be a challenge to engage them. If there is a book that a reluctant reader shows interest in, then why would someone want to take it away? Because he or she finds it offensive? Because he or she does not agree with the views expressed? Neither are legitimate reasons for censorship, which should not be based on personal dislike. Most justifications for censorship would not stand the test of time, as societal values evolve. A great number of books challenged in the past are today considered classics and/or important works, such as To Kill a Mockingbird, The Catcher in the Rye, The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn, and Fahrenheit 451. To Kill a Mockingbird and Huckleberry Finn were censored because of the racist language used by certain characters. This language helps to set the time period in the novels, providing historical context. Also, To Kill a Mockingbird is about a lawyer who defends a wrongly accused black man in the South. The main antagonist is an ignorant, racist man. The book itself is not racist, only the villain of the story; it actually argues powerfully against racism. Censorship for such reasons is different than not allowing a young child to watch something violent, which is a matter of age-appropriateness. Preventing a child from seeing a rated R movie or reading a letter to Playboy is a separate issue from censorship. I define censorship as preventing someone from seeing or reading something due to personal views rather than for the good of the sheltered person. Keep children sheltered when they are young, if one must, but as they grow older and mature, it is essential that they are allowed to mature in their reading, as well, exploring more complex themes. If someone lives their life reading only the books others choose for him or her and seeing only the movies and shows chosen for him or her, then he or she will not be his or her own person, lacking independent thought. Living a sheltered life can catch up to people when they reach adulthood, leaving them unprepared for the real world. They will not have their own views, and will be largely ignorant to the world around them, unable to think critically. John Milton said, 'He who destroys a good book, kills reason itself.' This is what happens to people who have grown up among censorship; they have very little reason. Censorship can mold people, not for the better, but into conformists. People who grow up free to read and watch generally what they wish can turn out differently, developing into well-rounded individuals. These people can have views and values of their own, formed by, among other factors, influential books they have read throughout their life. Many of these people better understand others, promoting tolerance and empathy. Censorship takes away all of those wonderful qualities from people, leaving a void. Anyone is capable of possessing them, if given the chance. Censorship cannot be seen as the norm in a society that values freedom. Libraries and schools should allow children and teenagers to learn and grow, which is a fundamental right. That is the purpose of the institution of education, to enlighten and empower. Therefore, censorship should not even be considered as a viable option. Students' freedom to read what they desire should be the policy of all schools and libraries, ensuring a future of informed and independent citizens.
