Nearly every person has seen, heard, wrote, or said something that offended someone at some point, as offense is often subjective. Most of the people that offend others do it on purpose in their music, books, or movies, intending to provoke a reaction. While some other people accidentally offend people by the way they worded something, with no malicious intent. If someone finds something offensive, they should ask for it to be placed somewhere else so it is still available for others, ask for a vote to remove it from the shelves, or just keep it to themselves until they know they're not the only one offended, which provides a measured response. When someone gets offended by something they see and hear in a library, that person should ask for relocation of the offensive material they seen or heard, moving it to a different section. In this case, other people can still watch, hear, or read the book or magazine, movie, or music, preserving access. Just because something is offensive to one person does not mean it is to someone else, who may find value in it. A book or magazine, song, or movie could be offensive to a lot of people, so it should be voted on to be removed or stay in the library, allowing for a democratic process. This way the material has a chance to be available in the future, rather than being removed by a single complaint. Some music and movies could get removed then replaced with the censored version so it is suitable for the people that were not offended, offering a compromise. In some cases there is only one person that got offended by something that was in a library, representing a minority view. In these cases the person could choose to wait until someone else is offended by the material to speak up about its offensiveness, ensuring the concern is shared. If material is offensive to someone they should get it relocated, voted on, or hold their peace, considering the greater good. If relocated the material is still available to other people who seek it out. When voted on it could stay or be removed based on community standards. Someone can speak up about the offensive material after someone else finds it offensive as well, creating a more compelling case for review.

Should books, magazines, music, and movies be removed from shelves, if found offensive? I think the answer is yes, as long as it offends more than a few people. They should be removed because offensive things can lead to more dramatic things. It's almost like when people were segregated by race; the segregation led to fights between the people. How would you feel if segregation was still around? You might be upset and find it unfair, because you cannot do some things. That is probably how some people feel when they get offended by the media, and such widespread offense can create real conflict. Why shouldn't they be removed for offending a few people? They shouldn't be removed because they might be able to help younger generations decide what is right and wrong. They could help by giving the people choices of what is right and what is wrong, allowing them to learn from the content. If there was nothing out there that offended anyone, how would younger generations learn how to decided what is right and wrong by comparing different ideas? In my opinion, it all depends on how many people are offended by it. There are ups and downs either way it goes. If you removed everything that offended anyone, it would be harder to teach younger generations to decided what is right and wrong by themselves. This would mainly be because you would only have one point of view, the point of view that is perfect for everybody. The way I see it, that point of view does not exist. Therefore, I believe by removing everything that is offensive to anyone, we would not have a media. However, if we did not remove anything that was offensive, serious issues could occur. For example, fights could break out or wars could even start, depending on how many people were offended and the severity of the offense. The last thing we need in our society is fighting. So my answer for removing offensive things would have to be yes and no, a balanced approach based on the scale of the offense.

There are countless books just like The Catcher in the Rye that are being taken out of libraries now and that could be deeply appreciated by the future writers and readers. Katherine Paterson has the perspective of many authors; taking out books that are offensive to people is going to cause us to have no books left at all. If they don't approve of the book then tell the child not to get it; that is a parent's right. A library is a place to enjoy the countless amount of literature of many different styles and should not be restricted to only the most inoffensive works. The library is a place of discovery, not a place of restriction, and it should remain open to all ideas.

Libraries are often known for protecting our children and keeping an educational atmosphere; however, you would be surprised the content our children might find in such a seemingly friendly place. With a simple library card, children could check out a boat-load of information that could be teaching them lessons you would not want them to learn. But nobody can be looking over their child's shoulders all the time. The answer to this problem is strict censorship of available materials. Books are big, powerful, and contain a vast amount of information. Even though most parents believe publishing companies would intend on not letting children read books that can be easily misunderstood, the truth is it's up to the library whether or not a book can be checked out. Most of the time, only adults can understand what the characters in a book are going through, grasping the complex themes and contexts. This might be because of the adult's extensively more experiences throughout their own life, which children lack. Another common belief is that separating a library for the younger and older would solve this problem. The fact is, even if an adult checks a type of media from the older selection, this does not stop the younger child from witnessing or reading something as simple as a video or magazine at home that was brought from the library. The only solution is to stop these materials from entering libraries in the first place and censoring the offensive, easily misunderstood media before it gets into the wrong hands. Libraries are great for research or school projects, but books and magazines that are inappropriate should never end up in the place built for an educational experience for your kids. Censorship has to be enforced to help keep and maintain our libraries' educational atmosphere and to keep our children safe from offensive material that they are not yet equipped to process.

In libraries, I think that if the librarian finds a story offensive, it should be okay for them to take it off the shelves; they work there after all and have a role in managing the collection. If it were me though, I'd just let it go, and if someone asks me to remove it, I might do it depending on the specific circumstances. A lot of people now-a-days, seem to take offense over everything. Well, what happens if you go to read the summary of this unfathomably great book, and you just feel...alienated, by the style that this book is written? Do you ever want to take that book off the shelf? Well, I do. But, if everyone takes a book off of a shelf that they are uncomfortable with, there would be a miniscule amount, if any books to read at all. Books based on race, religion and even personal appearance can be a nuisance, because it segregates people and creates divisions. When you go to the various sections of your local library, what section do you start sprinting towards? The adult section has tons of different genres of books, but what do you do when you find one about a different faith? If you are a person of a certain faith, and you find a book that is making fun of your faith what do you do then? Nothing, because there is freedom of speech. You might be uncomfortable about that book being sold in countries all over the world, but what if someone feels that same way about your favorite book. This is a topic people have been 'debating' for years without a clear resolution. Suppose you glide on over to an alienated shelf. This very colorful book is just screaming for your attention? You pick up the book and come to find, it is talking about religion. That could make anyone feel uncomfortable. I personally do not agree with making fun of people in this way. People are made to look different for a purpose, not to humiliate them but so not all of us look the same, and we can be our own person, unique and individual. What would you do if you picked up a book, where someone is being teased about their looks, and their size? Sure one joke can make everyone love you, but when one person is not very fond of you, well that speaks a thousand words. Different genres of characteristics include; being bigger or smaller, taller or shorter, having brown, blonde or red hair. Millions of people are criticized and teased relentlessly because they look just a little bit different. Everyone has been teased once in their life. It is not very funny to the person being teased; it can be hurtful and damaging. Books based on faith, religion and even personal appearance can be a nuisance, because it segregates people. I have written you this letter to tell you that I do not support some of the books on the market or the ideas they sometimes present, but if everyone felt this way there would be no books left at all. So I do not think we should take the books off of the shelves. We just need to embrace the fact that everyone is different, and that is not a joke. Where would the world be today, if we believed the same way we did years ago about these very topics? Do not take the books off the shelf, maybe one day it will signify what the world used to be and how far we have come.

It has been brought to my attention by some members of my community that the local library is planning to remove some materials such as our books, movies, and music. I've confronted them directly and they've made no such such effort as to amend the censorship that has already taken place. I understand that some works might be found offensive to some audiences, but I believe all people should have access to the knowledge they wish to acquire without restriction. These works they wish to condemn and banish are works of passion and labor, created with great effort. What I've noticed is, the materials they view as compromising are some of the most passionate, heartfelt labors of expression; and I firmly believe this removal act hurts more than those that are banished. This denies those artists of their own freedom of expression and represses something simple, our own expression and right to choose. The capabilities of the human mind are limitless, but yet those who display its functions are limited in their opportunities. Knowledge is the key to unlocking a much more vast understanding of the world around us and I believe this censorship highlights what I attempt to depict in my own exposition of our minds. I believe we have come very far in the evolution of our literature and I would hate to see the flame of inspiration for creation snuffed out in a modest dash, extinguished too soon. Just out of a few broken heartstrings? Or a spare tear lost upon the earth, dusted by some ignorance forsaken, misunderstood language doomed to be lost; out of a loss of understanding and empathy? I think not; the cost is far too great. In conclusion, I've noted what I wish to converse and I firmly stand against this censorship. I'm only one voice, but this is a call to arms and I believe we can accomplish great things together if we unite. So let's get the word out and defeat this repression of expression for the sake of future generations.

A library is a place to rent books, music, movies, etc., that you don't have at your home. Some people go to a library to use the computer for a project, or to check out books, musical materials, movies, etc. Censorship isn't a bad thing if the library has materials that are offensive to some people, but it must be applied carefully. If people don't want to see material that will offend them then they shouldn't go to the area in the library that contains the offensive materials; it is a matter of personal choice. In my own personal opinion, censorship doesn't really apply to me if there is offensive material in the library. If there is going to be offensive material in a library then you should be a certain age to rent it or read it, to ensure maturity. Not just anyone should be able to walk into the library and check out these offensive materials without some oversight. If someone that is under this age tries to check out this material, then they shouldn't be aloud to have them, as per the library's policy. Another opinion of mine on this subject, is if these kinds of material offend someone then they could not go to that area of the library. Instead the person can go around this section of the library or they could not pay attention to the materials on the shelves. The library could make a certain part of the library made just for these kinds of material, so that people nor children have to see them if they don't wish to. Also, if a child wants to see these kinds of materials then they could find another way to see them, perhaps online. They don't necessarily have to go to the library to find these kinds of things. If a child wants to do something badly enough then they will find a way to do it, or in this case the child will see something that they want to see regardless of barriers. If parents don't like these kinds of materials in the library then they should teach their children not to look at these kinds of materials, if they catch their children looking at materials that are offensive then they should punish their child and let them know that they shouldn't look at those kinds of materials. A library shouldn't have to take off their books, music, magazines, etc., just to satify parents; the responsibility lies with the parent. If the library took these kinds of materials off of their shelves then they would lose business from patrons who seek them. So in theory, libraries should not have to take their materials off of their shelves just to satisfy parents. Libraries need money so that they can buy new materials and without customers they have no money which enables them unable to buy new materials for the community. So parents should keep track of what their kids check out at the library, monitoring their choices. Offensive materials should not be taken out of libraries, these kind of materials should just have rules and guidelines for their access.

To begin with, a woman might read a book about wives and find it offensive. But it was her choice to pick up the book and read it. Should it be taken off the shelf? No, why should it? Different people have different perspectives on what they're reading. Not all people feel the same way about any given piece of media. The same thing goes for music, movies, magazines, etc. They might see a naked picture of someone in a magazine and not like it, but it was their choice to pick it up and look through it. No one held a gun to their head and said 'read the book' or 'look at the magazine.' Why should a book, etc., be taken off the shelf if one person doesn't like it? You still have the rest of the population who might love it, some might just like it, and others who might not. You can't just think about that one person; you have to consider everybody else. If that person finds that book, etc., offensive then they should have chosen more wisely the first time and/or never should have chosen what they did. It is their own fault and their own responsibility. For my conclusion, nothing should be taken off the shelf; if its offensive, just don't read the book and etc. Another person might read it and like it immensely. Some people who find things offensive are maybe looking at it in the wrong way or from a single viewpoint. Keep the book etc., on the shelf because if they take it off then sooner or later they will take everything off the shelf for being offensive to someone. Then what will we be able to read or listen to? We would be left with nothing.

There is much censorship that occurs in the world today. Music on the radio, television shows, or the internet is all censored to some degree. In today's society the library is a forgotten wonder to most, making it a secluded world of its own. The library is a place were one's mind can explore and discover as much as it wants without immediate judgment. The library should not be a place of restricted discovery, like on the television or the internet; censorship in libraries should be non-existant. People learn from all kinds of books; books with happy endings, and sad endings, and gruesome endings, are all able to provide valuable lessons for the attentive reader. Many say that history repeats itself. Therefore history is taught in schools so that the bad events that occurred in history can be recognized and prevented. This is the same for the books that are on library shelves. When reading a book, the reader is able to experience the lives of the characters as if they are living alongside them. Through the experiences of the characters, the reader gets to observe all the things done wrong and right by that character without actually living through the experience themselves. By the end of the book the reader will have new views on life, and will try to not make the same mistakes as the characters in the book. A major fear among parents is the inappropriate language or scenes that might be described in books. To be blatantly honest, there is foul language and inappropriate doings in this world. It is much better to have it discovered gradually through reading and maybe a couple of life experiences, than to have it all thrown in one's face at one moment. The censoring that occurs on the radio and television is fine for those mediums, but when someone wants to improve themselves by reading, they should be able to read whatever they feel is necessary for their growth. A library is a place of wondrous learning, but if there is censorship, it restricts one's learning and exploration. Through reading one is able to experience life without the consequences of experiencing life directly. All books are able to be learned from, and they should all have the opportunity to be learned from by those who seek them.

Have you ever felt as though your reading choices are dwindling? Censorship is taking away our freedom to experience and to read or listen to what we want; who has the right to tell us what we can watch, read or even listen to? As an avid reader of all kinds of literature I can't stand censorship. Kids today need to be able to read what they want, to open up their minds to new ideas and alternative ways of life. The so called 'banned' books are some of the best anyone can read, and as individuals we should be able to read what we want, whether it is offensive to some or not. If you want to put certain restrictions on a book such as an age limit I can understand that, but to completely take them off the shelves means we are losing our greatest right as a free citizen. To read and watch or listen to other media is a great way to learn about things other than what is in our own back yard. Regarding music and television I understand some censorship; I don't want my little brother or any younger youth hearing certain explicit language or seeing anything obscene, but these days it's getting harder and harder to control what they watch or listen to, seeing how it's so easy to obtain those sources of media. Many kids today have access to the internet which can be both good and bad. If a parent does not want their kids watching or listening to anything obscene then they have the right to put certain blocks on their computer. Kids these days mainly use two kinds of media which are the internet and television, but a kid who wants to read should have as many choices as possible whether it be fiction, classics such as 'The Catcher in the Rye', or educational literature. So are our reading choices becoming scarce? Yes I believe so, and it all has to do with censorship. We can't read some of the classics because they're deemed 'racist' or are 'pornographic', but you have to understand for the time they were written they weren't considered so. So let everyone read what they want when they want without unnecessary restrictions.

'Do you believe that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive?' No, I do not believe that just because someone individually finds something offensive means everyone else does. Everyone has a different opinion; we're all different and unique in our tastes. We need a variety of all books, music, movies, magazines, etc. to choose from. Censorship is understandable, in some ways and in certain contexts, but it should not dictate public availability. Without a variety for all, it would leave everyone with less choice and a narrower worldview. Your opinions, your decisions, and your outlook on life are one of a kind. How are you to tell someone they can't listen to a certain song or read a specific book? Exactly, that doesn't make sense, right? If individuals didn't have options and choices there would be no real entertainment or intellectual growth. In my opinion; if someone has such a problem with a certain topic, subject, etc. then they should simply leave it alone and not engage with it. It's a big world with more than just you with your singular opinion. Be open minded and consider others! Someone else is probably writing this essay with the total opposite response to this very prompt. It just goes to show no one's opinion is entirely right or wrong; it is simply their perspective. Individuals should all have their own individuality and the freedom to express it. Without variety and choice, how is that even possible? From music, to books, to magazines, to movies, disagreements are one thing but in questions like this you have to learn to agree to disagree for the sake of collective freedom.

'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf--that work I abhor--then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' Katherine Paterson said this about the topic of book censorship in the library. This is a very tricky subject because it seems no one will ever be completely happy. All books, music, movies, magazines, etc. can be considered offensive to someone, somewhere. When it comes to books in the library we should have clearly defined sections. One for young adults, children, family, activity, romance, etc. If we have those then it would cut down on what books children can easily look at and help guide their choices. One time I went to the public library and I accidentally wandered into the adult books section. I knew that I was not supposed to go into that section, but if they had it marked more clearly that it was the Adult Books section then I might not have gone in there. Parents need to monitor what their kids look at, or even what part of the library they go into. If a child wanders into the romance section then they are going to see that kind of book; it is not the library's fault or even the fault of the writer. If the parent does not want to monitor what the child looks at directly, they could set clear boundaries. They could say 'Do not leave this section.' If my mom said that to me I would stay around the child books. The parents could monitor the child to solve the problem of accidental exposure. Libraries need to decide what kind of books they are going to have in the library based on community needs, not individual complaints. If the library does not have the kind of books you do not want your child to see then your child can not look at that book there. If your public library does keep those books in the open the parents could always go to a town hall meeting and tell the mayor, librarian, or other townspeople about their concerns. If you tell people the library has that kind of books then others will perhaps stand up against the books or for them, starting a dialogue. If you do not like what the library has on the shelves, you can suggest sections for the books, keep watch of what your kids look at, or tell someone that can do something about the problem. What are you going to do to improve your public library? How are you going to make your kids not go and look at the books you don't want them to see without removing access for everyone else?

'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf-that work I abhor-then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' While many people believe that certain books should be banned from schools, just the opposite is true as students can learn valuable life lessons from these books, get a deeper understanding of the past, and comprehend the true meaning of an author's unique style. Over the years many well-written books have been on a 'censored list', meaning that they are at a risk of being removed from the library. 'The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn', 'Harry Potter', and 'Catcher in the Rye' are all examples of books that have been marked down as being offensive. These books are all written in a style of their own and can bring a different lesson to every reader. While one reader may love the story and wear out the pages, another may get halfway through and never finish it. However, the belief that there is freedom of choice in reading is correct. 'The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn' by Mark Twain is a classic example of a censored book. Throughout the book there is foul language used that is considered offensive to some. However, at the period of time the book was written, these words were not considered to be wrong. Books like this should be saved for older generations to read; however, we also have to realize that if a parent allows their children to read that book at a young age, there is nothing that can be done about it. None-the-less, removing the book from the library is not the correct response. Ever heard the saying 'learn from past mistakes'? Books are a fantastic way to learn about the past in a fun and enjoyable way. They are a tool of knowledge. Removing a book from a library is like removing hundreds of pages of knowledge. Every story has a unique style, which may appeal to some and not to others. Many books give readers a deeper understanding of what the time period was like when the book was written. 'Harry Potter' has been a known censored book from the beginning due to its somewhat dark and gloomy aspects at certain points throughout the story. How many kids do we see at school carrying around one of the 'Harry Potter' books? They often state that it is their favorite book of all time. If the book were to be removed from the library, it would cause many students to never have the opportunity to read a fantastically written book, which has a unique style about it. Throughout our twelve years of school, students are taught to think for themselves and make their own decisions. How are we encouraging this if we are removing materials from their grasp? If we cannot let students make such a simple decision as to whether or not to read a book, we are teaching poor life lessons.

Most works, even the more crude pieces, have some sort of educational value. Without articles based on the less comfortable or more gruesome items of life, people start to only understand in a surreal sort of way, not understanding how the less fortunate things function or how to avoid them. Those who pursue a true wanting to gain knowledge will look at many different kinds of informational items, no matter the subject. Allowing this to occur is allowing the library to be used as in the way it was meant to be used for, a resource for knowledge. All offensive items a library may have stored should stay in that very spot, for learning purposes. No one should be denied the ability to learn just because of the shielding nature of others.

Should we censor books in libraries? Katherine Paterson, an author, once said, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf - that work I abhor - then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' @CAPS1 provides a very valid point. If we start taking off books that we find offensive, there will be none left for anyone to read. Books are meant to provide information and insight into someone's life and experiences. If we take away that book, it would be like saying that person's idea did not matter, which is a form of intellectual suppression. The main reasons why we should not show censorship in libraries are a loss of insight, books, and personal creativity. Books provide insight into the author's life and the world they lived in. Also the things that are happening in history affect the author's tone or style, like @ORGANIZATION1. During his lifetime, @CAPS2 was ruled by kings, so if he wanted to be successful, he had to appease the @LOCATION1. It also helped appeasing the @LOCATION1 since he was sponsoring @ORGANIZATION1's plays. Another example of an author influenced by his time and upbringing would be @CAPS3. He was alive during the middle ages, and he constantly saw oppressive things like serfs. When he wrote his tales, he made the high class people sort of mean while he made the lower caste people on the humbler side. @CAPS3 was not afraid to displease the @LOCATION1 in his social commentary. If we start taking off books from shelves in a library that we think are offensive then soon there would not be any as Katherine Paterson wisely observed. Where one might find valuable information, another might find it highly offensive and vice versa. Every book would have someone say it was offensive for one reason or another. It might be the context or the tone or even the person who wrote it; it does not matter. Sometimes the books that are the most informative are the ones that are considered offensive. However sometimes it is good to have offensive things in books. It builds the tone and mood of the story or character, creating a certain image and teaching us not to emulate what these people are doing. The books sometimes show us a depressing ending of a person who lived a vulgar or criminal life. These stories teach us life lessons about consequences. Yes sometimes I read a book that I find offensive, but I have learned that if I do not like it, that does not mean someone else does not. It would not be fair then to take off a book that someone might have learned something from just because you do not like it. I am sorry, the world does not revolve solely around you and me. It revolves around us as a whole, and if someone starts taking off books, who is to stop someone else from doing the same? It would not be fair to impose one person's views on everyone. Finally, if we started taking off books, it would start influencing kids in thinking it was okay to throw away someone's creativity and hard work. It also might make them think that their own ideas would not matter and no one would be able to appreciate them in the future. I for one do not like doing things, if they might offend someone, but I could not imagine what it would be like in that type of restrictive society. Books are important to have. They teach us about events or people who were before our time or problems some people experience. It is important to be aware of what is going on around you in the world. I grew up ignorant of big problems that were occurring in society because my parents tried to shield me from the bad news and creeps in society. When you are taking your little kid to the library because they want a book you think 'hmmm, there isn't anything bad at the library its all education books.' But how would you feel if your child wanted to check out a movie there? You would probably be ok with it because no one thinks there are bad images or movies at the library. However, a little girl could be with her mom at the library in the adult section and they could see some things you would not want them to see. The romance books usually have girls on there half clothed and the guys in basically nothing. A child could easily see that and not know what it meant but they would have that image in there head for a very long time. Some of the kids could go up to the movies section and pull out a scary movie that shows blood and guns, which is also unsettling.  Its not just the kids seeing the stuff its everyone. A teen could easily get a book and not be paying attention and see stuff about the other gender that is too mature for them. A couple could go in the library trying to find a good healthy funny movie, but could find a movie that would make them uncomfortable with its content. An older person could try to find some music from back in their time but when they get it, all of it is about drugs, sex, or even alcohol, which is not what they expected.  The magazines always have girls half clothed, even in seventeen magazine, which is aimed at teenagers. The car magazines often feature girls modeling in front of the cars to make them look better or irresistible. You can get a baby magazine and it shows a mom breast feeding. You could have just wanted to look at it because of the babies, but you or your child do not want to see a mom breast feeding in a public context.  The library is a very resourceful place and you can get very good information about things there. They have some bad parts about them too. I think the music that talks about personal things and bad things should be in its own little place. Same with the magazines, movies and books; they should all be in a room together away from all the rest of the items in the library. They should have an age limit you have to be to be able to go in that room. They should tell you what type of stuff is in there before you go in, so you are prepared.  I'm not saying the library is a bad place for kids or teens or anyone. I just think that certain books, music, and magazines should be kept in a different place instead of out in the open where everyone can see them, ensuring a more comfortable environment for all patrons.

Libraries are stocked filled with all kinds of reading materials, such as books, magazines, and catalogs, but are all of these appropriate for the crowd that dwindle around a library? My answer is no, but should they be taken away from the libraries, no. Although many kids go through libraries, so do many adults trying to find good pieces of literature, which is why they should keep these books available to most, just with some thoughtful organization.  When I was in the seventh grade I recall reading a book, by the title of a popular author, about a child who had gotten sexually abused, and I wish I had never picked up that book. Although it made me very frightened, it taught me a very good lesson about the dangers in the world. I learned at a young age to never associate with strangers, and if it wasn't for this novel it could have been very different for me. Therefore I believe it is good to get children at a young age small dosages of the real life, not every thing in the world is sugar coated like some people would argue, and books can provide that perspective safely.  From classic novels to the bible, there is a vast variety of literature available. This variety provides stories for many different audiences and tastes. The libraries try to do their best by categorizing these books so that smaller children do not get their hands on the wrong books, using systems like separate shelves or sections. Instead of taking the books totally out of the repertoire, another suggestion that could be made is to have a system like they do for mature rated video games and only allow people over the age of seventeen to check certain books out. This would make it near impossible for children to get their hands on the wrong books without proper authorization.  Lastly, a suggestion that could be made is to label inappropriate books such as adult content and movies clearly. This could make a small difference and make children think twice before opening up a book labelled for mature audiences only, similar to warnings on other media. This provides stories for all, and protects small children from magazines such as those with explicit covers, ensuring a better experience for everyone.  Like Katherine Paterson said, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf... then you also have the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' I perceive what she is trying to say is similar to what I am advocating. She wants all the books to be provided and kids just to be shyed away from these, and hope that children can make the right decision when choosing a piece of literature from a library, which is a balanced approach to access and protection.

I think that if it is a problem for others and not all, why can't we just separate the things in sections? That way there would be no problems for those who are uncomfortable, while still allowing access for those who seek such materials. It is a simple and effective solution that respects everyone's preferences.  I mean, why change something entirely if only a few people don't like something? That's only going to lead to a big conflict and dissatisfaction among various groups. Think about if we were to try and give everyone what they want, how would that work out? Not good at all, as it would be impossible to please every single person. So you should just limit things down and put them in sections based on their content and intended audience, creating a more organized and harmonious environment for all library users. This approach maintains access while minimizing unintended exposure.

Censorship is a very sensitive topic. There are so many things people dislike, so they censor information, hiding the ideas from the people who don't know about them. I personally detest censorship. I would rather the world be an educated place with minor dangers, then a place where everything is kept secret and safe, as ignorance can be a greater risk in the long run.  You must be thinking, 'There are some things we have to censor, they can harm our children's minds.' But in truth, your children will find out about these topics in the real world eventually anyway, through friends or media. In reality, drugs, alcohol, sex, rape, violence, and all the other things you censor are common things that your kids will hear about. Most children first hear about them in school, normally elementary, and if not they will definitely find out in junior high. If they will eventually find out anyway, wouldn't it be better to let them find out the easy way, through controlled and educational materials?  Now you must be thinking, 'But if they find out too young, it could traumatize them.' That is a risk, but most teenagers are more traumatized anyway when exposed to difficult topics without any prior knowledge or context. If they already know what their dealing with they would know how to react, but if they have no knowledge of whats going on they could make a major mistake without even realizing the consequences. Once again, wouldn't it be better they find out from you or a book, then find out the hard way through personal experience or scare tactics?  Now, you might be thinking, 'Our children must be protected, this knowledge could just put them in more danger.' It might put them in more danger, that's always a possibility in any learning situation. The world is full of possibilities though, anything could happen at any time. This knowledge that you always hide from them might be what they need to know later on, and won't know when they need it most. What would they do if they see their friends start doing drugs, and since they have never heard of drugs, they don't know it's a bad thing to do? Or if they see older kids drinking, and are offered a drink, but don't know they shouldn't take it? Or if they wind up kissing someone they like, and it goes too far, but they don't know what their doing because they were never taught?  Anything could happen, and your children need to be prepared for the realities of life. If they don't know of these things, they can't tell if what their doing is good or bad, and they might wind up getting in trouble or hurt unnecessarily. Tell them, or let them read the books you always censor at the libraries so that they know and can make informed decisions. Life is full of risks, so let them know, that way when the time comes their ready to handle situations with wisdom and understanding.

As I walked through a local bookstore as a young girl I saw a popular magazine book, seeing this and being a girl that likes reading that magazine I opened it. I soon found out it was a book that I would never actually read because of its mature content. I found my self embarrassed and wondering why they wouldn't make it clearer that it should be censored or placed in an adult section. I think that censorship in libraries and book stores is a good thing for protecting young minds. Yes, kids need to learn about relationships and intimacy, but that is their parents jobs to teach at the appropriate time. A ten year old girl should not be able to see an inappropriate movie, magazine or book when ever she wants because we need to teach them ourselves in a careful manner. Censoring magazines gives children a chance to find who they are not what the world wants them to be, allowing for natural development.  Censoring the books helps by keeping small children 'sheltered' in a positive way; they don't have to know everything by age ten. It gives them time to grow up themselves without the pressure of adult concepts. The movies that are made often give a false out look on what sex and intimacy really is, creating unrealistic expectations.  You flip through magazines and see child stars everywhere feeling the pressure to grow up too quickly. They think they have to dress like an adult and act like one too, which is harmful. Children see this and think that if their favorite star acts like that so should I, leading to early maturation. The magazine industry really hurts children in the long run by promoting these ideals. They put the super skinny model in a barely there bikini on the cover. Sports magazines often prides itself on that image. Maxim has the swimsuit issue with a bunch of models laying around in clothes that barely cover them. The boys all think that its normal and that that's what every girl is supposed to look like, which is damaging. They get the men's magazines and drool over how the center fold looks. Letting small children see this makes them think that they have to dress and act a certain way to be accepted. It makes them think if you dress like this when you get older you can get all the boys too, which is a shallow goal.  Today there are so many books on how to keep your man happy, how to spice up the bedroom, and things to try in bed that a child could just walk and see easily. Many of these books have images of how do this and that that are explicit. That it could really make a child and his or her parent(s) feel very uncomfortable if stumbled upon. When you go to a bookstore or any book store they have a relationship, love section that are all these kinds of books. Many young people might think love, oh I bet that's romantic or a storybook tale. They see the cover that intrigues them, with a pretty girl on it. Censoring these books can give an ease to kids and parents by preventing accidental exposure. The kids can just grow up the way that they should, without being rushed.  Now movies give a very large false pretence on what sexual intercourse really is about. They see the people do all these things and they think that its normal and you don't have to worry about a thing, but kids here's the kicker sex is not just sex. When you have sex you have to make sure you are safe both emotionally and physically. This isn't just fun and games as portrayed. In our society today many young women get raped and assaulted. Does it show that on the movie no it doesn't, many young women as little as five go around thinking about how awful it was to be raped, but yet we set back and let pornography be made which often ignores these realities. Pornography is false, women don't just look at each other and get turned on without context. Sex is never going to just be sex, and by censoring the movies kids don't get that idea before they really learn and have the knowledge of what sex really means and is from a responsible source.  Censoring is something that I strongly believe in for the protection of children. To this day my parents still make sure the movies we pick are appropriate for our age. Parents and children can learn about sex whenever they want, but some parents choose to wait until their children are mature enough. By putting those movies and those books in a separate area it gives parents the chance to teach their kids in their own time, and the kids get the time to grow up without being burdened by adult concerns too early.

Katherine Paterson wrote, ''If I had the right to remove that book from the shelf that work I abhor then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else.'' This quote speaks to the core of freedom of speech, which is about believing in your own decisions and the choices you have made. If I were to reflect my views on censorship in libraries, I believe we all would have that same opportunity to state our opinion about what we feel should not be included. There could be inappropriate books in the library that we absolutely would not want our younger group of siblings reading. The best thing is to ask ourselves a fundamental question: Should we have the right to take our kids' freedom and right to read, listen to, and access updated media and publications from them when we had it? Should we put a censorship on the libraries really? I feel that censoring a library would not be necessary, considering a library is a manual guide of history. Our libraries are organized from A to Z in authors' names, separated into non-fiction and fiction, with CDs in one section, movies in another, magazines elsewhere, and adult books separated from children's books in different sections. Libraries all across the world have had a kid that might have chosen a book that was not appropriate for them to read, but what kid hasn't. What would a book hurt them if there is plenty of bad influences, peer pressure, violence, and sexually explicit publicity everywhere and prominently in the media. It would not be fair at all for us to rob our kids of the chance to read and learn from books. I feel no, we should not take our learning from our babies. Growing up as a kid I loved being able to go to the library; it helped to enhance my vocabulary, spelling, and I learned plenty of new words. The books I read growing up weren't perfectly suitable for my age, but I could relate to a lot of books I chose as a kid, so no, I feel we should not censor libraries. We need them to be a fun place for our children and us to go to for learning, fun, comfort, and etcetera. We can't take that from our generation; it just would not be right to deprive them of such a valuable resource.

Having offensive books and movies in a library shouldn't be allowed, as they can cause distress and conflict. If you were in a library and you saw a book or anything that you took offensive, more than likely someone else will find it offensive too, creating a shared sense of discomfort. So, by eliminating the problem before anyone else sees it, we will reduce problems before they even happen, preventing potential upset. Now, more than ever, you will find offensive things in libraries because societal sensitivities have shifted. More people get offended by lesser things now, which increases the likelihood of conflict. One reason to have censorship in libraries is that, if you had a child, would you want them going to the library and seeing derogatory writings and movies? I would be very upset if my child had to see that kind of material. It's teaching them different values and it's teaching them that since it's in a library it must be okay to do out in the community, which is a dangerous lesson. For example, if the library has a book or movie about doing drugs or anything sexual, they're going to look up to that and more than likely do those things, which they could end up harming themselves or others as a direct result. If the government provides the taxes for the libraries, doesn't it show that our government doesn't care about the offensive items on the shelves? It gives them a bad name and erodes public trust. If we look to our government for support and answers, we expect them to uphold community standards. How would we feel if they had no judgement about the offensive things in libraries? It would seem like they didn't care and that might cause panic throughout the country, leading to a loss of confidence. Which would cause many more problems then needed, creating unnecessary social friction. It would be an easier thing just to censor our libraries and avoid these issues altogether. If our libraries weren't consumed with negative and offensive literature, we would have a lot more room for things of greater value and educational merit. We could have books and movies that are educational and will actually teach a person something useful. Rather than lead them into making bad decisions, these materials would guide them toward positive growth. There are plenty of other sites and places you could get a book if you really wanted it; not just the library has books. You could find one quite easily if you tried, so the library does not need to stock everything. If a library does have offensive things, I think they wouldn't have a large variety, so it would be a better decision just to look for it elsewhere, where you could find a larger quantity of the subject you are looking for without compromising the library's environment. When I go to the library, I go there for educational books, not books that teach kids how to 'fill a bong' or 'different sex positions.' I highly disagree with such content and I think it's a negative outlook on our society by putting those things in our future generation's hands to read. So by putting censorship in our libraries, not only will it calm down some of the problems that are re-occurring in our communities, it just might eliminate the problem completely and create a safer, more constructive space for everyone.

There is a lot of different things that can be offensive to all sorts of people, making it a complex issue to manage. So if we started taking things off TV or out of books and magazines, we would be always taking stuff out, which is an impractical and endless task. If something is too graphic for kids, the simple solution is to put it in the adults-only area; this is a matter of organization, not removal. Would censorship be the answer to take out stuff? No, it is not the right approach. We need to be more aware of where our children are and what they are accessing, and there would be less problem as a result of this vigilance. If we made changes to the age limits on movies, we might be even better off, creating clearer guidelines. If parents were to watch the movie first or alongside their children, then the parent would be able to tell them what is okay and what is not, providing essential guidance. We need to put more true history stuff in them and make them where you want to watch them; we could be teaching kids more stuff so they know about the world. The music should be censored somewhat, like with rap music, which often contains explicit content. There is a lot of rap music that should be cleaned up so little kids don't hear it and are not exposed to inappropriate language or themes. There might even be a better way to control this stuff so little kids can't get a hold of it, perhaps through better labeling or restricted access sections. We can have teachers help tell the kids and let them know that it is not right for them to watch that, reinforcing the message at school. We also need to look at some of the new cartoons that are on TV, as their content is not always suitable. There are some that need to be cleaned up to be more appropriate for young audiences. There are also a lot of different opinions in what people want, which makes a single standard difficult. Then there are some that don't care about it too, adding to the complexity. Maybe someday we will figure it out and be able to do it in a way that satisfies the majority while protecting children.

A lot of people believe that books are useless and should not even be on a shelf, but this is a shortsighted view. Well I believe that no book is useless nor should it be removed from shelves from any library, as each has potential value. All books are worth something toward anything like careers, and being able to learn new things, providing unique insights and knowledge. Magazines may not be any help towards a lot of things like books are, but they are something to entertain you and offer current information. Music is not just something you listen to, but it's something to help keep you nice and relaxed while you are reading a book, enhancing the overall experience. Movies can have a certain impact on someone; a lot of people think movies are just entertainment for them to watch, but they could have some encouragement, or they can really show how a person acts if you really pay attention and look into what the movie is saying, revealing deeper truths about human nature. No book, magazine, music, or movies should be taken off shelves because they are not there just for you to read or listen to or watch, but those things are all there to tell people something about things people do not even know, expanding their understanding. People should take a second look at how all of these things can really affect a person's life in profound ways. More books, magazines, music, and movies should be put in the libraries of schools, or even the public libraries, to increase access. The more people read, watch, or listen to these things the better they may understand life and its complexities. I have noticed from experience that people just go to the library and read a book just to relax, but yet at the same time those people really do not understand what they are reading, missing the deeper meaning. It's really a shame that people do not look into what they are reading, that's why it would be important for more books to be put on the shelf to encourage deeper engagement. Just like Katherine Paterson said: 'If I have the right to remove that book from the shelf, the work I abhor, then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' If people really understood what that quote really means then they would have a better understanding of what books actually mean in life and the importance of preserving access to all ideas. We should be thankful to have authors like Katherine Paterson in our life because these authors are there to help us understand the meaning of these amazing books in this world and the diverse perspectives they offer.

A library is a public place for all ages, designed to serve a diverse community. They have many different kinds of books for specific reasons, catering to various interests and needs. For the children they have a nice comfy spot for them to pick a book and sit down and read it, making it inviting. For adults they have coffee tables, sofa seats, and many different things while they read their books, ensuring comfort for everyone. Never should a library have to disclose certain materials because of the ages that come in and out; access should be based on trust and personal responsibility. Censoring a library would not make it any easier to keep young children away from certain materials that are offensive; it would only limit access for others. I feel that when a child is in a library they should go to their specific areas for which they came for, and they should also be monitored by a parent or guardian while in the library to ensure they find age-appropriate materials. Most kids wouldn't go to a book that doesn't have a lot of pictures or colors in it anyway, as their interests naturally guide them. The library is a public place and is made for all ages, even though there are bookstores that sell just adult books, movies, and magazines, they still shouldn't be thrown out of a library, which aims to be inclusive. There should be equal rights all over, yes even in libraries, regarding access to information. The world is full of offensive things period, and sheltering children in one place is ineffective. Now while a child is not within a library they could be at home or in a public place and see things that they could also see in a book at the library, so removal there would not stop exposure. The removal of certain books, movies, and magazines wouldn't really stop anything; it would only create a false sense of security. I think that if the parents teach their children right from wrong there is nothing wrong with them being in a library that has adult books, movies, and magazines, as guidance is key. If I owned a library I personally would not mind all kinds of books that are appropriate to a certain extent in my selection of books, valuing diversity. I have been to plenty of libraries and have seen stuff that I thought shouldn't be in there but at the same time I was not in my right section or doing what I was supposed to be doing, which was my own responsibility. This subject really doesn't bother me, so no I don't think they should remove certain books just because children are in the library; instead, we should focus on education and supervision.

Censorship was the last time someone told you what you could, and couldn't do? Especially if it was something you didn't want to do. How'd that make you feel? You probably didn't want to do it did you. Censorship is somewhat the same way. The other day, my friends and I wanted to go see a new movie that just came out. We weren't allowed to see it though. You know why? Due to censorship, we weren't old enough to be able to see this movie. So, now the only way we'll be able to see this movie is if our parents go with us. Have you ever had your parents go with you and your friends? Doesn't go so well does it. Censorship violates freedom of being different. You can't listen to music, watch movies, or even read certain books, unless you're of a certain age. That's not fair. Censorship is like a modern day dictator. Tells you what you can and can't do, how you can dress, and what to say. Everybody would be the same then. How did that dictator do with his idea, he failed miserably. How do you think the historical victims felt, they were punished for believing, or doing something different. They weren't hurting anybody, they just wanted to live their lives a different way. That's what censorship is doing, classifying people into certain groups, telling them what they can and can't see, do, or listen to. That's what makes the world different, people that are different. Don't make everyone be the same.

The library is a place for people to go and read whatever they want. Some people just enjoy reading and others go to find information. People are allowed to read and write whatever they want and sometimes it might offend others but there's nothing you can really do about it. Katherine Paterson, who is an author, once thought that if a book was not one that she would want her children to read, then it should be taken off the shelf at the library. If you found a book in your public library offensive, would you want that book removed from your sight and public view? Personally, I wouldn't. I would not want the book to be removed because that book could be a good learning experience for others, offering a perspective I had not considered. In this essay, I will explain from my personal experience why I disagree with Katherine Paterson. In the sixth grade, I learned about how to find a certain book in a public library using the Dewey Decimal system. We had to find certain books in our school library, using this system, as an assignment. One of the books we had to find was the Holy Bible. I found it very easily because I knew where it should have been and what it looks like. But there was a child in my class who had never seen a Bible in her life. After helping her find the Bible, she asked, 'Why is this book so important to people? I don't understand it.' I explained to her in the best of my ability the life of Jesus and why this was important to me and many others. She soon found out that it was something she wanted to learn more about, sparking a genuine curiosity. It is against the law in some states that a Bible be in school at all. This is because of others' beliefs or non-beliefs. If it were not for the library having the Bible on a shelf, that girl would never have learned something that is now important to her. A book can be offensive to other people but that book can change a person's life forever. Katherine Paterson believed that some books should not be found in libraries. Unfortunately, other people think this also, which can limit access to knowledge. One book can change a person's life; what if that book was not in the library to change another? We must protect the diversity of thought that libraries provide.

Are there universally evil books that no one should read? Are good and bad no longer matters of opinion for the readers themselves? The answer is no. Censorship is a terrible practice masquerading as a boon. The right to read certain books should not be left to a conservative few, because everyone has their own opinion about everything. There is always something we can potentially learn from books, and it's never right to take that away. Freedom of speech should certainly come into play here as well, allowing the authors' words to be heard without interference from those who would dictate what we read. There is a reason libraries have many sections. They have to cater to the individual tastes of the masses, without regard to what other people find offensive. If one was to go through the library and burn every book they did not like, there would be scarcely anything left. Send in another person with different tastes, and then you have a completely empty library. It is far better to leave all the books alone so that everyone can find something to enjoy reading. Basically, there are bound to be people who have similar opinions to the author of just about anything, so allow the authors to share those opinions. Then we have the knowledge portion of the issue. Offensive material to one person might be what another person wants or needs to read, whether for recreation or class. There is much to be learned in the way of psychology and human nature from almost any writing. Perhaps a restricted section would be in order if the problem would involve corruption of innocent minds, but a full censor would never be necessary. Finally, there is an amendment in the Constitution of the United States for preventing censorship. It is unconstitutional to restrict any form of expressive speech, whether it be books, movies, music, or magazines. And what is more restrictive to an author than to have their books banned? The greatest difference between our country and a totalitarian government is the simple freedom allowed in the library. If we start restricting that freedom, what are we then? In short, censorship is a harmful practice that should never be used. People all have their own opinions, all media can be learned from, and our freedom should not be restricted. The practice of censorship is what should truly be banned from the shelves.

Censorship in libraries has been around for as long as there have been various mediums of art. In many cases, the censorship involves what many would agree is not suitable material for anyone to create and enjoy. But then there are other, more serious issues where the censor has deemed certain creations not suitable for a certain audience, or even for a whole country. What is it that gives a select few the right to ban any given number of imaginative creations, even if they are in some aspects more lewd in nature? Censorship has been and still is a very useful tool that many governments employ to accomplish a wide variety of tasks, considered to ensure the 'safety' of both our minds and bodies. Some of the more widely known cases of this most despicable tactic of control come from the countries of Nazi Germany, Soviet Russia, Communist China, and North Korea. In these countries, all materials that are deemed potentially hazardous to the welfare of the government are heavily policed and in many cases destroyed. The most noteworthy instances of this occurred in Germany, where the Nazi party would gather up large amounts of books from the people and burn them in massive rallies. The people were so enthralled by the party's leadership that they would often times freely relinquish their books with no resistance, and in some cases join in and throw the books in themselves. The same thing is still occurring in China today, with a censor still on their internet surfing possibilities. In 2010, the popular search engine Google attempted to set up shop in the country but quickly entered into a dispute with the government about the censoring of certain materials. Some months after the argument began over the censoring of China's people, the company completely removed all bans for a short time, much to the dismay of the government. During that time, it was reported that some of the main search topics were that of many social reformers and of different religions than that of the government's sanctioned religion. But the one country that takes the cake for having the most censorship is North Korea; their government has restricted and policed any technology in the country. The common people live in a so-called 'hermit kingdom'. In our home country of the United States, we are promised many rights to protect our freedom as citizens. We are promised the freedom of speech as well as press, and in censoring our libraries, they would restrict both. If we do not stand up and protect our rights, then who will? Are we not a government for the people, by the people? Why are we allowing the censorship of our own intellectual creations in a place that was created to provide access to said materials for those who are less fortunate, so they themselves can gain knowledge and understanding? If we as a people were to allow such a blatant restriction on our given freedoms, then we are in no position to have them in the first place. Our country was founded and later almost torn apart by the men and women who were willing to risk it all in order to protect their freedoms in this country. Are we descendants of those same people? If so, why should we allow ourselves to squander what was hard fought for and earned by our forefathers? The censor often poses a few questions that do cause one to wonder, 'is it really better off this way?'. They point out that for every great work of intelligent art, others of a more deviant nature create some more inappropriate pieces of 'art'. Pornography is the most prevalent of their examples, pointing out that if they did not restrict it, then who would stop the hundreds of children that not only roam the library's bookshelves but also the provided internet services. It is a reasonable question, one that should be taken into consideration, but in answer to it, I believe that it is and will always be the job of the parent or guardian that brings the child with them. It is simply not enough to drop a child off at the local library and hope they find something interesting. Helping that child find what they want is a journey that should be taken by both the parent and the child. And what about those who believe the censor isn't always right about what is and what is not acceptable for the general library? As author Katherine Paterson once said, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf-- that work I abhor -- then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' Censorship has been around for a very long time and will most likely never be fully cut out of any functioning government. That is sadly an inevitability that cannot be avoided. But the amount that it occurs in your daily life will be directly affected by how much of your freedom you are willing to stand up for.

Censorship is one of many important issues facing the world today. Many argue that materials considered offensive are damaging to society and should not be tolerated. Others believe that freedom of speech is a universal right that should extend to any and all forms of human expression. The issue is further complicated by the concept of what is and is not appropriate for children. Are there materials that are acceptable for adults but not kids? Questions such as this have plagued humanity for hundreds of years, and there is no simple solution. Today, so many people think of censorship as a bad word. In fact, there is nothing inherently wrong with the concept of censorship. It is only when people begin to abuse their power and censor materials that should not be censored that problems arise. For example, many countries have restrictions on selling and owning copies of 'Mein Kampf,' the book that Adolf Hitler wrote as a sort of mission statement for Germany. While many of the ideas contained within the book are horribly offensive, it still should not be censored. People have the right to read the book and form their own opinions on Hitler's teachings; it is not the government's place to decide for them. While oppressive dictatorship and mass-murder are crimes, reading about them is not. There are few materials available that should rightfully be censored and taken out of adult hands. If someone understands what they are reading and is able to form an educated opinion on the material, then nobody has the right to stop them from expanding their knowledge or expressing themself by creating similar material. However, the issue changes completely when one considers children. If adults want to view pornography or read accounts of extreme violence, that is their business. However, those concepts are obviously inappropriate for children, and any decent parent wouldn't want their young kids filling their heads with such things. Children need to be slowly and gently introduced to these concepts so they can fully understand them. In the case of children, careful censorship is necessary for healthy development. When it comes to libraries, there are very few materials that should be banned. If libraries are meant to be places of learning, then one has no right to limit the information they contain. However, that does not mean there should not be any limitations. Libraries should offer a children's section, as many do, that would contain materials only appropriate for youngsters. Then, it becomes the parents' responsibility to ensure that their child stays in that section. When a parent believes the child is ready to explore the adult section, they are free to take their kid there. This system gives parents the ability to keep their children away from harmful material without taking it out of the hands of adults. Many would argue that unsupervised children could gain access to inappropriate material, but that is really an issue that needs to be handled by parents, not the library. After all, it's better that a few kids see something they shouldn't have than all adults have to read censored material. In conclusion, censorship is a concept that has its place in society but must be used very carefully. When the goal is to protect people, especially children, from harmful material, it can be used sparingly. However, when those in power use censorship to attack ideas they disagree with, it becomes a form of oppression. Above all else, people must be free to educate themselves, form their own opinions, and express themselves. If someone doesn't like a piece of material, they can leave it alone, but they should never try to take it out of someone else's hands.

A very resonant and much talked about case of censorship is the popular book '@ORGANIZATION1 @ORGANIZATION1.' The book tells the story of a young white boy running off with an older black man. In the story, the word 'nigger' is used frequently, reflecting the historical context. A lot of people were offended by the using of this word, so they republished a new version of the book, replacing 'nigger' with 'slave.' While some people were happy with the word change, others felt that by censoring the word they were taking away a very vital part of the story's impact. I agree with the latter statement. The story's setting was back when black people were slaves and known by that term. I agree that the word nigger carries a heavy connotation, but that is the purpose of using the word. The author used it so that the reader could get a genuine feel for what life was like back then. When thinking about the coming generations, who will not know about slavery or black oppression, the book gives a raw insight into how life was for a black man. The word itself is a powerful symbolism of slavery, without it, the book is not as powerful or historically honest. Censorship is a fine line, and everybody has a different place where they draw that line. The story of @ORGANIZATION1 is just one example of modern censorship. On television, nudity and strong language is often censored when dubbed inappropriate for broadcast. It should be up to the parent to decide which books their child should read, which magazines they should buy, and which television programs they should watch. If the parent sees the book as offensive or thinks that their child should not read it, then they should be the ones who makes sure their child does not read it. The books should not be taken off the shelf because they will entertain and educate other children or parents. Books should not be censored; if a person does not think the book is appropriate, then they do not have to read it themselves or allow their children to read it.

Why should books that some people enjoy to read be removed off of library shelves? That is a ludicrous proposition. There are so many alternatives then to just take those certain books off the shelves completely, which is an extreme and unnecessary measure. We all have seen or heard of books that are inappropriate to certain audiences, particularly young children. It is completely understandable that young children should not read or be associated with these kind of materials such as: explicit books, magazines, poems, movies, and songs. It is totally unnecessary for children to be reading such explicit material, but it is possible for us to prevent their access without resorting to full removal. One way libraries throughout the nation can prevent this is by making a completely different section or even having the explicit materials be located in the total opposite side of the library from the children's materials. I know that many libraries tend to have opposite corners of the library dedicated to adult materials and childrens materials, but there should be more strict rules and perhaps even physical barriers regarding kids being in the adult section unsupervised. Another practical idea is to have parental permission settings on the child's own library card telling the librarian, when the child checks out a book, where in the library they are permitted to get a book from. For example maybe the childs' parents only will allow him/her to get materials from the children's section in the library; therefore if that child wants a material from a different area of the library they cannot get it, unless his/her parents are there telling the librarian the child is allowed to get it. This puts the control back in the parents' hands. I know when I was a child and I couldn't do something that my parents were doing, it made me feel upset and left out, but now that I look back I realize why they wanted me not to do what they were doing. They wanted me to be a child as long as possible. They knew if I was reading or listening to inappropriate materials then I was growing up way too fast and losing my innocence. I know that now and understand it now what they wanted for me. To conclude, lets keep those filthy books and magazines away from the younger kids through responsible measures. I don't want to see it get banned from the libraries or taken out of libraries entirely; I just want to see parents stepping up to be parents and not letting their young children be exposed to that kind of thing prematurely. It isn't the libraries faults if people's children are being exposed to this explicit material; it's the parent's fault for letting it happen and not monitoring their choices.
