Here in @LOCATION1, it is in our constitution that says anyone can have freedom of speech. This is a freedom to say anything they wish to get off their mind and to express their individuality and personal opinions. This fundamental right should also include the creation and distribution of books, music, movies, magazines, and any other form of entertainment and art. However, there will always be people that could take offense to others' ideas and opinions; that is an inherent part of freedom of speech. In a specific case where someone was to find a certain type of material to be offensive at a public library, then it should be known that he or she has the personal responsibility not to observe the type of material given. He or she should not throw a public tantrum over something that they find offensive while other people find it very enjoyable or meaningful. It is in that person's standpoint that they should realize and come to grips with the principles of freedom of speech. What they may not like could very well be what others do like and value. So, why should other peoples' form of enjoyment and artistic expression be censored and taken away from them just because of one bad lemon or a vocal minority? It shouldn't be. Everyone expresses themselves in their own unique way. It's a form of getting positive and/or negative energy out in a healthy and creative way. Whether it's writing books, posting articles, or writing music, it's a way to vent and some people genuinely like that venting person's style and perspective. It is completely up to that person who takes offense to materials on whether or not to observe such style; they can simply choose to look away. Censorship should not be allowed in public libraries. If there was a type of institutional censorship, it would be taking away what some person would like to enjoy and learn from. It would also be taking away the artists' or authors' freedom of speech and expression, which is a core democratic value. There are many famous books that were banned from schools throughout the country for various reasons. Just because an authority thinks something is right doesn't always mean it is right for everyone. Sure, they just want the people protected from certain offensive stuff, but why keep them from the realities of the real world? Let people out to see what this world is truly like and to experience its various types of art and literature for themselves.

Censorship for books? Never thought I'd see the day. But, that doesn't necessarily mean I approve or agree. Just because I don't approve or agree doesn't mean I do not oppose it. I find that I need to take a step back and argue both sides is sufficient and fair. Shall we? Among others, I find that if you censor one thing, you censor them all. Public items such as televisions, radios, magazines, and even books have wriggled their way into our not so perfect world. Yes, there are crimes and indecencies happening as you read this. But, is it entirely fair to say that these public items have completely influenced and brainwashed children into early adulthood? Maybe. Then again, maybe not. It is true that children, at their youngest, are easily molded and cut out into who they will permanently be, or at least until they're old enough to form their own opinions on certain topics. For instance, when I was younger, my cousin, who happens to be just a few years older than me, started to like a certain thing. After spending time with her for an elongated amount of time, I started to 'like' it too. I found myself obsessed with it. Now, before you start getting it into your mind that it was something bad, I can assure you, it was nothing other than stacks of Pokémon cards. Anyway, it wasn't until later that my mother informed me that it wasn't really my interest. It was hers. I modeled after her likes and dislikes. Every other child in the world has done something similar. What makes anybody think they wouldn't do the exact same after listening to uncensored music, watching uncensored television, or reading an uncensored book or magazine? On the other hand, it would be unfair to take away some books that people find to be improper or indecent. If that were the case, nearly every book would be out of sight, but not out of mind. Today, you can't turn on the radio without hearing something about sex, drugs, alcohol, or smoking. Now, those things are a lot more accessible to anybody. You can't turn on the computer without advertisements for porn or other sexually crude websites popping up on your screen. Books have gotten out of hand, as well, with content that was once considered taboo now being commonplace. The world nowadays has gotten ridiculous and out of place. But in the end, I'm sticking to my original opinion: If you censor one thing, censor them all. It's only fair. Radios, television, movies, and even video games have been censored. Books are not as innocent as they seem, anymore. So yes, my final opinion is that libraries should, in fact, censor their books, or at least make an effort to. Libraries are places to learn and have fun doing so, not have a mental scar leading back to what they read in a 'harmless' little book.

What is censorship? Censorship is editing or just plain getting rid of something. Censorship can be a good thing; it could also be a bad thing. Does censorship really help in our society? Actually, think about it, there are still murders, rapes, and whatever else with censorship. How I would argue with this, is by listing my own experiences, observations, and readings. Firstly, my experiences would have to be about movies and/or television shows. In some movies you get to choose what you want to watch: the unrated version or the censored version. Well, most people want to watch the unrated version, because it's more than likely more funny and shows more. Other people might choose the censored version, because of the fact that they have children and don't want them watching stuff that would be in the unrated version. I would preferably pick the unrated version, because I like all the funny parts that wouldn't show in the censored version. Then there are those television shows that 'bleep' out a lot of words, because of course you are not allowed to say them on television. Parents don't want their six year old going around and saying all of them nasty words. That's why most of the time you hardly ever see those kind of shows on in the afternoons; they are usually on at nine o'clock or later. Secondly, my observations about movies and/or television shows. I can't say that I don't watch shows that have some language in them, nor can I say that I don't watch shows that are all bloody and gory. I do watch them, but I would never watch them around my younger sister! She is eleven years old; I don't want my little sister going to school and saying a bad word and have a teacher hear her. Then she would say well my sister was the one who watched the movie. I would also never ever watch a bloody, gory, and really graphic movie in front of her either. Some movies could do without so much violence, but they have to make money some how. Right? Last but not least, my readings about, let's say books and/or music lyrics. So many books have been banned across the country, because people were offended by them or just didn't want that book on the shelves just in case their child reads it. Some songs can't be played on the radio, because of some of the stories behind the music and/or the words in and throughout the song. That's why the artist of the song has to make two different copies of their song, so they can be played and so they will get popular. I have read books that do have some words in them, but they are also my grade level and I'm pretty sure most people are more mature than they were. When I see a word that isn't the nicest word ever, I keep reading and don't let it bother me. Same with songs; the artist probably has a reason why he/she uses the words they use. Censorship can be good or bad; it really depends on how you look at things. Honestly, I have no objections to censorship and other times I do. My experiences, observations, and/or reading has made me think about how censorship could be bad or good depending on the specific situation and context.

Older authors love to write grusome stories about their pasts, whether it's fiction or nonfiction. Sometimes those books can get into the wrong hands and end up in the trash or burned by overzealous parents or community members. Other times parents get angry at what they're children are doing and saying, and they normally blame television or other kids at school, rarely considering the influence of literature. Parents don't always look at the big picture and consider all sources of information. Any child at anytime can walk right into their school or public library and pick up an inappropriate magazine, book, or movie, but parents don't usually catch on until it's too late and the material has already been consumed. There are all kinds of books out there and no two books are the same, each containing unique themes and content. Nobody can tell a book is going to be inappropriate just by looking at the front cover, as the content within can be surprising. Even though books are meant to be read, it doesn't mean they should be read by all age groups without discretion.  No book at any point in time should be completely removed from a library, that's just not right and constitutes censorship. No matter how graphic, perverted, or inappropriate a book can get, it should never be thrown away or destroyed. Those certain books are written for people with those kinds of interests or for educational purposes. Even books about drugs should be allowed to be read, some children or adults could be interested in what they really do do to your body and mind, and they'd rather read a book about it rather than trying it themselves, which is a safer alternative. Books about murder should also be allowed to be read, but not by children under twelve, as they may not be emotionally prepared. If people in libraries would just start putting books in organized age groups then there probably wouldn't be any problems with access.  The author should never be blamed for something they wrote, as they are simply expressing their creativity and perspective. It's their own personal thoughts and feelings and most of all it's their story to tell as they see fit. It's how they wanted it to be written and nobody should get mad over that, as artistic freedom is important. The rule should apply for magazines, music, and movies as well, as these are all forms of creative expression. Those people wrote the books, movies, magazines, and music so it should be expressed the way they wanted it to be, without undue interference. Even if the authors themselves thought their own writing was too bad for a child to read, or hear they would make it clear by putting something like, 'not for children under the age of twelve or whatever age they recommend' directly on the cover or in the introduction.  If adults are really getting mad about this then they need to look back at the kinds of things they were doing, saying, or reading when they were younger and maybe it would change their outlook a little on movies, magazines, music, and books, fostering a more understanding perspective.

Human beings, like snowflakes, are very much alike in a unique way, sharing fundamental humanity yet possessing individual traits. Just as there are no two identical snowflakes, no two humans are exactly the same in thought, experience, or curiosity. As everyone has their differences, there are always those who have a greater sense of curiousity, and prefer to think outside the box, exploring unconventional ideas. However, it is difficult for these curious people to extend their strive for knowledge, if they have restrictions as to what they can read or study, stifling their intellectual growth. Therefore, if a person is mature enough, and desires to study or read upon a certain topic at a library, they should be allowed to extend their knowledge on any topic of their choosing, with permission of a gaurdian of course, to ensure guidance.  Unfortunately, it is often times a group of minorities that ruin something for the greater minority by imposing their views on collection policies. Libraries often times take in account a child's age as a factor towards what a they can, and can not read, but age seems completely unfair to a child who is mature enough to read, and handle the more adult rated intell in a fashionable manner, as maturity varies individually. If one is legally eligable, and they have permission from their gaurdian, then he or she should have no restrictions to the materials provided at any library what-so-ever, allowing for personalized learning. Who is one to say a ten-year-old is too young to learn about historical figures and their horrible plans for the world? A person is never too young, or too old to learn something new, if the curiousity and the proper level of maturity is present to comprehend the material!  It is curiousity that has led mankind to discover something new each and every day, driving scientific and social progress. As well, it is curiousity that has brought mankind to the extraordinary level of technology, and inventions that it is at today, from medical advances to space exploration. The youth of the present will one day be the engineers, doctors, scientists, and moving leaders of the future, shaping our world. If these young people are curious, and desire to achieve greater knowledge on a certain topic for positive reasons, then let them be to explore and learn without unnecessary barriers.

In most libraries in the country, there are certain books, movies, music, etc., that could be inappropriate to younger children due to their mature themes. These books and movies can contain graphic content or offensive language that any young child should not be hearing or seeing, as it may be confusing or disturbing. However, this does not mean that the libraries of our nation should get rid of these books, videos, etc. entirely, as they serve a purpose for other audiences. The libraries should keep these books and videos because the adults of the community like to use them, the kids probably already know about the language and graphic content from other sources, and some of the books and movies that are offensive are very educational and historically valuable.  When you think about your childhood, there would always be things you couldn't watch or listen to because you were to young, enforced by your parents. Your parents and grandparents would watch movies that you couldn't watch because they would say you aren't old enough to understand the complex themes. They enjoy watching more mature movies because it is more interesting to them than cartoon shows or movies, offering deeper narratives. The mature content in movies, books, and more should be kept in libraries because mature audiences enjoy watching and listening to them for entertainment and insight. If they are taken out of libraries, this mature audience has nothing to watch or read in the library that suits their tastes. They do not want to be reading children's books all the time, as their interests are more sophisticated.  Also, most children have already observed or heard this offensive content in these books and movies from various sources outside the library. Most of the parents in the country have used offensive language infront of their child without even realizing it, modeling behavior inadvertently. The kid then starts using these words because they think they are cool if mom and dad use them, or they hear them from friends. Another thing is that most kids have seen a movie with graphic content in it, or they have played a video game with it in the game, often at a friend's house. They have seen blood, gore, and other things in these games and movies, so the content is not entirely new. It's already too late to try and hide your child from seeing or hearing these 'bad words' or 'graphic content' in today's connected world.  Many movies and books that contain offensive language and graphic content are very good and educational videos, providing valuable lessons. For example, historical war films were great movies describing the search for one man in the middle of a major world conflict. These wars actually occured and movies like this give a great amount of detail on what actually went on during these wars, teaching history vividly. If you want kids to know about the history of our country, they need to know what actually happened, without sugarcoating the reality. There is no point in trying to hide the truth of historical events, as understanding them is crucial.  Overall, most kids in the country have heard offensive language or seen graphic content through various media exposures. Whether it was from a parent or even their best friend, they have heard it, making library materials just one of many sources. So why would we try to hide this from them in a library setting? Keep these books, movies, music, and more in the libraries for the benefits of the adults, the kids, and for the history of the country, ensuring access to a full spectrum of information and culture.

Do you think censorship is going to prevent people from getting offended? Taking items such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., will not stop people from getting offended, as offense is a deeply personal and subjective reaction. The central questions are who decides what is offensive, and how is it offensive? What makes something offensive to one person may be entirely inoffensive or even inspiring to another, highlighting the inherent flaw in any attempt to create a universally acceptable standard for media and expression.

No Censorship. Do you enjoy reading interesting books, watching superb movies, or listening to appealing music that some people don't approve of? Most people would answer yes to the question because anything that a person reads, watches, or listens to can be found offensive or crude to someone else. Certain materials in libraries should not be removed from shelves if they are found offensive because different people find different materials offensive, people sometimes specifically come to libraries to search out materials they can't find elsewhere, and if a person finds a material offensive, they don't have to keep reading, watching, or listening to it. The first reason why censorship shouldn't occur in libraries is because different people find different materials offensive. Each person is different, and people have all sorts of opinions on books, movies, magazines, music, etc. Also, several different ethnicities exist in the world and many nonfiction books educate people on different cultures around the world. The ethnicity of the people living in the culture might find what the authors of nonfiction books are writing about them offensive because the book is talking about something in their culture they wouldn't want the public hearing about. However, the public needs to be educated on the cultures of different people. Students do research in libraries for research projects and essays. Also, books pertaining to racism such as To Kill a Mockingbird and books about slaves may be offensive to the race that is being victimized in the book. In contrast, some people may love the book because of a good theme, symbolism, word usage, etc. So, who would be the judge of whether a material is offensive or not? If the person who is doing this for a certain library finds many materials in the library offensive, the whole library could close down because many materials that could have been popular were taken out of the library. Another reason why certain materials shouldn't be removed off shelves if they are found offensive is because sometimes people specifically come to libraries to search out materials they cannot find elsewhere. Libraries are the one place that people go if they are looking for that certain book or maybe even a movie they can't find at a video store. In my experience, there have been an infinite number of times where I have wanted to read a book I have heard about, and I've gone straight to the library and found it there. Also, because no video store exists in the town I live in, I go to the library for movies because I know they have a large selection. Some of the books and movies I or other people like may be found offensive to others, so if they were taken off of library shelves, I'm not sure if I would go to the library as often. A third reason why censorship shouldn't occur in libraries is because people don't have to read what they might find offensive. Everyone has the choice of what materials they acquire from a library, unless it's something they have to read for school. If a person hears about a book that may be found offensive to them, why would they read the book? Also, if a person accidentally checks out a book or watches a movie from the library that they find offensive, they can always just stop reading the book or watching the movie. Censorship shouldn't occur in libraries because everyone has different opinions, and the role of a library is to provide a broad spectrum of ideas for individuals to choose from freely.

I do not think that any books should be taken out of libraries because they are found 'offensive'. Something that is offensive to me may not be offensive to another. Although I have all the right in the world to object to a book that I find inappropriate, somebody else might believe that that book is completely appropriate. The main issues that most people have with books are foul language, sex, and difference in opinion. These three categories are very sensitive issues, and some may not be comfortable discussing these issues. Many books in the library systems today contain foul language. Surprising enough a majority of the indecent language can be found in the young adult section. I don't believe that parents would be very happy to know what their children are reading, but that is a matter of parental guidance, not library policy. In our modern day world we are bombarded with images of sex and indecency. Books containing obscure acts are no different from television or magazines. Most romance novels are very descriptive and leave little room for imagination, and in the wrong hands can lead to some very prompting questions, yet they serve a legitimate audience. Difference in opinion can be a big problem for some libraries if patrons do not like the message a book sends. Religion, politics, and morals can lead to some nasty debates, but sometimes we have to just agree to disagree, and libraries should be a forum for this exchange, not a casualty of it. Can teenagers handle that kind of language and sexuality in a responsible way? Should the books be taken off the shelf just on the basis that we don't agree with what it says? Should there be a censor on what can and can't be put in libraries? I don't think that any books should be taken off of library shelves. If you don't agree with the book then don't read it. Instead of blaming libraries for what your children read, perhaps you should look at your own parenting and make sure they aren't reading something they shouldn't, thereby preserving access for all.

If every book was gone from the country, what would kids in school be able to read? Kids would start reading at a slower rate, causing grades to drop. Certain material such as books, movies, and magazines should not be removed from libraries. The quote by Katherine Paterson simply states that if everyone had the right to remove a book from a shelf, then we would have no books left on the shelf for any of us. The world of literature would be empty because there is always something that a person sees as offensive, whether for religious, political, or personal reasons. To each person that finds the material offensive, there are always ten people who do not find it offensive at all, and may even find it enlightening or necessary. A person's beliefs can cloud their views on things like religion or social issues, leading them to demand removal of works that challenge their worldview. There are so many wrong things out in the world that you can never do right by everyone, and attempting to do so through censorship is a futile effort. In places like libraries, you never know who might come in to check something out, from a student researching a topic to an adult seeking a new perspective. That is why it is recommended to make sections in the library, a practical solution that maintains access for all. Adult novels, children's books, science fiction novels all in different sections of the library. This would make a parent cautious of where their child goes and allows them to supervise their children's choices. If a child walks into the wrong sections, there is only one person to blame; the parent, for not providing adequate guidance. Children always wander off into random places because of curiosity, and it is a parent's role to steer that curiosity appropriately. Parents have to make sure that nothing horrific happens such as seeing something that a toddler or a teenager is not supposed to see, but this is a matter of vigilance, not censorship. One object, such as a book, a movie, or a magazine, can teach a person millions of lessons about history, humanity, and themselves. If those lessons are not taught yet, they will be taught later, often in a harder way. The person might have to live the lesson to learn it, and literature provides a safe way to explore complex themes. That is why some material should not be taken away; it serves as a crucial tool for learning and empathy. Everyone believes in different things, and a library should reflect that diversity. There is always someone that has a different opinion of things, and a public institution must cater to a public, not a single viewpoint. The world contains of many things that people find offensive, but it does not mean those things have to go; understanding difference is part of education. There is always a choice of what to do and what not to do, and individuals should be free to make that choice for themselves. Someone has to find a way to fix things and in a good kind of way where people can find peace with themselves and others, and that way is through dialogue, not removal. Removing material from libraries can cause many things; approval from some, disapproval from others, anger, and happiness. Most of all, it can cause fights and deep divisions within a community, which later on can turn into a war over ideas and freedoms. The material in our libraries is meant to teach people about life, and if people find that wrong, then it means they do not wish to fully experience life with all its complexities and challenges.

Censorship is not an easy question to answer; it involves a great deal of thought and consideration for various perspectives. When thinking about a topic like this you must look at a greater picture beyond immediate concerns. When it comes to censorship in libraries I feel that all the books should be left on the shelves, as a library's purpose is to provide access to information and ideas. So, why would we take books away from people who want to read them just so that others don't? This seems like an unfair solution that prioritizes one group over another. If you don't want a child to look at adult books, then you can censor them by watching them, and not taking them to places that have such books, thereby teaching them responsible media consumption. This way other people can read these books and benefit from the stories and knowledge they contain. If you truly think about it, then you will realize that if you are trying to keep something from a teen they can, and will, find a way of getting it, often making the forbidden content more appealing. If you are trying to keep things from them that will only make them want it more, fueling their natural curiosity in potentially less safe environments. Books are good for people; they expand the mind and foster empathy. It tells them stories that cannot happen, past events they did not live through, and even the thoughts of others, which is vital for a well-rounded education. Keeping books away from people is not good for them; they would not be able to learn from the things they read and would be sheltered from different viewpoints. So, maybe some books are more racy than others, that does not mean you should hide it from your children; it means you should be there to discuss its content with them. If you were to start censoring books in libraries it could cause some significant problems for the community. Now you will have no books for some people who rely on the library for their reading material. You will have taken most books out of libraries because one person thinks it is not good for the children, ignoring the needs of the adult population. This will cause arguments over what should and shouldn't be in the library, and people will stop going to the library all together, defeating its purpose as a community resource. So, when you think about banning books just remember that there are other places to get books, and banning them from the library does not erase their existence. Books are good for people especially teens, whose minds are developing and need exposure to complex ideas to grow. In some places books that are banned in other places are celebrated for their literary merit or cultural significance. When trying to get rid of books just think about the people you are taking them away from, and the value those books hold for them.

What is this country's main idea in the area of art, language, and music? The idea in those categories is freedom. Freedom is to write what we want, draw what we want, and say what we want, and in all, to express ourselves freely as a person. It is one of the amendments in the 'Bill of Rights', known as freedom of speech. Saying that, I believe that we should not be able to ban, censor, or remove any books, music, or movies from the American public. It is their right as an American to buy what they want. It takes away freedom from people, and when they do that, it makes citizens feel like toddlers. They can't choose for themselves what to see and what not to see, which is a fundamental right. Everything in this world can be offensive to somebody. Just because that one person finds something bad or distasteful, doesn't mean that they have to make everyone else stop seeing it. That's what gives the world its varieties. What someone might think is weird, somebody else might think is normal. When that happens, why is it okay to take away what makes that person feel normal? Just to make the other person feel better? I walked into the store once before wanting to buy a videogame. I found one I thought looked cool, took it off the shelf, and brought it up to the cashier. He took one look at the game, saw the rating for it, and said that I had to have an adult with me to purchase the game. I went on about how my dad would not care if I bought this game. The cashier said it didn't matter and that I still had to have him here. Then I had to search throughout the store looking for my dad so that he could walk back to the cashier to buy the game for me. What difference did it make? In the end I got the game anyway. That experience I had at the store that day let me know how it felt to have my wanting of something be shot down. It made me feel like a baby that needed permission to do something. It also helps me know how the writers, artists, and movie directors feel when they get their work censored, rejected, or banned because somebody somewhere found it offensive. We need to let people express how they feel. If we didn't then a lot of the stuff today would be different. Columbus had the idea of the world not being flat and that he could sail all the way around the world without falling off of it. Everybody thought he was crazy and got angry at his thinking. But he did it, and proved himself right. Galileo Galilei thought came up with the theory that the sun did not revolve around the Earth. He started doing experiments and tried to prove his theory. The people of where he did his work got enraged and threw him into exile and imprisoned him. After that somebody thought that it was a good idea, he experimented on it, and the people supported him. Now we have that theory as a fact, that the sun doesn't revolve around the Earth. That is what makes freedom of speech so important to the world. It makes people think in different ways and helps people think of new ideas. Freedom is the key to any way of living and progress.

Some people have even removed the Harry Potter books from local library systems, deeming them unsuitable. Does it even matter what the owner wants to sell? In most cases, no. The belief in a religion or even a book, magazine, or movie that had one small comment about; sex, drugs or alcohol is removed for just that. If we remove everything about any of that, the only thing left would be children's books. Some people would find ways to get those censored as well. We would become illiterate without books, magazines and other things of that nature, losing access to diverse knowledge. There's even an account of a person being fired from their job for reading a magazine on their break at work! This censorship is a major problem, very few people really care about this subject. Most think it should be done to most items, some think we don't need to censor anything, as we are a free country with rights to choose. So newspaper editor, please question yourself, ask yourself, 'Would I like to have all of my favorite magazines, books, and movies gone forever, never to be seen again?' Some books on the library shelves contain material that some may find objectionable, whether due to the subject matter, the presence of curse words, or simply being inappropriate for certain age groups. This raises the question: should the books at libraries be censored, or should we just leave them for the reader to decide if they want to read them or not? I do not think any of the books or magazines should be censored. If someone wants to read a book with curse words in it or anything like that, then they should be allowed to do so. Parents may not permit some kids to read them, but some parents just do not care. I think if children read them, they might repeat the words, but they will learn not to say them and that they are not very nice to say. The same principle applies to movies you can get at libraries. I do not think they should be censored either, because parents are not going to let their children get a movie or watch it if they do not think it is something they should be watching. The kids generally know what they can and cannot watch, so if it is something they know they are not allowed to watch, then they should not get it. Even if a child does get it, the parents could always take it away and explain that they cannot watch it. Should all books, magazines, music, or movies from libraries be censored? The answer is no. If it is a school library, everything does have to be school-appropriate. If a book, movie, magazine, or music is not appropriate, then the school cannot lend it out. A public library can stock a wider variety, and there are mostly adults there anyway. Children should know what they can and cannot watch, read, or listen to, so they should know better than to get something that is not for them. Some parents may agree with censoring materials, but if you do that, you are limiting the books everyone can read. Even the parents or adults would not be able to read them as well, which restricts access for everyone.

Censorship in libraries is almost a primitive, if not childish, way to exclude what one might think to be offensive from everyone else, is it not? Think about it. A kid who does not let another kid play with him at recess today, only because he stuck his tongue out at him during math the previous day, seems pretty childish, and several much more reasonable solutions come to mind to anyone who sits and thinks about the situation for more than a second. This scenario runs parallel with censorship in libraries. A book is a book to be read. That is, of course, an obvious statement. But why read a book? To get information. To learn something that you did not know, or to build on knowledge that you already had. How do you cook an exquisite meal? Go read a book to find out. How do you graph linear equations? There are books that will explain it for you. Is it fair for an avid astronomer, feeling no need to know how long a turkey needs to stay in an oven, to remove a book that teaches that very thing? Now, of course, cooking a turkey will most likely not come across as offensive to someone perusing through their local library; however, think about this. The book has been written, so is that not a sure sign it is not offensive to at least one person, that being the author? There are things people will not agree with. And just when you think you find something everyone likes, someone will come along and disturb the peace. Not everyone likes rap music, but it is still playing on the radio. It is a free choice to listen to it. It is a free choice to read a book, regardless of what it says. Just because people have the misfortune to be subjected to material they find offensive, by accident or otherwise, and then project their disdainful comments toward someone in charge, does not mean that the offensive material should be thrown out. Perhaps, radios and libraries can be even further examined. Radios have specific channels, playing specific music. There is a country music channel for those who want to listen to country music. As for libraries, there is of course the Dewey Decimal System, but that is about as far as categorization goes. Suppose books were even further distinguished by their location within a library. A certain area designated for certain genres. That way, if you happen to find books about historical concentration camps distasteful, then you can avoid the history and historical aisle of the World War Two section in your library. Problem solved. I find it hard to see something as offensive if I cannot even literally see it. You see, outright removal is not really the best option for pleasing dissatisfied people. Compromise is. Now, after having thought about this situation for more than a second, I am sure you have thought of much more reasonable solutions than something so ludicrous as censorship. Now the best part is seeing people enjoy books, and not being offended by the ones they do not like anymore.

Picture for yourself you, as a ten-year-old child sitting in front of one of the greatest philosophers of history, in ancient Athens. Days later, you come to find out that he has been killed for 'corrupting the minds of the children.' Why? One of the greatest minds in human history has been censored because they didn't like his ideas. This is censorship at a basic level, and it happens to millions of books, movies, and songs every day. Censorship is not only wrong, it's unnecessary. Here's why. Fundamentally, when it comes down to it, most books, movies, and songs are meant to be interpreted in many different ways. For example, some poems are written with a vague tone so that they can be interpreted in different ways based upon the person. Besides, most music and books are meant to entertain, not offend. Granted, some books are meant to be interpreted in a certain way, but that still doesn't mean that they were meant to offend. Think about it next time you look at a copy of 'The Catcher in the Rye' by J.D. Salinger; is it really that offensive to you? When you are given a book in school for a class assignment, they usually expect you to read it because it's of some educational value to you. Books like 'To Kill a Mockingbird' provide a huge educational value because they show what Southern culture was like, but everyday, someone new is trying to get it off the shelves of every school library in America because they find it offensive. Ask yourself, is it right? The answer for me is no, since books like that hold an educational value that outweighs their offensiveness. There's one last thing you must understand, and that is the fact that no matter how many books you take off the shelves, and no matter how many movies you ban, or how many songs you take away from us, the problem still isn't solved, it's just been suppressed enough for different problems to arise, and those problems are that there are people who wanted to read this book but can't because you thought it was offensive. Then this person complains to whomever banned this form of literature, and the book or other form of literature is put back on the shelves. Then you feel it right to try and ban it again, but what does that solve? Nothing. Even if someone doesn't unban it, people can still teach and tell of what it's about, making the ban worthless. I hope that before you think about complaining about some book you found offensive, you think about this. Your complaint that causes the banning affects everyone. It affects a teacher's ability to teach, and a student's ability to learn. Is it really right of you to take away a good teaching material? Or you could ask yourself, what does it really solve? Either way, you still must know that banning these things is wrong and ultimately counterproductive to the pursuit of knowledge and understanding.

The views on censorship in libraries definitely varies from person to person. There are those who are offended by the material that is out there for anyone to access, and then there are those who want the right to read, listen, and watch whatever they choose. I believe there are pros and cons to each choice, either way you look at it, but there does need to be some sort of censorship in libraries; the line must be drawn somewhere. The lyrics in music can come off extremely offensive to some people, containing vulgar language or violent themes. The inappropriate scenes in movies, whether it be involving two people of opposite sex or intense action moments, are not something people of a young age should be exposed to. The easy access to the library is part of the problem. Someone of any age can get their hands on just about anything they want. In my own experience, I have had the opportunity to get whatever I wanted at the library. The advertising pictures on the cover of books, movies, magazines, etc., gave me a false sense of what the material really contained when I was younger. I came home from a day at the library with materials that my parents did not approve of. If you look at it from the other point of view, you would probably be thinking, if we got rid of all material that someone would find offensive, our libraries would be left with close to nothing. In reality, I believe that once people realized that exposure to this kind of material is offensive, authors would change the way they would write; directors would change the way they produced movies; artists would change the lyrics to their songs. So yes, library's shelves would have been rid of many materials, but they would be replaced with what the people want. Others might argue that they have the right to read, listen, and watch what they would like. This may be true, but shouldn't others have the right to let their children go to libraries without worrying about the gruesome material they might be exposed to? Although to some people this argument could go either way, if the line is never drawn on what is available, who knows what the world will come to. From here, the material can only get more offensive, more disturbing, and leave a bigger effect on the minds of people. Children will be exposed to the 'evils' of this world at even a younger age, and if that is all they ever know, they won't realize what else this world has to offer them. Authors, directors, producers, and artists will all change their material if we show them that it is not what we want, leading to a more considerate cultural landscape.

I don't think censorship should be practiced in libraries, because it's not fair to everybody. If censorship was practiced everywhere, there probably would not be any movies or anything entertaining out, due to a large amount of people complaining about different topics. I have a few reasons also why I think there should not be censorship in libraries. My first reason is freedom of the press. In our Constitution, we are given the right of writing what we want, and if censorship continues, we will lose one of our fundamental rights. I don't think that's fair to control what we want to write or read, as it stifles creativity and open discourse. Another reason I have would be freedom of speech. Also written in our Constitution of the United States, we are given the right to say what we want, and nobody can control that. If we keep using censorship, then this right will also be taken away from us. We're slowly losing our constitutionally given rights, just because some people are offended by books and things of that nature. A personal experience I have was one day my friend and I were going to go to the library to get a book for our history report. The report had to be over the 1800's and slavery. Unfortunately, my friend was African American, and he had a hard time not being offended by the assignment and the material we had to read. When we got to the library, things got worse. All of the books we found were over how bad the slaves were treated back then, with graphic descriptions and illustrations. My friend was getting very upset at this point. Finally, he saw another book making fun of the slaves, then he went up to the librarian asking, 'Why don't you take those books off the shelf and put them somewhere else?' The librarian just looked at him with a straight face and said, 'No. What makes you think you should get any special treatment?' My friend was dumbfounded. He couldn't believe what he had just heard from the librarian. After he had came back over to where I was sitting, I had told him that she was right. 'What's that?', he said. I said, 'Because if she would've taken all those books down, she would've had to take about every other book down too, since somebody would find something hurtful in almost any topic.' 'You know, your probably right,' he said, realizing the impracticality of trying to please everyone. Censorship isn't fair, because it limits us to our abilities and what we enjoy. It's not fair to punish other people based on what they read, write, or say, as we all have different perspectives and sensitivities. We all have our own preferences; how would you like it if yours got taken away simply because someone else disagreed?

Censorship can be a very good thing when applied judiciously. It keeps inappropriate material from falling into the wrong hands, such as young children. It also keeps the horrors that are in the censored material out of the community and that makes the community a better environment to live in, especially for families. But too much censorship can become a bad thing, leading to a lack of information and stifled expression. For instance, Nazi Germany had an extreme censorship policy when he was burning all of those books to control public thought. There are also several books that talk about the censorship idea getting out of hand like the book Fahrenheit 451. Libraries should censor some of their material, but must be careful not to go too far. Books and magazines need to be censored according to their content. Books and magazines both use words and sometimes pictures to get their point across. If a book is using vulgar and inappropriate language it should be in some way censored, perhaps with a rating or restricted access. With this in mind I should not be able to pick a book and open it to find sexual dialog without any warning. I also shouldn't be able to find the constant use of swear words in a book or magazine that is readily available to young readers. Also lots of people get offended with violence and lots of gore, which can be disturbing. Magazines and books also use pictures to help get their point across. If there are inappropriate pictures in either of the two sources that material should be censored or placed in a restricted section. If I am walking through my local library and just see a magazine sitting out with a nude picture on the front I'm going to wonder about my library's censorship policy and its appropriateness for a public space. Another example would be that I pick up a book and start looking through it and it has an inappropriate picture in it, I am going to wonder about my library's censorship policy regarding graphic content. Also if a magazine has an extremely violent picture or extremely gory picture it should be censored to protect sensitive viewers. Overall if a book or magazine is extremely inappropriate, then it should be, in some way, censored or access should be limited. Music is another form of media that can be found at a library that should be censored. Musicians use artwork on the album sleeves to grab the attention of people. If that artwork includes swear words or inappropriate pictures it should be in some way or shape be censored, perhaps with a sticker or a cover. Musicians also play music of course. But if the lyrics to their songs are explicit or has many sexual themes it has to be censored for a general audience. Someone should not have to deal with wading through music like that in a public, tax-funded institution. No matter what, if an album of music is out of this world inappropriate, it should be censored or not carried at all. Movies are most likely the hardest things to censor. This is because they use language, pictures, music, and video, combining multiple media forms. Movies are multi-media monsters that can sometimes be very clean, and sometimes be very inappropriate for certain age groups. If a movie is rated R it should not be in a public library without restrictions, or perhaps not at all. Movies that are rated R for sexual content, nudity, drug use, alcohol abuse, or swearing should be censored or access should be controlled. A kid should not be able to get his hands on that kind of stuff in a public library without parental consent. Also depending on how violent and how gory a movie is it should be censored accordingly, with clear ratings displayed. Movies that are inappropriate, especially ones rated R, should be censored to maintain a family-friendly environment. The fact that this debate even needs to happen is sad, but it is necessary in our diverse society. But it does so we must censor certain things that people might get offended by if they saw it in their public library. Things containing nudity, sexual content, swear words, gore, and violence should possibly be censored or have restricted access. There also needs to be a line where we stop censoring or pretty soon, just like Katherine Paterson said we won't have any books left, as almost any book can offend someone. But overall there needs to be some type of censorship in public libraries to balance community standards with intellectual freedom.

For example, a book about slavery could be offensive to a white man, but a black man would consider it to be about his history. There are many opinions on censorship in libraries. Some people believe that if books are offensive in any way that they should be removed, while other believe that these books should stay since there are different opinions on what is classified as 'offensive'. I believe that books should remain on shelves due to the fact that all people view things differently and its free will that allows people to pick up these books of their own volition. No one is forcing them to read them; the choice is entirely personal. I believe when books, music, movies, and magazines publish offensive material that it is just a matter of opinion and subjective interpretation. I feel that people have different perspectives and personal thresholds on what they find appropriate or inappropriate. For example, a magazine article containing information about the wrong doings of the political offices or a cartoon of a certain candidate. Some politicians might find this article offensive and take it as a jab towards them while others see it just as an opinion on the matter or even as legitimate satire. Another example would be a book on religious purposes. For instance, a book on an unfamiliar religion. Some followers might take it as offensive if the information paints them as being a certain stereotype, but others may see it as educational learning about different cultures and beliefs. I also feel like this somewhat goes along with the idea of free will and personal autonomy. No one can force a person to not read a certain book or listen to a certain song; that would be an infringement on their liberties. It's free will that allows us to read, listen, and watch whatever pleases us and aligns with our interests. I feel that if someone was to go and demand that we take a book off a shelf that takes away from a person's free will who might be coming to rent the book that day for their own purposes. Its up to an individual to decide on what they will read and what their personal take is on the matter presented. I also feel that these types of media should remain on the shelves because of learning and educational purposes, which are central to a library's mission. I believe that even though some of these books or movies might have a couple of offensive lines or phrases that does not mean the whole thing is offensive or without merit. I think that the library is a place where people can go and research information from a wide array of sources. Some of the material found might be offensive to a certain person but that does not cancel out the rest of the book and mark it as being 'wrong' or entirely without value. I think that we must decide on what we believe is right in books and tune out what we feel is offensive or else many informational and historically significant books would not be available today for study. The library is a place where our free will comes into play and we exercise our right to choose. I feel that the offensiveness in books, music, movies, and magazines are all based on personal opinions and that they should never be removed from libraries for that reason alone. These books all contain information that could be veiwed in different ways and that it is up to the public to decifer for themselves what is offensive and what is acceptable for their own consumption. I believe that no one should decide for us what we can or cannot access.

Also it would start a big fight because a lot of people do not find certain things offensive like other people do, and when the people that find materials offensive start removing things that other people don't find offensive, a big riot will start over the control of information. Empty Rhetoric: Why is it wrong to censor? In the world there are today there is about eight billion people. All these people make up different groups with different moral codes, ethics, beliefs, and out looks on the world, creating a vast tapestry of human experience. With this in mind, there comes a problem with what is universally defined as wrong and right, as no single standard exists. The three subject that will be discussed in this article will be censorship, expression, and society, and how they intersect. To be censored puts a label on things that says this article is not fit to be seen, or heard by anyone, effectively silencing a perspective. Censorship was made to protect people from raw material that is seen as unfit or cruel by those in authority. Music is censored for the subject or matter it speaks about, whether it would be of sex, drugs, or politics, which are often contentious topics. This goes for movies, magazines, newspapers, television, or other forms of media that reach the public. the reasons that something is censored changes from place to place based on local norms and power structures. Expression of ones inner thoughts of the world or a general area could be disastrous in the eyes of some who fear dissent. To others, expression gives the chance to see who could be the next da Vinci, Socrates, or any other great thinker of the world whose ideas changed history. Censoring these people can and would be horrible for the progress of knowledge and art. The idea that just because someone has a different out look does not mean they are the evil that is in the world; they may simply see things differently. True their work could cause a problem for established ideas, but their idea should not be shunned by the world without consideration. The material they produce should be aloud to be seen by anyone of any age, with guidance where necessary. Society possess a big problem when it comes to agreeing on standards. Society or how one should act in public is different all over the world, reflecting diverse cultures. So therefore what is censored here would not be censored somewhere else, showing the relativity of such judgments. This also mean what is wrong or right is different to everyone on earth, making a single standard impossible. The society will have great effect on what is aloud to be seen or heard by those that live in the society and its institutions. if the society disagrees with the ideas of something the society will have it banned, suppressing minority views. If this is let to continue nothing will be aloud to speak its mind on anything, leading to stagnation. So ultimately, why is censorship wrong? Censorship is unjust to those with ideas unlike others, as it privileges certain viewpoints over others. If someone can censor someone else then that person that is being censored could in turn censor the person that is censoring them because of that persons views, creating a cycle of suppression. So yes it is wrong to censor anything or anyone for their ideas, morals, ethics, rules, laws, beliefs, or conduct, as it undermines mutual respect. Everything should be aloud to exist and be seen or heard by anyone who wants to look into that subject of matter, allowing for a free marketplace of ideas. In conclusion censorship, expression, and society will always have views but none of these view should ever be hidden from anything or anyone if we are to remain a free people.

When one checks out such media they should be required to state they are comfortable with the fact that their media might contain inappropriate and/or offensive content, acknowledging their informed consent. I personally find certain controversial poems or in the context of a song, certain intense themes fascinating from an artistic standpoint. Every time I look up these poems I have to accept an agreement that I am comfortable with its violent or hateful content before proceeding. Although, I do agree it should not be readily available to anyone looking for something new to read (or listen to) without their consent and a clear warning. I believe that simply asking the costumer if they are comfortable with a form of media's content would prove suffice for managing access. No one wants to settle for less or no frosting, and they should not have to when a simple solution of choice and consent is available.

The library is an important place for the knowledge seeker. The library holds books of past and current writers, preserving a wide range of intellectual work. It also holds information on past and current events, serving as a repository for societal memory. Censorship in libraries has become an ongoing debate in many communities. Censorship in libraries should not be allowed to avoid offensive history, books, or newspaper articles, as this practice undermines the library's fundamental purpose. Censorship in libraries should not be allowed to avoid offensive history. One reason to ban censorship in historical events is because it would create a loss of information for future generations. Periods like the holocaust, the genocide of about six million Jewish people by Nazi Germany, would eventually die with the generations that knew about it, leading to historical amnesia. The holocaust was an event that became known worldwide during the Second World War, which was a major historical event that shaped the modern world. The slave trade would be another historical event lost to censorship, erasing a significant and painful chapter. The slave trade is a major part in American history that helped shape the country it is today, and understanding it is crucial. Another reason to ban censorship in historical events would be because of their importance to our collective identity. If we censor certain materials we began to forget key parts of history that inform our present. Keeping those historical facts poses an opportunity to teach and learn from past mistakes and triumphs. Censorship in libraries aimed toward historical events should not be allowed if we value a complete and honest historical record. Also, censorship in libraries shouldn't be allowed to change books. One reason is because authors wrote their books how they intended them to be read, and altering them distorts their artistic vision. An example is Mark Twain. The author of The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn and The Adventures of Tom Sawyer. Both books use the word nigger to convey the tone and setting of the era they depict. Another example is the author of To Kill a Mockingbird, Harper Lee. Another reason to ban censorship in books is because that's an author's writing style, which is integral to the work. The author writes a book how they want it to be read, making deliberate choices about language. Therefore they use the language and words of the time period they write about to create authenticity. Mark Twain didn't use nigger because he was racist, he used it to convey what times were like and how people talked then. Censorship in libraries shouldn't be allowed to change books and compromise authorial intent. Finally, censorship in libraries shouldn't be allowed to get rid of newspaper articles. One reason is because newspapers were the primary way to send out information to the public before digital media. It brought people's attention to recent happenings in their communities and the world. It informed people of what was going on, fostering an informed citizenry. Getting rid of that is just another loss of information that could be vital for research. Newspapers were key players in getting out information about the Vietnam War, the Second World War, the assassination of President Kennedy and the Civil Rights Movement. Another reason to keep from censoring newspapers in libraries is because of their importance today as historical documents. They continue to keep people informed of recent and also past events, providing context for current affairs. An example is the death of Osama bin Laden and how he caused the deaths of many Americans on September eleventh. Articles about views on the death penalty also show the diversity of public opinion. Censorship shouldn't be allowed in libraries to get rid of offensive newspaper articles that are part of the public record. The library is a homestead to the knowledge seeker, a sanctuary for learning. There, they can read about past and current events without filtration. They can also read classics by great authors in their original form. Censorship should not be allowed in libraries to avoid offensive history, books, or newspaper articles, as access to unfiltered information is a cornerstone of a free society.

Dear Editor, Around the world there are people who censor what their people read and write, these works are oftenly produced by communist and socialist governments that control information. Here in America we have the right to say, read, and write what we want, about anybody or anything, as protected by our Constitution. Censorship does exist in the United States, and it is in the form of opinion that it exists, often through public pressure or political correctness. I have read articles in the paper about how text books have covered up the truth, due to what is politically correct and avoids controversy. I have heard of libraries taking down books that have a very strong political opinion, often these are books written by conservatives that challenge mainstream views. I have read about books coming out with the only intention of slamming, probable presidential nominees, which are highly partisan. Being a conservative myself, I do not believe that these books should not be in book stores, libraries, or other public venues, as that would be suppression. I believe this because in America we have freedom of press and, for these books not to reach the public is against that right and, the free-flow of ideas which is essential. You may ask why I believe this? I believe this because I too want others to hear and read about my ideas, on how to obtain life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness, which is a fundamental American ideal. Now that is why all books should be in our libraries, to ensure a marketplace of ideas. I agree with a restricted section where certain books should be stored, so little children will not get a hold of inappropriate material, which is a reasonable compromise. I would like this paper to put an article out about these thoughts to stimulate discussion. We the American people are a republic, and we for over two hundred years have encouraged the free-flow of ideas, which has made us strong. Why stop now? Thank you for considering my perspective.

'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf- that work I abhor- then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' This quote from the author, Katherine Paterson, means that there might be a book, magazine, etc., on a shelf that someone shouldn't see. I believe that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., shouldn't be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive. There are ways people can avoid seeing them. I think that if something is found offensive then they should be in a special aisle. First off, if there are items that people find offensive then they should be placed in a specific aisle. There are things that only adults should see so therefore there should be an aisle dedicated to the offensive or inappropriate things. And for someone to get into that aisle they should have permission to get into the aisle and show an I.D. so that kids and children don't accidentally slip in and see things they shouldn't. Because if a child sees something bad, then that might influence them to do bad things because they won't know any better. Secondly, if an individual finds a book or magazine offensive, then they can avoid it by simply walking away. That person doesn't have to read it or look for it in a library if it's in a certain aisle. But if someone is really offended by something then all they have to do is go complain to the person head of the library and it can simply be removed if there are enough complaints. Then again, it's not that hard to avoid something you don't like. It might bother you that it's there, but it should be out of the way for younger kids to see. Thirdly, the library will contain things that are found either offensive or inappropriate so children entering the library should have adult supervision so that they don't see the bad things. If a child sees something bad, they might find it interesting so they might want to pick it up and read it, which is bad because it might give them ideas. Finally, there are many ways to avoid seeing something you find offensive. You can walk away if you notice something you find offensive or you stay away from that area of the library. There are going to be many things out there that people find offensive and inappropriate, but there's not much you can do about it. The best thing to do is ignore it and walk away. And if you're that concerned about it then you can always make a complaint about what has offended you or what you think is inappropriate for children. Putting bad things in an aisle is a smart idea because little kids won't be able to access it, and this balanced approach protects children while preserving access for adults.

Conflicting works of art such as books, music, and movies, have always been seen in libraries. Whether it's a classic novel with controversial themes or a modern film with explicit content, someone is going to be offended. But whether or not these offending works should be banned is a common topic among authors, musicians, and movie-goers alike. I personally believe that all of these works have a right to be seen, heard, or read, because the creator has put much effort into stating their opinion and have a right to freedom of the press. You could take any famous work and someone could be offended by it because it displays something contrary to their beliefs. But this does not mean that that work should be banned! Banning a book would mean total rejection to the author's thoughts and opinions, and everyone has a right to those. The censorship of any work is unconstitutional because as citizens of the United States we have total freedom of the press. You simply can't apply censorship because whether you keep it on the shelves or not, people are going to be offended. Also, as shown in Ray Bradbury's Fahrenheit 451, the censorship of books could lead to a society unable to have a real knowledge of the past and the feelings and thoughts of the people of that age. To me, 'offensive' books, movies, and music are not bad, they are merely a stimulant for debate. They can allow you, rather than just the author, to express your feelings on what was presented in the works. But to completely remove the cometition of the debate would be sabotage. Judith Krug stated that 'if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf...then you also have exactly the same right and so does everybody else.' By saying this she is expressing that if we all could go into a library and remove the books, magazines, movies, or music that we do not like, then there would be absolutely nothing left. Every work would be remove because at least one person is offended by every work of the sort. Therefore, to allow books to be read, music listened to, and movies watched is to allow everyone the freedom of writing down their thoughts or stances. The censorship of any work, anywhere, is allowing for the 'shutting up' of ideas. These ideas are the ones that keep society going by making us think and helping to formulate our opinions. By allowing this we are creating future generations of great thinkers. In this case, by keeping books, magazines, and music on the shelves, we can continue to 'learn from the past' and utilize the information and ideas that have been used throughout history.

If someone is offended by a book or a movie from a library, should they be able to get it removed? In the following I want to explain my opinion towards censorship in libraries. I don't think they should be able to remove it, even though they might think other children shouldn't be able to get it either, but that's not their decision. Every parent has to decide on their own, if they want their children to get certain books, but one parent shouldn't be able to decide for everyone else by removing a book. Some people might be offended by certain books in libraries, but just because one person is offended by a book, doesn't mean that everyone else is going to be offended by it. Does this one person have the right to say that a book should be removed? It is their personal opinion that they don't like it, but by removing it they would also keep other people from reading it, and that is not fair. Different people like different books, and are offended by different books, so if everyone would remove a book they don't like from the library, there wouldn't be any books left. I think if someone is offended by a book, they just shouldn't read it. They could tell their friends and family not to read it, because they thought it was offensive, but in the end everyone should decide for themselves. I don't think people should be able to remove books from the libraries, but if the library itself thinks a book is offensive, then they shouldn't have it. It is their library, so it's their decision what books they want to have there. i also think that when the library doesn't have certain books, because they really pay attention to the books they take in their library, that that should be good enough for other people. So all in all I don't think people should be able able to remove certain books, because everyone has their own opinion towards what is offensive, and what isn't. We all should be able to read or see, what we want to, and not what others think we should, preserving the library as a space for diverse ideas.

Everywhere I go, there always seems to be something, small or big, that can be considered offensive. Because of these offensive things, there is often censorship in public places. It is acceptable to view non-noncensored materials at your own disgression and privacy, but not very acceptable to do so in public. I believe that censorship is necessary in libraries because of the wide range of audiences, the public materials, and the opinions of certain people. Libraries are considered public places and have a wide range of audiences. Whether it be children, teens, adults, or elders, some things are inappropriate and should not be accessible to certain people. This is directed mainly to children, however. Like the quote mentioned, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf.' Why put these offensive books in libraries then? Censorship will block out inappropriate parts of books, movies, music, and magazines in order to make these materials more suitable for all age groups. Because libraries are considered public places, their materials are considered public property. Everyone has the right to these materials. However, not every library will have the book, magazine, or movie you could be searching for due to the fact that it may contain profanity, or inappropriate content. Some people may be against censorship in libraries, but there often is not censorship in bookstores, movie stores, music libraries, etc. If you desire a certain non-censored material, then go purchase it. That way the material will no longer be public, but rather your own and you can do with it whatever you choose. We now live in a world where everyone voices their opinion freely and you can not be punished for doing so. Libraries are targeted toward every age group and censorship just allows everything to be appropriate for everyone. Certain parents do not allow their children to read certain books, view certain movies, or listen to certain music and this is just because it is their opinion and their parenting. Some parents, on the other hand, do allow their children to partake in inappropriate materials, and that is perfectly fine, because it is their parenting and their children. However, libraries should not have the right to introduce inappropriate things into the lives of children; that should be the decision of the parents or gaurdians. In conclusion, censorship should be allowed in libraries because of the wide-range audience, public materials, and the strong opinions of the people. Everyone deserves to read, watch, and listen to whatever they choose, but not everyone deserves to be around inappropriate things in public places. Not everyone can be happy, but everyone can be appropriate.
