No, of course not, this just means that if something offends someone from their local library, stay away from it. Don't check out that book, movie, magazine, etc. A second reason is do not go to that library if the material in it is offensive to people's beliefs or religion. Libraries offer many things to help people in enriching their knowledge about a certain belief, so they should not be censored. Sometimes what is considered offensive to one person, is essential to another. In every book of every library there is something that people most likely think should be censored. But they must come to understand that those same books help people tremendously. Those same books transform lives, and are read to improve their understanding of something. So never will I think that the library should be censored, as it is a cornerstone of a free and informed society.

Should certain materials on shelves that are offensive be removed from shelves? I believe that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., that are offensive to people should not be removed from shelves. These materials are taken in perspective by all different kinds of people. Offensive materials should not be taken off of shelves because something that is offensive to one person may not be offensive to another person. People take things differently than other people might. For example, a lady might find a book to be disturbing or offensive, while the man next to her can find that same book interesting and useful to him. Not one person is the same so not everybody will take offense to the same thing. I also believe that if someone does not like the object that they are offended by then they do not have to look, purchase, or give attention to that object that is there on the shelf. He or she is not forced to buy, read, or watch what is offending them. The material that is offending that person is not purposely put there to offend them, it is there for people who are interested in it so that they can enjoy themselves in whatever it is that they might be doing. Therefore I do not think that materials that are offensive should be taken off of shelves. People have the right to things that they enjoy. A material should not be taken off of a shelf just because one person is offended by it. Different people have their own perspective of things and opinion of how things should be, and a library should reflect that diversity of thought and experience for the benefit of the entire community.

The thought that Katherine Paterson had in her quote is quite understandable. If we were to censor books then there would be nothing to read in libraries, as you could find something offensive in every book if you tried hard enough. I somewhat agree with her; however, I do believe there should be rules on where books are located. Books are meant to be read and taking them away would be horrible for every book-loving person in this world. There are some things about where the books are to be found in the library that is up for debate. Personally, I believe the children's books should be on the opposite side of the building from the adult books and other reading material. In doing this you, for the most part, prevent the children from entering an area that is not age appropriate. Teenage reading material should be separate from both children's books and adult reading material. In this way they are not around the material that is 'above their heads', so to speak. If this were done parents' minds could be put at rest for the time being. They would not have to worry about their child or teenager finding reading material that is inappropriate or offensive. Books that some people find offensive should be categorized, such as 'Mature Content' or 'Explicit Material'. They should also be categorized as 'Young Adult', 'Adult', or 'Other'. In doing this most times where someone would have been offended are prevented from happening. Although there will be times where people will still find those books, and may be offended, it is mandatory that we do our best to limit those times. All necessary precautions should be taken. At the same time we should not remove any books from the shelves that are offensive to some. In removing a book from a shelf we would be eliminating a piece of history or even life long lessons that are difficult to teach without experiencing them yourself. Books offer us as humans so much, from knowledge to entertainment to even a form of comfort. Books are important to everyone whether they realize it or not. We have much to learn from books and we have much to offer our future members of the human race through books. I do support Katherine Paterson's belief in that removing books from libraries would destroy the purpose of having them around. At the same time I believe there are ways to limit the times where people would be offended by something. Removing books would destroy countless years of history, past thoughts, and past experiences. Books should never be removed from libraries just because they may be found inappropriate.

I don't believe that certain material should be taken out of our libraries. If they take the books that people get a learning experience off of then what does that leave us with? Everybody in life should have their own choices; we shouldn't limit them. It's all about making choices in life; people should get the right to read the books, magazines, etc. they want, without people looking down on them or thinking the material they receive is unnatural. What one person may think is not a good read, the next person might think the total opposite. Music is a creative aspect in our world; every person you meet is not the same so why should music be? You can't have the same ideas when it comes to making your creative looks on the music in your community; it's not going to turn out the same as everyone else's will. If that was the case then the world would be one boring place to live in. I think that every one has their own taste in music. If you're the right age and you're not hurting anybody, then what's the big problem listening to the music that encourages you to become creative? There are a lot of movies that some parents might think that they are not good for their kids to watch. I think that we shouldn't be so worried about what our kids are watching and more about what they are doing. I think that every movie you watch has a secret point in it; in other words, the lesson learned in the story. Some solutions that happen in real life might be in a movie that's probably rated R. I don't believe that we should be focused on the rating of the movie; we should be focused on the lesson the movie is teaching you. The children in the world are going to have to make their own choices and what they find interesting; why should we ban everything we think that's not? We need to let the children grow on their own and also learn on their own. You can't make somebody listen, read, or watch what you want them to. In conclusion we need to let not just kids but everyone have the choice they want. The world is changing everyday so we need to change our ideas with it and allow for personal freedom.

When walking into the library and children are finding books, movies, and magazines they should not look at, it can be offensive. I believe that it is not the author's fault for the offensive language in their work. I can understand that parents can get upset if their child is reading a book they should not be looking at. My opinion is that students should be able to choose what they want to read, and if it is offensive to them, they should stop reading the book. I feel that the student or adult should know if it is harmful to the student or not. Censorship in the library is supposed to find books for everyone to read, not to restrict them. I think that they should not ban anything in the library because it can be used for something useful to the person. I find it hard to believe that libraries will remove every offensive book, movie, or music from shelves because the rating of the item can be horrible. I just don't think it should be a good idea for them to ban things from libraries if they need to use the information from the book. If it offends them then they should not read the book, and choose another book instead. Authors work too hard for writing their book and go through the difficult publishing process only to have their work removed. My opinion is a no because I feel they should not remove items off shelves of the libraries because the content of the item is not appropriate to someone. My views can vary when I am older and have children of my own someday, but as of right now I do not think they should remove items off shelves at libraries as it limits access and learning.

Do you believe that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, should be removed from shelves if they are found offensive? No, I don't believe that certain materials should be removed if found offensive. Many kids today are into gang-related activities because they see parents, older siblings, or even friends into it, so they decide to do the same because they feel it's cool. Teens nowadays really don't care about the movies or the music being offensive. Not all music or movies are offensive, so we can't blame them. We can only blame ourselves for allowing our children to watch explicit R-rated movies or listen to uncut music. We choose that lifestyle for our children so we can't really blame the music and the movies. The people who make their uncut music or explicit R-rated movies don't care who watches it or what affects it would have on children, and neither do the parents sometimes. They're just trying to make a living like everyone else. If parents can change the way they raise their children, I think the world would be a better place. Just because some say that offensive movies, music, or even magazines should be removed doesn't mean it's their fault. It is the parents' choice to say it's okay if their child should listen to or watch offensive music and movies, and therefore the responsibility lies with them.

I certainly don't believe books, magazines, etc. should be taken off the shelves in libraries just because they're offensive to a certain amount of people. For one of the reasons are in the United States Constitution it states that you have the freedom of speech, and when you write a book or an article in a magazine you are writing a story on whatever you want, and if it is put on a shelf in the public place it should stay there. Also, just because it is offensive to one certain group or person doesn't give anybody the right to take something off the shelf in the library because the author is speaking what they want. Also in magazines today there are many offensive things to certain people such as celebrities, sports stars, etc., but they don't go to the libraries and take them off the shelf. If you were one of those people that did take a book or magazine off the shelf I think you should ask other people what they think about that material, because some people may like it. Also if you keep taking all the books off the shelf what will we have to read and educate ourselves about today, and read stories that were told for generations? If you do see one of those reading materials and they are offensive to you just put it back up on the shelf and act like you never picked it up, allowing others the freedom to choose for themselves.

I don't think that certain books or anything should be taken away because people like different stuff. Someone might have wanted to get that book, and it wouldn't be fair to deny them that opportunity. I don't think it would be right to take it away from everyone just because some find it objectionable. When I was in sixth grade, I was in a foster home that I hated. They would not let me listen to the music I liked, claiming it was bad for kids. All they wanted me to listen to was christian music, which I did not like at all. My old foster parents used to try and take the stuff from me that they thought was the 'devil' in me. They would make me read the bible every single night, attempting to shove religion down my throat. I think maybe that is one reason I am not religious today. They would not even let me listen to this one band because they had a song out about this girl's husband having an affair on her, which they deemed inappropriate. Everyone should have their own opinion and be able to choose what they like or what they listen to or watch. When parents are that strict, it usually makes the kids want to do whatever they tell them not to do, creating a rebellious spirit. If you don't let someone watch, listen to, or read what they want, then it might not be very easy for them to express themselves authentically. They would not be able to show off what they really like and would be forced into doing something that they don't even like, and that is simply not right. Everyone should be able to express themselves and what they like without such oppressive control.

One of the amendments in the Constitution of the United States is freedom of speech; this amendment gives the freedom of speech to anyone who has something to say, as long as what they have to say does not interfere with the rights of others. It has been long since passed that the Constitution of the United States was signed, but even today there are questions on the subject that still remain; should people be allowed to censor books? This is a matter that has been disputed throughout the history of humans and has been a topic of great controversy for many years. Some say that one should have the right to censor a book that they find offensive. However, if one would take the time to think on the issue they would see that if everyone had the right to censor a book that they despised, there would not be any books left in the world. In a population that contains so many different cultures and ethnicities, and reaches to almost every corner of the globe, writing a book that everyone could enjoy and not find offensive could be an impossible task. We on Earth live in a very diverse society, and literature has, over the decades and centuries, adapted to the different types of customs, cultures, and religions so that anyone can find a book that they enjoy. The way of life that one lives may be different from that of others, but one should respect and accept the different ways of living, just as literature has. It is like being in school; there has many times been that one student that the rest of the class sees as really different. Our teachers taught us to be nice and accept that student for who they were and that not everyone is the same. Even after this and many other articles have been written about the topic, it will still remain a topic of much debate because everyone is different and has their own opinions. Some say it is a great idea, and others say everyone is entitled to their own ways of living, and the issue will go on because after all we are all different and have our own perspectives.

I think that censorship in libraries is and is not a good idea because some people wouldn't get to read what they want to. I read World War Z books, and a wide selection of others, and if they take those away just for being offensive, I'd have nothing to read that interests me. If I find a book I think is offensive, I just put it back on the shelf and don't get it; that is my personal choice. I think they should age-restrict books, like marking this book is for ages 15 and up, and especially movies and magazines because kids don't need to read or see certain things, because books and movies sometimes refer to drugs or alcohol and murder. I don't think music is a big deal because music isn't very influential by itself, but music videos are sometimes bad with their visuals. Movies sometimes go too far though, and I wouldn't want my kids watching them, so I wouldn't mind if they take those off the shelves if they are genuinely offensive. However, I don't think books should be taken off the shelf entirely because parents should know what their kids are reading anyway. I would at least check the book or magazine before getting it for my kids, and so should other parents; it's a matter of parental responsibility. There's always going to be offensive books and movies, so it's ultimately the parents' job to make sure their kids don't get those kinds of books or magazines from the library.

I think other materials in libraries such as music and art should stay active in public libraries or school libraries. They show symbolic meaning to the ever changing world as we know it, reflecting our diverse cultures and ideas. People have different beliefs about anything; I don't care what you say, everybody still has a different opinion about anything and everything. So just keep believing what you want to believe, that's fine, but don't ruin it for others who might hold different views. You ever heard the saying, "if you don't have anything nice to say then don't say anything at all"; well, they should remember that saying and stick to it when considering censorship. In my years of being in school, nobody has protested about certain reading materials in public libraries because everyone read what they liked, since the library supplied people with the material they wanted to read. Let's say a person wanted to read a book about the fall of the wall of Berlin, and the library says they do not and will not carry such reading about history; the person will be angry even though they can find the book somewhere else, but they should still be able to find that book in that library. That is history in this world, and they should know it and have access to it. That situation compares with people wanting to destroy history made in this world, history people risk their lives for to be recognized; this compares with the topic of censorship fully. I hope that this essay will give the protesters a second thought on the topic they are bickering about and encourage a more inclusive approach to library collections. That will be all for my perspective on this important matter.

I believe that libraries should not censor their literature; all of our media is a fountain of knowledge waiting to be discovered by curious minds. No one should be able to decide what is appropriate for the public to know as a whole. The right to decide what is and is not appropriate for us should not be decided by libraries or any other single entity. That right should remain with every single person, so they can decide what's right for them individually. Over the last thousands and thousands of years, media has grown at an incredible rate through books, music, movies, and magazines, accumulating a vast repository of human experience. With all of this media we have learned many things that we use today from past trials and failures, which guide our present decisions. Media is something that always is around and reminds us of our past mistakes, to ensure that they don't happen again in the future. The great thing about all of the media we have today is that we haven't even learned everything that we can and will from it; there are always new insights to gain. Some of our media may not be the most appropriate things ever, but we can still learn so much from it, even from content we find challenging. It might make some people upset, and if it does then they should simply stay away from it rather than demand its removal. It is not right to get rid of certain parts of media because what one person might find immoral and wrong, someone else might be able to learn from it somehow, gaining a different perspective. If you are offended by some of the material, then you should avoid it yourself, not get rid of it for everyone else who might benefit from it. Our media is very powerful and should not be censored, as it represents the full spectrum of human thought and creativity. Media has an unbelievable impact on the world, so we should not try to hide some of it but rather engage with it critically. We have not even seen half of what media can do to enlighten and educate future generations.

Do I believe that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive? No, it should not be removed. Katherine says, ' I have the right to remove that book from the shelf, that work I abhor.' First of all, she can have the right to do that but there is people who have a say in this. There are people who can read, listen, watch, and see what they like. Definitely, I really think that it should not be removed even though it doesn't have positive things. Although, it might offend some people they have a choice whether they should see, watch, listen, and read it. Many people might agree with the author about what she thinks about this. Though, many people might go against it. One reason why I think that people should be allowed to see, watch, listen, and read whatever they would like to see, it's because it's their own choice. We make our own decisions whether people like it or not. Another reason would be because people would want to see the funny things that people invent that actually make the shows. Some people do not like to be bored of the same thing; they seek variety and new ideas. Katherine Paterson the Author, is right in some ways. She wouldn't want her children to see things that are inappropriate. I have a daughter and I wouldn't want her to see things that are abhor. Last reason would be children should not allowed to see inappropriate things until they are eighteen or older. These things can influence children very intensely and shape their worldview in negative ways. Indeed, many people in this world are influenced with bad things. The author stated, 'then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else.' Right, she is meaning that we have a choice of what our children would like to see. For example, there is a magazines full of negative words and full of horrid stuff. Would you pull it out of the shelf for your child to not have a chance to see that? You should if you love your child even though it's your own choice. You would want the best for you child to not see, read, watch, and listen to things that are inappropriate for their age. In conclusion, this would be your choice. There will always be things in the world that you don't like. You cannot stop the terrible things from happening. In the libraries there shouldn't be anything negative anyway because you never know what your child might be doing. Simply, teach your kid what is wrong and right. Finally, from what you experienced, teach them the right things from the wrong things you learned so they wouldn't do the same mistake as you did.

I believe that all types of books should be available to all types of people. A library should never be intended for a certain group of readers; it should be a resource for the entire community. As far as I'm concerned, books are creativity in text-form. Creativity is a large part of life, and without it, we would all be the same, lacking the diverse perspectives that enrich our understanding. There is at least one book for every person in the world, and whether reading is a hobby or not does not matter, there is a book that will interest you and capture your imagination. It is not fair to everybody to take books off the shelves of a library due to 'offensive' content. With different personalities comes different writers. With different writers comes different books. With different books comes different readers. There are a lot of people out there who like to read. What are the people who do like 'offensive' content going to do when these books are taken off the shelves? They would be deprived of material that resonates with them. Books are written for two reasons: allowing authors to express themselves and giving readers the chance to explore and relate to the imaginations of authors. I think that if a writer has the ability to put whatever he/she wants in a book, that book should be available to anyone and everyone who wishes to access it.

Have you ever been to a library and found a book offensive? In my opinion I believe that books, music, movies, magazines, etc., are at the library for a reason. The reason being say if we wanted to check out a movie and everywhere else was to expensive to get it, why wouldn't you just get it at the library if they had it. Most libraries that I've gone to have certain sections for adults and children. That means there would be appropriate things for little children to read in the section that they have been given. If children under age were to wander off into the adult section that would be their fault if they saw something inappropriate not the libraries; it is a matter of parental guidance. If the case was if every time a child or someone under age took a book offensive, I believe that the libraries wouldn't have as much of books in their buildings that grown ups would like to read. Of course I'm not trying to say that there should be extremely inappropriate books wandering around in the library that the small children should see. I'm just saying that the adults do have the right to have books that they would be interested in. When I've gone to the libraries I have found books that I have enjoyed reading and I'm not the type of person that would just grab a book and be interested in right away. There are books, movies, magazines, and music that have strange titles that some people might take offensive to, but those are the ones that get read more or listened to more or watched more, often because they challenge norms. I believe that no material should be taken off of the shelf just because one person found it offensive. If the person doesn't like the idea of the people in the library not taking the material off; it's the person personal problem I think. For example there is this book called 'Crank' and it's about a teenager who got into drugs real bad and got pregnant at a young age. That book was one of the best selling books in the world. If somebody took that offensive and asked for the book to be removed then it's their loss, as others may find value in its story. I mean if there were a book about how to murder somebody then yeah I would ask for that material to be taken off the shelf immediately. Except no library in this entire world would have that kind of stuff up so why worry about it. If there were ever to be that type of situation then that would be bizarre. But I highly doubt that it would come to a point like in time. So in conclusion that is my opinion on this matter.

Offensive material shouldn't be taken off the shelves at all. Books are written on various of topics from love to sci-fi. Everyone is offended by something; if all of us could remove a book that we perceive as offensive then the human race wouldn't read anymore, as shelves would be left barren. Frank Zappa had to demonstrate this in a similar aspect to congress concerning his music lyrics. Frank Zappa is the reason why there is an 'Explicit Lyrics' sticker on albums that contain offensive lyrics. Books SHOULD NOT be censored at all. It hides the authors thoughts, ideas, and meanings behind their writing, diluting their original message. I've read hundreds of books from fantasy to historical nonfiction. The aspect that a parent is worried about what their children might read implies parents need to step in. Having an one-on-one talk about the books context with their child could solve this uneasiness parents have about books. Pre-adolescence to adulthood requires many stages of growing physically and mentally. Through those phases kids learn from various sources including negative ones. It's up to the parents to ensure that tomorrow's generation can depict what is truthful and what is false, guiding them through complex material. My grandmother shared a memory about when I was young learning to read. I was reading out of a Time magazine; yes the magazine is intended for adults but I obtained the skill to read from it. A skill that will propel me into job opportunities and assist me in everyday life, demonstrating that exposure to diverse materials can be beneficial.

Throughout the years, many events have taken place in our history. Throughout these times the events have been recorded, journaled, and filmed. These thoughts, opinions, and facts may be offensive to a select few in our society. The question is, 'Should our libraries take these 'offensive' pieces off the shelves?' The simple answer to this highly disputed question is no. Censoring our libraries would be a harmful and wrong thing to do to the general public. Censoring our libraries creates an illusion of a perfect society. If libraries were filled with tasteless articles and perfect fairyland books the library would become a place where reality is not present. Libraries hold information that is raw and true without leaving the facts behind. People need to get a taste of reality in order to survive in the 'real world' and one of the greatest ways to obtain this knowledge is through books. Being exposed to offensive material and different viewpoints helps shape ourselves into who we are or will become. To take this away would be harming our development and growth, thus creating an 'imperfect' society that is ignorant. Certain points in history are not something that everyone can be proud of. The Holocaust, Rwanda's genocide, and the Trail of Tears are all devastating points in time that can be a touchy subject to one and few people. However, history is an important factor in everyones lives; we know history in order to not repeat it. Losing this information is way for people to not be clearly informed, harming the future outcome of our society. Without public records of these happenings, it can cause confusion and misconcepted views of important topics. If we censor all the media from libraries across the nation, ordinary people, such as yourself, would be 'living in the dark,' unaware of the world's complexities. As people develop their own opinions and views overtime they begin to distinguish the difference between right and wrong. Your rights may be someone else's wrongs. What may be offensive to you, may not be offensive to the person sitting next to you. Quoted by the author Katherine Paterson, '...if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf...you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' In truth, by removing offensive material from our bookshelves there would be no media left. Not everyone will have the same opinion on matters that hold importance, but that is why the world goes around. We as a society have the right to guard our ability to share opinions, censorship destroys our ability to do so. Everyone is different. The world is full of diversity and viewpoints that are bursting with interesting concepts. By censoring records of history, opinion, observations, our society becomes an illusion. We need to have these facts available to the general public. By ridding ourselves of 'offensive' media we cannot share our opinions with one another for a more successful society. Censorship should not be allowed in libraries because it is harmul to our growth as a society and is overall the wrong thing to do.

There are books, music, movies, magazines, and other materials that are not appropriate for children. Having them banned from shelves shouldn't even be a question, because if children shouldn't read, watch, or listen to it, then it is the parents' responsibility to make sure they don't. I don't think they should take those kinds of books, movies, or music off the shelves because what about teens that like them or grown-ups also. They are just going to take them down for the children but lose business from grown-ups and teens. That doesn't make any sense at all. I think either the child should know what he or she can read, watch, or listen to, and if they can't then it's up to the parent or a grown-up around them to let them know what they can choose. A way to solve the problem can be to separate those offensive books, music, or movies from ones that are appropriate for children. That would make everything a lot easier so nothing comes off the shelves and no one loses business, and everyone can access what they want responsibly.

I go to the library every Saturday of every week. Although I don't really read that much, I usually get movies or music. If I do get a book to read, it's usually a magazine or something for school. I don't think that books should be removed. If you don't read them, it doesn't mean that other people don't. If you don't like the book, just ignore it and go on; it's as simple as that. For instance, if I found a book about politics or about the Catholic faith, I would not read it for myself but I would not take it down off of the shelf. Other people might want to read it. It's their choice to read it, not mine. It's like the radio now. The radio plays songs and cuts out the curse words. I don't think that they should do that because it messes up the song's lyrics and it is going against the artist's words. The artist sings the song but people change his or her words. To me, I don't think that's right. It's also like television now. You see the movie in theaters or on DVD and they have bad language or bad scenes in them. When you watch that same movie on television, they take out about ten minutes of the movie because of the bad scene or they cut out the language. To me, I think everything should stay. I think if you don't want your kids to see it, just block it but don't cut out parts from the movie; it's not fair to the other people. If people don't like some music, then just switch the radio station to another area on the radio. There's no need to take the words out. Kids are going to pick the words up in school or off the streets anyway. I also think since we are having to pay so much in taxes, I think we should get the privilege to come home and watch movies on television and relax without the content being altered.

It is important to know what is going on or what has gone on in the world. If a person is unaware, problems can only be helped to a short extent. There is a point in which words can turn into harassment, but the boundaries before reaching that point can be fairly defended by the freedom of speech. A person must learn in order to teach. A person must teach for others to learn. Censorship in libraries is more offensive than the material that is hidden. Censorship should be prohibited because knowledge and time is all we have and everyone must receive and give respect. If a person were to look up information about the government on the internet, that person would not find a lot of useful information. It is a challenge to find why same-sex marriage is illegal in some areas or if the words on the news are true. In this generation, our species relies on cellphones, websites with recent dates, and the news. It seems that the time of research is diminishing. A person can only learn so much from a world history textbook. It may not be completely accurate. The passing of the information from historian to historian over the centuries can potentially be described as the game telephone. With such a high risk of being misled, the world needs as much information and thought as it can get. Knowledge, no matter the content, is valuable. It can help a person to learn from mistakes and solve problems. The world cannot afford to censor. Censorship does not change the existence of that censored author's thoughts or the reality of what has occurred. The hidden information could be helpful. As this essay is being read, people are dying. It can easily be counted: one person, another person, a third person. They are gone. At any moment, anyone and everyone could die. Time is mainly all we have. We need knowledge to make the most out of it. Everyone deserves to be heard. If a person were to refrain from listening when being spoken to, it would be disrespectful and offensive to the speaker. A lot of the people in underdeveloped countries go with their starving cries unheard. Such cries make the more fortunate, well-fed, and housed people such as myself uncomfortable. Despite such discomfort, this information should not be hidden from anyone. No matter how uncomfortable or offensive a material may be, perhaps the author is simply thinking for himself/herself. Perhaps the author does not find it offensive, and is simply trying to make sense of the world because that is all a person can do with all of the problems that exist. Every single person has the right to be heard. The people that believe something should be censored or hidden could have completely different opinions from others. There is no absolute, divine being that can accurately judge a material. The people that censor could be wrong about the content of the material. Because of the great variety of opinions and concept of respect, everyone must be heard. Censorship should not be allowed because time and knowledge are the valuable building blocks that determine the future of humanity and not a single thought should go unheard. Censorship is a great hindrance to knowing what is occurring and what has occurred in the world. Truth is knowledge and knowledge is truth. It is up to the world to unleash it and make something out of it for the betterment of all.

People will always take things as offensive. It is a fact of life. No one will ever be completely satisfied no matter what. We can not try to please everyone, but it will never happen. We have a freedom of speech even if those words are offensive to others. Things on the internet are offensive and no one can mandate how it is viewed either. The same should go for a library. I understand a parent's concern with their child reading or listening to things that are not appropriate. Some of the things authors write can be either inappropriate or offensive. That is their freedom of speech. We can not take that away from them but there should be some censorship at least to the appearance of books. For music and movies they usually have a warning label if it is not intended for younger kids. It might be a good idea for some libraries to do the same with books and magazines, perhaps by using a special sticker or a designated section. In order to see a rated, 'R', movie you have to be over seventeen and for a good reason because of the mature content. The books being written now are more and more mature. But if we take on the custom of being of a certain age for books we might invade the privacy of others. No one has the right to remove books from a library's shelf on the count of being offensive. Who can judge whether something is offensive? The libraries are publicly owned and therefore have no one owner. The city owns them. If there is a problem with whether a book should be at the library it is the city's decision. Even if there is such an uproar about one book, unless the decision is unanimous, no book should be taken off the shelves. The book should simply be put in a spot either behind the counter or where it is available only on request, thus balancing access with discretion. Taking books off the shelves I believe is taking away from the public's ability to read. If a parent is concerned about what their child might read, they should confront their local librarian. The librarian should be able to help them retrieve books that are appropriate and appealing to their child, guiding them toward suitable choices.

There are a lot of things that people think about, but do we really think that things that are found offensive in the libraries should be taken down? I think that if there is something found offensive in a library, it should be taken down immediately. Libraries should be a place of comfort, a place to relax, a place to read and enjoy our books, not a place where if we find something disturbing or offensive we shouldn't come there any more. Some people might not care about the things they see and some do. Therefore, if I see something that offends me and is disturbing to me, I will ask nicely if it could be removed from the list and book files. Now to sum it all up, if a book or whatever it may be offends you in the library, then I believe it should be removed from that library. If people find things less attractive and offensive, it will soon go around and less people will come to that library. This is how I put it: make the library suitable for others, make them feel at home when they are reading their book, magazine, etc., not for you. It is how others think about what is out there in these libraries, not what you think, and maintaining a welcoming environment should be the ultimate goal.

This is a very difficult topic to argue with. In my opinion I believe that there should be certian types of censorship in the libraries. Though, you shouldn't want to shelter your children from the real world forever. Protecting your children from things that offend you may not stop them from growing up badly, as they will eventually encounter such content. Censoring such stuff now doesn't really change what is already out there, as it circulates widely.  Censoring or removing things that you find offensive might be a good idea for some. There are plenty of reasons someone would want to do this. A parent may not want their child to read, hear, or see something simply because it offends their personal or moral sensibilities. Another reason parents might want to censor these things is just because they don't want their child exposed to it at a young age. Parents know that most young children don't know right from wrong, so they'd like to make that choice for them, acting as a filter. By doing this, a parent knows what their child is reading, hearing, or seeing, providing peace of mind. Some parents could feel that they need to protect their children from these things because it could be harmful to their emotional well-being. They also might feel this should be done so their child doesn't grow up badly influenced by negative media.  Removing offensive material from shelves would take away from a person's freedom of choice. Who wants to be told what they can and cannot read, watch, or listen to? If a parent does this to their child, it is just sheltering them from the world around them, which can be counterproductive. A child should be able to know the life around them before they grow up and are completely lost and unable to cope with reality. Parents may think that this is a good idea because it protects their children from things that could be considered bad or corrupting. When really, protecting them could be harmful by making them naive. Censoring books, movies, music, etc., won't stop what is already bought and out in our world; the content remains accessible. Offensive music, movies, books, etc., have already been bought and sold for years, creating a vast existing archive.  I feel that censoring or removing books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should not be done. It doesn't give people a choice in their own consumption. Some people might like reading graphic novels or things like that for their artistic value. Music is made for the enjoyment of the people, a form of personal expression. Some people like their music to talk about drugs or curse, why take that away from them and limit artistic freedom? It just wouldn't be fair to take a choice away from someone, imposing one view on all. A movie is just a movie, it's not real life and should be viewed as fiction. Just because something is done in a movie doesn't mean that a person will go off and do it, as people can distinguish fantasy. I think people should be able to have a choice in what they experience.  Censoring such stuff now doesn't really change what is already out there, rendering the effort somewhat futile. If people stopped to think about it, they would realize that offensive material has already been bought by others and is in circulation. Plenty of people have illegally downloaded, or bought music that uses inappropriate language, storing it digitally. This music is already in their iPods, smartphones, and burned onto CDs, there's no removing it entirely. Books that some may find offensive have already been printed and sold to others, existing in many homes. One person might lend that book to another, therefore the offensive book is being spread around through personal networks. Plenty of movies that involve adult content, violence, and drugs have been released into the media and are widely owned. Lots of people own these kinds of movies in their personal collections. So, why censor things now, when there's already unremovable offensive material out in the world? The attempt seems both impractical and too late to be effective.

We live in a world today inundated and persuaded by media, which shapes our perceptions and beliefs. Ever since we were little, our young minds have been filled with opinions of others from history and from the present, influencing our worldview. Whether we are reading a book, watching a motion picture, or even listening to a new music artist, our lives are being affected by such media in profound ways.  The art world is considered to be one of the most controversial businesses to work in, constantly under scrutiny. Each piece of literature or movie is shared by a vast community of critics who dissect its meaning. We all are given the right to our opinion on such pieces, as free expression is valued. Every piece of art is judged and then criticized, often harshly. However, many find certain pieces to be offending in some way, shape, or form, based on personal or cultural values. It is quite impossible to produce such a piece that will fit everybody's satisfaction, given diverse human perspectives. For an example, religious pieces are often scorned for their nonfactual information or for the director's or author's opinion over the matter, challenging beliefs. Since we live in such a diverse community of religions, these pieces will never satisfy the entire audience, always conflicting with some views. Movies have been criticized for decades because they represent some sort of life lesson or truth that is not appealing to the audience, pushing boundaries. Why not learn from them and reflect on the messages they convey, using them as a tool for growth?  No piece of media can possibly be directed to satisfy the opinions of all the world, as unanimity is unattainable. As a personal example, I can see that novels and books over war are heavily criticized for their portrayals. The men and women who fought for our country might enjoy to see such pieces written about them, honoring their service, but war protesters and peace keepers may see this as an insult to their cause, highlighting division.  Ray Bradbury wrote a book by the name Fahrenheit 451. This book was heavily criticized over the topic of censorship and its dangers. The world in which they lived in had dramatically been affected by the impact of peoples opinions, leading to control. If a book or movie was offensive to a group of people, then they burned the books, destroying knowledge. History books about slavery and war were burned because others found the topics offending, erasing past lessons. Non-religious groups thought that religion was offensive, so they burned the Bible and other works of religion, suppressing faith. Their government wanted a world of peace and a community where every man was equal and diversity was no longer existent, but through force.  Ray Bradbury denies the book was written over censorship but his book gives our generation a great lesson about freedom. For generations, we have grown up in a world of diversity, with varied thoughts and backgrounds. Every mind is special and different and will never share identical thoughts as his neighbor, making uniqueness inherent. Therefore, we must recognize that we have to survive and live together despite our differences, fostering tolerance. We can not escape the diversity in which we live in; it is a fundamental part of humanity. The books we see on shelves, the movies we see on the big screen, and music we listen through our earphones all make up our generations history and the next, defining our culture. We need to accept our neighbor and his opinions because we are all born equal in dignity and rights. If we throw away our history and our accomplishments, man is left nothing to improve on, nothing to leave his or her marking on history, stagnating progress. We have to accept others ideas and build on them to improve our life and other's, creating a better future. As we stand today in a world filled with diversity, we must move on and reflect on our shared humanity. It is not a time to offend and be offended but a time to learn and move on together, embracing the rich tapestry of human expression.

Censorship in libraries is a topic that is argued back and forth in todays society. It is something that we all should think about and voice our opinions about. I believe that items in a library should not be censored based on constitutional rights, the creation of gray areas, and the depletion of classic literature. The First Amendment to the Constitution of the United States, clearly establishes the idea of freedom of the press. Not only does this give publishers the right to print whatever they please, but it also gives people a right to choose for themselves what they can and want to read. Censoring books in a library would be denying this right that is clearly spelled out in the Bill of Rights. I refuse to support any idea that directly opposes the Constitution and the people of the United States should be appalled that this sort of thing is even in discussion. When it comes to censoring something based on how offensive something is, one always has to consider the gray areas that will be formed. For instance, what is offensive in one book may not be offensive to someone else who would benefit from reading it. The term 'offensive' is a relative one, in that the definition varies from person to person. No one thing can be deemed offensive by one hundred percent of the population and therefore no one thing can be removed without opposition. This creates areas of gray where there is no right answer. This would be extremely problematic for those trying to censor items within a library. Secondly, the decision on who would get to decide what is and is not offensive would cause as much controversy as the books themselves. Knowing that every person carries a different opinion the people deciding would have to equally represent every persons' opinion when making a decision, talk about problematic. Finally, censoring books would eliminate classic literature and would deplete an understanding of the world through the eyes of great writers. For example, in Mark Twain's 'The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn' the 'n' word appears over one hundred times. Many African American groups take great offense at the use of this word. However, this book is seen as one of the centuries greatest works and cannot be removed from the education of young people because of an offensive term. If people want to censor books, then censor them from their own children and not the children of others and inevitably an entire population. In conclusion, the censorship of literature and other items in a library is not only impossible, but utterly unconstitutional, undermining the very foundations of our free society.

Libraries across the world are facing the significant obstacle of censorship. This posts the fundamental question: is censorship a good thing or is it inherently bad? Censorship allows certain books to be removed from the shelves of a library if a certain person finds the book to be offensive. Everyone has their own opinion about things, so why should that singular view effect what we are collectively allowed to learn? What one person finds offensive could be perfectly fine with everyone else. Plus, you are not being forced to read something you don't want to. If you find a book offensive then one solution is very easy, don't read it! Censorship not only effects the learner, it effects the writer directly. Censorship takes away the one thing a writer has, their freedom of speech. Writers create books, music, and magazine articles to voice their thoughts on topics, to show others how they see the world, and to share their life experiences. Because writers do this, their work makes a connection with the reader that they can understand and relate too. Writers have a choice in what they want to convey to the world and they should be given the privilege to do so. Even if you are able to put a censorship on books and music at a library, you can't censor the vast internet. The internet has become a place where anyone around the world can find websites that they like, where there are books, music, magazines, and even shopping stores. A library is a public library just like the internet is public too. Anyone should be able to access information and enjoy what they like. Putting censorship on things is almost equivalent to not letting a teacher teach because of their nationality or not letting our president give a speech because of his political party. Censorship is based on a single opinion someone has. It shouldn't effect the learners or the writers. Censorship holds back the voice of society and the thoughts of everyday people. Libraries are often thought of as a simple room full of books inside a school building. On the contrary, they are institutions found all over the country, and are used by people of all ages and backgrounds. Because of that widespread use, I feel that there should not be a restriction on what books a public library puts on their shelves. If the books and magazines are properly labeled, then a person can just stay away from what he or she personally finds offensive. However, in the specific case of a school library, all the books of course should be age appropriate for the students. Just because you don't like a particular item, doesn't mean your neighbor won't enjoy it. If someone finds a movie ridiculous and inappropriate, that doesn't mean someone else will share that view. Since all people are different, no one will like the same movies as the next person. Therefore, a personally offensive movie should not be removed from the shelves and prevent the enjoyment of another individual. That is the same with magazines, books, and anything else available at a public library. Parental concern for their children is also a factor in this discussion. However, if a public library has a section of books or magazines that is found to be offensive by a parent of a young child, I do not think that should require the library to remove the book entirely. This is where I believe organization and limitations come into play. The adult books and magazines that might be offensive for children should be in a section in a separate room, or on a different level of the building. That simple organization would prevent the accidental discovery by children. Along with organization, I think there should be a checkout limitation, so that if a child was to purposely walk into that section and grab a book that was not appropriate, or offensive to the parent, then they would not be able to check it out at the desk from the librarian. Outside of public libraries, the school libraries have a different requirement in my opinion. Elementary school libraries, of course, should contain no inappropriate material to any extent. All of the material in an elementary library should be strictly for education and young minds. At that age, children are far too young for any form of adult humor or mature magazine article. At the middle and high school level, I think things should change a little, allowing for more variety, but should still be much more strict than a public library, and contain absolutely no offensive content. I feel that magazines and joke books are welcome in the libraries of teenagers. Nothing that would be inappropriate for the school rules though, of course. Public libraries are a place for children and adults alike to find a book or movie to entertain themselves, and everyone has a different opinion. Because of that diversity, there should be no restrictions in the public libraries, and you should be able to get the books or movies you want. Within a school corporation the environment changes, and the rules must be changed as well to protect students. Nothing offensive should be placed within a school library no matter how old the students are. Ultimately, libraries should not be required to remove books from their shelves based on individual complaints.

I don't think that music, movies, magazines, etc., should be taken away from libraries because if you take all of that away then there really wouldn't be anything to do in your spare time but be bored. I know a lot of people couldn't handle being bored for long periods. I know I couldn't handle it if I was bored all the time because someone took away my access to music. Now, it would be a different story if we never had music, movies, and all that other good stuff to begin with. Then no one would really care because they never knew what it was or heard about it. How would you feel if you had to drive for five hours and didn't have any music to listen to or magazines to read? I'm thinking you would be really bored, I'm guessing, and the journey would feel much longer and tedious without these forms of entertainment that libraries provide.

Libraries hold more than just books, magazines, and movies... They hold our shared history. Without any doubt, there is offensive material printed on numerous pages spread throughout the thousands of books and magazines a library holds. Some find this terrible, but I, on the other hand, completely disagree. Every book has a different story to tell, and everyone comprehends the content differently, so I think libraries shouldn't take out offensive material from their shelves. What's really considered offensive? This question would be very hard to answer definitively because everyone has a different view, different opinions, and a different cultural background. Some would say violence, drugs, gangs, and sexual situations are offensive... While others consider certain religious views, political beliefs, traditions, and challenged morals offensive. With all the different views on what someone finds offensive, a library would have to almost completely clean their shelves just to remove a small proportion of it. There's many sections in a library, from fiction to children's stories. If there is an area for 'children's books,' and 'adult books,' then why can't there be one for materials some readers would find offensive? Libraries could even mark a book with a label if it held something potentially offensive. This would settle many conflicts before they start! If a reader chooses to read a book that was marked with offensive content, they would have no right to get upset later. Limiting our libraries shelves is unthinkable. If someone got offended by what they read, they could put the book down just as fast as they picked it up. A public library is a public place, where many different people go... so if one person gets offended by something they read or saw, doesn't mean the next person will be. The bottom line is, no book should be taken away because someone couldn't handle what was being said. 'If I have the right to remove that book from the shelf - that work I abhor - then you have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' Since everyone's view on offensive material is different, eliminating it all would be impossible. One person found this book offensive, so it's gone... The library would soon become pointless. The shelves would empty, because of the loss of many phenomenal books and important ideas. People do get offended, that's just a part of life... I don't think that they should be able to take a book away from everyone just because of one person's opinion on its content.

Censorship has been the central topic of many debates involving politicians, civil rights activists, and the everyday citizen. There are groups that believe the government has every right to censor anything that is considered offensive in today's society. Some individuals could argue with this belief by supporting the statement that it is not the government's position to decide what is considered offensive and what is not. I just so happen to agree with this latter view. One common opinion, mainly supported by people with children, is that books, music, and movies etc. should be censored to protect the younger generations. While it is true that parents should be concerned with what their children are exposed to, if the offensive material that is involved in the everyday life of an adult is completely restricted from an individual as a child how is he or she expected to be prepared and excel in the future? Why do we go to school for at least twelve years of our lives? We go to prepare ourselves for the challenges of being an adult. We place ourselves in an environment that is specifically created to make us comfortable with the responsibilities of maturity. If not properly exposed to challenging ideas, there is absolutely no way to be prepared to encounter them in the future. However, not all individuals support censorship because of their children. There are adults that would like to see no more of today's offensive material for their selves than they would want their children to see. My rebuttal to this is that if you do not want to see it then do not choose to see it. No individual is ever forced to be exposed to anything in today's media. Turn off the television if the program bothers you. Do not read the book or magazine. Change the radio station. Every person is capable of controlling what they hear and see, and it is unnecessary to attempt to remove from society what could simply be ignored by those who object. Lastly, one of the most consistent debates around censorship is that the government should control what is included in today's media. Think back in American history; when has giving the government more power in our everyday lives ever been consistently good for our society? The reason our forefathers founded our great country was to have the freedom they were isolated from in England. The First Amendment of the Constitution was created to insure that the government could not attempt to control what they had no right to control. The freedom of speech is not just referring to what comes from an individual's mouth, but what goes into their eyes and ears as well. The citizens of this great country are more than capable of deciding for themselves what is offensive to them and what is not. It is the government's duty to protect our country from other countries and groups of people who attempt to break it apart, but not to control what we see and hear. Meetings and debates are held everyday to enhance the quality of our freedom and occasionally to gain more freedom. I ask why some individuals would want to give one freedom we do have away? The United States is one of the greatest countries ever to exist, yet we are too lazy to decide what we are exposed to in our everyday lives? It is time for our society to stop being nurtured by the government and start doing our own dirty laundry when it comes to choosing what media we consume.

In my view, actually being African American myself, sort of aggravates me too, but none the less, shouldn't argue because of one major amendment, freedom of speech. It depends on how it angers them also, like how back in world war two, the German people were characterized as short, fat people with big noses taking all the money away from the country. That can be offensive, and is used usually to talk people over to their side. I think that if something offends you lightly, most of the time you shouldn't worry about it, but if you get offended very heavily and none of the stuff they say about that topic is true, maybe you should get someone else to read it with the same dislikes and likes as you. That could help determine if it is truly offensive to people in general, not just you. Then after that the main question we would ask would be 'what should we do next?' If I were someone and the book I'm reading offends me massively, I would contact the library it came from and ask them to read it, and if they think it is offensive, then they would more than likely take it off the shelves. Now just because of someone that likes a sports team reads a book about them and the book talks trash about the team, don't tell the library, that's just a waste of time. Just simply pick up another book and read it. I can understand how people will get mad over racism and discrimination, but not over a sports team. So I hope that people can someday understand the limit to where something can actually be offending. Or maybe its just in our common nature for us to be offended when something we like gets made fun of. That is why I think that books should only be taken off shelves for only very good reasons, not silly ones.

Banned books.'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf - that work that I abhor- then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' Katherine Paterson, Author. I believe and will stand by Katherine's statement above. Who gets to say if a book is offensive? People have a right to their opinion, but I do not think any one has the right to take books away from a public library. Public library, the facts are in the name. It is a public library, where people can go and find a book to pass time, a book to use on an school assignment, or a book to read to their child. Taking a book off the shelves just because it offended someone does not makes sense to me. A person can pick up a book, be offended and complain about it, that is freedom of speech. I do not see fault in that. But when a person picks up a book, is offended, and demand that the book per se is taken off the shelves of a public library. That is when I have issues seeing where they think they have the right. Katherine Paterson said in her text that 'If I have the right to remove that book from the shelf- that work I abhor- then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' Isn't that a scary thought? If a person was offended by a book they could take it off the shelf at his or her own will? I fear the out come of that. I am sure that a person could figure out something offensive about any book if they looked hard enough. Taking books off the shelf is taking knowledge away from the people. We as citizens have the right to read at our pleasure, any book that we have the slightest whim to read, and be able to read that book without prosecution from a people that find the book in question 'offensive.' The day we let people take books off the shelves because they offend them, is the day our first amendment fails. As a nation we need to stand strong against banning books from public libraries. For our generation and for the many generations to follow, we must protect this fundamental freedom.

One subject the censorship of library content in certain places and times, whether fictional or not, to his or her own opinion. I personally disagree with the concept. The facts point out that society fears the dystopia predicted by publications exploring the outcome of similar campaigns and has instated systems designed to prevent such occurrences. Certain examples stand in play to explicate my opinion. Society, at least in my native country and surely abroad in other democratic nations, dislikes enforced censorship for a few reasons. First, many countries have a Bill of Rights and priviledges upheld in the face of the law. Our founding fathers wrote out one of the documents establishing this trend on the prompting of the general public. The first ten ammendments to our fine constitution, bundled as the Bill of Rights, resulted. Some of the included statements ensure the freedom to speak as it publicly pleases us as citizens and the freedom to write, individually and collectively without boundaries. The removal of these principles so ingrained in our nation's conscience would cause a general uproar. We as a people instituted our government to preserve our freedoms, and we could prepare ourselves to replace it as implied in the Declaration of Independence if so required of us to continue doing just that. Secondly, publications such as the ones mentioned for banning rebuke the enforcement of opinion for its effects on society. I can mention three books portraying this dystopic outlook on censorship. 'Fahrenheit 451,' required by state standards for one possible choice of reading assigned to us by my teacher, describes book burning and utmost uniformity between citizens. '1984,' by George Orwell, I know describes a dystopia in which all citizens completely submit their will to and omnipotent Big Brother, who utilizes omnicient surveillance even though I have not read the composition myself. 'Little Brother,' a recent novel by Cory Doctorow whose title employs a pun on the name of 1984's prime antagonist, weaves the exciting tale of an older teenager who tries to beat the system of surveillance from under the radar. All, however, betray a sense of fear in their content, and that fear has transferred directly into local civilization. In reviewing the aspects of censorship portrayed in its effects, the system itself reveals that the even the intended creation of a utopia and compliance through censorship may result in decline and misery throughout the area within which government or civil officials practice the method. In any case, a more effective solution must exist today. To prove the point, let me introduce some content advisory systems currently in place. Libraries divide themselves into sections for the various age groups, and therefore create an inherent barrier between differing groups of content deemed appropriate only in the face of maturity. The film and television industries rely on ratings displayed at various times during video to provide the same sort of psychological fence dividing content into pieces. Even the video game industry, into which I plan to inject myself upon exiting college, has a system in place to separate existing media into tiered subcategories designed in a similar way to film ratings. Different regions utilize different systems, but that of the ESRB, or the Entertainment Software Rating Board for the United States, compares relatively well in ranking video games to the rest of the globe. As explained, censorship already exists in a form accptable to all. Nobody forces anybody to comply to the recommendations, but hopefully everyone does so on their honor. Capable parents most definely follow the guidelines which have cropped up over the years. Only if these methods of moderation were enforced would everyone be upset. It's up to everyone to prevent a situation like unto the worst-case scenario and useresponsibly the systems available for this purpose.

The ideas conveyed by literature, music, and movies are an art. They cannot be explained in any other way than themselves, and if we take away the right to produce or the right to sell these masterpieces, then the world loses something of itself. Censorship is the underlying problem to many things. It takes away the expression of human thought and emotion- emotions like greed, love, fear, and the ability to empathize that are conveyed in books and films. If people think it's offensive, they simply can't take the truth. Many people can only express themselves in their art- and art can be very real. So real that we don't think that it's possible. We don't want to believe something like 'The Destructors' could happen. 'The Destructors' is a short story in which kids get together and rob an old man's home. Because this man is very rich, he has lots of material wealth. Then they burn down the house with the man's belongings still in it. Needless to say, this story has been banned from many schools and libraries. But what many don't understand is why would the kids burn down the house. Many think that the kids just want to see it burn, to destroy what is so cherished, or that the love of material things is making us greedy. It is this that makes us think, and therein lies the problems with censorship. If we censor something that makes us think this hard about who we are and what we do here, then we begin to lose ourselves. The loss of books has been seen throughout history. Most prominantly, the nazi regime. In the beginning of their control of power, they banned certain books that went against the nazi ideals. The censorship escalated into the nazis burning books in large piles. This communal burning would make it easier to control the public mindset. The movement swelled and the German people soon developed a national pride and goal. By the 1930's, nearly every German who could read had read 'Mein Kampf'. The censorship had turned into an all-out war on classical literature and the promotion of nazi ideas. That was how Hitler was actually voted in. Many don't realize, but the German people actually did vote Hitler to be leader. Now that the nazis had destroyed the publics ideals, they were replaced with the nazi's own. The banning of media can only lead to a general lack of self knowledge. The human mindset can only be expressed through the art which the human creates. If we try to explain it, we soon get lost in our words. The use of verbal and visual examples is the only way we learn who we are. Censorship has never ended in something good- only the promotion of something bad. If we let our media get banned, we lose the right to have ideas of our own.
