Certain materials such as books, movies, magazines, and comics can be offensive to certain people. When we look at a comic and see that the writer of the comic has said something offensive, what may seem offensive to you may not be offensive to anyone else. Certain pictures or writings that seem full of knowledge and vibrance to you may be completely something else in someone elses eyes. How many humans inhabit the world today? About six billion, researchers say. If you think about it, each and every one of those six billion minds thinks differently. If a librarian takes away the knowledge that you find so vibrant, it is like taking away a person's ability to learn. In the world today, many teenagers and young adults are becoming more involved. What that teenager reads in that magazine article could spark a whole new reason to help the world. For all you know, the magazine could have gotten the young adult or scientist one step closer to finding the cure for cancer. How could you just take that away? Again, the magazine could be offensive to a person who may have cancer or a doctor who treats cancer, but will they be offended when their cancer is cured? Or when the doctor can successfully say that all of the cancer in your body has gone away? If we take everything away that could possibly be offensive to other people, we might as well just take all the books, movies, magazines, and comics away that have ever been created. Once again, something that may be offensive to you would not be offensive to another person, because about six billion minds do not all think alike. If reading materials were taken away that are found offensive, our ability to learn and grow as humans might as well be taken away as well.

Culture and history are two very important aspects of the world, forming the foundation of our collective identity. Libraries are places that house these very things for the enjoyment and education of all who visit them. This is why I believe libraries should not censor any of their materials. Learning has always been and will be a key aspect of living and libraries offer this to people freely! How can one take that freedom away from another? Not all things in the world and history are perfect and have occurred in the ideal way. However, subjects such as slavery, the Holocaust, and other controversial topics must be known about. These horrible happenings in history offend some but they cannot be erased from the past. Learning is natural to humans yet we always try to fight it. It is not right to hide the truth from anyone. Some people are easily offended and some are not. But the true question is, 'who is to say what is offensive?'. There are people who believe that discussing the divinity of Jesus in the Christian religion is offensive and others who believe any type of homosexuality is also. Yet there are still others whose beliefs directly contradict these. Libraries must maintain all types of material because their purpose is to hold all knowledge and not just what people want to know. How can we make better decisions in the future if we do not recognize what has occurred in the past? Removing information from the library because it is offensive is essentially depriving people of potential solutions to problems. All aspects of culture and history should be preserved so that we can know where we came from, the mistakes we made, and how we plan to fix our new ones! History has never been in the control of man, and we should not attempt to control its narrative now. In conclusion, libraries should not censor any of their materials. What has happened in the past cannot be changed or altered to fit our ideal visions. And by doing this we deprive future generations of information that could potentially be useful. We must never forget who we are as a people, and where we came from. Our knowledge and ability to learn is our greatest asset and must be treasured and protected from any form of suppression.

People of all ages have the right to read any material that they want, but parents or other family members often tell their children not to read about a certain topic. Those children will either listen to their parents or not. If these children do not listen, we need to do something about it to protect them. We need to have clear rules in libraries. Children do not need bad influences in their lives from a young age. Adults have the right and responsibility to keep children away from this information. Leaders of a library have many different sections in their library for this very reason. Children and adults both have their own sections as well as teens. These groups of people have a right to choose what material it is that they want to read, watch, or listen to, within reason. I believe that if we make the sections have a strict age limit we can prevent children from finding bad information. Right now, children can read this information at any time without guidance. Adults can eliminate this risk with proper oversight. Children in libraries should be supervised by a guardian. Too many books are about drugs, sex, or pregnancy. Reading this material can give off bad information to a child who is not mature enough. Children are not old enough to be learning about sex from books alone. Parents should be the first to tell their child about sex in an appropriate manner. Young children know about drugs and know that those drugs are harmful, but detailed stories can glamorize them. Children learn about drugs in movies, books, and can hear about them in music. Many books deal with pregnancy as well. Learning about pregnancy makes them think about how that women got pregnant with a child. Those children then start to ask other adults and children, leading to confusion. Children can also read or listen to material about gun violence. Children read about gangs and think that it is cool or exciting. They then want to play with toy guns and pretend that they are in a gang. This information is very harmful and should not be allowed to children without context. After some children read about it they get their friends involved. This information can spread across the school quickly. Violence is very harmful for children's development. Librarians are not in control of the material people wish to read, but they are in control of its access. If that library has offensive material it is their job not to let that material get into a young persons hands. They should be able to have strict limits on age appropriate material. If a child tries to check out a book and it seems to be over their age limit, they should not be allowed to have the book. The sections that they might find harmful information should be closed to young children without an adult. Children in libraries should be supervised at all times. Books about drugs, sex, or pregnancy should not be allowed for children to read freely. Violence in books seem to spread across schools, influencing behavior. Adults can help prevent this harmful information from reaching all children by supporting these necessary restrictions.

What do we find offensive? This is a question with no single answer. In a library there are hundreds of materials that can be offensive to anyone, depending on their personal beliefs and experiences. For example with movies there are horror, sci-fi, comedy, romance, adventure, etc. and all of them are offensive to someone somewhere. If we were to take down all of the movies that are offensive to a single person, all the movies would be taken off the shelves eventually. Should we take all things that are offensive to us off the shelves, or leave them so people who do enjoy them can? I believe that we should leave these materials alone for the benefit of the whole community. It should not be right for us to choose what a public library should and shouldn't have on their shelves based on individual sensitivity. If a person finds an item offensive, then they should ignore it and move on, not make a big deal of it for everyone else. Many people learn to keep their opinions to themselves but some do not, causing unnecessary conflict. People who judge by what they don't like, tend to make themselves known, but that does not mean they should dictate access for all. A library's collection should reflect diverse viewpoints, not just inoffensive ones.

Censorship is the most foul and terrifying part of a modern society, eroding our fundamental liberties. Our lives have been taken over by political correctness, so much so that our voices are no longer our own, but are filtered through a lens of acceptable discourse. Until recently we had the freedom to convey our thoughts, no matter what those thoughts were, in any form of media. But now if something is found to be offensive in any way it is essentially burned and removed from public view. Censorship limits our freedoms, takes away our rights as citizens and people, shields us from the truths of the world, and limits the knowledge we can take from, as well as ensuring that one day there will be nothing left of media worth consuming. The Constitution of the United States, the document that our country lives by, says that we as people have the right of free speech. Censorship actively and violently violates that sacred right. Our country was built on free speech, and now it is being taken away piece by piece. Our own words are forced down our throats, never allowed to come out into the open. Censorship ensures that no challenging opinions will be heard, that no one's beliefs will be questioned, that no one can assume or think for themselves. Is this not what we are supposedly guaranteed by freedom of speech? We are supposed to be able to say anything we want to say. We know there are consequences for saying certain things, but we are supposed to be allowed to say them. Letting our own ideas into the world allows for new ideas to form and evolve. Arguments come, but these arguments allow people to see other ideas that they hadn't thought of and look at issues from new perspectives. We are able to see our world through different eyes when we hear or read someone else's opinions. And from there we can form our own opinions, allowing our world to be rich with ideas and knowledge, and allowing our society to advance. But censorship wants to take this all away from us in order to please everyone, which is an impossible goal. But there will always be someone who is unhappy with any given idea. It's the inevitable truth of a diverse population. Censorship is trying to shield us from the ugliness of this world, creating a false reality. In a way this makes sense from a protective standpoint. We don't want our children to understand the atrocities that happen in everyday life immediately. We don't want them knowing what's happening behind closed doors before they are ready. However, if we don't allow people to open these doors eventually, they can never understand the world or be prepared for the experiences that are to come. Learning the harsh realities of our society educates people, allowing them to stop these realities as well as be prepared for when they happen to them. For example, let's look at the issue of rape. Rape is a horrible thing, but it happens in our world. It is a nasty part of reality that must be confronted. Rape can be censored from books, television, and other forms of media. We can walk around pretending rape doesn't exist. But that doesn't accomplish anything meaningful. That doesn't get rid of rape. It still exists as a tragic fact. And if the people are uneducated on the issue of rape, how will it ever stop? How will a rape ever be able to be prevented? How will someone know what to expect or what to do? By censoring rape from media, we are ensuring that the people in future generations never learn about its signs and consequences. Knowledge of rape is important if it is ever going to be stopped and survivors are to be supported. Pretending something doesn't exist doesn't get rid of it; it only makes us more vulnerable. Censorship is supposed to protect the people, but it doesn't in the long run. It hurts the people, cutting off their access to crucial knowledge. We as people need knowledge to survive and thrive. We live off of knowledge, it is the fuel for progress. And the way we obtain this knowledge is through media and open discourse. Censorship takes away pieces of knowledge gradually, like death by a thousand cuts. It may not seem like a lot is missing now, but as time goes on the gap will increase, and more knowledge will be taken from our grasp. Is this fair to future generations? Is this right for a free society? Is this helping us grow? How does cutting out knowledge ever help a society advance? It brings us backwards in time, makes us fear what we do not understand. It is human nature to fear the unknown. The more that becomes unknown due to censorship, the more we have to fear in our lives. Censorship is taking away crucial pieces of knowledge that we must understand to get along in a complex society. This is wrong and immoral on a fundamental level. It is unfair, if nothing else, to limit human understanding. We should be allowed to take from any knowledge that exists, to read and learn without barriers. No good comes from hiding it away in the dark. Lastly, this gradual burning of knowledge is affecting society in horrid ways, creating ignorance and division. And as time goes on it can only get worse if left unchecked. Censorship is based off of offensiveness, a subjective and fluid concept. If something could be offensive to anyone, it is disposed of without a second thought. However, everything that exists in society could be offensive to someone, somewhere. Therefore everything and everyone should be censored in order to fulfill the ultimate goal of censorship, which is an impossible and dystopian standard. This means all media of any kind should be destroyed to avoid any possible offense. No one should say anything for fear of causing upset. The world would be forced into a silent, sterile existence. All knowledge would be taken away, leaving a vacuum. Chaos would ensue as people fight over the remnants of free thought. The people's freedom would be completely taken away, extinguished. The freedom to know would vaporize right in front of their eyes, lost forever. This is our future if we allow the censorship to continue its march. We cannot allow our lives to be taken over by censorship, to have our thoughts policed. Yes, people's feelings will be hurt sometimes, but we cannot rid our world of ideas and knowledge purely to spare feelings, as those feelings are temporary while knowledge is permanent. These ideas and knowledge are too important to let censorship take away from us and our children. Censorship is taking away our freedoms and rights, slowly stealing them away from us without most people even noticing. It also tries to shield us from reality, but instead hurts us, ensuring that we will never understand our world and never

Materials that are found offensive should not be taken off the shelf. People might need those materials for academic research or if they just want to find out about something for themselves. If the material is offensive to someone they can report it to a librarian, but the people that work at the library might not do anything about it if the material does not violate policy. The people that find something offensive could also simply ignore it and walk away, allowing others to access it. If I found something that was offensive to me I would just ignore it. I might look at it briefly to see what it says but I would not say anything about it or demand its removal. There are some people, like students or scholars, that would have to look at that very material for research or something else important. So why get it removed from the shelf for everyone? I have not seen anything that would be offensive to me yet but, if I did then I would not say anything and just move on. Now some people would say something but, what if you walked in a library looking for a specific book for your research paper, and it was not there because someone found it offensive? What would you do then? Yes you could get on the internet but, it might not have what you are looking for exactly or the specific details you need. I have had a lot of research papers throughout my schooling. There was one time when I went to the library and could not find a book or a magazine to help me with my research topic. I had to wait for over an hour just to get on the computer to look information up. When I did get on the computer I only had an hour to look up everything before my session ended. I did not get it done in time and had to turn it in late, which affected my grade. Computers are good for looking up stuff, but when you have a specific book in mind that would give you a lot of detailed information, you go for the book not the computer. I know there are materials that are offensive to people. I know people get mad at them but, it is not the library's fault for providing a diverse collection. They most likely have to have those materials on the shelf because that is what's required of them by their collection development policy. So if people do get mad they can report it or just walk away and ignore it, which is the most practical solution for everyone involved.

To whom it may concern, everyone in life has to deal with something offensive towards them at least once. It might be swear words in a popular song, or even people's behavior and actions on a regular basis that they find disagreeable. Be that as it may, nobody was made perfectly, and we all have to learn to cope with people's flaws and differing viewpoints. The library is for everyone; not just you specifically. Just like people's personalities we have to deal with different things that fit those specific personalities and interests. Katherine Paterson's quote said, 'But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf...then you also have exactly the same right...' This is a strong and truthful accusation, and I believe that things in a library should have some censorship, but only up to a specific point and not beyond. We all realize that the biggest population of people in a library-- and perhaps the most innocent-- are children. Each parent has different values and standards for their child, which they hope to instill. What might be offensive to one parent may not be to another. If one mother thinks a book that talks about something she believes to be inappropriate to her children should be removed, another mother may not mind it at all. The first mother's opinion is different than everyone else; she could say she wanted this book removed from the library, but then so could the second mother about a different book she finds problematic. If everyone voiced their opinion on what books they didn't think were appropriate for their children, then we would 'have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' according to Katherine Paterson. I believe she is right in this observation. Besides, who is to say what is right for everyone when tastes and morals vary so greatly? Not one person has the same morals or values as another. For one person to declare what is right could highly offend another individual with a different background. I have dealt with situations like this before; everyone has at some point. People tell me what they believe to be right, and I do not always agree with them. It is simply a matter of everyday life; people's opinions and morals are going to clash occasionally. Everyone is different, and if one person doesn't like a certain magazine in the library, another person may not like a different one. If we were to all voice our own opinion on what we want censored and what we don't, nothing would be left for anyone to enjoy. The library shelves would be completely empty, defeating the purpose of the institution. Even though everyone has different opinions on what should stay and what should go, I do believe that there should be some censoring up to a certain point for extreme cases. Taking into account everyone's diversification in this world, I do believe that there should be censorship up to a certain point. If something is in a book that a good majority of the population are against, I believe that the book, or books should be removed after careful consideration. I am not saying that because a couple of people weren't for a certain artist from the past that it should be taken away at once. If it is a major issue that highly offends many people in the community, it should not be in a public library where it causes widespread distress. Libraries are for obtaining information, and for reading; not for brewing up offensive opinions on certain topics that divide people. There should be a certain limit on what is in a library, because there are things out there people really shouldn't be seeing or hearing, especially children. But it shouldn't get to the point where people can just remove books from the shelf at their own free will without a formal process. Without some limit on censorship in a library, absolutely anything could be found there, which is not ideal either. When we think of a library we don't think of things that are offensive. People view the library as a positive place, created for people's own personal enjoyment and enrichment. That doesn't mean that we will never find something that might offend us in some way there, but people should not be able to just remove books from the shelf because they don't agree with their personal morals. Everyone is different, and nobody has the right to tell them what exactly is right or wrong, up to a certain point where harm is evident. I know from experience that it can be a tough thing to ignore sometimes, but we all seem to do it everyday with the people around us; we can't just choose to get rid of them when they disagree with us. Everyone wants to be comfortable, but sometimes we just have to deal with things in life like a book we don't deem appropriate for ourselves. So I believe that in a way, an excessive amount of censorship on things in a library can be a bad thing for intellectual freedom. If we all could get rid of what we wanted in a library, there would be nothing left for anyone to use or discover. After all, I wouldn't mind walking into a library with shelves full of magazines and books, instead of one completely empty due to overzealous censorship. Thank you for considering this perspective on a complex issue.

Movies are to popcorn as music is to headphones; they are classic pairings for entertainment. Right? It is all fun and games until someone's innocence is completely destroyed by the content within. But in our current era, the music industry is exploding with rap and hip-hop music. This type of music is often triggered towards the three ideas of sex, drugs, and violence. Why would you ever censor anything in a library, a place dedicated to knowledge and access? Apparently, it is because things such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., can be found offensive by some patrons. If something is considered offensive, why put it in a library anyway if it's going to be open to anyone in the public, including children? This is a valid concern that requires a balanced approach. First off, censorship is important in some contexts, but we don't necessarily need it in libraries of all places. Libraries are institutions where all sorts of literature and media come together in one place where they can be seen and experienced by those who admire them. Censorship stops this by pulling books off shelves simply because they are considered offensive by a few. If a book is deemed offensive, the first step should be to decide what kind of audience it would be offensive to. Then, decide whether or not it is offensive to even an adult audience. If it is found to be offensive to an adult audience, then perhaps it should be pulled off the shelves of a library, but this is a drastic measure. Otherwise, it should be placed in the adult section of the library where access can be managed. Libraries should have certain sections for certain books and other pieces of literature and media. As mentioned before, if a book is too offensive for anyone not of adult age, it should be placed in a designated adult section. Books that are suitable for children should be put in the children's section where they are appropriate. You can even have a separate section for young adults for books that are suitable for teenagers, bridging the gap between children's and adult content. Sections in a library almost completely defeat the need for outright censorship. These sections help correctly place books and other literature in a library so that only readers of certain suitable ages @MONTH1 read them, allowing for personal choice while providing guidance. In conclusion, using sections in a library can be an effective strategy instead of resorting to censorship. If we were to censor every book that someone found offensive on the shelves in a library, then eventually there would hardly be any books left for anybody to enjoy. Sections help keep a wide variety of books in a library, but they keep them in a designated place where the right audience can view them responsibly, thus preserving access and choice.

When you enter a public library; it is divided into sections according to interest, age, author, ect.. When you enter a school library it is done according to fiction, non-fiction and author. Censorship amoung public libraries is not needed. Adults, students, and childeren all go to a public library for different reasons. So, as the case may be why would you censor a library that goes for all ages. I feel that yes an elementary, or middle school library should not contain the same content as a high school library. But a public library, is for the entire public. Hints the name.  In conclusion, if even more censorship was done to public libraries, libraries would be used less than they already are. Some of the content in public libraries can't be found in school libraries, but also adults wouldn't be able to find the content needed for their own interests, jobs, or even schooling. So as the fact may be that some things may seem innappropriate to certain age groups, it can help someone in a completely different age group with their own unique needs and perspectives.

I personally believe that there shouldn't be a whole lot of censorship in libraries, except for things such as complete smut and pornography, which serve no real literary or educational purpose. However there are many different beliefs on this subject. Some parents might think it's necessary to control every bit of information a child takes in, while others are more forgiving and trust in their child's judgement.  The main conflict with this issue is how different everyone's restrictions are. A lot of parents believe that if any politically incorrect information enters their child, he/she will be corrupted for life, but that is completely false. Nowadays, almost every single person goes through something traumatic, witnesses something illegal, gets involved in drama, experiments sexually, and/or experiments with drugs. The truth is, it's everywhere, and your kids have already experienced it and are used to it. Reading one book with a couple curse words here and there, or an intimate moment isn't going to ruin your child, because chances are, he/she is already doing it all in real life. It might even be happening in your own home and there is nothing that can be done to stop it. Trying to control our lives as if it was your own provokes kids to rebel even more when the chance arises, seeking out the very content you tried to hide.  I say don't worry about censorship in libraries except for the obvious things like pornography, and sex novels, racist books, ect. Maybe if we quit hiding so much from the more mature teenagers, and quit treating them like toddlers, they wouldn't go looking as much for all of the 'bad' things out there. Parents need to quit thinking they can get their child to believe there is nothing bad in the world. If they aren't aware of the mistakes that can be made and the consequences from it, they won't know what to do if they find themselves in a similar situation as one of the characters in one of these 'offensive' books, which often provide valuable life lessons.

Offensive material. Material. Books, music, magazines, movies, commericals. Is it right to have all types of material shown to all ages? I disagree. A variety of people could take offense to the content this material contains. I think that there should be a designated area, or all the alarming material should be removed so everyone can be at peace when they are at the library, or just watching television in their own home.  Even though some people may not take offense to any type of material, you have to think about the parents. A majority of parents would not want their children to be surrounded by all the effects that this material brings. Some content may not be suitable to younger kids. Whether it be going to the movies or just going to the library, children can see all the violence and misbehaving going on in the world today. I believe that drugs, alcohol, and curse words have a big influence on kids these days. I think it is our responsibilty to protect them until they are at an age they can make their own judgements and understand the context.  Religion. Our religion plays a big part on what we think is right or wrong. I was taught to always treat people with respect and to try my hardest to get along with others. A lot of the material contradicts what I have been taught. If you see something on television with your favorite actor or actress on it, we tend to believe it is acceptable behavior. If you have ever been to a movie theater, you know they have certain ratings. The ratings are there to protect younger kids from getting into adult movies. They enforce this rule to an extent, but I don't think they enforce it enough. At the least, libraries and movie rental places could have a designated area for adult rated content to respect those who disagree with its themes.  A few years ago when my little sister was about two or three, she was watching a movie with me and it had a few curse words in it. She had never heard them that often and wasn't sure what they meant. For the next couple of days, she went around saying the word and my parents weren't very happy. She had no idea she was doing anything wrong because she heard it on a movie and if they could say it, then she could too. Children sometimes don't know any better and if they would happen to say it to a stranger, they would be offended.  Material can be harmless, but it can also be offensive. The safest way to keep the new generation respectful, is to shield them when they are young so that they can learn what is right and what is wrong. When they come out into the real world, they won't be difficult to put up with and will have proper manners. No one will ever agree on the same things, but in the end, we need to do what is right for the betterment of our community and its youngest members.

The book called The Contender. the book is about a young African-American man that starts school at a new high school. While the first few weeks in school he is picked on and made fun of. So one day he decides to join a boxing class, and the wreslting team at his school. But at the end of the book he ends up fighting everybody the was bullin him and ultimately finds his own path and self-respect.  I personaly the book should be kept on the self because its a life changing expersance for a young man, showing a journey of perseverance and personal growth. For some people this book they will or have even read this book several times, I know I have. I only hope that othere people will like or even love this book as much as I have, finding value in its story and message.  So I guess what I am trying to say is you really never know what you are going to like in till us sit there and read it from beganing to the end, allowing the story to fully unfold and reveal its deeper meaning and impact on the reader.

When you go into a library have you ever seen the many subjects people write about? Some from their own experience and some made up from pure imagination. I personally disagree that offensive books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed. The authors or producer of these sort of entertainment were made to be read, hear or watched by people that are interested in them! Also if the libraries are having diffculties with the complainments towards the offensive materials they should just make a separate section for such content.  To begin with, why are books, music, movies, and magazines produced for? Easy one! To entertain us; to expand our knowledge on things; to let us have intrest and explore different perspectives. If none of these things were invented, life would be boring, now i'm not saying we need these offensive materials, i'm saying it's there so we can think bigger about topics instead of them same-o-same-o. Producer produced 'offensive' material to catch attention and to be read, not so they can sit on the far back of library where nobody goes just because it has some things others might not like. If you don't like those type of things, stay away from them, don't bother reading or listening to them! Why should libraries stop the people that made those things from making money? Does that seem right to you? It's bad enough they're sencond guessing if they're good enough to be shelve worthy. There's many books out there that are horible and a waste of time reading it, so should they be removed to? Think about that one for a moment.  Secondly, I disagree with the removal of these type of materials because libraries could always make a separate section, perhaps with a simple age restriction or advisory notice. It might cost money, but what's more better loosing tons of costermers or finding extra room? Libraries are very big already and i'm sure they could find a little bit more room, they separate everything into genres already so this would be a logical extension.  Although I see where others come from about removing these kinds of materials from shelves. There might be some cautious parents that don't want their children exposed to that sort of stuff. Teenagers especially, they might get ideas of the language and scenes from these sort of stuff. I once read a story about a man that read a book one of his old pals from college wrote about killing women and teering there inside out, this man got a idea to do it to his mother. He beat his mom and cut her body open, leaving the insides on the outside lawn. The man is in jail now and the book was removed from shelves. Still I don't think it should have been removed because an imature, ignorate person thought it would be cool to do it. The book was made up and the guy was most likely dellusional and sick in the head to do it. And because of his actions and author has to suffer from money lost and big waste of his time and effort he put into it, which seems an unfair punishment.  In conclusion no type of material should be removed because it has been found offensive. Some people just have ignorance to not understand the books, music or movies was made for entertainment for those who like that kind of stuff exposed. Like i've said recently it was made to be either read; heard; or watched. A separate section would be a great idea to balance access with responsibility.

All terms of offense are based on an individual opinion. If one person finds a particular word offensive, that doesn't mean the next guy will feel the same way about it. Some parents aren't as strict on their kids as others are, and some just don't care about monitoring content. Of course there's always that gangster rap that talks about drugs and women being objectified that kids really don't need to be listening to. Then there are the horror movies that are rated 'R' for a reason, as they could cause a child to have nightmares for weeks. Children's mental states aren't fully developed at a young age like ten. They still can't tell what is real and what is not real. They need a trusted adult to rely on to tell them how to feel, how to act, what to do, and even what to think. Children just aren't mature enough to handle a majority of the material in this world. No books should be taken away or hidden from society; it should just be given to you at your own discretion when you are ready. Another possibility would be to have a group of many people gather and vote on age restrictions for particular material. All information is helpful in its own context, just not all of it is necessary for a child. These days it is hard to hide all harmful material from children, and even from some teenagers. This world is becoming less and less sensitive everyday. Eventually everyone will be completely insensitive to all the 'harmful' movies, books, magazines, television shows, and music. It won't even phase anyone anymore, and the concept of offense will have changed entirely.

Censorship in libraries is something good to have and something bad to have; it is a double-edged sword. I think that there could be some things adults can read and some things kids can read, a natural separation. You don't want the kids reading anything that's too mature for them right? Libraries are found all over the country. A lot of people say, 'Well, they shouldn't even have the book there in the first place.' But think about this, maybe you should just have your kid under control and watch what they read. Or option two, don't have your kid go to a public library. Public, which let me explain, is for the public. Which means the whole community can go pick out something they want. A public library is supposed to have a wide variety so anybody can find a book they would like to read. Yes, some things are very inappropriate for kids, but that doesn't mean we can't have it in a public library. Just make sure that you know what your kid is reading. If you do that you should be fine, and your kid will be the same, unharmed by the broader collection. That's how I feel about censorship in a library. It's public, so it's meant to have everything for everyone. Which everything includes the good and the bad. I think some people just have to live with it, as that is the nature of a shared community space. So I honestly feel that libraries, for the way they are, are to be left alone to serve their entire community.

Has anyone ever stopped and thought about the negative aspects of censoring a book? Many people of different beliefs and backgrounds take offense to books that show negativity to their ideas or challenge their worldview. When people are offended by a book the first idea that comes to mind is to try and get the book off the shelves by censoring it from libraries. I think that if a book offends a certain group of people they should just simply not read it; they can choose to look away. Why should other people not get a chance to read a good book just because it offends someone else? Banning books would go against what our country stands for, which is freedom of expression. How different would it make us if we started censoring books in our libraries like other countries with governments who have the final say on what can and can not be read? Imagine what life would be like if all books found offensive were stripped from our shelves; there would be almost nothing left because anyone can find something offensive in any book if they look hard enough. I understand that sometimes things written in books can really be disturbing, and offensive but that doesn't give anyone the right to just take it off the shelves for everyone else. Censoring books is a short term answer to a long term problem of differing opinions. I believe that if we always resort to censoring books then we will become a less creative and less open society. There are many people who actually want to read a book but never get the chance just because it is censored from the library. Books that are censored are usually the books that help ones imagination and encourage new thoughts. Would you want to live in a world where people are void of creativity and independent thought?

To be honest, if I was a librarian I would leave them up on the shelves according to what the state law would have to say about the matter. If the state doesn't have any problems with having them up on the shelves, then all student body will be able to check them out freely. Having magazines available shows what is new in the world and what is not, keeping students informed. Also, just like checking out a book where you have to take a test over it called reading counts, a similar process could be used. Then you would have to read an article from a page in the magazine and write an essay over it, demonstrating comprehension. You would then submit it to whomever is in charge of that department for grading and discussion, ensuring the material is being engaged with thoughtfully and academically.

Many things such as books, music, magazines, etc., cause problem acts for children to act different, but I say that everything should stay in the library because there are more things that cause acts than just the things that are listed. Many children get their acts from books, movies, and magazines but most get their acts from something different entirely. Children get most of their acts from the television that they're viewing at home, which causes them to think if their parents don't care about what they're watching then it's okay to view whatever they want. So the most that is causing acts is what is being viewed at homes or in the movies, not necessarily in the library. So I really say that it's okay for children to read or watch whatever is legal on television. But to me, in the libraries, it's up to whomever is controlling it to decide by ages what is appropriate. Just like legal things are only legal for adults, some content is only for adults. I say that it's only for adults because children start arguments from whatever they see, especially when they're around their friends. When children are around their friends they feel that it's cool to do whatever they see. And it's all coming from things based on violence in the books that children read more often. So to me I will say that it shouldn't be okay for just anything to be viewed by anyone without some consideration for age and maturity.

I have read a few books that I don't approve of, books with content I find inappropriate. And I feel that yes, I do have a right to want to remove these books from the shelves. But who's to say what I think should have an effect on everyone else? Honestly, I do not think that books should be taken off the shelves or music should be banned, etcetera. I think that there should be a little more authority on the age limit of books in libraries, and a separate, designated place for music and other things of that nature. I would not want my kid to walk out of the library with a book about explicit sex, violent gangs, or stuff that should not be known by a kid at a young age. Instead of banning or removing these kinds of books off shelves, why not put a strict, enforced age limit on books, and actually stand by it. Yes, there is an adult section and a kids section, etc., but I've seen so many young kids walking out with books, magazines, and other adult items that are clearly not meant for them. I know how it feels to try and concentrate on a book, newspaper, or magazine you are interested in when people are blaring their headphones, disturbing the peace. And I still feel the same way about the music as I do with books. Don't ban it from the library; just ban it from certain, specific areas of the library, like the reading rooms. It's all out of respect to people who are wanting to be in a quiet area to study or read. I'm not the type of person who wants to take things away from people because everyone has their own interests and beliefs in life, but I am one who believes in setting clear rules that should be followed by all patrons. I see good coming out of everything a library has to offer if only they could exclude things in certain areas to maintain order and a proper environment. And also, they should set and firmly stand by the age limits of the books being checked out to protect younger readers.

They should be allowed to be removed because some books are offensive and contain harsh material. Even if they are offensive, they can teach young teenagers about their past and the realities of history. The books could be about the KKK or the Nazi regime, detailing their ideologies and actions. Some young teens like to read books like this so they can learn and see what people went through during those difficult times. The books could also be a school assignment for a history or social studies class. The way I see it is if your teenage child is interested in the history or the violence of the past, you should allow them to read what they want to satisfy their curiosity and education. Some books such as historical novels, war biographies, and classic literature are great to read for school assignments. These history books are very helpful to read because you can learn about your own history and about the wars at the same time, gaining a broader perspective. I think if your child checks a book out from the library, he or she should return it in a week to ensure it's available for others. The library should give the child a certain, specific amount of time to return the book, like a one-week loan period. If the child does not return the book in that amount of time, they should charge them a small fee for every day it is late. If the book is damaged, they should charge whoever checked that book out for the repair or replacement cost. The book should be in the same condition it was in when it left the library so other people can check it out after it's returned and enjoy it. The library should keep certain important books always available at the library, such as the Bible and essential college textbooks. The library should allow a limited number of history books to each person, perhaps just one or two. Instead of three or four, this would keep more books on the shelves for everyone to share. It would also keep people from losing so many books if they only have a few at a time. I think people under twenty-one years old should not be allowed to check out R-rated movies or explicit music. I think they should have to show I.D. to prove they are over twenty-one before borrowing such materials. There should be more rules then just being quiet in the library; they should make people start keeping some reference books at the library and only allow them to take home fiction or history books. For instance, I check out a fiction book every week and return the previous one I checked out the same day I go to get a new one. I only check out the book I really want to read, and I read it and return it promptly. The magazines should never be checked out; they should remain in the library for everyone to browse.

I think they shouldn't be pulled off the shelves because everyone has different opinions and personal tastes. One person might think a book is offensive, but the next person may not find it offensive at all. Some people might think any books with God or Jesus in them are offensive, but that might just be because it is not their religion or their system of belief. If every single person took off a book that they thought was offensive or objectionable, there would be no books left on the shelves for anyone to read. Because people think so differently about what is acceptable. Or some might not like the horror genre books because of the graphic violence and gory descriptions, but to some people, those are their favorite books for entertainment, so that would be unfair to the ones who like the books that others don't. There are many books out there that not everybody is going to like; the difference is simply how you think and what you personally think is right and wrong, which should not dictate the access for all.

Censorship in libraries? Is it a problem that needs addressing? Should we fix this 'problem' or is it for the good of the community? People of different culture, background, and life could be profoundly affected by these articles in readings, finding either offense or value. Can these books be offensive? They could be offensive to some but to others only educational and enlightening. Statements have been made all over the world of people speaking on what they believe is right or wrong for public consumption. How many people believe that censorship in libraries is really offensive and should be removed from libraries as a practice? Who really are the victims when books and magazines are being thrown off the shelves? The author of that specific article that's who, along with the readers who lose access. If it is said that every reading that comes off as offensive should be taken off the shelves, then what would be left on them for people to learn from? Some people might take romances as being offensive or comedy or horror, based on their personal sensibilities. Romance could be hurtful to someone only because they maybe just got out of a difficult relationship, or comedy because they are miserable and don't know how to laugh anymore or know what happiness is. Who knows what personal history influences these views? Opinions such as these would be not only terrible for business but also terrible for the educational and history part of life itself, erasing valuable perspectives. People of different races and cultures will invariably have another opinion on the situation of censorship, as their experiences differ. From all over the world, there are cultures spreading throughout our communities, bringing diverse viewpoints. Being born into a specific religion could be a huge effect on what their outcome is on a book, magazine, or a movie, shaping their interpretation. Movies of past experiences or massacres that happened to a culture might be difficult for some people of that culture to take in, evoking painful memories. The normal response to a movie such as that would be to become angry or frustrated at the portrayal. Only for others, it is an opportunity to learn what those people went through and grieve for the loss of the people during that terrible time. To support the people who made it through those heart-breaking times and become a friend to them and learn more about them, their culture, and way of life, fostering empathy. Have you seen protests arise before you, perhaps at a city council meeting or a school board hearing? Anywhere in the world, these debates occur. On television, hear it on the radio, or see it in the newspaper, the arguments are widespread. Everyone has most likely seen this type of protest or attack on the opinion of another person, demanding removal of materials. There have been protests in the past over the freedoms of a person or even an entire race, fighting for representation. If everyone begins to complain and argue about what is being put on shelves in libraries, where will it end? What will come of our world if we erase all challenging ideas? What will we know about the past if we sanitize it? What will we begin to predict for the future without a full understanding of history? Anyone, and even I, can make observations of the acts going on around us, seeing the push and pull of cultural expression. In my experience, I have seen attacks being struck upon people who only put a picture in the newspaper, or a small article spoke out on television, facing backlash. Who are we to say that everything needs to be removed off the shelves in libraries based on personal discomfort? These are just people who have been hurt and don't want to relive that experience through media, which is understandable but not a basis for policy. Overall, my opinion on if censorship in libraries should be extinguished is firm. I believe the answer is no, it should not be practiced, because every person in the world is going to be upset, hurt, or broken about something at least a million times in their lifetime from now on, it is inevitable. Whether it be in books, music, movies, magazines, or anything else, offense is a personal reaction. They just need to understand that without any one person's culture and its recorded history, that there would be no complete history of life before us to learn from and build upon.

We as Americans have the right to say what we want, and do as long as it is within the laws of the land. If they take away some books because they are racey or because some people find them morally wrong, then they are saying we shouldn't learn the full, unvarnished history of our civilization. A great man once said 'Those who do not learn from the past are condemned to repeat it.' This quote is saying that if we take away the books that are even obscured or difficult, we are taking that crucial history away from our children and they will do the same mistakes that we have done in our lives, unable to learn the lessons. Taking away the content that is obscene or challenging will make our children unknowledgable to the fact that it happened or how the past really was, leaving them with a incomplete picture. 'Adventures of Huckleberry Finn' is under criticism because it uses the 'n-word' a lot in the text, which is considered offensive today. There is no reason to change the book because that is how the people talked, back in that day, and how things were done historically, reflecting the reality of the era. If they change the book, they change history and they take away knowledge from the children of tomorrow that slavery was a harsh, harsh thing that used dehumanizing language. When I think of censorship in the library, I think of how certain political groups are trying to change the past and how it is trying to nerf the children's history of what really happened, creating a softened narrative. Censorship should be on tv, movies, and music so the little kids don't see the wrong things too early, which is a form of age-appropriate protection, but when it comes to literature in the library, they shouldn't do it at all because only the literate people will know what it means and what the text is actually saying, and they can process it. There should not be a censorship in the literature of the past, the present, and the future, as it is essential for a well-informed and thoughtful society.

In my way of viewing things, I say that what I think is that books, movies, music, and magazines should be put in a critical order because some of us want or like to read or see stuff about what we want to see, like the news that is in one way good to us. But some others like to see what's behind the reality and want to speak up, but they cannot because they are afraid that they would get hurt for speaking up. So I think that those things—books, music, movies, magazines—should not be removed from the shelves because those books or movies can bring you what's going on in the world and how it is affecting us in the way of not paying attention to it. Some experiences that I have involve music; I had once heard a song in Spanish called 'Los Mandamás' and it talks about the corruption in our country and how the people from the bottom suffer because of the people from the top who do not care about them. The song explains that if you treat them as kings, they will treat you as slaves, and that if you give them the power to control you, they will take advantage of it. It describes how honest people work hard to bring food to their homes, but it is not enough because of the leaders on top who want everything for themselves. It is a very good song that says the truth about the situation and that nobody does something to finish it. So I do not want that songs or books that show the reality to disappear because some people do not like them at all. They serve as a vital mirror to our society, and their removal would silence important voices and perspectives that need to be heard for a fuller understanding of the world we live in.

I believe that everyone's opinion deserves to be publicized fairly. Just because one person's view is considered to be right, doesn't mean another is wrong. What is offensive to one person might be informative to another, offering a different perspective or a necessary truth. I've read a lot of books that parents might not pick out for their children. In reading these books, I see that there is no glamour in doing drugs or getting in trouble with the law; instead, they often portray the harsh and unappealing consequences. For some teens, books like these can show them the side of life they haven't experienced and help them find that they never want to go down that path. If a book is too explicit for children, simply place the book in another section, such as a restricted adult area. I realize that there are books with graphic sexual details, and those should only be permitted to be checked out by adults. Parents should have concerns about their children's innocence, and I also believe that they should watch over what type of books their children are reading to monitor the vulgarity of them. Some music contains profanity or sexual innuendo, some contain praise and worship, others even have screaming. Any of these types of music can be found offensive by someone. That doesn't mean we should run off and hide all of them, because there'd be no music left for anyone to enjoy. Not everyone shares the same opinions in this world, therefore there should be equal opportunity for people to read, watch, or listen to whatever suits them. I'm not saying that there should be a stock of porn in the library, but if there are movies or books about shunned religions or beliefs then they should be just as welcomed as the ones about common religions and beliefs. Everyone finds different things offensive. If there was a bible in the library and someone found it offensive, should it be removed? It's one of the most popular books in the world, yet some people still find offense by it. Someone who is Mormon, Muslim, or atheist might find it offensive if there is nothing in the library about them because some people find their beliefs offensive. The library is a place of knowledge, not judgement. I don't believe that certain books should be removed from the library if they offend someone. If you don't like something that is at the library, don't rent it. If you don't want your children to, don't let them. Simple as that. Everyone is entitled to freedom of speech; authors express themselves through books and articles, directors through movies, and musicians through their music, and this expression is a cornerstone of a free society.

I believe that if a book or other media has offensive language then it shouldn't be left on the shelf for unrestricted access. Also, it really does matter if it has offensive language because you don't know who, where, or when your child is going to learn offensive words. Another thing is that he's going to say any offensive words he picks up. Next, one of the most important things is that if you want your child to never have offensive language or any other bad thing, you should watch what you say and what you do around them. One reason why is because once he is growing up he might follow your footsteps and mimic your behavior. Another thing is that if the magazine, movie, book, etc., might have some racist content, like judging the person from where he or she comes from, how they look, or how they talk, it can end up in a bad situation by promoting harmful stereotypes. In conclusion, what I'm trying to say is that it's both the parents and the book because the book your child has chosen might have bad things, and the parents should watch themselves on how they act to provide a proper example and guidance for their children’s development and understanding of the world.

Every parent wants to protect their child's innocence. They do not want their children to come in contact with things that might influence their decisions negatively. The truth is though that they are going to run into these types of things eventually, whether it be from other kids at school, what they see on television, or what they see on the internet. It is their choice as of what decisions they are going to make, so I do not think libraries should be censored due to the content of the material. One reason libraries should not be censored is because nobody is forcing a person to pick up material that might have offensive content. It is all about personal choices and individual responsibility. There are a lot of other options on the shelves that do not include such topics. Some people might want to read or watch something with such content for educational or personal reasons. Taking these pieces out of libraries would not be fair to them. People should have the option to read or watch what they wish. Censoring libraries would take away these people's right to access such topics. Another reason libraries should not be censored is that eventually nothing would be left. As Katherine Paterson said, 'And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' This is a very true statement. After one censoring, people might still think topics are inappropriate, and the libraries would have to be censored again and again until there is nothing left for anyone. People eventually will not be able to use libraries for their intended purpose. Losing libraries as an option will cause people to lose their right to that valuable resource. A final reason that libraries should be left uncensored is the difference of opinions. What might be offensive to one person might not be to another; offense is subjective. How would what should be gotten rid of and what should not be decided? It would be much easier to just leave the people to make their own decisions on what is okay to read and watch and what is not. Nobody is forcing people to pick up a book or magazine that is going to offend them. If you do not like what is being discussed, do not read or watch it. It is as simple as that. When you become a parent, you take on responsibility for the life of another person. This responsibility includes the child's health, safety, and his/her surroundings. Why can't we leave the parenting of children to the parents? When children turn into teenagers and teenagers become adults, they earn many privileges. They earn the right to drive, then the right to vote, then the right to drink responsibly. There is a maturity level that goes into making decisions on your own; if you are mature enough to decide who you want to run your country, how could you not be mature enough to decide something as insignificant as music choice? Authors, artists, composers, and photographers, all by living in America, have the right to the freedom of speech and freedom of expression. By censoring what products are published and put in public, we take away that right. Some may argue that the artists and authors still have the right to express themselves, but they are expressing material that is too risque or graphic to promote. This is an understandable point, but who is the government to promote only what they want to promote? Why should the government have total control over what people are exposed to? If this were to happen, could it easily be taken too far by power-hungry politicians? Wouldn't America no longer be a democracy, but rather a communist country? America prides itself on being a 'melting pot' and being accepting. If America were to adopt such strict censorship, that would mean the restriction of expression and originality throughout the country. Would you really want to live in a country where originality isn't really original, and acceptance was only what the government decided was acceptable? Would you be proud to live in a place where people don't have the opportunity to express themselves to others freely? I wouldn't. Although the censorship of media through a library is only on a small scale, censorship is censorship. It is discrimination against composers of a certain genre of works. It is the removal of choice from people's lives. It is denying the composers their right to freedom of speech. Whichever way you look at it, censorship is censorship, and censorship is wrong.

Library Censorship. Libraries shouldn't have 'offensive' books removed from shelves. Parent supervision, librarian supervision, and your own common sense are three of the reasons why books shouldn't be removed from shelves if they are considered to be offensive. Parent supervision is one of the top priorities for knowing what your children read. If they don't want their children to grow up being 'stupid' then they should teach them to focus on educational books more. When they see their child in a row of books that they think is inappropriate, then they should remove their child from that area and take them to another area. The librarian's supervision is also an important priority. Maybe they don't know the children's actual age, but if the librarian sees them in a place that they think is inappropriate for someone around their age, show them another book shelf. Just like parents, librarians will try to find an educational book that the child might enjoy. But, librarians obviously like to read since they are around books all day, so the child might be lucky and the librarian finds an adventure book for the child, or something else that the child finds interesting. The person's common sense is also a reason why 'offensive' books shouldn't be removed from libraries. Most people know how old they are and what kind of books they should read. If they are in an area of the library that other people might think is inappropriate for them to read, go to a different area. Once again, I don't think there should be a censorship in libraries. If parents want their children to read books that won't 'rot your brain' then they should observe what books their child reads, trust the librarian to show them the correct books to read, and expect their child to have good common sense. This approach respects individual choice while maintaining a responsible environment.

No, the books and other materials should not be moved from the library, because anybody can be interested in them. Someone could come into the library looking for any of those specific items and be unable to find them simply because the library removed them, which would defeat the purpose of a public resource. First, there will be no valid reason for removing the books from the library unless more new books and other materials are coming in and space is a genuine issue. Everyone is into different materials, books and stuff, and personal tastes vary widely. That's why I say do not remove the items. People might come into the library looking for a specific book that they want or need. If that person cannot find it they might complain to the staff, or take their business elsewhere to another library or a bookstore. Then the library could start losing business and community support. Second, if the library starts losing business it might be forced to close down due to a lack of funding and patronage. Then if the library closes down the people who come there often, such as students or remote workers, won't have any place to study or work or nothing at all. What if those people don't have reliable personal transportation; they will not be able to get to another library that is farther away. The owner of the library can lose money and their investment if it closes down, because everyone doesn't have computers and extensive book collections at home. They can come to do their research and rent books for free or a low cost. Third, some people go to the library for peace and quiet, and the library is their only place for such an environment. Little children go to the library looking for books and other items too, and if they can't find the book they want they might start crying out of disappointment. If they start crying, people who are working or studying can be disturbed by the noise. Then that person or people who are disturbed might leave and never come back and that's money and patronage lost. Students whose schools might not have the book they are looking for often come to the library, and if the library doesn't have it that student won't have access to a necessary book for their education. In conclusion, these are some reasons and examples why I don't believe the books and other materials should be taken out of the library. Someone can be really interested in those specific items and they come to the library to search for them and would be very disappointed if they can't find them available.
