So many young kids could check things like that out, and not even know what it actually is or the content it contains! Could you imagine your child coming home from the library, and handing you a book, magazine, or movie that was way beyond anything they should ever see at that age? It would be disastrous for their development and your peace of mind! I do not have children of my own, but I do have younger cousins whom I care about. I know for a fact that if they brought home something inappropriate or offensive, their parents would be having a major talk with the librarian about the library's collection policies. Libraries should have major restrictions on what gets checked out by who to prevent such situations. For example, my local library has three different kinds of library cards to manage access. One card is just to check out regular books from the general collection. Another is so you can check out movies, music, and books from a broader media section. Then the third and final card is so you can check out books, music, and movies from the adult section located in a small, separate room at the back of the library. However, to even be eligible for the third card, you have to be eighteen or older and show valid identification. I strongly believe that if a library does carry materials some may find offensive, they need to be kept in a small, designated room at the back of the library, or perhaps behind the librarians desk where access can be monitored. This way, no one who does not want to see the materials doesn't have to be exposed to them accidentally. If someone did want to see or check out these materials, they should need to show proof that they are eighteen or older, such as a driver's license. This would make it easier for the librarian to keep track of who looks at or checks out the materials and ensure they are not reaching minors. Another thing to consider is, what if one person finds something offensive that someone else does not? Well, I honestly think that at least two or three different people should comment on it being inappropriate or offensive, before it is actually taken off the shelf completely. If more than one person does say something, the librarian should then place the book, magazine, movie, music, etc., in with the other offensive materials, where there is an age restriction for access. This is how it is at my neighborhood library, and I strongly believe that this library is a model for all libraries wanting to have more restrictions to protect young patrons. If all libraries had more restrictions like these, it would be better off for everyone involved. Parents would not have to worry about their young children wandering around the stacks and finding something that is totally wrong for them and their age group. Older teenagers and young adults would still be able to get their homework or research projects accomplished without having all the distractions of the offensive materials being openly displayed. In conclusion, I hope you take all that I have said to heart and consider the importance of these measures. I hope you write an article talking about the need for sensible restrictions in libraries, and how they would make everything better off for families and the community. Thank you for taking the time to read this and consider my perspective.

I believe that some materials in the library should be taken off the shelves. Some people may find them offensive because they might have bad things in them, such as explicit content or strong language. Some types of music, for instance, have bad language in them and people don't want little kids finding them and listening to them. If a little kid saw or heard that stuff then they would learn bad things and inappropriate words. And they would likely say it in front of everybody, perhaps at school or at home, and then other children might start saying it too, causing a problem for parents and teachers. A lot of books are perfectly ok to read because they don't have bad things in them and are suitable for all ages. Some people like reading books that have drama and intense plots, and some people don't, which is a matter of personal preference. Most books are generally ok to read and are harmless. But some books can have strong language in them and shouldn't be allowed in the open library sections where children can easily access them. But they can still be in the library collection because some adults might want to read them for their own interests. If people don't want to read them then they simply shouldn't get them; it is a matter of personal choice. Some movies also have bad stuff in there, like violence or adult themes. That kind of stuff should not be in the general collection because a lot of people don't want to watch movies like that, especially in a family environment. And if a kid would walk in there and get one and if it had that stuff and the parent found out, then the library could get sued for having that material accessible to minors. So they should be taken out of the general library area so young people won't get them accidentally. The library can keep children's movies in there to watch because they are not bad and are age-appropriate. If I worked at a library then I would take certain magazines out of the main reading area. Sports magazines would be ok to keep in there because they are generally safe and about athletics. But a lot of the other ones should not be there on open display because they have a lot of bad things in there, like gossip or explicit images, and I wouldn't let people take them so I wouldn't have them in there. But sports and hobby magazines would be ok because sports are not bad for people to read about and are often educational. People like reading about sports because it is interesting to read and follow their favorite teams. That is just what I think about the matter. Other people might see it the other way and they can have their own opinions; that is their right. People are different and they will think different things about what is appropriate. Some people might want to read that material and some people don't, which shows the diversity of public taste. So it just shows you that people are different because they think things differently than other people do. And some libraries have that stuff and some don't, based on their local policies. So if you are one of those people that like that stuff then you can go to one of the libraries that have that stuff in their collection. And if you are one of those people that don't then you can go to one that doesn't have that stuff so you can get what you want and they can get what they want, and everyone is satisfied.

I have seen some truly offensive books on the shelf of public libraries. Books that make you worry about what would happen if a child of a young and impressionable age looked at these books, since that is where their mind absorbs the most knowledge, but what if this knowledge was offensive to a race of people or a persons religion? These children are the future of our species and what they learn matters. This kind of material should be censored in libraries to protect them. Try to imagine if they had looked at books written by Adolf Hitler and other nazi members during nazi Germany's rule. Maybe they looked at a book by a serial killer or other famous murderers. If they saw a photo book about the massive Jewish death camps in europe, the images could be deeply traumatic. Movies that show war torn battlefields such as Normandy, Iwo Jima, world war one, or world war two could be too intense. The famous movie 'The Killing Fields', a movie based on the cruelty of the Khmer Rouge and the Cambodian genocide, is another example of heavy content. This is my view on censorship; it is necessary to protect children from the offensive things in or on books, music, movies, magazines. There should be censorship in all things children can get into within a library. Imagine a world where there was no control over media and what they could put on for anyone to see; it would be a frightening place for a child to learn and grow up in, which is why we need these protective measures in our public institutions.

The library is a public place for the entire community. Everyone is allowed access to the library and its resources. It supplies everyday people with information that they are seeking to learn about, for education or for pleasure. There are so many different forms of information and entertainment offered inside libraries, catering to diverse interests. Books, music, movies, etc, they all can be found there in one location. Since they all can be found, censorship in libraries should not be allowed, as it restricts access to knowledge and art. Genres were created for a reason, to help people find what they like. Certain items have different forms and categories to them. There are many forms of music, for example, each with its own style and audience. Classical, rock, and blues are just some examples of musical genres. Since music is categorized in such a way, there should be no need for them not to be on the shelves at a library. If a certain type of music or book is known to be offensive to an individual, then that certain genre can be easily avoided by not going to that section. There is no need to even visit a section of the library if one knows that he or she finds its content offensive; it is a simple matter of choice. In the United States the American people are given many rights that are often taken for granted. The freedom of speech is one of these fundamental rights. It is a privilege that if taken away would tear the country apart and undermine its principles. The freedom to say what you please also includes singing and artistic expression. Certain music that is on the shelves at a library does have the right to be there under this protection. Just because a certain group of individuals finds the type of music offensive, does not mean everyone also thinks that way; tastes are subjective. For this reason any genre of music can sit on the shelves at a library as long as it is legally produced. Another freedom given to the American people is the freedom of the press. Anything put onto paper is legal to publish and distribute. Criticizing the government or fantasising about fictional events, it is all legal and protected. Books can be offensive to many people depending on their viewpoints. They can persuade one in ways that is unbelievable and powerful. Like music, books have many categories and genres for organization. Whatever is put inside those books is allowed to be there no matter what, as per the law. Movies are located at libraries as well for people to borrow. They are categorized just as much as books and music, often by genre and age rating. The term 'don't judge a book by it's cover' is true sometimes, but not always. This can also be used with movies; the cover often gives clues. The title of a movie or book will often tell you what it is about or its general theme. Certain movies that are not meant to be seen by children are rated R or NC-17 for a reason. These ratings help censor things to a certain extent by guiding viewers. It is not illegal for a library to have a rated R movie in its collection. It is illegal however to check one out to a child of a young age, and libraries have policies to prevent this. Censorship should not be allowed in libraries as it contradicts the principle of free

Do I believe that certain materials should be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive? I do not think it should matter whether we have music, movies, or magazines in the library, as these are all valid forms of media that serve different purposes for different people. Some people like to come into the library to relax and look at a magazine or listen to some music, finding it a pleasant way to spend their time. I do not think it bothers anybody by what other people are doing there; if it is not bothering them directly, it should not bother anybody else, as we all have different tastes and preferences. I see people sometimes reading a book and listening to music through their headphones, and it does not bother me when they do this. It is a way for them to drown out the world and enjoy a good book without external distractions. There is only one reason why we should keep certain materials out of the library, and that is related to behavior, not content. It is that some people get very loud when they're looking at magazines in a group, or when their music is turned up way too loud and disturbs others seeking quiet. Other than that specific issue of noise, I do not think we should keep those types of materials out of the libraries, as they provide valuable services. I am a reader myself and I like to read in peace, so I understand the need for a quiet environment. So I like to listen to my music quietly while I am reading, and I also like to read magazines every once in a while, which I find to be really relaxing. Those are my reasons on why it should not matter whether we have those types of materials in the library, as their benefits far outweigh the minor inconveniences.

Do I think that books, movies, music, or magazines should be removed from the library? No, I don't. I think that they should be removed only if they cause a significant disruption, but removing them simply because someone finds them offensive would probably make you lose more customers, as people come to the library for a wide variety of materials. I'm going to be honest here, most people like to read, and the library is a vital resource for them. I know I sometimes read to study, and if they got rid of the books that I read to study, how would I be able to complete my work? Even teachers go to the library to study or to get books for their classes, or maybe to get books for their grandkids or their own kids, showing its importance to the community. Parents do the same thing, relying on the library for educational and entertainment resources for their families. People don't understand that music helps everybody at some point in time, providing comfort and focus. I know people who listen to music to help them concentrate on different things like homework, regular work, or even when they are feeling stressed out. There are a lot of different ways that music helps a lot of people, and it has been a positive force for many. If people decided to feel offensive over stuff like that, then something is wrong with them because after all these years there have been no major complaints about the music selection. Honestly, I have never gotten movies or magazines from the library before, but I know many who do. People do it for their kids or grandkids, and I don't really see the big deal, as it provides affordable family entertainment. It's not like they are watching anything bad; they mostly have kid-friendly movies, not inappropriate ones. Why would people want to take little things like that away from little kids, who are just trying to enjoy a story? In a way, that makes me mad because I like little kids, and they don't hurt anybody by watching a harmless cartoon or reading a colorful magazine.

Did you know that libraries contain books, movies, music, magazines, and many other resources? Yes! They have it all, creating a wonderful hub of information and entertainment for the community. If you ever need something for research or a project, you can just go there and you will likely find what you are looking for. But if there is something on the shelf that you do not personally like, the simple solution is to just keep going and choose something else. I do not think that the books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive by some individuals. I think that if it is something that offends you, then you should just keep walking and select a different item that better suits your tastes. That 'something' that might offend you could be incredibly helpful or enjoyable to others, as we all have different perspectives and needs. So, now you know if you ever see something that you don't like in the library, the best approach is to just walk away and let others make their own choices. It could be helpful to you in the future and is certainly helpful to others in the present. If things that offend you are removed, how would the next person learn about different viewpoints or find the information they need? They won't, and that would be a great loss for the community. Don't only think about yourself in this situation; think about others and the greater good of shared knowledge and access.

I don't believe that we should censor or take away anything off of our library shelves that seems either offensive or inappropriate for viewers, as this restricts access to important knowledge. However, I wouldn't recommend it for the kids who are not ready for that sort of material until they are at an age where they are mature enough for that sort of viewing, and that is a decision for their parents to make. The reason why I say this is because I believe and know that people sooner or later are going to see, hear, and go through that sort of viewing and/or experience sometime in their lives; it has happened to many people and it will continue to happen to everyone. The events that happen to many people are awful but yet are true, and the difficult topics that go around in the world should be known to other people and understood. People need to know how to deal with a situation or at least know what to do; we should know how to act when certain events occur. For example, if a certain person of a race is minding his own business and passes a group of race oppressors and they begin offending him by words, then he shouldn't worry unduly. Because if a person is only going to constantly use words, then you should know that he or she is just a weak person trying to get on your nerves and likely won't do any physical harm to you. There are many harsh realities that people don't like and try their best to hide from others, but that would only make the situation worse for everybody. Keeping people in the dark would leave them clueless if they got exposed to what some people attend to hide; we shouldn't hide the truth from others and keep them from knowing what has happened or what is going on. I believe that nothing should be held back for the people who are ready to see or know what is going on in the world, no matter how cruel or painful the subject matter is. They should know what it is and how to take care of themselves when they experience it at first hand, as knowledge is the best preparation for life's challenges.

Censoring our history and ideas is a dangerous path. We all know that language is the foundation of human legacy, allowing us to pass knowledge from one generation to the next. Language is spoken to mean anything the speaker is trying to communicate, and written words capture those thoughts forever. To take books from the shelves is to steal the words from the mouths of many great speakers and thinkers who came before us. We have the obligation to keep the stories and history that we have created alive for future generations. If something is forgotten, it is as if nothing ever happened, and if nothing happened, it will likely reoccur—whether the event was good or bad. To hide away words from our children is wrong and ultimately futile. If not by word of print, word of mouth will lead them to the same discoveries as they would have come to if reading it from a book, but perhaps in a less accurate form. But even more importantly, what good is hiding the truth? When many speak of tragic incidences, they speak, 'lest we forget.' If we should not forget, why should the youth not learn? There is nothing in print that cannot be conveyed in a different communication form, so censorship does not erase the idea. Our collective memory is written on the pages of literature, preserving our triumphs and failures. The books we read are the property of all humanity and should be read by all to educate us of our mistakes as well as our triumphs, helping us to grow. A commonly debated topic in the world of censorship is 'The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn.' This novel is a work that displays what life was truly like in one of America's most racially barbaric times, offering a valuable historical window. One might argue the fact that it uses an offensive 'n' word more than a few times, which is understandably jarring. To understand the novel, one might argue that Jim, the enslaved man who stood by Huck, was genuinely loved by Huck as a friend. A book in that time period displaying a friendship between a black and a white man is truly a ground breaking feat. The 'n' word was common place in that time period—a genuine friendship between a black man and a white man was not. Is it really important that a child knows of just another offensive word that they are bound to discover eventually anyway, or is it more important that they learn that color of skin does not change a person's worth? Do not take the opportunity for a child to learn what really matters away by focusing only on the offensive language. To take one book away is to take all of them away, setting a dangerous precedent. Censoring one piece of literature opens the doors of debate for every other piece ever created, leading down a slippery slope. The world has seen what can happen when things get censored on a massive scale. During various dictatorships, nearly everything from the internet, to books, to newspapers, to television programming, to movies, to music, to magazines were censored so only what the regime wanted got through. The people were brainwashed by this controlled information, and those who were not and rose up were often shot down. Do not let the world come to that again; we must learn from history. We are better than that and our literature shows our capacity for complex thought and empathy. In other words, to censor media and the literature that surrounds us, we deprive ourselves of education and freedoms that are critical to the well being of future generations. Do not hide the free speech of authors, do not hide our history from our children, do not let us make the same mistake that has been made before. Let us educate our children thoroughly for the future of humanity. Let our history not repeat its worst chapters. Let us innovate and create a new, better world based on knowledge. Let us allow our words to flow freely as they were meant to. Let us allow our legacy to live on, uncensored and complete.

The author Katherine Paterson said, 'All of us think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf that work I abhor then you also have exactly the same right and so does anyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' I do believe certain materials, such as music, books, and movies shouldn't be on a children's shelf to read, but rather on an adult shelf where access is more controlled. I believe every author has his or her right to express oneself and to be accepted for that. We all have our own beliefs and standards that we would like others to respect even if we don't agree on their beliefs. If every book that was found offensive was taken off a shelf we would soon have no books left. The reason for that is because everyone finds certain things offensive, and there is no universal standard for what is acceptable. Many children are interested in certain things and we can't hold them back from that unless it is inappropriate or goes against family morals or values such as religious beliefs. It would be a good thing to monitor what your children are reading, watching and listening to, guiding them towards age-appropriate content. On the other hand, adult shelves will have many different things that would be offensive to many different people, unlike children's books which are generally curated. Writing is a way to show a person's expressions and what they stand for although it may not be pleasing to me or any other person. But what if we write a book and somebody does not like it then we wouldn't like it if they took it off the shelf. That would show disrespect to a person who has thought long and hard on their work. Learn to stand proud on what you believe. Learn also to respect others as well and to let children be around safe family type of books, music and magazines, fostering an environment of both freedom and responsibility.

I am against censorship for good reasons. Everyone is for censorship, well I'm on a different perspective. If you are not old enough to get a movie or a book that's for a reason, as these ratings exist to protect the young. On another note if you are an adult then it shouldn't matter what you choose to consume. People should have their own choice in these matters. If they want to go out and get a rated R movie and watch it with their kids that's their own choice as parents. It's definitely not the person who makes the movie's choice to censor curse words and stuff out; the creator's vision should be respected. That's why they make edited CDs so people can buy them instead if they so desire. People have different beliefs, and it's whatever they believe in is how it should go for them. And if somebody else with different beliefs doesn't like that then I guess they need to write a paragraph like I'm doing now to express their own view. Also, people want everything censored out, but eventually there isn't going to be nothing left to read, watch, or listen to if we remove all offensive content. So all you people that want everything to be censored, I hope you're happy when the world has nothing to do because of your efforts to sanitize all creative expression.

Censorship for the future kids of America is a topic that requires careful thought. Personally I have read some disturbing books and also watched some grotesque and twisted, disturbing rated R movies. Not even talking about all the messed up music I've heard so far in my lifetime, which has shaped my views. What it comes down to is a lot of the music today is about sex, drugs, money, and violent crimes and gangs. The movies have a rating system which helps out for little kids by providing guidance. Books any one can get from a public library and some are about murder, rape, gang violence, and all the horrible reality of the devilish deeds in the world. I personally don't have a kid but if I had a kid and he read a book that was bad or heard a dirty song with some of those lyrics and if he watched a rated R movie I would wanna file a complaint because that's not how I want my kid growing up. With a twisted mind and a vocabulary of a little punk with curse words every ten seconds coming out his mouth is not the future I envision. Also I wouldn't want my kid kissing his mom with that kind of stuff coming out his mouth; it's about respect and upbringing. But the library association needs to keep all that stuff away from kids until they're old enough to go get it on their own, like they need to be seventeen to go see a rated R movie. That is how it should have always been, with clear boundaries to protect the young while allowing adult access.

I feel that materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should not be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive. Some people like offensive things that they have in the library; it caters to their interests. Some people would sometimes want to know about certain things that is offensive, seeking understanding or perspective. Most materials could be offensive to a lot of different people for various reasons. Different individuals have different things that are offensive to them personally. What might be offensive to you is probably not offensive to me, and that is the core of the issue. People that don't like offensive things just shouldn't check it out, and people that like offensive things just could check it out; the choice should be theirs. I feel that they just shouldn't be removed just because some people don't like offensive things; they just shouldn't check it out themselves. You just can't remove things that are offensive just because some individuals don't like offensive things. Everyone does have their own right but some people like offended things, and their rights matter too. I read a book that was offensive to me, but it told me how to react to the situation and how to overcome my situation, providing valuable insight. So some things may offend you, but some things you just have to read about it more because some things tell you how to overcome that situation or it will tell you what to do about the situation you had been offended by. That's why I feel that you shouldn't remove offensive books, as they can offer unexpected lessons and growth.

Moving Forward The Difficult Things In Life! When you enter a library or a book store of course you will find things that you like and dislike; that is the nature of a diverse collection. Your opinion may not be the same as someone else's, and that is perfectly acceptable. Sometime you can feel a little bit uncomfortable with the situation and the way things are going when confronted with challenging material. People have different looks about different things in this way of life. You are going to come across good things, bad things, happy things, sad things, things you agree about, and things you disagree about; such is the spectrum of human experience. I believe that books, music, movies, magazines, or anything else should not be removed if they are found offensive to anybody. The reason I state that is because if any of those items offended one person they might not be offensive to another, highlighting the subjectivity of offense. Different people have different interests in many different subjects and genres. So therefore it should not be any reason that the materials should be removed from the shelves, especially if they are not hurting anything or anyone physically. Speaking from personal experience there were many times I felt offended about certain topics. I feel that abortions can come off a bit harmful to a life that has not been born yet, which is a deeply personal belief. Killing a child that has not experienced the things you have is not right from my perspective. But some sometime the way I can feel can be a lot different to other people, and I acknowledge that. So who am I to tell another person what they can and can not do? That comes with voicing your own opinion while respecting the rights of others. You can not change the way another person is thinking or feeling, as thoughts and emotions are personal. If you find a book or anything like that hard to deal with it is crazy to demand its removal for everyone. Think about the difficult situation that you might come across and can be offensive to you; others may find value in it. It will be a lot of times you will disagree or have an opinion but can not change or do anything about it, and that is part of living in a pluralistic society. Things will be much easier and less difficult if we sometimes deal with the difficult things in life with understanding and tolerance, rather than through removal and censorship.

No, they should not have the CDs, books, and other materials removed from the store shelves; they should leave them on the shelves, I think. They should only remove the genuinely outdated media, such as old video games, and perhaps obsolete reference books and music formats that are no longer in use. Every other type of current and relevant material should remain available for the public to access and choose from, ensuring the collection meets the diverse needs and interests of the entire community. It is important to maintain a wide selection for everyone.

In many public libraries across the nation, a numerous amount of books, magazines, movies, and music aren't provided because they are found offensive. I do not believe this should happen because everybody is unique and may find different types of work offensive. Who is it that chooses these items to be taken out of libraries and why should they be the only ones to say what goes and what stays? Everybody is different in their own way and everyone has their own interests and opinions. Some people are athletic, gothic, preppy, and nerdy. The library is open to anybody that wishes to enter. What happens if the people that choose what content is provided in the library don't like scary books, so they take all of the scary books out? What if there is a person that only reads scary books? What then will they have to read? I bet if that person had the ability to choose what stays and what goes in the library, they would only have horror in the library. I do not believe that anybody should have the right to censor what content is provided in public libraries. Everyone has their own opinion and interests so they should have everything open in libraries. There is a reason that public libraries are called public. That means that it is open to anyone and everyone. There should be all kinds of different genres to read and all sorts of movies to choose from. Just because one person doesn't like a certain kind of genre, or doesn't find it appropriate for a certain viewing audience, does not mean that they can take it out of a public library. That would be why there is such thing as sections in libraries. If you don't find a certain type of book appropriate, place it in the 'Adult Fiction' section of your library. For example, Stephen King, he is a very popular author to many different viewing audiences. His ideas are very different than most. He writes horror but displays gore and a lot of sexual content in his writing. It is his own writing style. If the people that choose what is in the libraries don't find that appropriate or if they find it offensive, they should put it in the 'Adult Fiction' sections or even the 'Horror' section. It should be up to the childrens' parents what their kid is reading; not the library itself. I do not believe that anyone should choose what is and isn't provided in libraries. Everybody is unique, different and have their own opinions on different things and ideas. If you remove a specific type of book, movie, magazine or music from a library, and it's the only kind a certain person reads, what then will they have to read? What if somebody took out the kind that only you like to read? What then will you do? If everybody had the choice and right to do this, I don't think that anything will be left in libraries. All genres of everything should be available to the public. If you don't find a book appropriate, place it in the Adult Fiction section of your library to still have it open to anybody. That would just be a big warning to anybody who decides to pick it up and read it. You need to think of everybody, not just yourself.

Should books, magazines, etc., really be censored, taken off a shelf in a library, just because you might find them offensive? Some of you who are reading this would say yes, but why? What would be the reason behind it? So to answer the first question I asked, my answer would have to be no, because a library is a public place for all ages, and each area is labeled or should be labeled with the genre of book, magazine, etc., that it is. I myself read almost just about everything I can get my hands on, and for some people it's the same way. Yes, I understand that if it is offensive to you that you probably would feel they should censor it, but what about those that it isn't offensive to? What would you say to them? How would you explain why it was offensive? Most of all, how would you react if they held it against you? If it was because of one person or a small group of people that one of my favorite books or series was censored, in all honesty I would be pretty ticked. Books are for everyone to read; they shouldn't not be able to read the books they love because they have been taken off the shelf. I think that if a person really doesn't like the book and finds it offensive, they should then just ignore it and move on to find another book; they shouldn't have looked at it in the first place. Books will be offensive to someone somehow; usually a book is written to target a certain group of people. For instance, what if someone found the romance novels a lot of people love, offensive? What if that was all the person read? Well, the people who only read romance novels wouldn't have a book to read because someone had them censored and taken off the shelves. Books have been written to help teach, to get away from the real world, to create a place to go for a person with an imagination, to give someone hope, mystery, and excitement. Books aren't something that should be taken off a library shelf; they are a bit of something for someone who just loves to read. Some materials in libraries contain information that is offensive towards others, causing genuine hurt and discomfort. But should they be removed if they are found offensive? Some people believe that they should be removed depending on how bad the offense is and the potential harm it causes. But materials should be removed if it is a sexual, racist, or life threatening offense, as these categories represent significant harm.  Some material may have offensive comments that is sexual in nature, which can be deeply unsettling. If its an offense that is sensored and the author or artist of the material went too far, then that could be a good reason for the material to be removed from public access. It can make the person feel emotions that bring them down, causing distress and anxiety. It may also make the person feel violated and offended, impacting their sense of safety and well-being.  There can be material that has racist comments, which perpetuate harmful stereotypes and divisions. Racism is one of the biggest conflicts in the world today, leading to discrimination and injustice. It is something that starts fights and arguements, disrupting community harmony. It also causes individuals to feel bad about themselves, damaging their self-esteem and sense of belonging. Racism can cause people to feel very hurt also, leaving deep emotional scars. So if there is too much racism in a material, then that should be removed to protect individuals from such harm.  There are some material that might have offense that seems life threatening, creating a sense of imminent danger. Say that it is a book about the whole nation and the author slips in something that could seem like the nation would be in danger, someone might feel offended and want that material removed for public safety. Material with too much threat in it can make one feel like their life is in danger or like something bad is going to happen, fostering a climate of fear. They would feel a life threatening offense and want it to be removed from the shelves to restore a sense of security.  So should offensive materials be removed from the shelves? Yes they should, when they cross certain boundaries. If they were to be found sexually, life threatening offense or had racist comments, they should be removed so individuals won't feel these offenses are life threatening, hurtful, or cause negative emotions that undermine their right to a safe and respectful environment.

Taking 'offensive' books from the shelves of libraries is like taking away the right of speech, which is a cornerstone of our society. There is not a point to it, as it undermines the very principles of intellectual freedom. People in this country have the right of speech, a fundamental liberty. Along with that comes the right to have your voice be heard, to share your perspective with the world. An author's opinions may be offensive to some but does that mean he or she should not have a voice? Writers get their ideas from somewhere and society plays a huge role in what ideas these authors conjer up, taking these books away will not change the way people think and feel, and most importantly citizens of the United States have the right to make their own choices; that being if you don't like a book don't check it out.  Writers might state things that to some degree could offend one in a million people, as it is impossible to please everyone. Others see it as freedom of speech and writing, a necessary part of a vibrant culture. An author who writes a story that involves sex is not trying to extend their writing and thoughts to second graders, but is often writing for a mature audience. But if a person has a problem with the way the author sees the world walking out their front door will show that same thing, as literature reflects reality. Some books may be fictional but that does not mean they don't get ideas from somewhere else. Society plays a big part in the ideas and thoughts of most writers, influencing their narratives. So when they write a book that has 'inappropriate' actions in it they got it from the way people truly are in the world, holding a mirror to society.  Banning a book from the library that has a sex scene or provacitive language does not --by any means-- make the world stop having sex and saying curse words; it merely ignores these realities. Kids are learning this through hearing their parents swear or their peers in class talking about sex, from various sources around them. Reading a book about it will not change the fact that they are still learning about it in many other ways, through television, music, and the internet. If the books that swear were no longer on library shelves society still will not change, as the behaviors exist independently. There is no perfect society, and pretending otherwise is naive.  Setting a book on a shelf with offensive language does not cause harm to anyone, as no one is forced to read it. If an idividual doesn't like the way an author expresses themselves through their writing that person should not check that author's books out from the library, exercising personal choice. No single person is forced to read a book they are offended by; they can simply select another. Getting rid of a book because of an unhappy parent does nothing but waste paper and intelligence, depriving others of potential value. The library is not liable for the feelings of the readers, as it is a repository of diverse ideas. If the reader does not like the book they are able to close it, a simple and effective solution. No one has glued their fingers to it, forcing them to continue.  Many people in today's world would agree that banning books from our public libraries will not have as much of an effect as some would like it to, as ideas cannot be so easily contained. Banning books is an unknowledgeable thing to do to keep your kids from learning bad things, as it avoids addressing the root issues. Society shows that the writers are getting their ideas from somewhere, taking these books away will not take away the way people think and behave, and if some one does not like a book they should not read it, allowing others the freedom to decide for themselves.

One could understand why some would wish to censor libraries and remove all rude, unwanted, or offensive forms of media from thier shelves, seeking to protect vulnerable minds. However, one must take into account that, as Katherine Paterson said, if one person has 'the right to remove that [a] book from the shelf...then you have exactly the same right and so does everyone else,' leading to a chaotic removal of all content.  With that thought in mind, do we honestly think that censorship of libraries is a smart idea? If everyone was able to pick and choose which books to be taken off the shelf or which music to ban, then we would have nothing left, an empty repository. You simply cannot please everyone, as tastes and sensitivities vary widely. Are there benefits? Of course there are benefits, such as shielding children from mature themes. One certainly wouldn't want one's child exposed to certain material at a young age. But one must not censor libraries for the whole community! If one wishes, as a responsible parent, that their child keep away from a particular book or movie, they should take that matter into their own hands and not condemn the book off the shelf, thereby respecting the rights of others.  By condemning the book, one condemns the author and their creative expression. As an American, one has the freedom of speech, and this applies to media as well, protecting diverse viewpoints. The author has the right to author a book that some may view as offensive, and no one has the right to remove his or her right from the standing, as this is a protected liberty.  Paper burns at 451 degrees Fahrenheit. In the classic novel by Ray Bradbury, Fahrenheit 451, the protagonist struggles through life in a world antagonized by the banning and burning of books. The story takes place in the future, however, it contains an interesting undertone that hints at the possiblity that this 'future' may be nearer than first imagined, serving as a cautionary tale. To be blunt, the protagonist's life is horrible, he lives in a world that bans books, yet he is quite the bibliophile, creating a deep internal conflict. He is employed as a fireman, not to clear fires, but to create them, a twisted duty. Bradbury's firemen are responsible for the delicate task of book burning, which is a rather frequent occurance, symbolizing the destruction of knowledge. However, with the main character's love for literature, how can he burn books? This is his central dilemma.  Throughout the novel, the character tries to come to terms with himself and attempts to put an end to the madness, only to be forced out of civilized society, becoming an outlaw. The book is freightening, but an amazing read: it emphasizes the dire reality of censorship and its consequences. It's everywhere, a pervasive force in his world.  Now, one certainly doesn't need to worry about Bradbury's futuristic hell, coming to life any time soon, but the symbolism remains powerful. But one should know the dangers of censorship and how it can escalate. No one person has the right to remove a book from the shelves that they feel is offensive, let alone ban it entirely, as this sets a dangerous precedent. The banning of books, is a banning of freedom itself. Freedom of speech, freedom of ideas, freedom of thought are all compromised. Another disutopian world that comes to mind is the world of George Orwell's 1984. Though, granted, our society is certainly not headed for that any time soon, if ever: it is still a valid point about the slope of suppression. Once some freedoms are removed, others will follow, eroding liberties gradually.  Libraries should remain entirely intact, forever, as bastions of knowledge and free inquiry. Every person, every man, woman and child should have ample access to knowlede, which is essential for an informed citizenry. Whether this knowledge be gained through books, magazines, movies or music, it needs to be readily avaliable in its diverse forms. Instead of banning certain media, one should label said media with a warning, providing guidance without removal. Parents should have enough sense to pay attention and thus, the problem is solved without imposing on others, fostering responsible consumption.  Censorship is wrong, censorship is unnessesary, and there are a plethora of alternative means for protection against pottentially 'offensive' media that do not involve removal. Thus, the case can rest with the knowledge that all forms of media need to availiable, no matter what the content, to preserve the fundamental principles of a free and open society.

The common phrase 'knowledge is power' accurately paints the situation at hand. Through censorship in libraries, which are meant to allow free access to all media-related materials, we take away the opportunity for people to empower themselves through knowledge. The reasons for not censoring media in libraries are numerous and include, but are not limited to, unconstitutionality of censorship, the lack of proper definition for 'offensive', and the contradiction censorship poses to the core of what a library is. The first, and most blatant, reason for not allowing the censorship of materials in libraries is the unconstitutionality of the matter. Freedom of speech and freedom of press are both protected by the constitution upon which our country was founded. Censorship of said materials will effectively undermine both of these rights. Authors, illustrators, journalists and the slew of other individuals who compose the materials available in libraries are exercising their right to free speech through their works. They are constitutionally protected in the things they say. Notice that citizens have a right to free speech and not a right to free speech so long as no one is offended. The freedom of press is the means by which they share their ideas and concepts with the world. They are utilizing their free speech by means of press. Censoring library materials would be limiting the means by which artists can share their ideas with citizens of the nation. This would be a clear failure to uphold the rights of the citizens. For this reason, we cannot censor libraries. The constitutional concept of equality of man plays into the situation as well. There is no adequate legal definition of 'offend'. People could be offended by something as serious as a personal attack on their beliefs and personal entity or something as light as a personal distaste for certain mindsets and ideas. So, because all men are equal, we would have to respect the 'offense' taken by all people and to all degrees. This leaves every single work of art, whether it be a book, movie, magazine or any other form provided by libraries, open to the fickle definition of offensive and vulnerable to the personal feelings of every individual. If said offense taken by individuals to works is able to mark a work as 'offensive' and thus make it open to removal from libraries, we are effectively allowing citizens to undermine the rights of other citizens. This is something that cannot be allowed in our libraries. The final core issue is the essence of censorship versus the essence of a library. Censorship is meant to create a politically correct and non-offensive environment through the limitation of exposure to materials. Libraries, however, are meant to allow public access to works that stretch and challenge knowledge, beliefs, notions and all ideas held by people through the works of others. Censorship cannot be implemented without a clash with the essence of a library's purpose. If censorship were to be enacted, a library could not provide new information if someone else did not like what was being taught. A library could not provide works that challenge and stretch individual beliefs if someone was offended by the means by which the stretching occurred. Pre-conceived notions could not be defeated with the presence of factual knowledge if someone did not like the truth. In all of these ways, and many more, a library's core ideals and purpose could not be upheld with the induction of a system of censorship. All in all, we can see that censorship could only hope to destroy the system libraries abide by. The constitutional rights of citizens would be infringed upon, the fickle nature of humans and the lack of definition for 'offensive' would allow people to undermine the rights of others, and the essence of what a library really is would be ravaged. We cannot, as a society with rights, employ a system of censorship.

Going to the library is one of the best ways to explore new things and gain knowledge. Some items are not appropriate for everyone though. Certain books, movies, magazines, and music should not be accessed by everyone due to their mature content. Having an adult only section would be a practical way to solve this problem effectively. Removing certain materials from the library entirely would not be in the public's good interest. Any popular material should be available at the library for those who wish to access it. Many best selling books would be wrong for children to read, but they would be perfectly fine for adults. That doesn't mean these books need to be taken out of the library completely. Children should be restricted from viewing the explicit materials though. Having a designated section in the library from which only adults can rent the items would remove this problem. People under eighteen should also be restrained from looking through these materials to ensure their appropriateness. Having a children's section in the library would also keep them away from adult materials and provide a safe space for younger readers. The library needs to make itself user friendly for all age groups. People who frequent the library often pick up a book, not knowing what it holds inside. When inappropriate material is inside, a child might innocently read into or see something they are not supposed to encounter. Parents should not have to worry about their kids seeing inappropriate pictures or text during a visit. They should feel safe letting their children look through all the books in the children's area. Library workers should also make sure the adult materials stay in the hands of adults by monitoring the sections. Allowing children and their parents to feel safe and welcome is an important part of the library's mission. Taking adult materials out of the library is not a good idea as it would lower its popularity and utility. Everyone has different interests, and they want to research them at the library freely. The safety of children is also important and must be considered. Making sure children cannot reach these materials is a primary concern for the institution. Having separate adult and children sections could solve this problem neatly. Not allowing anyone under eighteen to check out explicit materials would also help maintain a safe environment. Keeping the library full of information but still safe for children is the ideal situation that we should all strive to achieve.

If I was an administrator in a school, I would look at what is the meaning behind the book and what it is trying to express to the reader. For example, if a book is offensive to someone, for instance a book written by a hate group leader, this piece shouldn't be allowed on the shelf. But if it is a book about the Civil War and the South's view on slavery, this would be ok for educational purposes. Because the hate group book is more about spreading hate than anything else, it is for instance promoting discrimination and that isn't right. But the book on the Civil War and the South's view on slavery is a part of our history; it shows different ways of thinking of the time that we don't really know if they were right or wrong, it is just what they believed historically. So my point I am trying to express in this piece is that you shouldn't hate a book because maybe the language in it or the events in it may not be what you agree with, but you should judge the book because of the message that it is trying to express. Hopefully you will agree with me in this perspective. But if a book talks about certain things it should be banned, such as hate against other races, or it talks negatively about someone's religion, as these promote real harm. I have expressed my opinion on this matter; I hope you agree with me and can maybe convince the school that they need to take a second look at what kind of books we keep on our shelves and what kind of books we take off our shelves, ensuring our decisions are guided by the content's overall message and educational value rather than isolated elements.

I am not in agreement because young children should not be exposed to certain offensive books. It is better to have a system where access is managed, such as placing certain books in a restricted section for older patrons, rather than eliminating them entirely. This approach protects young children while still preserving the full range of literature for the community. Ultimately, censorship is not the solution, as it hinders intellectual freedom and the ability to learn from a wide array of perspectives, which is a fundamental value of any library.

On the other hand, public libraries are under state and city law, and they should not be able to show adult things to children. For example, in many libraries around the U.S., there are all books called manga or anime books; a lot of them show partial nudity and other graphic things not suitable for younger children but are only rated 13+. Do your rights end where mine begin? In such a diverse society, clashing opinions are unavoidable. Does that mean another human's rights should be abused because we don't agree with their practices, beliefs, or lifestyle? Everyone in this world is entitled to their own opinion. What is wrong to some people might be right to others. For example, one family might view their children using curse words as offensive while another might see no problem with it. Diversity in beliefs does not mean that it is acceptable to censor society from cursing, religion, or violence discussed in published works. These concepts exist in the world and censoring them will not make them disappear. It is understood that there is both bad and good in the world, and pulling materials from the shelves of libraries will not change that reality. Censoring books, magazines, music, and other media is denying someone the ability to see ideas from all points of view. Whether or not you prevent a young child from seeing all perspectives does not mean the bad and good do not exist. The saying 'one year older, one year wiser' can refer to the acknowledgement of different ideas and opinions. As a child grows, he will learn more about the materials that were once censored from him. In some cases, such as in the classroom, your rights do end where mine begin, but when it comes to learning about the beauty of diversity, everyone is able to choose what they pick from the shelf. The definition of 'offensive material' is simply a matter of opinion, not an objective truth that justifies widespread censorship.

Now, do I think that the books should be not given to students who are very young of age? Yes, due to the fact that some books are a little above others' age of reading and comprehension. Sometimes you might have kids who are interested in what others don't read. Books such as those about gang violence and drug abuse are some of those books in categories of which some can't read. I think that in this case kids under a certain age shouldn't read these books because of some of the content that is involved in it. Kids find these books, movies, and magazines interesting because many things that happen in the world today happen inside those books. I'm not saying that it's a good thing, but I'm saying that the things they read and see in those books and movies are things that some of us have seen in everyday life. When I was younger, I went to a library in my hometown, and whenever a kid would choose a book that wasn't for him or her they would always say 'you need your parents permission to check this book or magazine etc. out'. Once I actually noticed and got the point of why they would do this I thought that it was a good idea. I figure that all libraries should be like this considering that kids shouldn't read books that aren't for them. This is also a good way to get kids from reading things that are not age appropriate to finding something that is suitable for their level. So the main answer to this suggestion is, no, I don't think that these materials should be moved from shelves out of libraries. Why? Because once they are gone then some kids might not even attend the library anymore because of the books that they find interesting are gone. So my suggestion is to not move them and let them stay on shelves just as any other book would, maintaining access while encouraging parental guidance.

Do you believe that certain books, movies, or magazines should be taken off the shelf in a library due to censorship? There are many times when you hear a parent tell their child not to look at that magazine because they don't want them to see the vulgar things on the inside. I've heard parents tell their children not to ever watch that movie because it'll show things that they don't need to be seeing. Almost every day we're put in situations like these, not knowing whether we should pick up the magazine or just leave it on the shelf. In my opinion, I believe that libraries should remove anything vulgar from the shelves. Kids are encouraged to go to the library as much as possible, but not if there is vulgar things on the shelves. Kids are told many times a week by their parents, teachers, and other adults to go the library. They can work on their homework, read a book, or do some studying for school. When they get distracted from finding the book they want with a book that has vulgar things in it, they're going to be curious. The main reason I disagree with having vulgar things on the shelves is because of young children. The last thing they need to be looking at is something that isn't appropriate for their age. It's hard for a child to turn down a movie or magazine they've never seen or looked at before. In most libraries the adult section is seperated from the childrens section. This doesn't mean that a child can't over hear something that the adults are listening to or watching. The childrens section is made for fairytale stories and kid movies, but when the adult section has things going on over there that aren't the most appropriate then kids can over hear. If children and adults are going to be in the same library then I think they should make it completely impossible for children to veer over there and see what's new on that side of the library, perhaps by installing a physical barrier or a monitored checkpoint. Another reason I think libraries should censor themselves more is because of teenages in the community. After school hours, a lot of teenagers in our community enjoy going to the library. If this is such a good environment for teenagers to be then why are they able to download bad music off of the internet? Some teenagers listen to bad music with cursing, vulgar language, and much more. Libraries should make it impossible for teenagers to do this. If they want to download bad music then they need to do it somewhere else where youngers can't get ahold of any of it. My last argument for this is a heads up for the parents. Parents should check out what stuff their kids are looking at when they go to the library. You might not think your child would look at something with vulgar things, but sometimes, they're curious. All children are and it's human nature to be curious. I, myself, would go with my child a few times just to see what's in the library and tell them not to take things off the shelves that look bad. Some libraries can't completely fix everything. They can't take every bad or vulgar thing off of the shelves. In the quote it says, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf.', I can think of books and magazines that I would never want any child to look at, especially at a young age. Libraries need to be more interested in taking vulgar things off the shelves so that younger children cannot get ahold of them. It's one thing for a child to see a book or magazine that isn't necessarily appropriate, but in a library it's a completely different story and the responsibility ultimately falls on the institution to protect its youngest visitors.

Billions of books float from shelf to shelf each day: fictional and nonfictional, horror and comedy. Writers reside in every part of the world composing works from complex life experiences to simple dreams. Being an author, who has the right to freedom of speech, story plots become to have endless combinations. Every reader seeks out a different style. Libraries contain books that tower to the ceilings, any kind, every kind. Books are divided into their individual sections according to truth, kind and cover, each category holding about four options. The necessity for censorship should never be an option. Writers compose for all sorts of people. For some to say what's 'right' or 'wrong' is not a legitamate reason for a piece of work to be removed from a shelf. If, perhaps, more books had ratings such as movies do, an adult only cubicle could be created instead of allowing young people to have access to such vulgarity. Taking away the enjoyment for some readers, however, is unethical and limits the diversity of available thought. Whether pertaining to books, music, magazines, etc., censorship is unnecessary. Those who compose the entertainment should not have to worry about the content of their expression and/or interpretation. If the worry is concerning youth, parental guidance should be in affect. Resulting in cancellation can affect those who relate to the source so it's important to consider all options. To each, its own, and the freedom to choose what to read should remain with the individual and their family.

Censorship, or the ability to control what is seen or heard, is a term that is taken very differently from one person to the next. Music, if it is found offensive or inappropriate, can be consored or even banned from listening. Some magazines that are found at grocery stores, libraries, and sometimes even airports, have opaque covers on the front to visually censor the front page of the magazine. Movies are given ratings based on their level of explicit material, and when shown on basic cable, they sometimes can have either silenced words, or more appropriate words brought in to fit the dialougue in the movie. Books, although very rarely, have been banned from libraries and censored from the entire world. Some books have been previously censored, but became uncensored and brought back to libraries. In my opinion, censorship should not be based on a single person's view of the material, but rather on the viewpoint of the public. Growing up, my parents would watch carefully about what shows I watched, what music I listened to, or the types of magazines that i looked at. When I was growing up, I loved to watch professional wrestling. I loved to watch big scary guys as tall as seven feet hitting each other with steel chairs, crashing each other into tables, or throwing each other off of twenty-foot steel cages. My brother and I used to have a favorite wrestler that we would for every week, The Undertaker could freighten any other wrestler who stood in his way. My brother and I loved to watch The Undertaker compete every week for a chance at a world chamionship belt. As time passed, professional wrestling began to welcome in beautiful women into their business. These women would come out onto the ring with tight, shiny, lingerie on as they became eye-candy for the men who watched professional wrestling. One day, I'm watching two girls fighting in a match when my mom walks in. She takes one look at the half-naked girls fighting each other and turns off the television and declares that professional wrestling is too adult for me. Even though I was twelve at the time, I didn't want to get in an argument with my mom about how much I should be allowed to see. Censorship can be based on the ideas and viewpoints of the parents and guardians. I was in grade school when I fell in love with the show, 'South Park'. South Park is a show about four boys who go on unintentional adventures to save their friends. These four boys, who are all around eleven years old, use curse words that some adults would be afraid to use in every day life. Their behavior is very controversial and the show itself has been forced to ban a few of their episodes for safety reasons. One problem with South Park show was that my dad loved South Park show as well, and tried to get my mom to like the show. When my mom saw the show, she immediately banned me from watching it because of its explicit content. Now that I am older, I am able to make my own decisions about what I watch, but as a kid, my parents decided what was appropriate for me. I grew up listening to several different types of music. My brother listened to rap, alternative, and even songs that were in musicals because he was in show choir. My dad introduced me to classic rock, and my mom loved soft rock. Although I didn't necessarily like the music that my mom liked, I learned to love my dad's music and my brother's music. I loved to listen to music from artists like The Beatles, Led Zeppelin, Aerosmith, The Rolling Stones, Metallica, and so on. My musical tastes branched out into a variety of different genres. One day, I'm walking in the hallway when I hear some music coming from the living room. I go to see what is playing because it sounds unfamiliar. My dad and my brother told me to go into another room and not listen to the music. The song was by a band named Guns N' Roses. Even though it might seem unfair, censorship, given by the parents and guardians, is very necessary for a child's development. Although some people might find a certain piece of material offensive, it doesn't mean that the entire world should be banned from the material itself. If that person wants to keep away from the material and keep their kids from seeing or listening to that material, they are able to do that. Censorship, given by the parents or guardians, is the best way to view censorship. Nothing should be banned from a library, music store, or any other place that sells these materials. Censorship is important, but the entire banning of a certain piece of material is unjust and limits intellectual freedom.

What would you do if a woman walked into a library and started throwing a tantrum about how inappropriate a book was, and she wanted it removed from the shelves? Would you just stare and wonder if she was crazy? Would you think that this is a public place, and everyone has their own opinions? I believe that even if someone thinks a material in a library is inappropriate, the material should not be taken off shelves. Many people actually believe materials in a library are too offensive or inappropriate. Unsurprisingly, libraries can't exactly do much about that except remove them from the shelves if absolutely necessary. However, when you think about it, if everyone complained about a certain book being offensive, there would eventually be no more books left! For example, I would not want my little brother reading certain books because some chapters contain a sex scene. However, my brother will eventually be older, and he'll be able to understand such mature content. If I would have gotten rid of that book, I wouldn't be letting other people enjoy it or learn from its story.  If you were to get books removed that were about science because you were religious, many students wouldn't be happy to say the least. This could be about any subject matter, however. The more books that are removed from the library, the less people will know about the subject. Eventually, as I've said before, there will be no more books left! Everyone has their own opinion of what is appropriate or not, and everyone's views are different. The solution to this problem is simply to not remove the books. Sure, you might get complaints. But odds are, more people are unoffended rather than offended. Americans do have the right to fight for this, but with the majority being unoffended, it's a tough case to win in a public forum.  I believe all books would be fine left on shelves. If you take off one book, you might as well take off the rest, starting a dangerous precedent. Next time you are picking out a book, and you find it offensive, think about how other people might want to read it. They might even need the information for a paper they're writing for a class. You never know who might need the information contained within its pages. Don't be selfish; keep the books on the library shelf for the benefit of the entire community.

Certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive. The material should be removed if they offend one's gender. Also, the material should be removed if it offends one's religion. Finally, it should be removed if it offends one's race. The material should be removed if it is offensive to anyone's gender. First, the material can make a person feel unworthy and demeaned. Second, the material can cause a large altercation between the author and the person who is being offended and maybe others who join the dispute. Third, the material can also harm someone by them picking up the book and reading the text, which could be psychologically damaging.  Also, the material should be removed if it is offensive to anyone's religion. This can cause someone to hate every other person with the same religion as the writer, song writer, actor, and/or director, fostering unnecessary division. Second, the library should be about education, fun, and interesting contents not about offending someone's religion or their deeply held beliefs. Finally, this can cause a person or people to act as terrorists from this offensive content, which is a severe but possible consequence.  The material also should be removed if it is offending someone's race. First, the material might call the race of the person that is reading, listening or watching a name that's a very offensive name, even if not directly but in general. Second the material can speak of the race as if it was bad or inferior in some way. Last, the material can influence other kids to disrespect that race and not like people of that race, perpetuating harmful stereotypes from a young age. The material that is offensive to anyone's gender, religion, and/or race should be removed from the shelves of a library. The library is a place where everyone can read, listen, or watch about something that is interesting and not to offend other people in all ways, making it a safe space for all.

Often we go to the library searching for a good book or magazine to read without actually knowing what books are available. In order to find a book that interests you, you have to explore by picking up the book and looking at the cover and reading its background. Sometimes we come across a book or magazine that is inappropriate for children, and wonder why that book is still on the shelf for anyone to pick up. I believe materials that are offensive to some people should not be permitted in the public library. To begin, the books selected to advertise on the shelves of a library are not restricted for a certain age level. Libraries are broken up into different sections on where to find a genre, but a young child may not be aware of these distinctions. I believe there are certain materials found in a library that should not be put out for the public. Perhaps you have a five year old child pick up a book about sex and drugs, this could lead the child to learn things they shouldn't know until they are older and more mature.  To continue, offensive books should not be put into libraries because they give that library a bad reputation within the community. If someone were to come from out of town and the first thing they seen on the shelves of a library was a book with a naked body or drugs, they would immediately be taken back and form a negative opinion. Offensive types of books can include books you wouldn't want a first grader to see and also books about racial or religious topics. Certain people would take offense to a book that was against what they believed in, leading to potential conflict. This could result in a huge confrontation between library patrons and staff.  Lastly, offensive books can include books about someone's opinion on a certain topic, which can be inherently divisive. If someone against the writer's opinion started to read the book, they would automatically be offended by what the writer was saying, feeling attacked. There is never an agreement when two people have a different look on something, making such materials a source of constant friction. To conclude, although some books are offensive to some people and not to others, we have to be aware of what might cause problems to certain people in our community. I believe any book open about opinion, and books that would be considered 'x-rated' should not be kept in a public library where anyone can access them. We could easily solve this problem by making a separate place to hold these books so people will not take offense to it and the library can remain a welcoming environment for all.
