READ WITH CAUTION I do not believe that libraries carry the responsibility to censor reading materials. When a person enters a library, they immediately must infer that, because libraries are place in which knowledge is accumulated, that some of that information they find may not coincide with what they believe. If a person believes a book is offensive, they can just as easily put it down as they had picked it up. Obviously, however, there are certain exceptions. Childrens' sections, of course, should be limited to those intended for younger readers. Putting 'Fifty Shades of Grey' into a childrens' section hardly seems logical. just as much as putting 'The Very Hungry Caterpillar' into the adults section. In addition, author Judy Blume once stated that if she was able to ban a book from a library, the same right would have to be given to all other patrons as well. Thus leading to all the books in a library being unable to be read, the knowledge contained within them unknown. There are, as with any ordinance, exceptions. For example, if a library is intended solely for the use of younger audiences, censorship should hardly be considered a crime. The exclusion of inappropriate items, such as promiscuous reading material, keeps children from formulating ideas about concepts they may not be able to fully understand. With all these things considered, banning books from a library hardly seems to be the best course of action. A library should be a place of enlightenment. Opposing ideas should be presented. Leaving the readers to formulate their own decisions about what they believe. Because books are like atoms. When two opposing types collide, a burst of energy is released.

A library is a place for people of all ages to come and get a book, magazine, music, movies and much more. Libraries are a key essential to learning and helping those with reading skills. Studies show that reading will make you much smarter and able to understand and comprehend well. However, in my opinion, offensive reading, viewing or listening material does not belong in libraries, to some extent. As I stated earlier, libraries are a place of learning and for developing skills. Books that are for 'adults' can be found in adult type stores or even at a regular local book store. Parents bring their children to the library to support their reading ability and to advance it. They don't want to have to worry about making sure their kids are not looking at anything bad or inappropriate for their age. A few years back, I heard about a teenage boy that would go into the library about once a week to look for movies that his parents would not approve of. Later on that boy was caught and punished. If those kinds of movies were not there in the first place, his parents would not have had to worry about it. Almost everywhere you go and everything to see and hear has some type of wrong background to it. Parents should feel okay and worry-free when it comes to letting their kids do something as simple as going to the library. This problem can be easily fixed with removing that issue. I strongly believe that library material should be censored in the way that those who should not see it, can not see it. On the other hand, material such as religious or cultural learning items that people find offensive should not be taken off the shelves. Religious and cultural books, music, movies, and/or magazines are for those to learn. From what I have seen, someone might want, for example, a book about Christianity taken off the shelf because they are Jewish and might not support their religious ways. I find this wrong because it is a free country that includes freedom of religion and they can't be denied informing others about that religion. Libraries are a place to feel safe and relaxed. Everyone likes to sit in the library for hours and soak in a good novel. Material that is found offensive does not belong there, unless it is for real educational learning, and its presence undermines the library's role as a safe haven for learning and discovery.

The subject of censorship in libraries has been brought upon many times. Censorship is a rule prohibiting the view of a book, music, movies, magazines, etc. This censorship is because of it's rating or the content in it is inappropriate for some viewers/readers. Of course, many people have their own opinions about this censorship in libraries, as do I. I believe that censorship is a good idea in some cases. These cases being music, or movies. However, I don't believe censorship is a good idea in books. Children all over the world read books and as time goes on, our children are becoming more and more advanced and read on higher levels. This is where censorship comes into play. Libraries want to censor higher reading level books because these books include profanity, violence, sex, drugs, and any other aspect of adult themes. I disagree with the censorship of these books because this is basically telling our children that they can't challenge themselves or they can't learn about certain things because of their age. These books, in my opinion, can only help them. These books will help them learn about society, what's wrong and what's right, and will help them grow as they get older. The higher reading level books help them understand words better, and also help them learn about literature and past times. When I was in middle school, I was not an advanced reader by any means, but I did like to read occasionally. One day, I went to the library in search of a challenging book. The book I found was a book called 'The Book Thief' by Markus Zusak. This book was a fictional story taking place during the Second World War. As I put in my pin number to check out the book at the front desk, the librarian informed me that I couldn't check out the book because it was a young adult book, meaning 'too advanced' for me. She said I needed parent consent before I was able to check it out. That night, I asked my parents about it and asked if I could read it. They said yes, mostly because they were so thrilled that I even wanted to read a book so challenging. The next day I got a note from home informing the librarian that I could read the book. I was so thrilled when I was finally able to check out the book and read it. From my experience with the library censorship, I think that the best route to take is that if there is a parent/guardian who is over eighteen, and they approve of the checking out of the book/magazine or whatever it may be, then the child or student is allowed to check out said book/magazine etc. In conclusion, the censorship of books, magazines, etc. is an overall mediocre idea, with some exceptions. The rule of parent/guardian consent is the best route to take in my opinion. Of course, this subject will be argued for many years to come and many people will have their own opinions. Each side of the argument has valid points, but I think that it is imperative that we keep censorship out of books and keep our children learning and reading at their highest ability, no matter what the reading level is.

Should certain materials in libraries be removed from shelves if they are found offensive? I do not think books or any other materials should be taken off the shelves for some people. There are many reasons that the books should stay on the shelves. I am going to tell you all of the reasons I think the books should stay on the shelves. One reason I think the books should stay on the shelves is because some people might need the books for a school project. For example, a student could have a project over evolution. A book on evolution could offend many people. Just because it offends some people does not mean it should be taken off the shelf because other people might need that book. Someone might need a certain book for a project. If the one book they need is taken off a shelf because it offended someone they could fail a class. That is one reason I think the books should stay on the shelves. Another reason I think they should stay on the shelves is that it's their opinion if the book offends them. Just because they don't like the book and it offends them doesn't mean other people do not want to read it. Why would you take a book off of a shelf because it offends one or a couple people? There could be many more people who want to check out that book and read it for enjoyment or for their own educational purposes. If a book offends you just don't look at it. Why would you look at something that offends you? I don't understand why libraries would have to remove a book from the shelf just because it offends someone. Especially, when that person could just ignore the book and pay no attention to it. That is my last reason my opinion is what it is. So after reading this I hope you understand why my opinion is what it is. There is no point in taking books off the shelves. People need them for research and projects. It is someone's opinion if they do not like what the book is about and if it offends them. For example, if I didn't like something on a menu at a restaurant they are not going to take it off the menu for me. My last reason the books should stay on the shelves is the people can just ignore the books and not look at them; that would be easier than taking books off the shelves and restricting access for everyone else.

Is censorship right to have in libraries? This question could be answered in two very different opinions. Some people might want all censorship items out of public areas. On the other hand, there are people that might like to read this type of material. This is a very opinionated topic. In my opinion, libraries are places I go to find a book to read, research, listen to music, rent movies, or relax while looking at a magazine. Libraries are public areas and not everyone is going to agree. Everyone has their own favorite book or genre. I believe it is unjustified to take away censorship in libraries because this might be one's favorite genre. Why do libraries need to limit their choice while no one else does? For example, many parents would love if all clothes stores would ban holes in jeans because they are too revealing. The stores don't. They do not ban holes in jeans because many teenage girls like holes in their jeans. American Eagle is not going to ban capris just because I do not like them. There are different favorites, likes, dislikes, and opinions. A great resolution for this disagreement is categorizing. By putting all of the censored books, movies, magazines, and music in one area, it will decrease arguments on this topic because all of the people that like censorship in libraries will be together in their area. Whereas the people that do not want the censorship in libraries do not have to be around that section. This is a quick and easy fix. There is no reason to take away one's favorite genre because someone doesn't like it. If this is true then our world will have nothing because not everyone likes one certain thing. For instance, I do not like blue Aeropostale shirts. Pink are my favorite. My friend Sarah likes the blue shirts and hates the pink shirts. We both write to the manager to get rid of the shirt color we do not like. This is nonbeneficial for either of us because now the one we do not like is gone but so is the one we do like. This is nonsense. There will be nothing left in the store. People in charge can easily sort material at a store or a library to make it fit the communities likings. Getting rid of material is not the answer. Categorizing is the fix that needs to be put into action immediately to satisfy the diverse needs of all library patrons.

In our society today there is an enormous amount of exposure to materials that many adults didn't have when they were a child. Young children today see drugs, alcohol, sex, and teen pregnancy portrayed as things a normal child's everyday life consists of. Certain television shows, books, and even some popular songs condone these behaviors that many parents are opposed to. While libraries may seem to be the most unusual place to have access to these materials, many young children can checkout books that are simply not appropriate for their age. Censorship of materials, such as books, movies, and music, that are found offensive or inappropriate are a way to teach young children that life isn't all about what the media portrays it to be. One very important reason to allow censorship of materials in libraries is that you might not know what type of book you're looking at. Many children, and adults too, walk into the library and look among the books until they see a cover or a title that grabs their attention. While most of the books in a library are age appropriate a child can still grab a book that isn't something they should be reading. There are mass amounts of influential materials from the media and also from peers that a child is subject to. Censorship in a library will make it a safer place for children to go and pick up any book in the proper section for them and will also allow the parents to not have to worry about what their child has selected. As author Katherine Paterson so rightly said, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children have taken off the shelf.' Parents should never have to worry about what their child can get ahold of in a public library. A second reason to allow censorship in libraries is that video stores already have censorship in their shops, along with ratings on all their movies and video games. Most video stores have a separate section of movies that are deemed to have 'adult content' in them. A minor cannot walk into a movie store and go to the section of movies deemed for adults, or someone over the age of eighteen. A minor can't rent an R-rated movie without proving that they are seventeen, or they have an adult to rent it for them. The same thing occurs with video games, for example a video game with a rating of M, or mature, cannot be rented or bought by anyone under the age of eighteen. This same censorship should be applied to libraries. Having separate sections based on adult content allow movies and books to be set in a separate location so that no child can possibly rent something that they have no intention of watching or reading. This type of censorship also allows for a parent to choose if their child can see it. An example of this would be for a sixteen year old boy. While he cannot go and rent the R-rated movie, if his parents deem it acceptable for him to see, then they can rent it for him. This gives the parent control of what their child sees, instead of the child having full control. This same type of censorship that video stores have is a perfect way to place censorship in a library. Perhaps the most important reason for censorship in libraries is the early exposure the materials give to the children. Many young children have been watching television shows or hearing things on the news that make it seem acceptable in our society to drink at parties when you're not of age, do illegal drugs for the feeling, and have sex at an extremely young age because it's what 'everyone's doing.' This is a very risky path to let the young children in our society take. Allowing our culture to become this way can lead to various sorts of problems, as we have seen all too well. Many young kids, some as young as fourteen or fifteen years old, go to parties and drink. When it comes to getting a ride home they go with their seventeen-year-old friend who has a license, and who has also been drinking at the party. Now hopefully the story ends that all of the children make it home safely, but that is not how it works in many cases. There have been so many drunk driving crashes recently in our nation with children who should not have even been drinking. This ties back to censorship because of the way these kids were pressured into drinking. Many adults in the society blame it on peer pressure; but where do the peers get the idea that this is acceptable?

Library books offensive? The right to remove a book or not isn't up to us, the general public, per our individual opinions. If someone has an issue with a particular book; next time, simply do not check it out. I know that we shouldn't have the right to remove books from the libraries. It's not up to us to make that choice for the entire community. I know people sometimes find something wrong or inappropriate in a book at the libraries', but if it wasn't to your liking, don't read the rest of it or recommend it to a friend. I have had personal problems with this before. I went to check out a book and my mom said that she didn't like the topic that it was about: honestly, its her opinion. A person should have a right to his or her opinions but it shouldn't affect someone else's access to information. One person might really like the book and someone else might hate it, obviously there are people out there who enjoy that type of book so there isn't a really good reason to get rid of it entirely. The only person who should have a say in getting rid of a book would have to be the librarian. That professional knows what is acceptable and what isn't for the library's collection. If a book includes something graphic or racist, you can talk to them about it in a calm conversation, because they may be a librarian but they don't read every single book that is in the library. Some items can be offensive to some but not others. The library is there for knowledge and entertainment. We can have opinions on matters and discuss them appropriately without causing a big ordeal because there could be reasons why things are where they are. You need to leave the choice up to the person who is educated on the matter and who is in charge of the library, trusting their professional judgment for the benefit of all patrons.

To whom it may concern, Censorship is an issue that has plagued our society for centuries. It is not only unnecessary, but unconstitutional. As Americans, we have certain rights that we are guaranteed by the documents that keep our society out of anarchy. If the right to pick what literature to read, watch, or listen to is taken away, where will that put our country? Censorship should by no means be allowed in our country today. In the Declaration of Independence, the Constitution, and the Bill of Rights, we are given certain freedoms. Some of these rights, including freedom of speech and freedom of the press, have already been constricted, which is 'wrong' in the eyes of the government, but nevertheless, it is taking place. We may not have 'lost' these freedoms, but they have definitely been constricted. Why should the government be able to tell us what to read? If censorship is allowed, what is to come is frightening. If our government, which is supposed to be 'for the people' tells us what we can read and not read, what is going to stop them from telling us what to wear, drink, or even eat? Censorship in libraries is one of our biggest issues. There are countless examples on why censorship of written literature should not be allowed. For instance, if a college student is writing a research paper about the psychological effects of rape on a child, but the government sees rape as 'too graphic', what is this student to do? He or she should be given the right to use what materials are necessary to write a fully-informed paper. But by censoring our libraries, and taking books out, the government is hindering the education of its country's youth. Some American classics are also being speculated against. The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn has been known as a classic since it was written. It is used in classrooms everywhere around the country for education. But recently, the availability of the book has been questioned. Throughout the novel, the 'n-word' is used, but never as an insult. During the time-period of its writing, this word was more common, and had a much less severe meaning than it does in modern day societies. But because time has changed its meaning, it is being removed from libraries and curriculums across the country. This is unlawful censorship. One of the greatest books of our time, an American classic, is being removed from the lives of our youth because of 'racy language'. Censorship is not only taking place in written literature. Movies and music are also under the magnifying glass of censorship. Movies are rated for a reason, to give the viewers an age group for which the movie is appropriate. This is helpful to parents to be able to self-censor their children. But it is not up the the government to be able to choose what a specific child is able to view. It is a parents right to be able to expose or not expose their child to whatever they see fit, not that of our country's lawmakers. Music is one of the biggest parts of our society today. With the invention of iPods and similar devices, music has become much more common, and portable. Censorship is becoming more severe with the change of music style. The music styles of modern teenagers greatly differs from that of their grandparents. Almost nothing is seen as unacceptable by many of today's rappers, as displayed in their choice of lyrics. The music business is taking quite a beating for what has become the most popular. With the most common themes of sex, drugs, and money, it may seem offensive to some citizens, but others may just shrug it off as a normalcy. So how can someone say 'No, you may not listen to that,'? This should not be allowed, yet it is. How can one person, or a group of people decide what is acceptable and what is not? They cannot. Censorship is morally wrong, as well as lawfully wrong. Taking the media from its citizens, such as books, movies, and music, is unconstitutional. What would our forefathers think of what censorship has become? Before you pull that 'unacceptable' book off the shelf, remember the rights of our great country's citizens, and the freedoms of individuals like yourself. Sincerely, A Concerned Citizen.

It is a prominent question of debate whether or not certain materials in libraries such as books, music, movies and magazines should be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive. Although there are materials that may be harmful to children, freedom of information is far more important than protection because censorship is unconstitutional, prevents readers from an impartial perspective, and in some cases hides pressing societal issues that are deemed improper by the censors. The First Amendment states that freedom of speech, religion and the press shall not be denied or abridged. In more general terms, the First Amendment grants freedom of expression. Censorship is effectively unconstitutional. It prevents freedom of expression. Students and scholars alike cannot access all information that should be available to them if not for censorship. Although private business and libraries can be permitted to censor because they have their own contracts that permit this, public libraries and schools are effectively breaching the constitution when they censor. Censorship prevents a whole and complete perspective on an issue. Censors often ban particular books because of personal views of alleged 'immorality.' Without a clear and complete access to all information, how can one make any valid conclusion about anything? If, for example, one wants to learn the difference between an agnostic philosophy and a deist one, but has no access to any agnostic books, which were banned by intolerant religious zealots, you cannot effectively learn anything. Every special interest group wants to ban a certain type of material. Author Katherine Paterson said that 'if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf--that work I abhor--then you have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' Indeed this is true. If every special interest group deems it proper to censor material that is against their interests, there will be no material left. There will be no knowledge left. Without knowledge, we as a human race are left in the dark. Many books are banned that address great problems of society. Ray Bradbury's Fahrenheit 451 addressed the growing problems of censorship and the dangers of technology. As the fireman Guy Montag burnt books, so ironically the novel was censored. Perhaps this is a ploy by the censors to defend their special interest, that is censorship. They feel powerful when they restrict other people's freedoms. A novel by Kurt Vonnegut, Slaughterhouse-Five, was banned. Apart from vulgar language in the book, Slaughterhouse-Five also denounced free will and portrayed the US's brutal bombing of Dresden in World War Two. This book reveals much about human truth, yet it was banned. How will society ever change if any time a revolutionary book is written it is banned? Censorship is a great problem. Although there are many works that are meaninglessly violent, brutal and cruel, no book or any other material should be censored. In public libraries and schools, censorship is blatantly unconstitutional. Censorship prevents people from seeing the whole perspective, and censorship hinders societal change. Censorship must be denounced as a restriction on our intelligence and liberty, for it ultimately stifles the very progress it claims to protect against.

Children are our future because when I am old they will be the ones who are caring for me, so for me censorship is a big deal. It's a big deal not only because of how it will affect my children, but because it will affect me and what everybody else will be able to read. I agree that censorship is an important issue but to what extent should it be taken. People should have the right to read what they want to. They should also be allowed to find it in their local public libraries. My view on censorship in public libraries is that most things should be allowed to stay on the book shelf. I can understand censorship to an extent, but taking books out of public libraries makes it hard to choose where to draw the line. You don't want a book taken out just because it has a bad word in it. Just because some books are classics that everyone knows, does that mean that we shouldn't take that book out of a public library? I do believe that some books should stay because adults don't want to be reading kids books they most likely want to be reading a more complex book for their own education and enjoyment. I think there are some books that should stay out of the library though. An example is books that are extremely racist. These books should be kept far away from our children. This is needed because younger children might try to act out things they might hear or read because there are audio books and those would just make them say those things without understanding the context. This could cause them to get in trouble for things they don't understand yet. There are things that you can do as an alternative to keep these things out of the hands of children. There is already one method that is used in public libraries and it is separating the adult books from the children books. You could also move these two sections to opposite sides of the library. The books that are more explicit could be put higher up such as on a top shelf. Most kids would not be able to reach as high as an adult, providing a simple physical barrier. These are my views and ideas on censorship in libraries. The ideas and views that I have are most likely different than most people. I thought that they were good ideas though, ones such as separate section for kids and adults. I thought my best one was putting the more explicit books up higher and moving the sections farther apart, which seems like a practical compromise between access and protection.

Books, music, movies, and magazines are all a form of expression. We have the freedom to express the way we feel or think, but can it be too graphic for some to read? I believe censorship in libraries is needed to protect the minds of children and people who are easily influenced by the thoughts of others. Books are a major factor in expressing the way one feels about a topic from romance to horror. Many children like to read books or comic books that involve a great deal of violence. Childrens minds are like sponges, which means they soak up anything they read about and it has a great chance at influencing their functioning in everyday activities, potentially leading them to mimic what they have encountered. If you go into a music store you will find many different types of music from rap to blue grass. I've noticed in my school that a particular type of music that stands out is rap and the favorite artist is often someone like Eminem. Eminem has been known for rapping about drugs, sex, money, and violence. Many teens think that if their favorite artist can do all this why can't they? I've only listened to a few songs by Eminem and in every song one of those four key topics comes up, reinforcing these themes repeatedly. Like Eminem the movie industry is starting to come out with more and more movies about drugs, sex, money, and violence. Many students in my school talk about the latest comedy movies like 'The Hangover', 'Superbad', 'Project X' etc. and how they turned their life into something like those movies when they go on spring or summer break. Movies like those are funny to watch but for someone who is easily influenced shouldn't be watching them, as they might not distinguish between on-screen antics and real-life consequences. Books, music, movies, and magazines, they surround us with their stories and thoughts of another human being. We do have the freedom and the right to express ourselves but we also have the responsibility to consider limiting it if we feel it is endangering the minds of others. I think censorship in a library from certain things is a good option in cleaning up a mind poisoning mess, ensuring a safer environment for vulnerable patrons while still upholding the core principle of access to information.

I think whatever is offensive should be taken off of the shelf because it is inappropriate. Books do not need to be like that because they are supposed to be fun for you and help you learn; yes, you can have a little violence in an action or adventure book to get the mood of the character, the setting of the story, and to understand it perhaps. Offensive books can be okay at times, so if you have a comedy magazine or a book that is making fun of something or someone, it can be taken in an offensive way, or just as a joke and in a non-offensive way. To most people, they are going to want to take those kinds of books off of the shelf. Offensive books to them, such as parents or maybe even friends, they can teach a child wrong, and that child might not learn the right way. Kids when they are little, their brains are like sponges, so they learn and remember stuff well at that age. A child getting a hold of a book or being taught something from a book like that will most likely remember it. I think those kinds of books should be taken off of the shelf because kids don't need to be reading that kind of stuff when it's already on television and talked about. They need the educational books that can teach them and prepare them for their upcoming higher grade levels, so then they would have a fresh start on new words or grammar, which is a more productive use of their time.

I think they should be taken off the shelves if they are too vulgar for young children, like if it has to deal with sex or violence they should be taken off shelves. They should only be allowed to put appropriate stuff on the shelves for a general audience. I think that they shouldn't even make books or magazines like that unless they can keep them hidden from people under a certain age. But people are gonna do what they want to do, and that is the reality of the situation. That is all I have to say on this matter, and I hope you have a nice day.

Katherine Paterson made a valid point in stating that some books are too offensive for some people to read, but that does not mean they should not be read. Time and time again throughout someone's life we hear things that we do not like nor want to be bothered with, but it is good that we do. Libraries should have the right to open all types of books to their shelves and not have them be censored by the public, and this is why. We, as people of the nation, have battled through hard times. Wars, racism, and extreme poverty or depression are just a few to recall. Having dealt with those issues we always tend to repeat them out of a lack of knowledge. Slavery and other historical conflicts were some of the nation's lowest moments and they were also very gruesome. Recalling those memories is difficult but something that needs to be done; if books were to be censored then many young adults would not be educated and could repeat such horrible actions. Pertaining to movies, music, and magazines the same law applies. Though not in the same way, many times these publications are written about current news or social aspects of life. Music is a form of expression and everyone has their own taste. Not having the option to choose from a variety of styles is wrong and unfair. Music can not only be an expression of feeling about love or anger but it can also teach life lessons. Some artists like to sing or rap about their life journey. This can educate others into knowing that if you do this then this is the result, good or bad. In a magazine, they tend to lean towards more current topics such as politics, jobs, or young adult lifestyles. Movies apply to the same rights and topics. Each one is equally as important and if a group of citizens feel that it is not then who are they to make that call. What gives a group of people the right to say this is inappropriate and that you should not read it? They do not have it. In the constitution, it states that you have freedom of speech and that means you can express it anyway you choose. By censoring what people read, that is in a way taking away that author's right to speak, which is unfair. Though Katherine Paterson made a valid point in saying that some books are too offensive to read, she just simply is not right. A library is supposed to be a place where people can find a book, music, movie, or magazine of any genre and read it. If materials were censored then that is unfair to someone else who does want to read it. The bottom line is that you have free will and you have the power to choose whether or not you want to read something.

There are things in the world that are not meant for certain people to see. Things like rated R movies, mature books, alcohol, and explicit music are not meant for children. Yes, people have rights; they can view whatever they want. If a child wants to see a rated R movie or drink a beer, that is the parent's choice to let that child see that movie, not the person running the store. If you are under the age limit, a storekeeper should have the right to tell you that you can't go in the store or buy his product. Is it okay for a storekeeper to tell your child no? Some would say yes to this and others would say no. If your child is trying to buy a movie with guns, blood, and killing, and you don't want your child to have this movie, you might be mad if a storekeeper let your child buy it. On the other hand, you might be mad if this storekeeper told your child he wasn't allowed to buy this movie. If the rating is based on maturity, how does this storekeeper know how mature your child really is? Your child could be one that likes to copy the things they see on movies; the storekeeper doesn't know if this is true or not. He doesn't know this child; he can't say if he is mature enough to watch this movie with guns, blood, and killing. How would this storekeeper feel if this child watched this movie he let the child buy and the child went out and killed someone? How would you feel if this happened? This wouldn't happen if there was a clear and enforced age limit. If a group of sixteen-year-olds who just got their license go into a liquor store and try to buy beer, who is going to stop them from drinking and driving if there is no age limit on drinking? Lives get wasted when teenagers make choices like drinking and driving. When you're a teenager you don't think about what's going to happen after you make a choice; you just think about how fun it's going to be while you're doing it. Most young people aren't mature enough to make decisions in the spur of the moment. Therefore, there should be an age limit for some things, maybe not all things in the world, like whether or not your child can buy a candy bar or a soda. But an age limit on buying an R-rated movie, alcohol, guns, knives, etc., is necessary. What would the world be like if children went around with these things? With an age limit on certain things, there wouldn't be a problem with these dangerous situations.

What do you go to the library for? In earlier times, libraries used to be the place where you went to study. There were no computers, and so you had to go look up your work in an educational book at the library. Is that truly what people are doing at the libraries now, or are people there to look at vulgar books, magazines, and movies? A library is meant to be the place where you can go to work in peace and have a helpful resource of educational books. But now you can go to the library and be tempted to look at books you shouldn't be looking at. Instead, you could be on the computer the whole time playing games of some sort; the possibilities are endless. People now could go to the library and check out a magazine, movie, or book on pornography, drugs, alcohol, or worse. Is that really what you want your kid to accidentally pick up at the library? Personally, I myself witnessed a little kid pick up a porn magazine at the library, and his mom had to grab it very fast before he had the chance to look at the magazine. The library should not be used for this, and the threat of young kids accidentally looking at these materials should not be happening in the library. The music someone could listen to is also very bad, and your child could listen to that. Then what if they want to keep listening to it? Yes, the world does have a huge impact on what is put into the library because drugs, sex, scandals, and alcohol seem to be what most teenagers are interested in at some point in their young life. But a library is a community building and there is no stopping someone from coming in and easily getting these vulgar things. The thoughts of the youth are completely swayed after they watch, read, or listen to this, and this needs to be controlled. Women and children can find all of these materials offensive. These materials need to be censored more than what they are right now. Libraries should be a safe place where people can go to study or get a book, and not to be tempted to look at something they should not be looking at. Many people find this offensive. Yes, in the end, libraries are a great place, but the people who do not use libraries for the right reasons are why these materials need to be censored at the libraries to protect the community's values.

A library card is one thing a kid always looked forward to, a small but significant milestone. It's the first piece of identification that many kids have that they are allowed to carry around themselves, a token of responsibility. The card opens up a whole new world of entertainment and stories that can take you anywhere you want to go, from magical kingdoms to distant galaxies. Once a kid owned a library card, they were allowed to check out any book they wanted out of the huge selection of items in a library. But how do you keep a young child from checking out a book, movie, or magazine about inappropriate adult material? A solution to this problem should be formed so that people can be protected from material they don't want to see in a book, movie, or any other source of entertainment. Libraries today normally have a specified children's section, where picture books and short stories litter the shelves. The rest of the building is a scattering of books and other materials sorted only by author name and genre. The only way to understand what the item is about is to flip through the pages or read the back cover and try to find a hint of how the plot goes. This could be dangerous at times because not all materials give a specific summary of what happens, leaving the content a mystery until it's too late. I once rented a movie expecting it to be a scary thriller about a killer in a trailer park. It ended up being scary for another reason, as multiple uncensored sex scenes were displayed throughout the first couple minutes of the feature. I had no idea the movie was going to involve scenes like that and I was disgusted that there was no warning. I believe items like that should be placed in a separate area or at least be required to give a summary of the kind of offensive material in them. Libraries could collect viewer comments, allowing people who had checked out an item to write what they thought about it, noting any surprising or mature content. People could then read these comments before checking out that item. Viewer comments would be a good way to get someone else's opinion on what the item contained before another decided to rent it. Another effective way to help this problem would be to give materials a certain rating, like the ratings of movies when they come out in theaters. A specific rating would warn viewers or readers from checking out an item that is offensive or inappropriate. Libraries could also give specific age ranges according to the ratings on an item, not allowing anyone under a certain age limit to check out a book from the building, similar to how movie theaters enforce age restrictions. Ratings would help keep offensive books out of a child's hands, or that of anyone else who didn't want to be exposed. Libraries hold all different kinds of materials about any subject you could think of. They can open a whole new world to learn and be entertained but also a world of inappropriate items. I believe items with offensive material should be either put in a separate area, or given a certain rating in order to warn people before checking it out. Allowing viewers to make comments about the material could also be very helpful. Libraries are a wonderful place full of great stories and adventures, so they should not be polluted with offensive and inappropriate material that can be easily avoided with these simple systems.

Every individual has their own opinion on censorship. Some people believe that, in some instances, it is perfectly fine, but others disagree. I'm one person that thinks that, in some instances, things should be censored. Schools have the right to censor what is put in their libraries for their students to read, especially magazines. Some of the magazines out there have articles in them that arent appropriate for school hours or even in the school building. Schools may not want something inappropriate on their shelves where students can see it. For example, a magazine with mature content or violent imagery does not belong in a school setting. Censorship is even more understandable in elementary schools. Younger students' libraries should be monitored even more carefully. Younger kids, such as elementary age, don't really know what they should and shouldn't read and could be easily influenced. In public libraries, things are a little different. Parents can usually monitor what their kids check out. Most adults know to read the summary on the back of the book to know what is being checked out. If the summary is too vague, then they know to read a few pages inside the book. A couple of times, I've gone to the public library and I checked out a book that I thought was a suspense. When I got home and began reading it, it turned out I was wrong. The book was a romance book that I didn't care to read. So, I returned the book to the library. Most of the time you can read the synopsis on the back of the book, but that doesn't always reveal too much about the book. So, the best thing you can do is read a couple of pages out of the book before you check it out. Everyone has a right to their own opinion on censorship. I believe that in some instances things available to be checked out should be censored. In other instances, things should be left up to the adults and the parents to decided what they want to be allowed to checked out, as personal responsibility plays a key role.

Well if one person has a right to something then it would only be fair for the other people to have a right for the same thing. So if one person owns that book then another person wants that same book then they would have every right to grab that book and there's really nothing you could say to them. I know how it feels not having the same right as every one else. Now the third guy that was watching, he doesn't have the right to keep any videos of the fight and he should get a ticket for causing more trouble. The principle of equal rights should apply to everyone in a fair situation.

What do I think? When I heard about the problems some libraries were having, I thought to myself, what is the big issue over censoring movies, disks, books, and magazines. I don't mean like they are getting hurt or anything, but it helps keep them from growing up and not knowing about things they shouldn't at age eight. So, once again, I would like to let you know that we can fix this together to protect our youth.

No I do not believe that certain materials should be removed from the shelves because I don't see how they are offensive to other people. There are all kinds of books, movies, and even magazines out there. Most libraries have a huge selection for all types of readers or people who would like to watch a movie. They could even have stuff that the young minds should not read. Have you ever thought about what would happen if a little kid grabbed onto something that he/she was not supposed to read? When it comes to things like this, there is a huge range of topics. Some of them are not supposed to be looked at until an older age. That's why I think there should be a certain section where only a certain amount of ages are allowed to go. When it comes to books, there will always be some books that are not appropriate for the young mind. They could include multiple things that could scar a kid for life. Some of the things that they might read are probably things that their parents would like to talk to them about later on in the future. Books are great for learning, don't get me wrong, but there are some that are more adult related. Now there are a ton of books that kids can read and parents won't need to worry about them reading. Another way libraries can help is put the movies in a certain section. The library could make a section called 'family and kids'. This section would hold a perfect spot where parents wouldn't have to worry about their kids getting the wrong ideas from movies. In our library, we have this section. My grandma and I would always go there and find an incredible family movie to watch together. Finding a great family movie to watch is the best feeling ever. Finally the last way a library could help is by making sure the child is old enough to check out a book or a movie. Clearly a child of ten shouldn't check out a movie that is rated R, that's just wrong. Libraries should make sure the child is at the correct age to check out the movie. That's why the movie companies rate movies, so they can give people heads up about what's good and bad about the movie. Also the libraries should make sure a kid is checking out the appropriate type of magazine or book. The people that work there could look through it before and make sure its the right type of book they should read. There are an infinite amount of ways we can protect the minds of young ones. I don't think libraries should ban books, magazines, movies, or even music. I think they should just make sure the kids are checking out what they're allowed to read. Books are a great way to learn things, but they should be learning about the stuff that is suitable for their age. Libraries are there for us to learn and enjoy ourselves, and with careful organization, everyone can find materials that are right for them.

The last thing I would want my children seeing in a library is offensive material. A library is thought of as a learning zone, a sanctuary for intellectual growth. Somewhere for people to learn about new things and expand their knowledge in a secure setting. If there are dirty magazines, movies on sexuality, offensive music or inappropriate websites available to children it completely defeats the purpose of having a safe learning environment and corrupts its fundamental intent. My opinion is that libraries should be used primarily for educational purposes. That means that there should be appropriate books and magazines that are also age appropriate, carefully selected to foster development. Computers are also a great resource but can contain many offensive material, posing a significant risk. My standpoint on this issue is that the computers in the library should be monitored by staff or through filtering software. If someone wants to look up inappropriate images and websites, then they should do it on their own time, in the privacy of their own home. It should not be allowed in public where innocent children will be exposed to it. That isn't fair to the kids, and it isn't fair to the parents who have tried to protect them from that kind of suggestive material and instill good values. I'm sure that there are many people out there that would disagree with my proposal. However those might be the type of people who aren't morally structured as I, or those who don't have kids to look out for. Or perhaps they just aren't as concerned about the issue. They will argue that there is really no severe need for the computers to be monitored, or that they have blocked websites. Yes, they might think that there is no real harm. But that may just be because that is the way they were raised, causing them to think in that same respect. With the magazines, some may argue that children will be exposed to suggestive material sometime, so why not now? But if everyone were to start thinking like this all morals would be forgotten and our societal standards would erode. In some cases morality might not be the issue at all. In fact, religion might be the most important issue. A lot of people are religious and their particular religion may be against looking at suggestive and 'unholy' material. Parents will not want to walk into a library with their children and find them staring at images that go against what they believe in. They will think of it as losing their child's innocence, a profound loss. Having these things out in the open and accessible to kids and teenagers could unintentionally send a message to them that indulging in sexual activities is acceptable when according to their religion it is not, creating a deep conflict. When I was a little girl I remember going to the library often with my mother to pick out books for school. I distinctly remember seeing naughty magazines laying across a table as I was walking toward the children's section. My mother was appalled that they had those laying out in the open like that, and especially right next to where the children's books were. She complained to one of the librarians and asked that they please remove them. The librarian apologized and agreed that the placement of the magazines was a little out of line. Ever since then my mom has been a little skeptical and dreads going to that library. I suppose that is why I am so involved in this issue and the reason for this informative article, as that memory left a lasting impression. I did not write this to place blame on anyone or to judge people for their beliefs. On the contrary, the purpose for my writing this was to inform general public of these issues and to explain my side of the argument. I don't see the reason of having these materials on hand at a library where almost anyone has access to them. I do not understand the need for them to be obtainable at a library, or if there is a need at all. I'm hoping that by reading this I have opened the eyes of some concerned parents out there, or have at least made them aware of the matter. Thank you for your time. Sincerely, A Concerned Parent.

These are all great forms of literature and a way of learning different things about the world and ourselves. Well, people should be able to get whatever they want if there an adult, as they are capable of making their own informed choices. Libraries, they are everywhere and all together they contain millions of books that influence everyone who reads them, shaping thoughts and opinions. Whether a book is being read about historical figures or the complexities of modern society there is always something influential to be read and pondered. Some books have more adult themes or references to certain subjects which most adults find inappropriate for readers of certain ages, leading to calls for censorship. The question is, is it a good idea for those books that are now being censored to be taken off the shelves? In personal opinion; yes those types of books are influential, yes it is possible that it could negatively effect the youth, but everyone has the right to read what interests them and explore diverse narratives. Being influential is one of the main priorities of most reading materials, aiming to leave a lasting impact. There is a point to be proven or a side story to be shared within most books, offering unique insights. Is this a bad thing? Is it 'bad' to explain a point of view or to explain a life experience? No, having experiences is only half the point of living; sharing it is the rest, creating a shared human understanding. Historical accounts explain one of the more major downfalls in a society and how it brutally effected the people struggling for life and money, providing crucial lessons. Popular fiction shows the softer side of love and that anyone can be happy if they set their hearts on someone, offering hope and escapism. These are not only experiences but things to ponder upon, and losing these factors in life would be a horrible mistake, leaving us intellectually poorer. The youth of today is portrayed in mostly a negative light, often criticized for their interests. Whether they are considered monsters or maybe even the devils offspring; our youth need positive influences to guide them. Reading is one of the major sources of inspiration for students to grow and prosper, opening doors to new worlds. Most students find reading to be boring when it is forced upon them. In school you are not offered what you want to read, which stifles genuine interest. Lists are made, and guidelines are created so that only certain things are read and taught, limiting exposure. Young adults need creativity and books are there to shine a light on their eager minds, fueling their imagination. Taking away the books students and young adults are interested in is one of the many growing problems contributing to people not wanting to read, creating a disengaged generation. Teachers, principals, business men, and even children deserve the right to reading what they like, as it is a fundamental freedom. If you were a sports major and suddenly the population decided sports journals and sports themselves were too harmful and badly influential to people; what would you do when suddenly everything sports related was taken away? Censorship in libraries should not be allowed, as it infringes upon intellectual freedom. People should have the choice to read or watch whatever they want to, according to their own interests and judgment. Just becuase one person finds a book offensive doesn't mean that another person will also find it offensive; tastes and sensitivities vary greatly. The libray's need to let the community deem what they find offensive or not through open discussion, not through unilateral removal. Some parents say that they do not want bad or certain materials in the library becuase their children might read it and be influenced. If parents are that concerned about what their children see, then they should sit down with their child and discuss why they should not be able to read or watch that type of material, providing context. Parents should be able to make their children understand why they shouldn't read or watch the certain material instead of accusing the library's themselves just for having the material available for others. If some books or movies are deemed very offensive by public consensus, then they should be placed in a special area away from the main collections. This special area should be clearly marked with a sign that says 'Mature content' and should only be able to be viewed by adults, preventing accidental exposure. This would solve many problems such as children being able to check out certain materials without permission. Doing this would grant the people who wish to see this type of material access to the material without restricting their rights. This would also solve a problem becuase it would be in a back corner or area that not many people go to so children will not very easily see it, addressing concerns proactively. The best solution to this problem would still allow the library's to put certain material that are found offensive in their library's, maintaining a comprehensive collection. But instead of banning them, put age restrictions to being able to check out the material and also putting it in a differnet section of the library than the normal material. This balanced approach respects both parental concerns and the freedom to read.

Today, we live in a world where there are many different political, religious and personal views; and with time, these views are only going to become more varied and more wide spread. Unfortunately, it is not always easy to cater to every single persons individual takes on the world. When it comes to libraries, it is even harder to have different books for all the different opinions that will not offend people with other opinions. Let's take the United States for example. There are many different races and people with different religions living here. This is a place that has already been through a Civil War and has fought against racism and slavery. Although these are things that our country has overcome, there are still going to be arguments and disagreements over these problems. When there are different opinions, there are always going to be different books out there about the same topic from multiple points of view. As the readers of these books we need to know what point of view this is coming from and not choose a book that goes against our personal beliefs. This is where the offensiveness comes from. We live with many different people and we need to understand that not everyone is going to have the same views on life that we do. When I was in eighth grade, I was volunteering at a local community center with some friends. One of them was pulling her eyes back (like someone would do if they were imitating an Asian person) because they were itchy. A very pregnant Asian woman walked in and took offense to my friends eye movements. She yelled at us and said, 'I would have thought your parents raised you better than that.' At first, we did not understand what this woman was talking about until we realized that our friend had been pulling her eyes back. This showed us that different people can take offense to different things because of their heritage. There is nothing we can do about the expanding cultures in our country. We cannot change the views of certain people in order to match those of our own beliefs nor can we change the fact that all the different people are going to voice their opinions and view them as 'right'. However, we can change the way that we view these people. We need to understand that there is no 'right' when you are dealing with multiple opinions. At this point we need to embrace everyone else for who they are and what they believe because there is nothing we can do to change those beliefs. So next time you pick up a book at the library, read the summary and check to see that the author agrees with you before you take the book home or there are going to be disagreements in your views. If you get a book and you don't agree with it or if you are offended by it, there is no one to be mad at but yourself for not checking to see the author's stance on the topic before you started reading it.

Should we have censorship in our libraries? This is a question that both sides can argue with creditable facts. However, censorship is mostly defined as not allowing certain items or things to be seen or heard of until a mature age. How can you tell when someone is of a mature age? Maturity lies behind one's self to cope with various thoughts, ideas, actions, etc. Censorship should be allowed to an extent, but that extent must be carefully considered. Censorship plays a big role in society today. It has changed the content on our television from decades ago to modern day. The government is more lenient today then they were many years ago. On television in the past, you would never hear a swear word, or see a couple sleep in the same bed. Now, some swear words are considered okay, because people can handle them. It is like they are part of our daily vocabulary now. Censorship has changed a lot over time. Books of all sorts should be allowed to children and adults of all ages. Certain literature provides a cornucopia of topics and subjects to be helpful to a processing brain. We learn and understand at different rates. Some books with 'adult content' may be suitable for more intelligent minds. Authors sometimes put in so-called 'adult content' to add suspense and drama towards the bigger picture or message behind their work. Books help the mind to expand and gain a higher standard of learning and understanding. Movies are different. Some movies have sexual content that our youth should not see. Most magazines have the same principles as movies do. They are both rated differently on levels of age. Therefore, we can protect their innocence and fellow youth from potentially harmful material. Music is healthy to the mood of a person. Music should not be censored. People just have different tastes in music. Some may be fond of other genres and some may dislike the other genres. There is a wide array of music that people can enjoy. There is no way to censor the universal language that music provides to its listeners. Censorship should come down to what the adult allows for the kid to see and hear. Censorship of books is not fine, but censorship of movies and magazines are acceptable for younger audiences. Music, however, can not be censored effectively. The lyrics and sounds speak to many people in strange ways. It is all helpful in the end for personal growth. Everyone should have the right to watch, read, or listen to whatever they want. It all comes down to learning, and there is no censorship on learning new things. So, please do not censor our libraries. Allow the adults to censor what should be censored in their own families according to their values.

I think there is many things that can help prevent someone from feeling like the library needs censorship; number one would be have a special room just for things that are deemed inappropriate to someone, which leads me to my next point: there should be a worker just for determining if something should be kept in a special room. I think there definitely should be a certain age to enter a room for uncensored materials. If they do not meet the requirements, don't let them in. I do think in some cases then they should have to say why they want that certain material just to determine it is for all the right reasons, such as academic research. But I also do feel that there should be some rules and requirements as to what is appropriate and what is not. Books should be removed only if they are found to possess a certain degree of offensive content. Some other books, though, are meant for educational use and are not intended to offend anyone. People sometimes take it too seriously, overlooking the author's original purpose. Many books have posed a great educational source for many years, providing valuable lessons. Books have been around for a very long time, serving as vessels for knowledge and stories. People many years ago used to read books on scrolls, or even in pictures to tell stories. Stories have been around for a very long time and are meant to be stories, not criticised pieces of work to put down other people. There are a lot of books, however, that have been meant to put other people down. These books I agree should be taken off the shelves since they might promote people to turn on certain races and spread genuine hatred. A good book that demonstrates it is not putting others down but sounds like it might is 'To Kill a Mockingbird'. This book has been intended for people to read it and learn of the life back when there was slavery or, a time just after slavery but where people did not respect the newly freed men. Another book that tells of times during slavery is 'The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn'. This book tells of a young boy that runs away to live his old life and meets up with a runaway slave named Jim. This book has been meant to tell of what slaves would be punished by if they were caught, serving as a historical lesson. Many other books exist as these. But I guarantee that over ninety percentile of books are meant to be used for educational purposes due to the context they have been used in. Most people will take books the wrong way, but that is only because they are afraid that they will be judged, just as the book was judged by its cover. I have read many books over the past couple years, and I find that many of the books that I read have proved to be educational to me. There are some books though, that I agree should be taken off the shelves due to them being over the top on offensive content. Censorship has a job to protect us from many unnerving topics and I agree that certain books should be taken off the shelves. But, I think that sometimes, places go over the top with censorship and should let certain people decide which books are right for a place, as well as movies. The world is maturing, even as everyone speaks, and people are learning all the time. There should be some censorship in public places, but only on over-the-top topics where authors have written about an issue that will offend many people without a redeeming purpose.

'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf-that work I abhor- then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' wrote by Katherine Paterson. If you think about it when you go into a library there is a ton of books to choose from, a vast collection of different ideas and stories. But how many do you think is appropriate for every age and including children, not very many. That is why they have sections for the books, like a children's section and an adult section, but there are times people are rude and mix them up on purpose, creating confusion. How many times have you been in a library and find a misplaced book? Many of times right, that can be accidental or on purpose. I know if I took my child or children to a library and they got a book that was inappropriate for them, I would take it to the front desk and complain about that book. Now if it was a book that has been misplaced I would simply take it from them and return it. But, yes there are some books, magazines, movies, and music that should be removed from the library due to their content. I remember from when I was a little girl going into the library to check out books with my mom or my dad, it did not matter they both enjoyed taking me to the library. They were pleased that I loved to read but, one day my mom took me to get books from the library, she did not think about looking at the books I got until we got home and she realized one of my books had a cursing word in it. She was not happy at all, I had no clue what she was doing, being so young. But I figured it out, she grabbed me by my hand and took me to the car. She fastened me in and off we went, back to the library. She had no problem going off and complaining, I can remember her every word she said it sounded like this. 'Excuse me, my name is Mrs. Smith and this is my daughter Sarah she is six years old. We were just her about an hour ago, but you want to know the funny reason we are back. Well if you can give me a funny reason for why my six year old daughter has a childs book from here with cursing in it. Please speak up and explain I would love to hear it.' The lady at the front desk was stunned she has never had someone go off on her for the seven years she had worked there, completely taken aback. But the book is no longer in the public library, I can not remember the title of this book, I just know that with a mom like mine she can get something done through sheer determination. Just like Katherine Paterson said, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf- that work I abhor- then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' I can tell you from experience and observation, you can do and get what ever you want with a little power and persuasion. It may cause trouble but just set your mind to it and you can help and solve problems when you do set your mind to it, though one must always consider the broader consequences.

Libraries have no right in my mind to decide what is offensive and what isn't, as this is a highly subjective matter. Libraries shouldn't have the view on censorship the people who rent or buy the items should, as they are the consumers. The library board has an idea of what is offensive but they shouldn't be able to make that decision unilaterally. If the library wants business they should try to make sure the customers are happy and feel represented. Libraries should take surveys of what everyone wants to get a better sense of community needs. Not all the people in the world have the same idea of what is a offensive book, magazine, movies, music, etc., which makes a universal standard impossible. The different views of people can vary from a lot to none at all, from deeply offended to completely indifferent. If the people feel that they are that offensive then they should bring it up with the library management and find a solution instead of getting rid of these items entirely, promoting dialogue. A safe but easy solution would be to create a section just for offensive items the library or people claim them to be, allowing for choice. Another possible solution would be to just rearrange the area's of the books into two main category's such as offensive and none offensive, and then break it down into their specific categorys for better organization. So the libraries need to have a survey showing what items the people think are bad and the librarys opinions and then go on from there, creating a collaborative process. The surveys could be made up of a paper one you fill out in the library itself or on its online website for accessibility. The survey would have a list of books, movies, magazines, and music that people could check off based on their personal views. Now the library needs money to keep books and other items in stock and so they can repair them if necessary, which is a practical concern. So if the library feels that a book is offensive they shouldn't have the right to censorship without public input. All these books have been in libraries for this amount of time why change it now, as they have historical presence. Think about it if it was offensive why did they put it into the library collection in the first place, suggesting initial acceptance. So in conclusion the library should have no right to censorship books, movies, magazines, music, or any other item they have, as it oversteps its role. This would cost time and money which they don't have, resources that could be better spent elsewhere. Customers could possibly stop coming in because of the change which would be a loss of money, affecting the library's sustainability. Now everyone knows a big loss of money could hurt any business and possibly bankrupt them, or could take weeks, months, or even years to recover and no business wants that, making it a risky endeavor. So the easy way to make sure that doesn't happen is to just leave everything the way it is, maintaining the status quo and avoiding unnecessary conflict.

There are many reasons why censorship can be thought of as a good thing, or a bad thing. I am against censorship. My reasons are that just because something is there that you don't like, doesn't mean that you have to look at it or use it. There are plenty of people that would like to have access to that information or entertainment. Another reason is, that if there's something that someone doesn't want their child looking at, then they should either trust that their child won't look at it, or prevent them from seeing it. Finally, what would be left if everyone were to remove something that they took offense to? Nothing would be left to read, listen to or watch. First, why I think censorship is wrong, is that the people that take offense to what they want removed, don't have to look at what's offensive. No one is forcing them to look at it or use it. They're better off just ignoring it. Because other people, that don't take offense to it, have the right to look at or use it. The library might be the only place that someone could have access to that sort of material. So if someone were to remove that material, the person that needs or wants it, would not have the access to use it. And they are given the right to use it. Their child might even have the right to it. Second is that some people wouldn't want their child seeing those things. But removing it shouldn't be that persons first instinct. I believe that the parent should be able to trust their own child not to look at it. And if they can't, then they need to somehow prevent their child from viewing it; not by removing it. The parent should be able to come up with a reasonable way of preventing their child from viewing things that they don't want the child viewing, rather than taking that thing away from the child, and the whole community. Lastly, let's say that in a library, there's at least one book to each person in a community that offends that person. If they were each given the right to remove the book that offended them, what would be left to read? Absolutely nothing. And each of those people that removed a book, most likely would enjoy another book that someone thought was offensive. So now there isn't a single book for that person to read, just because everyone else disliked the books they didn't think were offensive. Once someone starts removing, other people will join in, and you'd be left with an empty library. That's what I think about censorship. It's really just wrong. Personally, I would like to be able to go to my library and pick out a good book. And I know other people like to do that too. So why should anyone else be able to take that away from them simply because of a personal objection.

Pornography, vulgar language, grotesque scenes and many other things make books and movies inappropriate for some audiences, particularly younger ones. In a culture like the one we have today, censorship usually takes the back seat to freedom of expression and access. The media constantly portrays sensual elements and the language is also bad, which can desensitize viewers. People have always had a right to view what they want and read what they want due to the freedom that this very country provides in its founding documents. Every person is titled with their own opinion but there should not be censorship in libraries that restricts adult access.  There are many things in libraries today that portray bad images and contain questionable content which some find objectionable. Books and movies have things in them that indeed children shouldn't view, but the library is not able to take them down simply because a few complain. People enjoy seeing and hearing these things, that's why the film industry comes out with more rated R movies than all the other ratings combined, as they are popular. They make the most money off of them, driving production. In today's economy, the library needs to keep these things on their shelf so that they can stay in business and attract patrons. If people are offended by it, then stay away from that area and don't pick up the book or movie; it is a simple choice. If someone were to decide to take down a book or movie that they view as offensive then they are breaking the freedom that this country has always stood for, imposing their view on others. Censorship is an opinion based topic that one cannot make on their own for an entire community.  As one can see, the censorship of books and movies is not entitled to a personal opinion or individual preference. It is the duty of the library to keep the freedoms of the people and provide them with the entertainment that they want and demand. Books and movies with adult content in them can also provide insight on what a society should not be like, offering valuable lessons through negative examples. Parents should modify what their children watch, monitoring their exposure, but as an adult they are able to watch or read anything that they want to without restriction, which is a fundamental right.
