Censorship in libraries is a big argument today. Many people wonder what is considered 'appropriate' for our children. With several religious and cultural factors these days it is hard to find something that is not offensive to ones culture. Three main reasons we are not able to find a book reasonable, yet non-offensive for our children in libraries includes racist content, cultural beliefs, and religious beliefs. Racism was a big deal in the late sixties to early seventies. Thanks to legislative efforts, slavery became illegal in the United States. Although, there are still many racist comments, articles, and films published today. If someone does not stop the harsh comments, then it will never stop. Even though it is not such a big deal today, that doesn't mean it won't continue to happen. Children do not need to see or hear racist comments made toward their race like many of their ancestors did, as it can be damaging to their self-esteem. Harsh put-downs and comments toward cultural beliefs are also inappropriate for the society, let alone for children to read. Books containing this are not considered appropriate for children and need to be placed in a different section of the library, perhaps with a content warning. As a teenage reader, my biggest belief and interest is learning about other cultures to see what it would be like to live in another country, but this should be done respectfully. There are countless religions in the world today, many of which are accustomed by their own god(s). I belief it is of a great cause for children of the modern day world to celebrate their own religion how they would like. However, I believe it is not right to make hateful opinions toward other religions. This is also a thing that yet children have the ability to read about, which could lead to prejudice. Children should not be reading about fictious facts of religions and making the thought process in their head when they assume something is true about that religion when it is not. It is definitely a great idea to stick those materials in the adult section to ensure maturity of the reader. For now, children should be receiving material that they can easily comprehend and find interesting, free from these complex and potentially harmful topics. It would be a great idea to make a fiction section appropriate for kids and then a separate section for kids and/or adults with more mature themes. An idea to take into consideration is that every local public library could have a meeting to decide whether to keep the library in easy-access form or not, involving the community in these important decisions. That is for you to decide based on your own values and the needs of your community!

Every single person has there own beliefs and disbeliefs when it comes to books, music or anything in life for that matter. What might be a bad and vulgar book in our opinion may not be bad in others opinionated views. Everyone will have there own views about a book, music, movies, or magazines. That's why censorship is good in a public place like a library, to create a neutral space. Does that mean we're saying that you can't like what you want to like, listen to what you want to lisetn to, or watch what you want to watch in your own home? No, by censoring all that in public places like librarys or say video stores your helping fight a lot of trouble and concerns that could happen in the future, such as public outrage or child corruption. Then again censoring movies, music, books, and magazines in a library could also be a bad thing. Not everyone is going to like the same things or be interested in all the same movies or books. At the same time though we can't censor every single thing someone doesn't like. By removing something because one parent has a complaint over their child watching, or reading a book they thought was too 'vulgar' then your giving that right to any parent that complains about their child doing that, which could lead to endless removals. It's not the librarys responsibility to watch over everyones child, to make sure they watch and read what their parents want them to; that duty falls on the parents themselves. Kids will be kids and they'll do what they want to do, regardless of restrictions. By censoring and taking things off shelfs of librarys your not preventing them from watching a movie they shouldn't be seeing, or reading about book they're not supposed to be reading; they can easily find it elsewhere. Censoring librarys is just like censoring words in movies, by doing that it's not stopping your child from hearing or learing vulgar language. Children now in this day and age hear more vulgar words in school then they do in movies and television, from their own peers. What does the word offensive really mean to a person? Everyone has their own opinion on whats offensive and whats not. Like i said, everyone has there own opinions and views on life and everything in it. You can't remove everything off the shelfs because one parent doesn't think it's right for their child or other children to be seeing, looking at, or listening to. We all have freedom to look at what we want and listen to the kind of music we feel like listening to. By taking things off the shelfs that maybe other people like oppose to others then your taking that right away as a free citizen. Censoring on some things like, sex scenes in movies, or maybe vulgar language in music is alright in my opinion to maintain a basic standard. Taking books off the shelf because you don't like the way its written or you don't like the person who wrote it, or you don't like the kind of language the author decided to use in it isn't alright to me, you're pushing the limit on that one and infringing on creative expression. Books teach kids things everyday, books give children imagination and knowledge about the world. By taking books off shelfs i think you're hurting a childs ability to grow and understand complex realities. Censoring is a good and bad thing, a double-edged sword. It could hurt children or it could help their ability to grow depending on how it is applied. Censoring some things are a good thing, but like i said not everything with vulgar language should be censored, or vulgar scences, as context is important. Sometimes in order to grow and live in this world children need to read and see the things we as people put in books and movies to be fully prepared for life's challenges.

This is along the lines of personal thought. Some people can be happy with things ,while others disagree. Unless its racist or sexist no one has any right at all to say something can't belong in a public space. If someone doesn't like a book than walk away from it don't ponder at why its there, someone else might want it for their own purposes. So I dont like this topic personally but i am ok with writing about it. Its not a choice just like it really shouldn't even be a choice for people to say what belongs where, unless it is rightfully owned by the individual and not public property. I know there are many things I dont like but I dont try and get things moved and banned, as that is not fair to others. Its there people want to read it, and that is what matters. Plus the person who wrote or made the object would be shot down, feeling a deep sense of sadness or rejection from the community. Along the lines of insulting a race and/or being sexist, If that is being done in the book it should be stopped and disposed of to prevent harm. People have the right to say they are not happy with that but if they just dont like the topic but others do than they need to move on and not make a big deal out of it, practicing tolerance. Now if the title clearly says what the book is about than walk away don't pay attention to it; you have been warned. People might use it for research or something in the future, so it has value to someone. Now people can be self-centered and just want what they need so they cause a huge, argument or fight over stupid little things, which is counterproductive. Thats the people that always got things handed to them which I imagine is why this topic came up in the first place. So that is my thoughts and believes about the topic of Censorship. It doesn't matter where, in school or at a library it is there because someone is/was interested in the item, and that interest should be respected. I know this is my thoughts and believes, people may completely think what i wrote it stupid, some may think its smart, and that is their right. Its just the culture you grew up in and state of mind you are in that current time and place that shapes your view on such matters.

I do not think that there is a need to remove offensive materials from libraries. Some people may find these things offensive, but I think that others will be greatly offended if they remove these things, creating a different problem altogether. Take rap music for example. There are many people that think that the lyrics of those songs are just terrible and offensive. Other people think that rap music is amazing and a vital form of artistic expression. I do not think rap is very good at all, but I would not go the extent of saying that rap songs should not be played on the radio, and that the CDs should not be sold in stores. The same principle could be said for these materials in the library. Some may find them offensive but others greatly appreciate it and have a right to access them.  Some people might be interested in these topics. Just like some people might be interested in fantasy or comedy, others have a genuine interest in materials that deal with challenging or mature subjects. It would not be fair for libraries to remove these materials from the library, and deny the people that do like them the right to rent these materials. A library's purpose is to serve a diverse community with varied tastes. Another factor is the maturity of the reader. If the person who is reading a book or viewing movies that might be offensive is viewing them for clear interest then there is no problem with it. But if the reader is not reading for interest, then there is a problem there. It all depends on the maturity that people have when they enter a library. The materials in libraries are there to give everyone a chance to find something that interests them. Just because someone else might find those materials offensive is no reason to take them off the shelf.  I can see why some parents might be upset that their kids could see some of the things in the library that might not be appropriate, but all the libraries that I have been to have had a special area for kids materials. If the parents were worried about their kids seeing some of the questionable materials they could simply bring the kid to that designated area. This is a practical solution that respects both parental concerns and the access rights of adult patrons. Ultimately, I dont think that these materials that might seem offensive to some people should be removed from libraries. Everyone is going to be offended by something and it is not fair to deprive others of those materials even if they are offensive to some, as this would lead to a diminished and homogenized collection for everyone.

Censorship in libraries should not be allowed. Libraries are given to people for new learning opportunities and for entertainment purposes. Everyone has their own likes and dislikes, not two people are the same, and a library must reflect this diversity. First of all when a person goes to the library they should know that the books that are in there were selected by the owner or the governing body of the library. Therefore it is their responsibility to put books into the library and take books out. What the owner of a library will try to do is to put a little bit of everything in it. What is meant by this statement is that there are so many different types of writing that people are bound to not like something. So that is why the owner will add a bit of everything into their library to cater to a wide audience.  If someone has gotten a book that seems to be to their type of book, but after they start to read it they find it offensive to them they should not just throw the book out all together, but they should take it back to the library and talk to the owner about it. People have their rights to do what they want with a book, but if it is a book from the library then it technically is property of the library. So if someone gets offended with a book they should go talk to the owner, let them know their concern, and try to have something done about it through the proper channels. In truth they will not be the only ones who have that opinion. It takes one person to make the difference and start a conversation.  Books are not made for just one person they are made for many people to read and possibly enjoy. People have their opinions and will stick by them. That's expected to happen with books, they are all different as are people. The society that everyone lives in is filled with people of diverse opinions and who are not afraid of expressing them. There is nothing wrong with expressing them either, actually its better that way only because then others can hear about a book and either agree with that opinion or disagree, therefore finding out what type of writing do they really like and forming their own judgments.  Books yes can be thrown out by rights, but the moment everyone starts doing that is the moment when everyone can no longer spread their opinion. To spread an opinion is to let the world know where someone stands on a specific topic. Without that the world would be just plain old boring having nothing to talk about because people would all share the same opinion. Censorship in libraries should not be allowed for more reasons than one, as it fundamentally undermines the free exchange of ideas and the educational mission of these vital public institutions.

Need help with Censorship in my local library. (I changed the name of this story that I heard from my grandparents because I could not remember the real one. This is not really happening at the library I think, but it illustrates a common issue.) To the people at the newspaper I would like to tell you and your readers that there is something wrong with the library. Nothing really all to serious I guess. It seems the librarians there are censoring tons of books and other materials. One of which I really need for a homework assignment on the movie Psycho.  They say that they are censoring what I need for the assignment because it is too bloody and scary for some of the other readers. There have also been some complaints from parents as well, saying that their kids had nightmares for weeks from the movie. To that I said well can I still use the computers there to get information. They said that they have already blocked all the inappropriate sites as well. I do not have internet at home so you can see how well that is going to go for my schoolwork. So then I tried to get the library board to uncensor all of the stuff they have all ready have censored. So that way I could just make them censor all the weird adult rated things at the library. That way no kid will have nightmares any more. I also threw in the idea of separating all the books and movies by age group like child, teen, older teen. To this they said all right but they were going to keep the classic movies and books accessible.  The board said they would try my idea and see if it works but I would have to volunteer at the library and go through all the stuff that has been censored over the years. To this I said ok, but after I saw how big the censor list was it was like a nightmare over a hundred pages of books at least. I was too scared to see how long the other lists for movies and magazines were. So seeing that it was too big for me to handle alone I got most of the other volunteers to help me. I thank you all for reading this article, if you are not able to help then see if there is anyone else you know that would be willing too, thank you. Together we can work towards a solution that allows for both responsible access and the availability of important materials.

I think that if there are offensive books, music, magazines, etc then they should be put in a section of their own, or the librarians should have them kept up and if someone needs or wants them then they would have to go to the front desk in order to get them. This approach allows for access while providing a basic level of screening. I think also, if a young child or teenager cant see, read or hear those types of things than they should not be in there period, meaning they should not be in the general, freely accessible areas. This is a matter of common sense and responsible stewardship. Such a system balances the need for availability of diverse materials with the legitimate concerns of parents and the community regarding age-appropriate content, ensuring the library remains a resource for all without imposing outright bans.

Have you ever read or seen a book that you thought was not appropriate? Did you want to ban the book from the library you got it from? Well many people have experienced this and many of them have wanted to have more censorship in libraries but we can not always do this. Maybe that book that you just put down, deeming it inappropriate for all to read it, is someone else's favorite book. You might never know but maybe someone might think your favorite book is not appropriate. There are many different people in the world and they all have different opinions. So instead of banning them how about libraries and schools just censor them in a reasonable way.  Censoring seems like a no brainer but a lot of people do not think about it. We can not just close our eyes to all the inappropriate books out there but we can at least censor them by making them less accessible to young children. Censoring them could be as simple as just putting a tag on them or making a different section for just those kinds of books. The tags should be clearly marked so that people can see it and know what to expect from the book before they check it out, allowing for informed choices.  People do not have to get rid of some books completely but they need to recognize that young children could pick it up and start reading it without knowing that it is not very appropriate for them. Parents do have the right to check and monitor what their child is reading. Although if you just get rid of the book completely, people are also getting rid of other people's freedom of speech and access to ideas. No one has the right to determine what books are not appropriate and what books are for everyone, so no one should have the right to just have certain books just removed from the shelves entirely.  Instead of banning the books or complaining about them, people could try a rating system for books. When you buy movies a lot of times people check the rating on the movie to see if it would be appropriate for their child or even for themselves. This is what we could do with books too and maybe there will not be as many problems with books regarding content and suitability. It sounds simple enough but people need to take action and start to do something about it in a constructive manner.  You may not be able to make everyone happy but at least people can be more informed about the books they are reading. If everyone can help out in the effort to make our libraries and school more thoughtfully organized than all the libraries would be a lot happier places full of adventure and learning for every age and interest, which is the ultimate goal of any library system.

Offensive materials can be anything, but I'm talking about libraries and what's inside. Books, music, movies, and magazines can be offensive to someone but not everyone. Removing these materials from library shelves because a few people view them as offensive material is not a good idea because if they find it offensive then somewhere someone is enjoying it. Not everyone will find a book, song, movie, or a magazine to be offensive and for that reason no books, cds, movies, or magazines should be withheld from the public in any library. My friends liked reading a certain author's books but I did not like them, but I did not make them stop reading because of it, just like a classic novel can be offensive but if you find it offensive don't read it, plain and simple. There will always be one person who doesn't want their kid to watch a certain movie, or read that author's book, but that is not a good reason to remove any materials from the library shelves, let people read what they want to read, watch what they want, and listen to what they want, there is no good reason to remove a book from the library shelves. We all have a right to read, watch, and listen to anything we please. Having somebody you have never seen get a book, movie, or a magazine removed from the library because they find it a little offensive, is like having someone kick you because you don't have a lot of money. Many books from all over the world can be considered offensive to at least one person and that one maybe two people do not have any right to tell anyone what they can not read. Censorship in libraries is a horrible idea because not everyone will read that book or listen to that cd. Having a chance is all we need to read a book or listen to a song that might change our lives, for better or worse it should be our choice to read what we want. Any material can be considered 'offensive' but most of it is not offensive just what people don't want their kids to read. Offensive or non-offensive materials can not be declared by a few people but by an entire country. What one man considers offensive another man considers to be life changing. Anything can make someone change and in order to have that chance we should have the freedom to read whatever we would like. If you find a book offensive remember this you had a chance to read it, now give that chance to someone else, and let them decide for themselves.

Today's world is filled with racism and criticism. Anything we do is either right or wrong, no in-between. Whenever you're out to eat, or shopping you can hear offensive comments or see images all around you. The newspaper, news, and internet make events appear worse than what they are, if it refers to certain people they take it offensively. If you go out looking for a good book to read, or a movie to watch, or music to listen to laying in bed, you pick what interests you. When you're looking through the selection you're going to see and recognize titles, or pictures that offend you. I know when I do I pick the object up and look and see what it says on the back, and then I make my own informed choice. In some way, someone, is going to find a movie, music, books, or magazine offensive. Say we take everything off the shelves off every store that is offensive in any way to people. What would be on the shelves? Nothing, authors have the right to write about anything they want, singers have the right to sing about what they want. In this country every single person has the freedom of speech. So libraries can't take something off the shelves just because someone finds it offensive. That's the point of the different genres of music and reading, so you can read and listen to what you want. Every individual has the choice of what they pick up and listen to or read. If someone finds something offensive, then they shouldn't pick the object up. Then, when that person complains about it, the bottom line is that it's their fault for reading it. There's going to be offensive things said about race, culture, looks, and weight. That's just a part of life and how people act anymore. Everyone has a preference in works of literature, such as books, magazines, movies, or music. Different types of these works are significant to each person for various reasons. If everyone had the right to completely remove one piece of work that displeases them, then ultimately no works would remain on the shelves. Therefore, I firmly believe that no materials such as books, music, movies, and magazines should be removed from public libraries or other public places. Everyone has unique ideas, necessities, and personal preferences that deserve to be accommodated. A few years ago, I had a classmate who held different ideas from a myriad of people on the topic of religious persecution. He disliked the idea of mixing people of different religions into one community and wrote a detailed paper containing all of his ideas on how the world should function in terms of religion. He tried to publish it, but did not succeed because his work was widely considered offensive. Even though I personally disagree with his ideas, I do not think his work should have been rejected outright. There could have been people in the world who did agree with his thoughts and would have been genuinely interested to read them. There could even have been ideas in his paper that could've helped countries solve various complex problems. I believe it is fundamentally unfair that his paper was rejected and thus made inaccessible. People have different necessities based on what they have to accomplish in their work or studies. For example, I was reading a book last winter about a girl who was doing a school project on racism. She went to the local library to search for a book about apartheid in South Africa but couldn't find anything relevant. She asked a librarian if there were any available, but the librarian told her that books such as those were considered offensive in that local library and she would have to search elsewhere. I believe that it is unjust because the girl might not have had anywhere else to go to get the crucial information about her project. She should've had the right to access the information that she needed for the project to prevent her from failing her assignment. Another reason that no books should be removed is simply because everyone has unique preferences and tastes. In the world, there are books that certain people would enjoy more than others, and literature should be abled to be used for the purpose of entertainment and personal convenience. If I were to go to a library now, I would hope to find many selections that correspond to my ideal novel or magazine. Every person should have that same right of access. If people start removing materials that are offensive to them personally, then soon nothing on the shelves would remain and not one person would have the right to have access to the materials they desire and require. In this world, diversity exists everywhere among people and ideas. People have and always will want, need, and desire different things for themselves. Works of literature are just one category of these things. If people begin to eliminate offensive materials based on everyone's individual frustration or displeasures, then indeed no books will remain on the public shelves. Therefore, materials such as books, music, movies and magazines should never be removed from public places, as these things are necessities to the world and its diverse population.

Do you think libraries should have the right to take books and movies off the shelves if they find it offensive? In my opinion I do not agree and I think they should not be able to take them off the shelves. Many people have different thoughts and opinions and I am going to state mine in the next few paragraphs. To begin with, not everybody likes to read or watch the same types of books or movies; tastes vary widely. Some like romantic stories, some like scary ones, others prefer mysterious plots and there are many more selections available for everyone. For instance if one person reads something that they do not agree with, that does not mean the next person to read it is not going to like it either. Sometimes I enjoy reading books where people get hurt and sometimes killed but if someone else reads it, they might think that it is horrible and very offensive, yet that doesn't mean it should be banned. Another reason is, when I go to the library I expect to get the book that I want to read, not what others prefer or approve of. One time I went to the library and I was looking for a specific romantic book to read and I could not find it on the shelf. So I went up and asked the lady at the counter and she said they do not have it anymore, and I asked why and she told me a lady found it wrong for children to be reading such material. In my opinion, maybe that lady did not even like romantic books herself. They should not make decisions just based on what one person believes is appropriate. The next reason is, the library put the movie or book on the shelf in the first place because they thought people would enjoy it and find it valuable. The writer or producer would not be very happy if he found out that his or her movie or book got taken out of the library because one person found it offensive. Just give the book a chance and see how everybody likes it over time. I understand if everybody thought it was really offensive then to consider taking it off, but not just based on one person's complaint. To end with, my belief is that if they had the book in their library at one time it should just stay in there till it gets old and falls apart from use. The library is open to any and every type of books, not just the boring or universally approved ones. So I believe the books should not get taken off the shelves; they should just stay right where they're supposed to be for all to choose. If they do not like the book or movie then suggest to other peoples family not to read it or have them read it and see their reaction firsthand before making a decision for everyone.

When you walk into the heavenly sanctuary that is our library, you have opened yourself up to a vast wealth of knowledge that is available to you at the click of a mouse, the push of a button, or the turn of a page. There are those of a select few, however, who are under the paradigm that not all of this information is for all eyes. They feel it should be locked away, as if it were some eyesore to be hidden from view. Allow me to address this view with retaliation and distaste on a number of levels in the following document. I am a musician by trade and passion. Music is my deepest passion and my creative gears are forever turning, seeking new inspiration. Often I look to other artists' works for this inspiration, and the one place to get that music is, you guessed it, the public library. How disappointed am I when I find that the music I want has been removed from the collection for being too explicit or controversial. It was not the lyrics or any foul message I sought, but the beautiful melodies and harmonies contained therein! It does not do well to isolate media without first seeing the good that lies in it and the strong, valuable feelings it has to convey to a willing audience. We might be tempted to discard the world's greatest novel because of perceived racial discrepancies or themes of wizardry. We might carelessly throw away a moving song because of its provocative lyrics. We might even trash a movie after only reading the title, never even giving it a chance to be understood. How fair is this practice? Even now there might be those who refuse to read your newspaper because of their disagreements with one, individual editor. That is no fair crop in my right mind and sets a dangerous precedent. I implore you, as a public, as people of sound mind and stout hearts, to reconsider the censorship of those works which have a clear and true message and were forged for the benefit of our humankind. All things have a story to tell, even those we find challenging. A friend of mine once said to me that there were three ways we could absorb things that we find undesirable. We can reject them outright, we can ignore them, or we can absorb and interpret them for ourselves. To reject leaves you no smarter than you were before. To ignore leaves you in fear of the unknown. However, to absorb, you gain new knowledge, be it of a new culture or a new type of person. Everything must be taken with a grain of salt and considered critically. Let us watch something we find immoral and then take the time to understand why it is considered so, for it is these very things that help define us and our values. If you do not see what is or is not right, who is to say what is truly ethical for society? We need material of substance in our libraries, for our exposure and for our fathoming of new knowledge, which is essential in our modern world.

No, materials should not be removed from the libraries. First, most books, movies, and music are the best way to support different ideas and perspectives. They all have their own unique way of convincing you and presenting a viewpoint. There are many different ways to understand the world, but these mediums are certainly among the most effective. Like a movie, for instance, some people need to see things visually to understand them fully. Because it takes time for some people to process information by seeing it unfold, rather than just reading or listening. It allows people to just sit and watch, which is a great way to absorb a narrative. Of course, some people might interpret a movie in a wrong way and get the wrong type of thought about something, which can make it feel offensive to them personally.  Like music, it is a great way to understand what an artist is trying to say or get across to the listener. You have to take time out to really listen and hear what they are talking about in the lyrics. If you hear a song only once and you just take it the wrong way, you never let your mind fully process what was said. Some people let one word or two make them think differently about the entire song, which is why it is important not to judge hastily. So before you judge, you should listen to the whole song and consider its complete message.  A book is one of the world's best ways to understand where someone is coming from, offering a deep dive into another person's life or experiences. A book is like living a short, alternative life. If you judge a book by its first couple of paragraphs, you would never get the true meaning out of it. With a book, you have to give it a chance to seep into your mind so that you can gain a real understanding. A book can tell you a lot of things, and sometimes, the themes can be challenging, which is why some people might take it as offensive. These types of materials should never be removed from libraries. These things are great ways to understand complex issues and diverse viewpoints. So if you find one thing offensive, try another medium; perhaps it offers a better way for you to understand the subject. Without these materials available to us, we would never understand or discover anything new in our world, and our growth would be limited.

I do not believe that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from shelves at a library if they could be found offensive. It is good to be exposed to unique perspectives, and no matter how inappropriate a subject might seem, it is often still factual and helpful in the process of learning and understanding the world. If anything, they should just put a label on the cover of the book that says something along the lines of 'adult content' to warn readers. History repeats itself, and this quote reminds me of periods in history where we need to learn from our mistakes, no matter how bad the subjects are, such as the Holocaust, and the Jim Crow segregation laws in the deep south.  What about the Holocaust, when six million Jewish people were killed because they were Jewish. Some individuals might find books on this topic offensive, but that does not mean the Holocaust never happened. There are many offensive and controversial pictures and stories about events that happened during that dark time. Even though this is a very depressing and horrific subject, it is still good for our youth to learn about what happened to ensure it is never repeated. And other difficult categories need to be read because it can help young people to understand right from wrong, and help prevent them from making big mistakes in their own futures.  The Jim Crow era started from the 1870s all the way until the Civil Rights Act of 1964. The Jim Crow laws took a toll on everyone in the American South, but some people, particularly African Americans, couldn't handle the oppression as well as others. In the south, most white people treated black people as inferior. They did not let them into their schools, their clubs, or their churches; they were rude towards them, and most horrific of all, they lynched them. There were a set of laws called the 'Jim Crow laws,' which pretty much was a list of rules designed to treat African Americans as unfairly as possible. If a kid were to pick up a book or magazine with pictures of lynchings in them, they would remember it their whole life, and if that one picture truly bothered them, then throughout their whole life growing up, they would realize that what was done to African Americans was deeply unethical.  Some books and magazines in libraries are really explicit, but we cannot shelter our youth their whole lives from the harsh realities of the world. Parents need to sit down with their children when they have questions and discuss the truth with them openly and honestly. What are parents going to do when their children go to school and hear other kids talk about subjects such as sex? Children could get the wrong idea about sex or not know exactly what it is because their parents never actually sat down and explained it to them. I am not saying to go let your young child look at explicit material by any means, but when children get to a certain age, their parents need to step up and talk to them about uncomfortable subjects such as puberty, sex, and babies.  It is time parents stop hiding the truth from their children, or hovering over their shoulders like helicopters, controlling every piece of information they encounter. If children do not learn the truth about the real world and about how many evil and manipulative people there are in society, when they go to college they will not be able to stand up for themselves. If young people do not learn about history and what has been done, it is kind of like we are treating the books the same way the Jewish people and the African Americans were treated. Just because these books are different or challenging, we will just get rid of them, just like how there were attempts to kill off all the Jewish people and African Americans because they were deemed different. And that kind of censorship is wrong and inhuman, going against the very principles of learning and freedom.

Censorship in libraries is when a librarian has the right to remove certain materials, such as books, movies, music, magazines, etc., from the shelves of a library, if the item is deemed inappropriate. I believe that libraries should not have censorship as a standard practice. I personally think that it should be up to the individual library system if they could have that power, but it is generally unnecessary. If it is a library where there are always smaller children present, then I could understand if they might want to have a form of censorship for a dedicated children's section. In such a case, however, I believe it should be the parents of the smaller children's responsibility to make sure their child's book is appropriate for their son or daughter, as they know their child best.  Now, say if it was just a normal public library with a mixture of both grown-ups and children, then I would say there still is no need at all for a censorship policy. First and foremost, because it is your personal choice of the item; if you think a particular book or movie is offensive, then simply do not read it, watch it, or listen to it. The power of selection lies with the patron. Second of all, it would not be fair to the other people in the library who liked a certain item, but could no longer access that item just because one person thought it was offensive and complained. Also, people might start saying they thought an item was not suited for the library just because they did not like its viewpoint, which is not a valid reason for removal.  Last of all, if censorship were implemented, members of the library would likely demand the same right as the librarians to challenge materials. So many of all the members have such different feelings and opinions on various items, that so many different books and movies would be taken off the shelf, that by the end there would be very few materials left for anyone to enjoy. This would defeat the purpose of a library as a repository of knowledge and diverse thought. In conclusion, personally I do not think censorship is necessary in libraries. It would not be needed because smaller children's parents should be responsible enough to check their child's items, and also because there would be so much conflict over what items were taken off the shelf and how many items were removed. Therefore, I believe censorship is not needed in libraries, as it restricts access and creates more problems than it solves.

Do citizens have the right to remove books, magazines, and other materials from shelves because they personally do not agree with the content? Censorship in libraries is a subject with an unclear answer. Some believe it is in their right to get rid of books, music, and movies with what they believe is 'offensive' material. Others think library censorship is wrong, that people should have access to whatever material they please. Censorship is simply a way of preventing knowledge from those who wish to learn more about worlds outside their own. In today's society, there are no limits. The human imagination can create beautiful works of literary art and music, but it can also create material not suitable for every age group. Library censorship is a way to keep this 'unsuitable' material away from young and curious eyes. However, what may be unacceptable for children to view may be perfectly fine for a mature adult. Censorship is purely opinion. If a person is a strict believer that God created the world in seven days, they might find it offensive to see a book or a movie that supports the theory of evolution. If a parent does not want their child to watch a horror movie, they would rather their children not see a horror movie disk in the children's section for their child to see. If one person harbors a profound grudge against a certain political ideology, it is unfair to others if all related content is removed from a library's shelves. If a person does not wish to have access to certain 'offensive' subjects, then they do not have to expose themselves to it. But it is not in their rights to remove it from the view of others who may wish to educate themselves on the said matters. Writing is a form of self-expression, a method by which to convey feelings and thoughts and share them with others. It is also a way to teach and to inform others about the past. But if what is written is not shared, how can one form their own opinions and thoughts when they are not exposed to the opinions of those outside their community? It is unfair to prevent someone from learning about a certain subject simply because one or two other people oppose the content. If books and movies containing information unacceptable to one person were removed, then everyone else has the right to have material of their choice removed as well. Eventually, there would be nothing left because everyone is offended by one thing or another. That is one of the beauties of being an American citizen: freedom of speech. By living in the United States, one has the right to read or learn about whatever they please. Censorship prevents learning from those who want it. Parents are possibly some of the biggest advocates of library censorship. Not wanting their children to be exposed to explicit or graphic material is understandable. But just because they do not want their child to see a movie about devil worship or the Civil War era does not mean the parent has the right to prevent all others from seeing it. Children need to be exposed to these kinds of things at some point to encourage open-mindedness and acceptance of others. Libraries provide a source by which young people can educate themselves on the religions, beliefs, and customs of the outside world. It should not be up to the parents to decide what is put on the library shelves; if they do not want their children to have access to certain subjects, do not allow them to go to the library. In conclusion, one can say library censorship is a matter of opinion. Citizens have a right to read, listen to, or watch whatever material they please. Granted, it is acceptable for parents to shield their children from certain subjects, but it is unacceptable for those same parents to prevent others in the community from learning. Freedom to express one's opinions in the form of literature means nothing if that literature cannot be shared with others. As Katherine Paterson once said, '... And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.'

Debates are a main part of our society today. Everyone has an opinion on how things should be in the world, and no one is necessarily right. Books that show how other cultures behave, that to the people being described in the book may seem offensive, are important because we as people need to absorb as much as we can about other cultures. Our businesses are in other countries, many people living in America speak multiple languages, and people have the right to read things that may in fact be offensive to a race of people. Businesses thrive in other countries. A lot of our country's income is from our factories and companies in other countries. China is a place where much business happens for the United States. If we, as Americans, can't learn about the Chinese, how can we learn their business methods and way of life? To the Chinese, these books may be offensive, but to us they are learning tools describing Chinese culture. Being bilingual is a trend that millions of people adhere to. High schools require that we learn some foreign language, even if it is only the basics. The schools do this so that we can go to other countries in the work force. Learning about their language and habits comes from books. The Mexican population might not like the way we depict them in our stories, but this is necessary to learn about them. In the United States, there are all kinds of freedoms that we as Americans use freely. Freedom of speech says that we can say whatever we want when we live in America. Books are not excluded from this rule. I'm sure that other countries have offensive books about us. It's a common theme around the globe. Businesses thrive in foreign countries, so we must be able to read some books about them, even if they seem offensive. Learning new things is something that every school teaches and there should be no limit to what we can learn. If a book has vulgar language and sexual scenes, it should be taken out of the children's section of the library, not banned completely. This is the same case with other populations of people. They cannot take offense to what we have to say, because worse has been said about them than what we can possibly put in a book. Learning is a necessary tool in our society and nothing should be restricted, as it is through this exposure that we build a more interconnected and understanding global community.

Books are very important to our society. They hold a special place in our hearts, and contain much of our world's knowledge. Books are vital to learning things. We put all of our knowledge into them, even hundreds, if not thousands, of years ago. When the libraries in Alexandria were burned and/or destroyed, we thought our knowledge was gone forever. Thank goodness for the back-up system that no one had known about out in the desert. I believe that the Bible is the most important book in the world. Without the Bible no one would know of the wonderful things that our Lord above has done for us, and what he is doing for us now. However, some people can take what the Bible says to be offensive in regards to homosexuals and divorces. But would we allow the gays or divorced men and women to take the Bible off of the shelves? Of course not! If we would not allow them to take off that ever so important book, then why should we allow to have other books to be removed? Books are so very important to us and our world. They hold our world's knowledge, and they also hold our hearts. Just think about what our world, our knowledge, our society would be like if we did not have these precious things. Can you imagine it? I cannot. Books are one of the most important things that we have in our world. Just because someone finds something offensive in a written work does not mean that everyone else will, too. Books, if they are offensive to anyone, should be kept on our shelves for our future generations to come so they may learn and grow on our knowledge of our past.

Books, movies, magazines, music, and other media make up a huge part of our entertainment system in our lives today. Whether it be informational or just purely for entertainment, many diverse forms of entertainment are found in your local library today, whereas in the past most libraries only contained books and reference materials. Although, our entertainment today is much different then it was back then and will be much different than it will be in the future. In today's society books, magazines, music, movies, and so on can be found in your local library, and contain many different types of material. Some material could be informational about our solar system or about the human body. Other material could be a fiction story filled with action, horror, or love. Some material could also be filled with true, life changing, and inspirational stories. Which ever it may be, these types of things may come off as offensive to some people more than others and may not be appropriate for younger ages. Certain books, movies, magazines, music, etc., containing offensive, inappropriate, or rude material shouldn't be banned from libraries, just because those younger than adults should not read them, or because those who dislike the material believe that that material does not belong in the library. Generally most libraries are quite large and organized into various sections throughout the building. One area might be for fiction books and another for non-fiction books, another area could be for childrens books, and another for magazines, movies, music, etc., all based on different types and genres. Simply do this for those materials that should only be read by adults and not for children or teens. Take the books that may contain offensive material, or may be inappropriate for those younger than adults and place them in their own divided section in the library. When a book from that section is being checked out merely ask for an ID from the person checking that book out to make sure that they are of age. This can also apply to movies, magazines, music, and so on that are placed in that section. Some materials found in libraries that may be offensive to one person may not be offensive to others. Taking those offensive materials out of the library won't benefit everyone and would disappoint some of the people who don't find that material offensive. Placing these certain materials in their own section is the best way to go to benefit everyone. As you can see just because one person may find certain material in magazines, books, music, movies, etc., offensive, rude, or inappropriate, doesn't mean that everyone else does. It also doesn't mean you should completely take out and get rid of all the materials that are found to contain offensive or inappropriate material. Dividing those specific materials into their own section, and regulating who may check them out is really the best way to go. It benefits everyone at best so that those who want to read that material can still go to their library and check out that book, magazine, and so on, and those who wish to not have anything to do with that certain material don't have to worry about finding material that is offensive or inappropriate, because they will be in their own divided section.

I do not think that materials, such as books, music, movies, and magazines should be removed from shelves if they are found offensive. I think this because people have different views and beliefs on certain types of things, particularly regarding religion, culture, and sexuality. Some people can be offended by it, but others might be informed and learn new facts that they didn't already know. People are not going to look at things the same way. Everyone has their own way of life and thinks differently. If one person feels a book was offensive to them and they take it off the shelves, then one by one people would find other materials offensive, and what does that leave us with? No more books, music, movies, and magazines. Let's face it, everyone has different beliefs, values, and purposes, but taking materials off the shelves because they are found offensive is ridiculous to me. I say if they find it offensive, don't read the book again or the magazine again. Feel offended over a movie? Don't watch it again, and the same with music—don't listen to it again. It's as easy as that. Materials give us resources and we learn new things from them. If we didn't have materials like books, music, movies, and magazines, we wouldn't be as smart as we are today. America is about being free and having the right to speak our minds, so removing materials from shelves is not the answer to dealing with offensive content.

So, regarding this, yes we should keep the books, music, movies, and magazines on the shelves. We need to start fighting for what we want and how we want it; it should not be anyone else's choice to decide what is good for us and what we can access for our education and entertainment.
